HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
New League Plans Partnership for Clubs and Players

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Learning a lesson from Major League Baseball, the United Baseball League, which will be unveiled today, plans to begin with a "true partnership" between clubs and players. The league, according to its confidential proposal, will offer players 35 percent of a team's pretax profits and a 10 percent equity share in all teams collectively.
Founders of the league, which would be the first new major baseball league in 80 years, will announce its creation at a news conference in Manhattan today. The proposal, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, lists the co-founders as Bob Mrazek, a former five-term Congressman from Long Island; John Bryant, a Congressman from Dallas; Richard Moss, a player agent, and Andrew Zimbalist, an economist at Smith College. 
 Under their current timetable, the founders plan to begin play in 1996 with eight teams in the United States, one in Canada and one in Mexico playing a 154-game schedule. They hope to expand to the Far East in the third season, with two teams in Japan, one in South Korea and one in Taiwan.
The locations of the initial 10 teams have not apparently been decided, but will come from a list of about 20 possible sites, including Long Island and northern New Jersey.
"The owners," the proposal says, "will enter into equity and profit-sharing arrangements with the host cities." The league will offer each city a 15 percent pretax profit and equity share in the team in return for the construction of a "fan friendly" stadium or the use of an existing "first-rate facility."
Cities, in lieu of rent, also would receive 50 percent of luxury-suite revenue and a third of parking revenue.
Under the profit-sharing plan for the players, the league would allocate 35 percent of a team's pretax profits to players, based proportionately on their salaries. The initial payrolls, covering base salaries only, are expected to be around $14 million per team. A player with a $1 million salary would also receive a fourteenth of the share of profits.
Under the equity part of the plan, players would participate in a collective 10 percent share.
"The players," the proposal says, "will realize their return from this equity share whenever a U.B.L. team is sold for a capital gain or whenever an expansion team is created."
As another element of the partnership the league wants to create, players would serve on the league's executive council.
In another marked departure from Major League Baseball, each team's financial books would be open for cities and players to see.
The proposal says the league will make "an unprecedented effort to attract minority investors and provide them full participation in every aspect of the league's activities."
Sites will be selected and owners approved by a management company that, the proposal says, will exist for six years. Besides the four founders, the proposal says the management company includes Curt Flood, the former major league player; Tom McMillen, the former National Basketball Association player; Alan Altschuler, president of Seaport Capital Inc., a merchant bank; William Gray, chairman of the United Negro College Fund; Robert Keefe, chairman of Keefe Company, a public affairs and lobbying firm, and Eric Vinson, vice president of the United States Trust Company.
The league will encourage owners to provide a limited public stock offering to fans in each city. Further, it will "suggest a commitment be made" that at least 15 percent of the seats at each stadium be sold for $5 or less.
With an increasing number of major league players available as free agents, the United League projects that at least half of the players on its teams in the first season will come from Major League Baseball.
If the players' strike persists, the proposal says, "we anticipate that the U.B.L. will be able to hire many more major leaguers."
Each roster would consist of 45 players, 25 on the playing team and the other 20 on the development squad. Those 20 players would travel with the team and play the home team's development squad in afternoon games. Players would be eligible for free agency after three years.
The last league to challenge Major League Baseball was the Federal League, which lasted for the 1914 and 1915 seasons before folding.

HEADLINE: Q&A

BYLINE: By C. CLAIBORNE RAY 

 BODY:

Nicotine Problems
Q. Leaving aside the matter of tobacco addiction, does nicotine have any harmful effects itself? 
 A.It can be harmful, depending on the size of the dose. In fact, concentrated nicotine derivatives are used as insecticides. Nicotine also stimulates pleasure centers in the human brain, but there are unpleasant symptoms when its use is abruptly stopped.
A description of how nicotine acts on the body appears in the "Physicians' Desk Reference" (Medical Economics Data), in its discussion of the Parke-Davis Products drug Nicotrol, a nicotine patch. Nicotine mimics the effects of a neurotransmitter called acetylcholine. It binds selectively to receptors in the autonomic nervous system, which controls things like heart rate and blood pressure. It also binds to receptors in the adrenal medulla, at junctions of nerve and muscle and in the brain and leads to the release of other chemicals that can affect the central nervous system and cause pleasurable effects, either stimulating or relaxing.
Nontoxic doses of nicotine can cause constriction of the peripheral blood vessels, accelerated heartbeat and elevated blood pressure. Because of effects like these, the "Desk Reference" advises, "The risks of nicotine replacement in patients with certain cardiovascular and peripheral vascular diseases should be weighed carefully against the benefits of including nicotine replacement in a smoking cessation program for them." It is to be used with caution in patients with other diseases, like ulcers, and in pregnancy.
The A.M.A. Encyclopedia of Medicine (Random House) says that in someone unused to smoking, even a small dose of nicotine can alter the heart rate and cause nausea and vomiting. A tolerance develops with continued use, however.
Withdrawal symptoms can include craving, nervousness, restlessness, irritability, anxiety, drowsiness, sleep disturbances, impaired concentration, increased appetite, weight gain and a variety of aches, pains and twinges, the "Desk Reference" says.
Toxic levels of nicotine cause nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, profuse sweating, flushing, dizziness, hearing and vision disturbances, confusion, weakness, palpitations, altered respiration, abnormally low blood pressure and occasionally death. However, the doses usually administered in smoking or chewing tobacco are not high enough to produce such symptoms.
 C. CLAIBORNE RAY
Readers are invited to submit questions about science to Questions, Science Times, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: Israelis and Arabs Talking Business

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CASABLANCA, Morocco, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Two thousand business executives from 60 countries and scores of senior American, Israeli and Arab officials began a two-day conference here today to explore ways of cementing peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors through regional economic projects.
Half the Israeli Cabinet, led by Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and several dozen businessmen armed with nearly 150 proposals for joint ventures with Arabs, arrived for the gathering, underlining Israel's keen interest in exploring the economic horizons of the Arab world. 
 In a strong push to strengthen the new economic tissue binding Israel to the region, Secretary of State Warren Christopher proposed the establishment of a multibillion-dollar regional bank that would finance small and medium-size business ventures in Israel and Arab countries. He spoke at the opening of the conference, called the Middle East-North Africa Economic Summit.
Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi businessman, suggested the establishment of a development fund to boost the nascent economy in areas of Palestinian self-rule.
But as the first day of meetings and debates ended, it was clear that the virtual absence of economic contacts between Israeli and Arab business people in the past half-century is an obstacle that will take several more such gatherings to remedy.
"We don't expect to sign deals," Dan Gillerman, chairman of the Federation of Israeli Chambers of Commerce of Tel Aviv, said in an interview here. "That would be naive, but the main message of this conference is that doing business with Israel is now legitimate."
"This is a totally new experience for us to meet our counterparts in the Arab world," Mr. Gillerman said. "We realize that with some of them it may take time, but it is a chance to make the contact, to prepare feasibility studies for what is possible."
Israel's Minister of Economy and Planning, Shimon Shetreet, said that the conference, which was jointly sponsored by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum and the New York-based Council of Foreign Relations, was "a beginning, a good one as the strategic environment for peace is positive in the region."
Arab officials and businessmen appeared less sanguine than Israelis, suggesting that real economic ties cannot precede the removal of lingering shadows of the Middle East conflict that are still keeping Syria, Lebanon and to some extent the Palestinians, from fully normalizing ties with Israel.
Syria and Lebanon refused to participate in the conference, as did the Sudan and Iran, which have inveighed against it as an attempt by Israel and the United States to dominate Arab economies.
Some Arab experts said that regional development, when it comes, will have to be paid for by outside powers, since the emirates of the gulf region and Saudi Arabia have long depleted their reserves of cash and investments, in part because of the costs of the Persian Gulf war, and have been unable to replenish them because oil prices have plunged in the last decade.
Some noted that international sanctions and other forms of containment against Iraq, Iran and Libya, as well as the civil war in Algeria, deprived the Middle East region of four of its wealthiest oil economies.
"With Iran and Iraq out of commission and Saudi Arabia and Kuwait suffering from growing debt, it is difficult to see economic cooperation benefits being reaped immediately or even in the medium term," said Mohammed Abdul Jabbar, an expert with the Washington-based Petroleum Finance Company.
Foreign, economic and planning ministers from Arab countries were also present at the gathering, along with numerous representatives of the World Bank and other international funds. The heavy presence of these officials highlighted not only world interest in Middle East economies but also the problems that the World Bank and other international donors have had in fulfilling previous pledges of financial help like the ones extended to the Palestine Liberation Organization in the past year.
P.L.O. officials said they had received less than $100 million from pledges of $2.4 billion that were to be disbursed over five years.
Part of the blame in the slow movement of funds lies with the P.L.O., World Bank officials said, because it has failed to create a system of accountability for the aid funds waiting to be disbursed. But World Bank officials and other business executives here agreed that international financial institutions have proven in the last decade to be big on promises of financial aid but slow in delivery.
Amr Moussa, Egypt's Foreign Minister, said the conference and other events that will follow may not bring instant economic prosperity but they will lay the groundwork for a period when peace takes root with all Arab countries. "Economic well-being is for everybody in the region without exceptions," Mr. Moussa told a news conference here today.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Warren Christopher was in Casablanca, Morocco for a conference to discuss cementing Mideast peace with economic development. He proposed a bank for regional development projects. He and a security agent passed a palace guard as they arrived at the royal palace in Casablanca. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Haiti's Capital Throbs With New Life

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct 31

 BODY:
Haiti's capital is bustling again. At night, with people no longer fearful they will be kidnapped and killed by the gunmen the army used as enforcers, restaurants are full. People are flocking to bars and music clubs to dance to their favorite songs in the syncopated Haitian compas style.
And on streets that were eerily vacant once darkness fell even two months ago, families take late-night walks to buy ice cream at parlors that have been able to reopen because they now have a regular supply of electricity. 
 On every corner, it seems, stores have reopened and informal markets have spilled out into the streets, attracting huge numbers of customers and gapers from dawn until dusk. With the lifting of the American-led embargo that crippled the Haitian economy and with cargo arriving again, Haitians are rushing to buy and sell goods not seen here in more than a year, from perfume to automobile parts.
In neighborhood after neighborhood, both rich and poor, Port-au-Prince, the capital, is once again coming fully to life. While the new feeling of well-being has not yet reached many areas of the countryside, Port-au-Prince's 1.5 million residents are realizing that the worst of their ordeal is over and resuming business routines and simple pleasures with an intensity that suggests they are trying to make up for lost time.
"I never could have imagined that normal life for Haitians could be like this," said a diplomat who arrived here little more than a year ago, at the height of the military repression and just before the start of the most severe international economic sanctions. "Only now that I see Haitians relaxed and breathing easy do I realize the full extent of what this country has been through."
Even the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has joined in, finally emerging from the National Palace, where he was sequestered for all but a few hours of the first two weeks of his return from exile. Accompanied by an intimidating American military escort, he left the official presidential quarters late Friday to spend a long weekend at his private residence in a middle-class neighborhood near the airport.
Beyond the reduction in fear, much of the resurgence can be traced to a single factor: a dramatic shift in the supply and cost of gasoline. For the last year, gasoline was available only on the black market at prices that surged to $15 a gallon or more because of the economic sanctions applied against Haiti's military Government by the United Nations. But for the last week, gasoline has been selling at the pump for a much more congenial $2 a gallon.
"I took my car out of storage this week and drove it for the first time in almost six months," Serge Etienne, a 42-year-old bank employee, said happily as he filled the tank of a battered Honda Civic at a reopened gas station. "Gasoline was getting so costly toward the end, and thus the bus fares so high, that often I could only afford to walk to work."
As a result of the cheaper gasoline, however, the streets are clogged with more cars than ever before, local residents say. Formidable traffic jams are now common around schools at starting and closing time and on main arteries full of axle-breaking potholes that the former corrupt military dictatorship neglected to repair. Even worse, the return of automobile traffic has cast a hazy blanket of smog over the capital and fouled the air.
To control the congestion, which often threatens to bring all movement on the streets to a halt, international police monitors from Bangladesh, in green uniforms and yellow hats, have been directing traffic at major intersections. The remnants of the Haitian police force, which was more skilled at terrorizing the population than at normal police duties, often stand by observing. The Haitian officers have tried to apply the lessons they are learning, but they are held in such contempt that drivers often simply ignore them.
Guy Malary International Airport, renamed earlier this month in honor of President Aristide's assassinated Justice Minister, has become another center of commotion. Large crowds gather outside the terminal every afternoon during the hours the United States military has set aside for commercial traffic. The planes arriving from New York, Miami, Montreal, Paris and the Caribbean are full of jubilant Haitians returning from exile with oversized gifts and tearful embraces for the relatives they had been forced to leave behind.
"Oh, it is like a dream come true to finally be back home again," Hubert Maillot said as he disembarked last week and craned his neck looking for his brother and mother, who were to meet him. "There were times when I wondered if it would ever happen."
American Airlines and other carriers that have resumed regular flights to Haiti report that their planes are carrying full cargo loads as businesses rush to replenish supplies of goods and raw materials that were exhausted during the embargo. Much of the freight belongs to "Madame Sarahs," the generic name given here to the generally portly and gaudily dressed women who dominate small-scale commerce in market towns around the country.
The upsurge in activity on the streets contrasts sharply with the silence emanating from President Aristide, who remains under heavy security and out of reach of ordinary Haitians. During his first eight months in office before his exile, the President thrived on contact with his supporters. But until he departed late Friday for his home in the suburb of Tabarre, he had left the palace grounds for only one public event in the two weeks since his return and has only occasionally been seen or heard on television or radio.
Instead, friends and former opponents alike have been going to the palace to meet with him behind closed doors. Last week he met with leaders of political parties to discuss, among other things, how to revise the timetable to allow adequate preparation for parliamentary elections that were originally scheduled for next month, and he has telephoned prominent business leaders who supported the coup that overthrew him.
"I smile because I want to go to the countryside," President Aristide said Saturday at an informal news conference at his home when he was asked why he had remained cloistered in the palace. "I stay here because I have a lot to do, but at the same time I try to make it easier for those who are trying to provide security."
Associates of the President said that much of his time in recent days has been devoted to putting together his Cabinet. Last week, he nominated Smark Michel, a 57-year-old businessman, as Prime Minister. But 13 other Cabinet posts, along with several Supreme Court seats, must also be filled, and the process has not been easy.
The left wing of the Lavalas movement, the broad coalition that brought Father Aristide to power in the December 1990 election, was disappointed that he did not choose his Foreign Minister, Claudette Werleigh, for the top job, so it is looking for some measure of satisfaction in the other appointments.
But President Aristide is also said to be feeling pressure from the United States and the business community, still deeply suspicious of his populist instincts. They are urging him to look beyond his immediate circle of associates to fill some of the more sensitive slots, especially those having to do with trade and the economy.
Under that pressure, President Aristide clearly relished the chance to take a look at his simply but elegantly furnished home, which had to be redecorated after he returned because Haitian soldiers and policemen had ripped out air-conditioning and plumbing, smashed windows and fouled the floor while he was in exile.
The President said he was "happy to be back at my house, but happier to forget about what they did."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The return of the exiled President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to Haiti has brought the capital, Port-au-Prince, back to life. With fear receding and with the lifting of an embargo that crippled the economy, Haitians are rushing to buy and sell goods. Vendors offered their wares last week at a bus stop. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Woman Wins $5 Million For Tailhook

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 31

 BODY:
A former Navy lieutenant who said she was sexually assaulted by other officers at an aviators convention three years ago was awarded $5 million in punitive damages today from the hotel where the gathering took place.
A Federal jury ordered the Las Vegas Hilton and its parent company, Hilton Hotels Corporation, to pay the damages, which will be added to $1.7 million in compensatory damages, to Paula A. Coughlin, whose suit said the hotel failed to provide adequate security during the September 1991 Tailhook Association convention. 
 "I think justice was served," Ms. Coughlin said, speaking with reporters for the first time since the trial began on Sept. 12.
Ms. Coughlin settled with the Tailhook Association for an undisclosed amount of money before the trial here started.
More than 80 women said they were sexually assaulted by drunken aviators at the convention.
The four-man, four-woman jury awarded the compensatory damages on Friday. This afternoon, it began deliberating the punitive damages. It made its decision less than an hour after hearing testimony about the company's assets and then arguments from both sides.
Ms. Coughlin testified earlier that she was trapped in the hotel's third-floor hallway on the Saturday night of the convention by a group of men who shoved their hands inside her clothes and tried to pull off her undergarments.
Ms. Coughlin's lawyer, Dennis Schoville, had urged jurors to issue a multimillion-dollar award "to get the shareholders' attention," saying that would discourage future assaults and possibly cause some executives to leave the company.
"They're still equating the damage done to Paula Coughlin and her life to a broken lamp," Mr. Schoville said of the Hilton legal team.
A lawyer for Hilton, Eugene Wait, said today that the Hilton corporation had already been punished enough by negative publicity.
Mr. Wait tried to discourage the jury from giving Ms. Coughlin punitive damages by arguing that such an award would injure fellow Americans and the jurors' community.
"Americans and others have invested their money in this company," he said. "These are the people that you'll affect."
Financial statements introduced in court showed the net worth of Hilton Hotels at $1.089 billion, and the Las Vegas Hilton at $274 million.
Though Ms. Coughlin and her lawyers expressed satisfaction with the decision, the former helicopter pilot, who has been unemployed since leaving the Navy in June, said she did not know what she would do now.
"I'm hoping to slip into obscurity," she said. "I want to paint my house. I just want to go home."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE REPUBLICANS;
It's the Economy Again, as Democrats Attack the 'Contract With America'

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
In their advertisements and campaign speeches, many Democrats assert that the Republicans' "Contract With America" would entail massive cuts in Government programs ranging from Social Security and Medicare to student loans and border security.
Republicans counter that their promises of tax breaks would be paid for by specific, itemized, relatively painless spending cuts. And they maintain that a memorandum written this month by Alice M. Rivlin, the budget director, shows how the Clinton Administration is contemplating large tax increases and deep reductions in Social Security. 
 Much of this, featured in the final television advertising blitz by both parties, is pre-election hyperventilation. But the Republican contract and the Rivlin memorandum do illustrate a fundamental difference between Republicans and Democrats on fiscal policy.
Most Republican candidates this year continue to hold to Ronald Reagan's politically appealing maxim that taxes can be lowered and the Federal budget balanced without Americans making sacrifices.
Democrats this year are more apt to make the painful admission that the new Government spending they favor -- what President Clinton calls investment and Republicans call social spending -- would require ordinary citizens to pay higher taxes or give up Government benefits they now enjoy.
For most of this year, questions about spending, taxes, deficits and debt were hardly part of the campaign debate. Then last month, more than 300 Republican candidates for the House of Representatives gathered on the steps of the Capitol and signed what they called a "Contract With America."
The contract, written by House Republican leaders after close consultation with pollsters about what the American public favors, involves 10 measures that the Republicans promise to bring to a vote in the first 100 days of the next Congress if they win control of the House.
Most of these bills would provide for tax cuts: a $500 per child tax credit; tax credits for adoption expenses and the care of elderly dependents; a lower capital gains tax; tax breaks for investment by businesses; more tax advantages for individual retirement accounts; a repeal of the 1993 bill that raised the proportion of Social Security benefits subject to taxation; an increase in the size of gifts and estates not subject to taxation, and several other tax breaks that would primarily benefit middle- and upper-income taxpayers.
The Republican staff of the House Budget Committee has calculated that the tax cuts would total nearly $220 billion over the next five years. That would be partly offset by about $70 billion in spending reductions over the five-year period.
Most of the reduced spending -- $40 billion -- would result from lower welfare payments. The Republicans would knock beneficiaries off welfare after two years. They would deny welfare and housing benefits to unmarried mothers younger than 18 and allow states to raise that age to 21. They would also deny benefits to noncitizens residing in the United States for less than five years.
The remaining items listed by the Republicans as spending reductions are actually proposals that, while lowering spending in the next five years, would substantially increase spending in later years. One such proposal would give businesses that make long-term investments in plants and equipment less generous depreciation rules immediately, but much more favorable rules later. Another proposal would encourage taxpayers to put income on which they would pay taxes now into I.R.A.'s with the understanding that the interest and dividends on the account would not be taxable when the money was withdrawn at retirement.
The budget law requires that all tax cuts be completely offset by tax increases or spending reductions. Republicans say they plan to comply. While the offsetting measures are not listed in the contract, Republican leaders say the party will support spending reductions listed in a budget plan submitted last year by Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the top Republican on the Budget Committee.
The House rejected the Kasich plan last year and approved President Clinton's budget on party-line votes.
The Kasich plan outlined $176 billion in specific spending cuts over five years. More than $50 billion would come from cuts in Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, and Medicaid, the health program for the poor.
This highlights another difference between the two parties. Members of both agree that the health programs can be cut. But most Democrats want to spend the money saved to help pay for expanding health insurance. Republicans want to use it to reduce the deficit.
The next biggest saving in the Kasich plan, nearly $20 billion over five years, would result from turning over the air traffic control system to private operators.
But even if the spending cuts described in the Kasich budget would more than offset the specific tax cuts in the Republican contract, it does not get the Republicans over their biggest fiscal hurdle. The first item in the contract calls for a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget by 2002.
As matters now stand, about $700 billion in spending cuts or tax increases would be required to balance the budget by 2002. If balancing the budget were accomplished by spending cuts alone, some estimates show, Government programs might have to shrink by an average of 10 percent or more.
The idea of the Republican contract was conceived by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who is in line to be Republican leader in the next Congress. It may have been a political misstep.
Few Republicans are using the contract to buttress their campaigns. But the Democratic National Committee began running television advertisements in many states today asserting that the contract would require a cut in Social Security benefits of almost $2,000 a year. George Stephanopoulos, one of President Clinton's top political advisers, said this was the average amount that would have to be taken from each retiree if all Federal programs except the military were cut by the same percentage in order to reach a balanced budget.
Republicans say they have no intention of cutting Social Security or of reducing programs across the board by an equal percentage. But they do not say what they would cut to balance the budget.
In fact, there is no way to do that without enacting measures that would be enormously unappealing politically -- so unpopular, in fact, that they could cost the politicians who support them their jobs. Almost certainly, they would include steep new taxes and sharp cuts in benefits for affluent retirees.
This is where Ms. Rivlin comes in. Her memorandum, an internal document that is dated Oct. 3 and was somehow obtained by Republicans a couple of weeks ago, is a straightforward accounting of the choices faced by the Clinton Administration, the kind of options paper that a budget official would be derelict not to write. The problem is that it leaked out just before an important election, and the choices it outlines are not attractive politically.
She did not talk about balancing the budget, which has never been a Clinton priority. But she wrote that if the Clinton Administration intended to fulfill its goals of increasing spending in areas like technology and job-training, of providing universal health insurance, of reducing the deficit, and perhaps even of allowing a tax cut for middle-class working families, then money must be found elsewhere.
"There are only three possibilities," her memorandum asserted, "all of them tough." The possibilities are to raise taxes, cut spending for specific Government programs or reduce entitlements.
She then offered pages of alternatives for the President to consider, one of which was a gradual reduction in Social Security benefits.
Republicans pounced on this option and forced President Clinton to declare that he had no intention of cutting Social Security.
All this shouting will doubtless fade away after Election Day, but the underlying issue will not.
The Federal deficit, which is now falling because of the flourishing economy and the budget legislation enacted last year, will begin to rise again by the turn of the century. Mostly that is because of the rapidly rising cost of health programs. Whenever the next recession occurs, the problem will become even worse.
Something must be done. What may be decided in the election on Nov. 8 is on whose terms these decisions will be made, Democrats or Republicans.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "COMPARE AND CONTRAST: Two Parties' Views on Government and Its Future Role"
 
THE REPUBLICANS
An excerpt from the Republican proposal for legislation action in the next Congress, known as the Contract With America:
 
1. The Fiscal Responsibility Act
A balanced budget/tax limitation amendment and a legislative line-item veto to restore fiscal responsibility to an out-of-control Congress, requiring them to live under the same budget constraints as families and businesses.
 
2. The Taking Back Our Streets Act
An anti-crime package including stronger truth-in-sentencing, "good faith" exclusionary rule exemptions, effective death penalty provisions, and cuts in social spending from this summer's "crime" bill to fund prison construction adn additional law enforcement to keep people secure in their neighborhoods and kids safe in their schools.
 
3. The Personal Responsibility Act
Discourage illegitimacy and teen pregnancy by prohibiting welfare to minor mothers and denying increased AFDC for additional children while on welfare, cut spending for welfare programs, and enact a tough two-years-and-out provision with work requirements to promote individual responsibility.
 
4. The Family Reinforcement Act
Child support enforcement, tax incentives for adoption, strengthening rights of parents in their children's education, stronger child pornography laws, and an elderly dependent care tax credit to reinforce the central role of families in American society.
 
5. The American Dream Restoration Act
A $500 per child tax credit, begin repeal of the marriage tax penalty, and creation of American Dream Savings Accounts to provide middle class tax relief.
 
6. The National Security REstoration Act
No U.S. troops under U.N. command and restoration of the essential parts of our national security funding to strengthen our national defense and maintain our credibility around the world.
 
7. The Senior Citizens Fairness Act
Raise the Social Security earnings limit which currently forces seniors out of the work force, repeal the 1993 tax hikes on Social Security benefits and provide tax incentives for private long-term care insurance to let Older Americans keep more of what they have earned over the years.
 
8. The Job Creation and Wage Enhance,ent Act
Small business incentives, capital gains cut and indexation, neutral cost recovery, risk assessment/cost-benefit analysis, strengthening the Regulatory Flexibility Act and unfunded mandate reform to create jobs and raise worker wages.
 
9. The Common Sense Legal Reform Act
"Loser pays" laws, reasonable limits on punitive damages and reform of pruduct liability laws to stem the endless tide of litigation.
 
10. The Citizen Legislature Act
A first-ever vote on term limits to replace career politicians with citizen legislators.
 
THE DEMOCRATS
 An excerpt from a memorandum dated Oct. 3 and written by Alice M. Rivlin, President Clinton's budget director:
All of us know what we would do to improve the long-run health of the economy and the average American's prospects if we had the resources. Although our priorities may differ somewhat, all of us want to:
 
Increase public investment -- in technology, infrastructure, communities and the skills of the present and future labor force -- to raise productivity and raise living standards;
 
Reduce the deficit to release saving for private investment and reduce longterm interest rates;
 
Provide universal health security and reduce the rate of growth of health care costs;
 
Insure retirement security and the future solvency of the social security system;
 
Cut taxes especially for middle class working families.
 
The big problem is that we cannot do ANY of these things without freeing resources that are now devoted to other things.
 
Where will the resources come from?
 
The experience of ther last two years has reinforced what we already knew about the difficulties of finding resources for new initiatives. There are only three possibilities -- all of them tough:
 
Discretionary spending cuts
With enormous effort, this year and last, we shifted significant discretionary spending from on-going programs into our highest priority investments. But Congressional resistance is strong -- witness our limited success in cutting highway demos and LIHEAP -- and there is unlikely to be much more room here. Moreover, a more conservative Congress could lower the caps further and force cuts that would likely fall mostly on our investments.
 
Tax increases
The anti-government mood probably precludes any general-purpose tax increase. However, revenue increases may be possible to fund specific initiatives, especially if the tax has a logical connection to use use -- as in a tobacco tax or a tax on high-cost health plans tied to health care reform. It might also be possible to gain support for a revenue-neurtral restructuring of taxes -- such as reducing tax breaks for high-income people to fund a middle-class tax cut.
 
Entitlement spending cuts
Since entitlement spending, unlike discretionary, is still growing and projected to grow more rapidly, everyone looking for budget savings points to entitlements. But the specifics are daunting. A package of benefit reductions for veterans, farmers, government retirees, etc. would meet heavy public and Congressional resistance. COLA cuts are indiscriminate, hitting the most as well as the least vunlerable. Conconrd-Coalition-type schemes to recapture big savings if they only effect the truly well-off, and may erode support for these programs among upper-income groups. Moreover, 90% of savings would come from Social Security and Medicare, and would probably be labeled by opponents as tax increases.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE ISSUES;
Facing Social Problems: Proposals by Cuomo and Pataki Often Are Vague

SERIES: Governing New York -- A periodic report on issues facing the next administration.

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
In a gubernatorial campaign heavy with talk about crime and taxes, debate about the social problems that cost New Yorkers billions of dollars each year has been light.
Events like the recent visit of President Clinton focused attention momentarily on the issue. Campaigning for his fellow Democrat, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Clinton said he would allow New York to begin experimental welfare programs and would press for improving Medicaid payments to the state. But the welfare waiver would involve only 21,000 of the more than one million New Yorkers receiving welfare grants, and the Medicaid help would require Congressional approval that would be difficult to win. 
 State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor, issued a welfare agenda earlier in the campaign that he said would be a "dramatic" effort to "break the cycle of dependency." But even one Republican Party official said the four-page document was "filled with platitudes and very little detail."
Both developments reflect the campaign pattern, in which the candidates are offering vague, middle-of-the road proposals that fail to show voters in detail how each would deal with the mounting social problems straining the state's resources.
Strategists in both parties acknowledge that Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki have ideological differences over the causes and how to solve the entrenched social problems that financially and emotionally tax the people of New York, among them a rising welfare caseload that now stands at 1.6 million, the seemingly intractable homeless population, staggering Medicaid costs and deinstitutionalization of the mentally ill.
What the candidates share is a fear driving each to play down those contrasts and avoid the issues: neither wants to be called an extremist.
"Social programs, poverty, those are really lightning rods to voters, especially during difficult economic times when everyone feels like they need some relief," said one elected Democratic state official, who insisted on anonymity. "And Mario doesn't want to be called 'hopelessly liberal' any more than Pataki wants to be called 'radically conservative.' So they both head for the tall, safe middle grass where they can basically hide."
As he campaigns, Mr. Pataki says that "the best welfare is a job." He proposes penalizing welfare parents whose children are regularly delinquent from school. He calls for increasing the number of welfare recipients who must work to keep their benefits. He supports a tax credit for low-income families.
What the Republican nominee does not call for, as he once did, are more severe measures to hustle people off welfare, like restricting how long they can get benefits. In fact, judging from Mr. Pataki's performance on the stump, he could well be reading from the position papers, proposals and policies of Mr. Cuomo.
In campaign appearances, Mr. Pataki has extolled a program that Westchester County has run for the last five years requiring able-bodied childless people receiving welfare to work on public projects, like cleaning graffiti, raking leaves and painting community swimming pools.
The program, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has said he intends to emulate in New York City, also combines aggressive eligibility screenings of applicants and has been credited by Westchester officials with holding the growth there of caseloads for Home Relief, the state benefits program for single people, to less than one percent.
Mr. Cuomo's aides are quick to note that the Westchester model so embraced by Mr. Pataki was begun during the Cuomo administration. They stress that both the Governor and the State Social Services Commissioner, Michael J. Dowling, have been urging local officials to push more Home Relief recipients into jobs, training or public works programs like the one in Westchester.
"Given the careful positioning during this campaign, the differences between them are in the nuances," said Gordon L. Berlin, senior vice president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a nonprofit organization. "If you listen carefully, Pataki is saying that dependency is the No. 1 problem. He is not saying a word about poor people. Just push the numbers no matter what it does to people's lives. Cuomo in his heart would rather end poverty -- he just can't afford it. Neither of them can afford to do what they want. So they stay vague."
 
Medicaid and Care
 While both candidates have been saying little on social issues, Mr. Cuomo has a rich record of oratory and policy to mine. But he has been shifting emphasis -- though not position -- on these issues, satisfying a more centrist appeal.
Mr. Cuomo once extolled the fact that the state gave Medicaid recipients flexibility to choose their own doctors and made many services available to them -- a range beyond the Federal demands.
He is now proposing to trim Medicaid services to encourage recipients to join cost-saving managed-care programs, which would require a Federal waiver. Although the Governor's initiative is aimed at cutting the vast Medicaid budget to provide insurance for more low-income people, the Governor clearly understands that it is politically wisest now to seem prudent rather than lavish with benefits for the poor.
Mr. Pataki joins Mr. Cuomo in this position, saying that he too supports putting Medicaid recipients into managed care and scaling back the services covered under Medicaid.
But the candidates' lack of detail in discussing social policy is frustrating for, among others, advocates for the mentally ill, who want to see the state commit more of the money saved from closing psychiatric hospitals to community-based programs and homes, and for child-health-care workers, who want to expand medical coverage for the children of the working poor.
"Not to have these as important issues in the campaign is a disservice to the people of this state," said Gary Billings, executive director of the State Communities Aid Association, a citizens' advocacy group. "Large numbers of kids can't get the basic health care they need.
"The Governor was successful in putting a little bit of money each year to fund school-based clinics through a combination of funding streams, but he never found a permanent authorization for the program. He had a bill in this year, but it was never enacted and there wasn't any evidence he pushed very hard for it. And then there's Pataki, who just simply ignores the issue."
 
Homelessness
 People who work in social services said they worry that an amorphous debate on social policy will undermine their efforts to maintain financing for and focus on critical programs. For instance, advocates for the underprivileged have long been urging Albany to raise the shelter allowance, the rental grant for a welfare family, which has been the same since 1988, a level widely considered to be so low that it aggravates an already seething problem with homelessness.
For a family of three, the typical size of a welfare family in New York, the shelter allowance is $286 a month. The vacancy rate for apartments that cost less than $400 a month in New York City is less than 1 percent. Housing a homeless family in temporary shelters, however, costs about $3,200 a month.
When pressed in an interview with The New York Times, Mr. Cuomo acknowledged that the allowance was inadequate, but he said he never pressured the Legislature to raise it "because I thought I wouldn't get it." Mr. Pataki has not addressed the issue.
"This is a very critical issue that needs to be dealt with, but the current climate makes it difficult for any politician to touch," said Barbara B. Blum, president of the Foundation for Child Development, an advocacy group, who also is a former State Social Services Commissioner.
 
Local Control
 Local government officials say one of the worst problems they face in delivering social services efficiently and effectively is that they are required to carry out and partially subsidize policies and regulations issued by the state with little input on those policies.
When they fail to meet the state's regulations, they are fined, while the state is not held accountable for the policies it mandates.
"Most states have moved to a state centralized system -- we're a real dinosaur," said Russell Sykes, deputy director of the State Communities Aid Association and chairman of the New York State Welfare Reform Task Force.
The biggest state-imposed burden that local governments face in providing social services is paying a part of Aid to Families With Dependent Children -- the main welfare benefit program that covers mostly families headed by single mothers -- and, more significantly, contributing to Medicaid costs.
Most states do not require localities to share financing for those programs, which states split 50-50 with the Federal Government. Of the ones that do, New York demands the biggest local contribution, an even split of the state's portion. In endorsing Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Giuliani said he could not understand Mr. Pataki's position on the split while he knew Mr. Cuomo was committed to working for greater fairness.
Mr. Cuomo has tried and failed to persuade the Legislature to support a complete state takeover of those costs. Mr. Pataki said he also supports a state takeover. In an interview with The New York Times, Mr. Pataki said the money saved by treating Medicaid recipients in managed-care programs would enable the state to afford taking over a larger part of the Medicaid costs now borne by local governments.
"This overshadows all other mandates," said Beth St. Dennis, legislative director of the New York State Association of Counties. "The counties have no control over what they spend on these programs and too little control over how they administer them. These one-size-fits-all solutions don't work. Whoever becomes governor is going to have to change the basic way these programs are conceived and funded."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Resumes Its Fall As Bonds and Stocks Falter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most other leading currencies yesterday as the American bond market sagged.
Stocks, bonds and the dollar rallied in the United States on Friday after the Commerce Department said the gross domestic product grew at a robust annual rate of 3.4 percent in the third quarter, without showing signs of an acceleration in inflation. But few investors expect inflation to remain under control as long as the economy is growing at such a rapid pace, and bonds and stocks fell yesterday, dragging down the dollar. 
 Currency traders have been tracking the performances of bonds and stocks to gauge foreign demand for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them.
The dollar rose on Friday "more on panic and blind buying than on thoughtful positioning," said Jerry Egan, managing director of currency trading at the MTB Banking Corporation. "When people got an eye on bonds falling" yesterday, they sold dollars, he said.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5037 German marks, from 1.5102 marks on Friday. The dollar slipped to 96.93 yen, from 97.27 yen on Friday.
The dollar has fallen 13 percent against both the mark and the yen so far this year.
"People are still expecting a lower dollar," said Richard Vullo, foreign exchange manager at the Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank in New York.
The dollar remains near a two-year low of 1.4860 marks, which was touched in trading in Europe on Tuesday, and a post-World War II low of 96.42 yen, set in intraday trading in New York on Tuesday.
The dollar rose on Friday, said David Wilson, vice president of currency sales at Credit Lyonnais in New York, only because traders who were short dollars tried to lock in a profit on their positions, he said. To short dollars, a trader sells them for another currency, hoping to buy them back at a lower rate later.
"I don't see any reason to make people buy dollars," Mr. Wilson said.
The dollar fell against most other currencies in New York trading. The British pound rose to $1.6355, from $1.6240 on Friday. The dollar slipped to 1.2565 Swiss francs from 1.2595 francs and fell to 5.1495 French francs from 5.1665 francs. The dollar also slid to 1,537.50 Italian lire, from 1,541.50 lire on Friday. The Canadian dollar fell to 73.92 United States cents from 74.03 cents.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Drops to 2-Month Low As Inflation Worries Ease

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gold plunged yesterday to its lowest price in two months on signs that inflation remained subdued.
 On other markets, gasoline and soybeans fell, pushing the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities down 1.18 point, to 233.30.
Gold is traditionally a hedge against inflation because it and other precious metals have tended to hold their value better than other investments. Gold had risen above $400 in recent weeks on fears that inflation was accelerating. 
 But those inflation concerns eased somewhat after the Commerce Department's report last week on gross domestic product showed no significant pickup in inflation. And the Commerce Department said yesterday that consumer spending rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, another indication that growth may be moderating.
"Gold has effectively broken down," David Hewitt, a trader with Chase Manhattan Bank, said. On the Commodity Exchange of New York, gold for December delivery fell for the seventh consecutive day, losing $3.80 to close at $384.90 an ounce, its lowest price since Aug. 23. The December silver contract dropped 10.5 cents, to $5.262 an ounce.
Gold's plunge could end soon, traders said, as demand from commercial users, like jewelry makers, increases with the decline in price. Jewelers typically buy most of their gold in the months leading up to Christmas, their busiest season.
Gasoline prices fell yesterday as demand declined for gasoline that would not meet new Federal regulations.
Refineries must begin selling a reformulated grade of gasoline to dealers in December to comply with new clean-air regulations. While conventional gasoline can be sold at the pump until the end of December, starting today, supplies delivered through futures contracts must be of the new grade. The contract for November delivery expired yesterday.
November gasoline slipped 1.48 cents, to 57.08 cents a gallon, on the Mercantile Exchange in New York. December crude oil fell 4 cents, to $18.19 a barrel.
Soybeans and soybean oil fell as warm, dry weather in the Midwest over the weekend allowed farmers to wrap up harvesting this year's record-breaking crop.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, November soybeans fell 4.5 cents, to $5.4225 a bushel, while December soybean oil fell 0.89 cent, to 25.66 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Incomes Had Sharp Gain In September

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Americans were taking home more pay and saving more, too, in September, as the strongest gain in incomes since April easily outpaced consumer spending.
Analysts said the figures released by the Commerce Department today were in line with an economy that continues to expand at a steady, moderate rate. 
 The department said incomes climbed six-tenths of a percent in September -- the eighth consecutive increase -- while spending rose two-tenths of a percent, the weakest showing since it dropped three-tenths of a percent in April.
"The income numbers look quite solid," said Lynn Reaser, an economist for the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "Consumers took somewhat of a breather in September."
She said higher interest rates, expected to slow the economy, were also helping replenish bank accounts with many Americans getting a larger yield.
Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates for the sixth time this year at a Nov. 15 meeting of its policy-making panel.
The income data were a little stronger than many analysts had expected, and the spending was a little lower. The report appeared to have little effect on financial markets.
The new data meant that Americans' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- was up to 4.1 percent in September from 3.7 percent in August.
"Consumer spending is not the mover of the economy now -- it's the follower," said Laurence Meyer, who heads a St. Louis forecasting firm. He said that auto sales, after a particularly strong August, leveled off in September and helped hold down overall spending.
Accounting for two-thirds of the nation's gross domestic product, spending was up for the fifth consecutive month and has risen seven of the last eight months.
The Commerce Department also said that disposable income -- income after taxes -- climbed six-tenths of a percent in September.
The overall income advance matched the gain of six-tenths of a percent in April. Income last fell in January, when it slipped six-tenths of a percent. During August, personal income increased four-tenths of a percent and spending jumped eight-tenths of a percent. The spending figure was revised downward from an earlier estimate of nine-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Issues Decline in Profit Taking

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday as investors took profits from last week's advance and awaited today's economic report from the National Association of Purchasing Management.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed 22.54 points lower at 3,908.12, giving back nearly half of a 55-point surge Friday on a Government report showing strong third-quarter gross domestic product with mild inflation. 
 In the broader market, declining issues led advances, 1,160 to 1,047, with 302.8 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts said the inflation-wary stock market was uneasy after the Chicago Purchasing Management Association said yesterday that its October business index rose to 64.3 from 63.3, a sign of continued economic strength.
The prices-paid component of the index rose to 72.5 from 72.1, showing "significant" price pressures building across the Midwest.
Analysts said the regional numbers could signal what to expect from the report by the National Association of Purchasing Management today.
In the inflation-sensitive bond market, the benchmark 30-year bond ended the day off 6/32 point. Its yield rose to 7.97 percent from 7.95 percent at Friday's close.
On the stock market, investors' uneasiness over interest rates kept stocks in check throughout the day, analysts said. Most of the Dow's drop came in the last half-hour of business, when computer-guided traders turned sellers, they said.
"Up until that last half-hour or so, the market, in spite of the fact it was down a little bit, looked pretty solid," said George Pirrone, senior trader at Dreyfus & Company.
With the bulk of third-quarter earnings reports already posted, investors now have little to distract them from their fixation on interest rates, analysts said.
On Friday, the Government will report October's employment rate, a key factor in calculating inflationary wage and price pressures.
"The market is just taking a breather," said Guy Truicko, equity portfolio manager at Unity Management. "They're going to look at the data this week and decide what to do."
Among individual stocks, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation ended up 1/8, to 6 7/8, after saying it plans to offer a 19 percent stake in the Nabisco Holdings Corporation in an initial public offering.
RJR also said it was dropping plans to buy a 20 percent stake in Borden Inc. Borden fell 1/4, to 13 1/2.
Philip Morris Companies sank 2 7/8, to 61 1/8, on news of a decision by a Florida judge on Friday to certify a class-action lawsuit against major tobacco manufacturers.
The General Motors Corporation fell 7/8, to 39 1/2, on speculation that the auto maker would cut up to 60,000 vehicles from its fourth-quarter production plans, analysts said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mexican Drops Plan to Buy Most Westin Hotels

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31

 BODY:
An ambitious young Mexican entrepreneur has abandoned his plan to purchase most of the Westin hotel chain for $708 million.
The entrepreneur, Bernardo Dominguez Cereceres, said today that he and his group of investors were pulling out of the deal because of rising interest rates, volatility of high-yield bond markets and Westin's inability to achieve the rates of return they had projected when the purchase was announced in February. 
 Officials at Westin's headquarters in Seattle were not immediately available for comment, but financial analysts believe that the company will try to find a new buyer for the hotels that were to have been sold to Mr. Dominguez.
In a statement, Mr. Dominguez, 33, said the group had raised $260 million of the equity portion of the purchase and was close to securing the rest through debt and other equity arrangements. He identified his partners as the Zullig Financial Group of Switzerland and four Mexican investors, whom he did not name.
His decision to pull out did not come as a surprise here. Mexican analysts believe that financial institutions were unwilling to lend Mr. Dominguez the money needed to complete the transaction because he had severely overextended himself on the deal.
Mr. Dominguez's seven-year-old company, DSC Ingenieria Inmobiliaria, is primarily involved in residential construction in Mexico. It also runs the small Qualton hotel chain, a travel agency and a few hardware stores.
When he announced on Feb. 14 that he would buy 74 Westin hotels in the United States, Mexico, South America and Europe for $708 million, Mr. Dominguez was portrayed as a brash new kind of Mexican businessman. His purchase of an international hotel chain, a month and a half after the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect, was seen as an indication that Mexican businesses would not be content simply to be acquired by others.
But financial analysts here said Mr. Dominguez may have acted too aggressively and had not built up sufficient confidence among Mexican and United States financial institutions to get the money he needed to buy Westin. The skepticism about his ability to close the deal was strengthened by a widespread belief that he was overpaying for Westin in offering the owner, Aoki of Japan, its full asking price, or close to it, while most bids were hundreds of millions of dollars lower.
In an interview at the time, Mr. Dominguez said he considered the Westin hotels a long-term investment that would greatly appreciate with time.
Analysts now say that his high purchase price may have made it impossible for the hotels to produce the kind of returns that would have made his investment profitable, especially as interest rates in the United States kept rising.
Aoki bought the entire hotel chain for $1.53 billion in 1988 but had trouble carrying the debt. Its deal with Mr. Dominguez did not include 14 Westin hotels in Asia and 6 in Canada.
The purchase was supposed to have been completed by June. Mr. Dominguez's lawyers could not say whether he would have to pay a penalty or to surrender his deposit for failing to complete the deal.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Green Point Savings Settles Depositor Suits

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The Green Point Savings Bank of Flushing, Queens, said yesterday that it had settled a series of lawsuits by depositors challenging the bank's conversion to public stock ownership.
Under the settlement, the bank will send depositors a coupon for $500 off the closing costs of a mortgage and offer them the right to invest in a five-and-a-half-year certificate of deposit with an interest rate that is 65/100 of a percentage point higher than the bank is providing on its five-year account. 
 Green Point will also pay the lawyers for the depositors fees of as much as $3.9 million and a further $150,000 in expenses. Terms of the settlement and lawyers' fees must be approved in Federal Court in Brooklyn at a hearing on Dec. 12.
"This is the close of the final chapter of the conversion," said Rich Humphrey, a senior vice president of Green Point. The bank says it has done nothing wrong but is settling the suit to avoid litigation.
Mr. Humphrey said the bank was completing a strategic plan to determine how to use the $800 million in capital it raised in the public offering. Most likely, it will acquire other banks or related financial companies, he said.
Green Point was a mutual savings bank -- meaning that it was not owned by shareholders but was responsible to depositors -- and was the largest such institution in the country. Its plan to convert to public ownership through a stock offering last fall was challenged because many members of the bank's management and board would have received millions of dollars in compensation.
In addition, the Republic New York Corporation made a hostile takeover offer for Green Point, in which it offered to pay extra interest to depositors.
Several lawsuits were filed last November challenging the management compensation and arguing that the Republic bid would have been better for depositors. The New York State Banking Department in January ultimately approved the offering, but canceled the management and director compensation plan.
The lawsuits lingered in the courts until the settlement yesterday.
The settlement is available to those with deposits at Green Point on Feb. 28, 1993, which was the deadline for participating in the public offering.

Companies
 RJR Nabisco plans to sell 19 percent of its Nabisco foods business, in an effort to free the growing food business from the taint of tobacco that has held down the value of its stock. [Page D1.] 
 Warner Music is not alone in undergoing upheaval in its management ranks. The effects of corporate empire building are shaking the entire music industry as entertainment conglomerates have swallowed the last of the big independent labels. [D1.]
 Biogen will not seek marketing approval for Hirulog, one of its most important drugs, and will take a $25 million charge as a result. [D1.]

 Mail-order companies are sending out more catalogues than usual in anticipation of an increase in postal rates. [D1.]
 Incomes grew six-tenths of a percent in September, while spending rose two-tenths of a percent, the weakest since April. [D9.]
 The E.P.A. reached an accord with marine-engine manufacturers on cutting smog-producing hydrocarbon emissions. [A24.]
 
International
 A conference to promote economic projects between Israel and the Arab nations began with 2,000 business executives from 60 countries and scores of American, Israeli and Arab officials. [A8.]

 Blue-chip stocks retreated as investors took profits from last week's gains. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.54 points, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index declined 1.42 point. [D12.]
 Gold prices plunged as inflation fears eased. Gasoline fell on weak demand for gas that would fail new clean-air rules. [D21.]
 The dollar was weaker against most leading currencies. [D21.]
 Prices of Treasury securities were mixed amid concerns about the weak dollar and a supply of new Treasury securities. [D22.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 412 words

HEADLINE: Beating the Clock

 BODY:
Daylight is a gift of nature, but humans have successively taken it on themselves to measure, subdivide, standardize and even politicize nature's schedule. Once the motive was to help ancient Egyptian farmers predict the annual Nile flood. In modern times it is to synchronize everything from train schedules and prime-time television to working hours and private appointments.
Standardization has disconnected our clocks and our lives from strict local solar time as a sundial might measure it. It has also increasingly put governments in charge of the clock. That, along with increasing urbanization, made possible the 20th century's great leap forward in artificial time measurement -- daylight savings time. 
 The idea goes back at least to Benjamin Franklin. The purpose, then as now, was to economize on fuel for artificially lighting homes, businesses and public places in the evening. The opportunity comes from the early morning daylight "wasted" in summer, since most urban dwellers rise considerably later than the summer sun.
Of course, no daylight is actually saved or even shifted from morning to evening. The only things that actually spring ahead and fall back are the numbers on our clocks.
By World War I, fuel rationing and increased urbanization made Franklin's originally facetious proposal seem to some governments a practical necessity. Germany was the first country to officially establish daylight savings time, in 1915. Britain followed a year later. The U.S. Congress created both standard time zones and daylight savings time at a single stroke in March 1918.
Farmers and rural dwellers prefer living by the sun, and they got Congress to repeal the daylight savings provisions soon after the war. That left states and localities free to decide for themselves until Congress again stepped in and enacted year-round daylight time during World War II. With peace, local option returned. But since 1966, Congress has repeatedly tried to nudge the nation toward uniform timekeeping. Everywhere but Hawaii, Arizona and half of Indiana, clocks were turned back an hour on Sunday morning.
Some Americans have felt the change mainly through this week's dramatically earlier sunsets. Others are glad they no longer have to get up while it is still dark outside. But for most, Sunday morning offered the chance to savor that rarest of modern treats, one precise and precious hour liberated from the tyrannical thrall of man-made time.

HEADLINE: WARY OF EXPENSE, ARABS BLOCK PLAN FOR MIDEAST BANK

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CASABLANCA, Morocco, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries refused today to support a Clinton Administration proposal for a multibillion-dollar development bank for the Middle East, saying that their own economic problems make it difficult for them to put up the necessary money.
In a rebuff to the United States, the Arab countries said at an economic conference that while they support peace with Israel, they should not be expected to provide the financing for the bank because of their problems with mounting debts and low oil prices. 
 The Arab objections to the development bank came at the end of an unprecedented conference that brought hundreds of Israeli and Arab business and government officials together for two days of meetings and deal-making.
The idea for the development bank was strongly supported by Israel and advanced by Secretary of State Warren Christopher in the hope that it would be included as part of a communique at the end of the conference. The State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, said tonight that he was "confident there will be a bank" eventually.
He said that a group of economic experts were studying the proposal to structure the bank in a way that would be acceptable to various parties. American officials said that they agreed with many objections raised by the Saudis but were confident they could be resolved.
The United States has recently presented Saudi Arabia with several requests for financial commitments, including requests to purchase American aircraft and arms, while the Saudis have been having difficulty meeting current payments on commitments already extended. The Saudis have been running budget deficits averaging $10 billion a year in recent years; the budget called for $42.6 billion in spending in 1994.
In a tour of the region last week, President Clinton met with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to reassure him of United States commitments to defend the Kingdom. But Arab officials here said that no discussion of the bank project took place.
The economic conference concluded today with an initial agreement to establish regional chambers of commerce and offices of tourism staffed by Israelis and Arabs as part of a broad five-page "Casablanca Declaration" outlining plans to cement peace talks between Arabs and Israelis with foreign participation in capital and expertise.
But the disagreement over the development bank highlighted the obstacles facing the conference's stated objective, which is to construct a network of private-sector projects and investments binding Israel's economy to that of the Arab world surrounding it.
Lack of money emerged as a separate hindrance to hopes for speeding the negotiations between Syria and Israel.
"We have an abundance of lending and financial aid institutions operating under capacity in the region," said Soleiman Soleim, Saudi Arabia's Commerce Minister, who argued that creating one more financial aid institution is a waste of time and effort that would be better used to activate dormant money that is under Arab control.
Other Arab delegates, speaking privately, said their countries support peace talks with Israel but argued that oil prices have been dropping or hovering at record low numbers for more than a decade. They said that the huge bank deposits they accumulated in the 1970's have been depleted by the cost of the Iran-Iraq war in the 1980's and the Persian Gulf war in the 1990's.
Another strong United States plea to abolish totally the Arab boycott of Israeli businesses also met with considerable Arab resistance. The central Arab argument was that the political problems among Israel, Syria, Lebanon and the Palestinians needed to be resolved before the boycott could be further lifted.
Arab businessmen said that the initial contacts made here were a success and are bound to be pursued. But Arab politicians attending the conference and influencing its outcome also said political considerations take precedence at the moment.
"We cannot succeed by putting the cart before the horse," said Arab League Secretary General, Esmat Abdelmeguid. "A durable peace must be based on a just solution of land for peace and on the successful end of all Arab-Israeli talks." Mr. Abdelmeguid's comments, delivered to an audience of business investors and Israeli officials, reflected a general mood among Arab delegates.
Still the enthusiasm demonstrated by the hundreds of businessmen who flocked to the conference -- sponsored by the New York-based Council of Foreign Relations and the Geneva-based World Economic Forum -- suggested that the experience was widely seen an initial success.
"We are witnessing the birth of a new Middle East," said Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, who sat next to Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, at the closing session of the conference this afternoon.
Of the Arabs, Morocco, Egypt and Jordan were the most eager to expand commercial ties with Israel.
"We have long spoken on the Middle East in conflict," said Amr Moussa, the Foreign Minister of Egypt. "Now, here, we are speaking about peace. I'm not saying we are dreaming but the view is clear ahead of hope in the future."
Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan called the conference "a civilized economic achievement," while King Hassan of Morocco said the peace negotiations with Israel were now irreversible.
Israel's business delegation arrived here with 140 ideas for joint projects, while a delegation of 100 Egyptian businessmen proposed some 50 business ventures in areas of agriculture, construction, tourism and manufacturing. There were many business card exchanges and long discussions over lunches and dinners.
"I think it is time for real cooperation to concentrate on the private sector in this region, on small projects to get people employed and get the economies rolling," said Omar Mohanna, an Egyptian investment banker.
Mr. Arafat succeeded in lobbying for an acceleration of financial aid meant to support the self rule of the Palestinian Authority in Gaza and Jericho. He won support from the conference to oppose further closures of the borders of these areas by the Israeli Army, which barred Palestinians from entering Israel after recent attacks on Israeli soldiers and civilians.
"It is important that the borders of the Palestinian territories be kept open for labor, tourism and trade to allow the Palestinian Authority, in partnership with its neighbors, the opportunity to build a viable economy in peace," one clause of the Casablanca Declaration read.

HEADLINE: Newsday Publisher Departs; Management Dispute Cited

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company said yesterday that the publisher of Newsday had resigned "as a result of differences in business philosophy" with the company's senior management.
The move was surprising because it was evident that the publisher, Robert M. Johnson, 49, had not planned to leave the Long Island and New York City newspaper, and there had been no public signs of differences over business approach. 
 Some senior executives of the newspaper appeared to be shaken by the departure of Mr. Johnson, who had been publisher of Newsday since 1986, and uncertain what it meant.
Executives of Times Mirror and of Newsday said Mr. Johnson, who was also president of the newspaper, had negotiated a confidentiality agreement that barred both sides from discussing the reasons for his departure. Telephone calls to Mr. Johnson at his Newsday office were not returned.
Some newspaper executives and analysts suggested that the departure of Mr. Johnson represented a long overdue effort by Times Mirror to stanch multimillion-dollar losses at the newspaper's New York City edition and respond to sharp circulation losses that have affected Newsday for two years.
Times Mirror named Raymond A. Jansen, 55, publisher and chief executive of the company's Hartford Courant, as the new publisher, president and chief executive of Newsday, effective immediately.
The company also said that Mr. Johnson's deputy publisher, Steven L. Isenberg, 54, had been promoted to publisher of New York Newsday, and would report to Mr. Jansen.
Times Mirror executives said Mr. Isenberg's appointment, giving New York Newsday its own publisher, was intended as a signal that the company remained committed to the separate New York City edition, which it began in 1985.
For years, analysts have said that Times Mirror was counting on the death of either The Daily News or The New York Post in its planning for Newsday. The analysts have expressed skepticism about whether Times Mirror would continue to support New York Newsday as it became clear that the two other New York tabloids were resisting extinction.
The skepticism grew particularly intense last year when word leaked out that Mr. Johnson told his staff that New York Newsday had been losing $8 million to $14 million annually for years. Mr. Johnson's remarks drew particular attention because they came as Times Mirror was feeling increasing financial pressure from sharp advertising declines at many of its newspapers, especially its flagship paper, The Los Angeles Times.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Jansen said his appointment did not signal any retreat by Times Mirror in New York City. "There will be two newspapers," he said, referring to the New York City and Long Island editions of Newsday. "There should be no misperception out there that I'm arriving on the scene to alter that."
But Mr. Jansen did not dispel the suggestion that his tenure might involve an effort to cut the financial losses in New York. In response to a question, he would not confirm that there had been losses. But he said, "Quite frankly, I'm not used to operating anything at a loss."
The change in publishers at Newsday came on the heels of unusually bad circulation reports for the entire newspaper industry this week. The paper's combined daily circulation for the six-month period that ended Sept. 30 dropped by 54,334, or 7.3 percent, to 693,556, compared with the period a year earlier.
Newsday's total daily circulation drop was the biggest, in terms of percentage, among the country's largest 25 newspapers. The New York Times, for example, reported a weekday circulation drop of 2.3 percent, while The Daily News slipped 1.1 percent.
Newsday's total Sunday circulation also shrank by 5.5 percent.
New York Newsday's circulation figures showed particularly sharp drops. The weekday circulation declined by 13 percent, to 230,150, and the Sunday circulation plunged by 14 percent, to 213,650.
In an interview last month, Mr. Johnson acknowledged that the circulation drops were a problem for the paper. But he noted that Newsday's advertising revenue, which fell along with the revenue of many other newspapers during the recession, have been rebounding lately.
Mr. Johnson said the circulation drops were tied in part to increases in newsstand and home delivery prices, as well as labor problems that disrupted distribution both in New York City and on Long Island.
Until yesterday, there had been no public indication that Times Mirror's top management in Los Angeles was deeply concerned about Mr. Johnson's handling of Newsday's problems. He was an ally of David Laventhol, a powerful Times Mirror executive, who was widely seen as the architect of Newsday's expensive gamble that it could build a valuable paper in New York City.
But health reasons forced Mr. Laventhol, once Newsday's publisher and most recently Times Mirror's president, to step down to lighter duties in December. Since then, there has been wide speculation in the newspaper industry about whether the next generation of Times Mirror leaders would be similarly committed to Newsday.
Mr. Johnson, a former labor lawyer with a tough manner, made some enemies. Yesterday, according to staff members who were present, the editor of New York Newsday, Donald Forst, said at a meeting that relations had become "scratchy" between Mr. Johnson and Times Mirror executives in Los Angeles.
