HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: MONEY;
Contractors For Albany Contribute To Both Parties

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL 

 BODY:
Election Day is approaching, and engineering consultants for the New York State Department of Transportation are already picking sides.
Steinman, Boynton, Gronquist & Birdsall, a firm with $84 million in state contracts, including major design and inspection work on East River bridges, is so far sticking with the incumbent, Mario M. Cuomo, and has made $16,000 in contributions to the Democratic State Committee. 
 Parsons, Brinkerhoff, Quade & Douglas, which has $63 million in state contracts, including design work on the Meadowbrook Parkway, is hedging: $1,000 for State Senator George E. Pataki, $1,000 to Mr. Cuomo, and just to make sure, $21,000 for the Democratic State Committee and $8,250 to the Republican State Committee.
These contributions, especially those to the incumbent Governor, are part of a pattern of political involvement by government contractors that has been a fixture for decades in New York State -- as well as other state capitals nationwide -- despite occasional investigations, good-government reports and legislative proposals.
Four out of every five firms with engineering contracts from two state agencies, the transportation department and the New York State Thruway Authority, in the last four years have contributed to the candidates for governor, many to both candidates. The contracts have been worth $1.8 billion.
Those contributions, like contributions over all, have been getting larger. The size of the average campaign contribution to Governor Cuomo, for example, has risen steadily, from $1,228 in 1982 to $2,002 so far this election.
A computer study by The New York Times shows that hundreds of lawyers, architects, engineers and construction companies with state contracts are making contributions of at least $500 to Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki, as well as their state party committees: a total of $2 million in contributions during the last four years.
Mr. Cuomo has received contributions of at least $500 from 15 law firms, 35 architects, 70 engineering consultants, 31 construction companies, 17 companies that lease properties to the state and nearly all of the dozens of unions that receive state occupational health and safety grants from the state. In all, Mr. Cuomo and the State Democratic Committee have received $1.47 million from contractors since 1990.
And with the race a close one, Mr. Pataki and the State Republican Committee have received about as many contributions from contract holders as Mr. Cuomo. But they are smaller and far fewer of them are from engineers and architects. His campaign has contributions from 10 law firms, 16 consulting engineers and 9 architects with state contracts.
He has also received contributions from 52 companies with state construction contracts, which are usually put out for competitive bidding. Mr. Pataki and the State Republican Committee have received more than $563,000 since 1990.
"Why are the construction guys giving to Pataki?" asked Meyer S. Frucher, a longtime adviser to the Governor. "Because hope springs eternal. Why are the engineers and architects giving to Cuomo? Because he kept the industry alive while rebuilding the state during a depression in the construction industry. They are grateful."
But Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's deputy campaign manager, disputed that analysis. She said that Mr. Pataki has pledged to reduce the number of state consultants, including perhaps some architects and engineers. The contractors are supporting Mr. Pataki, she said, because he will revitalize the economy. "A revitalized economy will create jobs," she said.
The computer study reviewed 12 years of campaign filings by Mr. Cuomo and contributions to Mr. Pataki since 1990, along with most of the filings by the Democratic and Republican State Committees since 1982. It matched the campaign contributors to a state tape of contract records. The study did not attempt to match the names of partners and employees with their firms, and thus may understate the number of contractors who made contributions.
The study found more than 930 contractors who were also listed on campaign records since 1982, including 760 contractors who have held at least one contract during the last four years. These contractors made 3,800 separate contributions totaling about $6.9 million since 1982. They had contracts worth more than $7 billion, or $1,021 in contracts for each dollar in campaign contributions.
"It is the same old story: we have a campaign finance system that is out of control," said Travis B. Plunkett, the associate legislative director for the New York Public Interest Research Group. "Contractors with something to protect are going to give to those in power and those with a potential to get power."
During the late 1980's, after a political corruption scandal roiled New York City, a state ethics commission investigated the fund-raising practices of state office holders and found that the system "gives too much influence to wealthy favor seekers and too much advantage and temptation to incumbents."
In a report titled "The Midas Touch," the commission, headed by John D. Feerick, now dean of the Fordham University Law School, criticized the fund-raising of Mr. Cuomo and called for a ban on contributions from anyone doing business with the state, as well as for public campaign financing. Mr. Cuomo, who at the time had amassed a large surplus in campaign funds, supported the legislation and for a time, voluntarily abided by strict limits on spending.
But Mr. Cuomo later dropped the self-imposed restraints and Joel R. Benenson, his director of communications, last week defended the contributions from contractors. "If you say these people are beholden to the state for business, you are drawing an unwarranted conclusion," Mr. Benenson said. "These people happen to do business occasionally with the state. They have political interests and give money to a variety of candidates, including Democrats and Republicans."
Few state contractors were willing to discuss their contributions. Clough, Harbour & Associates, an Albany engineering firm, has given $45,000 in campaign contributions since 1989 and received $74 million in state contracts. Mr. Cuomo received $6,500; Mr. Pataki, $1,150. The rest went to the state committees, $2 to the Democratic committee for every $1 to the Republicans.
Ray Kinley, marketing director for the firm, said it supported both parties because "we have partners who have various feelings on both sides of the political scene." He said the partners viewed the contributions as "part of their community involvement."
At the State Department of Transportation, the chief spokesman, John Iaccio, a former scheduler for Mr. Cuomo, was on leave from his $62,500-a-year job to work on the campaign.
The deputy press spokesman, David Murray, said any campaign contribution "never enters into our consideration" when a contract is awarded. All contracts, he said, are screened by a committee that is not told the contractors' names.
Hodgson, Russ, Andrews, Woods & Goodyear, a large Buffalo law firm, has three state contracts worth $157,000 and has made $29,150 in contributions, most of it to the Republican State Committee. Mr. Cuomo and the Democratic State Committee received $1,000 each.
John C. Courtin, who chairs the firm's political and charitable contributions committee, said the contributions did not constitute an endorsement of any political candidates. "What motivates us more than anything else is who asks," he said. "If a client of long standing asks, we tend to say yes. If the Felix G. Rohatyn of Buffalo asks us to make a political contribution and he is a client, you say yes."
Unions, especially public employee unions, are among Governor Cuomo's strongest supporters. They give contributions to incumbent Republicans, too, and many also receive state contracts.
The United Federation of Teachers, along with its affiliates, has been one of the biggest campaign contributors in the state for years, and has given Mr. Cuomo and the Democratic State Committee more than $500,000 since 1992. The union is also among the largest beneficiaries of contracts from a state occupational safety program. Teachers' groups have received eight separate grants under the program since 1988, worth more than $900,000. They are used in part to train union leaders on asbestos issues.
Sandra Feldman, president of the union, said that there was "absolutely no connection whatever" between the grants and the union's contributions to candidates.
Ms. Feldman said that she favored government-financed campaigns. "But as long as businesses and rich individuals can make huge contributions," she added, "I don't see why unions shouldn't be able to."
Mr. Pataki opposes public financing of campaigns, but Ms. Mucha, his deputy campaign manager, said he would come out with a plan later, though she could not provide any details. Mr. Cuomo supports public financing of campaigns, but has no intention of turning away contributions from contractors.
"The preferred system is public financing of campaigns with strict contribution limits," said Mr. Benenson, the Governor's director of communications. "But the Governor is not, nor should any public official who supports campaign finance reform, going to disadvantage himself when the Republicans continue to block reforms. They have raised contributions from fat cats."
 
 
CAMPAIGN DIGEST: On the Trail
 Developments yesterday in campaigns in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
 
NEW YORK
 Governor: State Senator George E. Pataki dropped his insistence on a one-on-one debate and challenged Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to appear at a forum that would include B. Thomas Golisano, the independent fusion candidate. But Mr. Cuomo rebuffed his Republican rival, citing his longstanding position that he would attend only if all six gubernatorial candidates were invited.
Meanwhile, President Clinton, in the state two weeks ago for Mr. Cuomo, will make yet another appearance, this time at the State University at Albany on Thursday.
 
CONNECTICUT
Governor: A day after a state panel ordered them to do so, the Middlebury police refused to release a report on a domestic dispute between John G. Rowland, the Republican candidate for governor, and his former wife. It seemed unlikely the report would be made public before the election.
 
NEW JERSEY
United States Senate: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg pushed for voter turnout in cities as he criticized his Republican challenger for not repudiating Bob Grant, the WABC radio talk show host. Chuck Haytaian, continuing to press for his flat tax plan, said his rival was skirting the issues.

HEADLINE: Data Raise New Fears Of Inflation

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Fears of inflation and robust economic growth were rekindled in financial markets yesterday by two fresh economic reports, which sent stock and bond prices sharply lower.
Analysts said the new economic data increased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would move soon to raise short-term interest rates -- perhaps as early as Friday -- and could move them higher than previously expected over the next six months. 
 An October survey of purchasing managers at more than 300 industrial companies showed that production had reached its highest level since December 1987. And the Government reported that construction spending posted its biggest gain in six months during September.
By the end of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 44.75 points, to 3,863.37. [Page D8.] Long-term bond prices plunged while long-term interest rates, which move in the opposite direction, surged back above 8 percent, to 8.06 percent. [Page D17.]
As recently as Friday, stock and bond traders seemed comfortable with the idea that the economy could grow at a relatively strong clip without a surge in inflation.
That sanguine view seemed to develop after the Commerce Department reported on Friday that the economy grew at a 3.4 percent clip in the third quarter while inflation remained in check. The report sent stock prices higher and the yield on the 30-year bond back below 8 percent.
The reverse in course yesterday seems to reflect how nervous investors are about inflation and how unsure they are about the economic outlook. That uncertainty makes it easy for the market to shift its course sharply from day to day as it digests new economic data.
As the first report on economic conditions during the month just ended, the purchasing managers survey is closely watched by private analysts and policy makers. Yesterday's report shows a manufacturing sector that not only was strong during October, but, the analysts say, shows no signs of slowing down.
"The strength of the manufacturing numbers greatly reinforces the probability the Fed will increase short-term rates by half a percentage point in November," said Paul D. Mastroddi, a managing director at J. P. Morgan & Company. "And it raises the possibility the pace of interest rate hikes may be accelerated over the next three months to six months."
Because of the economy's continued strength, analysts have been predicting for weeks that the Fed would raise its short-term interest rate target again in November, most likely after its policy-making Open Market Committee meets on Nov. 15. Since February the Fed has raised its target for the overnight Federal funds rate five times, or by 1.75 percentage points, to 4.75 percent currently.
Yesterday some analysts contended that the timing of another move could be moved up to Friday, when October's employment report from the Labor Department is released, if the report is strong.
"The case for a tightening was very clear before these numbers today," said Joseph D. Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "And if we get a strong employment number, that will be further evidence."
In its report yesterday, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly index of economic activity rose sharply, to 59.7 percent, from 58.2 percent in September, as production reached its highest level since December 1987.
A reading of more than 50 percent indicates a manufacturing expansion, while a reading of less than 50 percent indicates a contraction. The index has now been above the 50 percent level for 14 consecutive months.
The report on construction spending from the Commerce Department showed a larger-than-expected 1.6 percent increase in September, reversing course from an unchanged showing in August. The construction strength was widespread, ranging from housing to commercial real estate and public projects, the Government report showed.
To bond traders, who focus on signs of rising inflation, a big increase in the purchasing survey's price component, which in October rose to its highest level since July 1988, was especially worrisome.
All of the prices covered in the survey are commodities, and previous reports show they have been rising all year.
But analysts noted that prices companies paid for their raw materials increased at a faster rate than in previous months. Even though those price increases have not yet shown up in broader inflation measures, like the Producer Price Index, the analysts said that inflation pressures were building.
"Under the surface, we see pockets of inflation bubbling," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc.
However, many of these signs have been visible for months, and yet inflation has not accelerated appreciably even as the economy has continued to expand.
While puzzled by the development, most economists continue to expect the strength of the cyclical upswing will inevitably lift inflation.
But others are not so sure, and said yesterday's price report from the purchasing managers sent a false signal.
"Either I am missing something, or this index is vastly overstating what is going on," said Steven S. Roach, co-director of global economics at Morgan Stanley & Company.
In Mr. Roach's view, the report is consistent with "upstream pricing pressures" that he said had been in place for nearly two years.
"These pressures are being overwhelmed by the dramatic compression in labor costs," he said, "which account for about 70 percent of total production expenses."
Indeed, Ralph Kauffman, chairman of the purchasing group's business survey committee and procurement manager at the Oryx Energy Corporation, said that even though 19 of 20 industries reported paying higher prices in October, "our members are saying they are having a hard time passing through the price increases" to consumers.
But the comment was lost on bond traders. "If the price component starts to decline, people would start feeling better," Mr. Fine of Chase Securities said.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN DIGEST;
On the Trail

 BODY:
Developments yesterday in campaigns across the country.
VIRGINIA -- A computer check of state and Federal election commission reports by the Rainbow Coalition has found that more than 40 contributors to previous political campaigns of David Duke in Louisiana have donated a combined $38,000 -- more than twice what they gave Mr. Duke -- to Oliver L. North, the Republican trying to unseat Senator Charles S. Robb, a Democrat. A North campaign spokesman, Mark Merritt, said the money from Duke supporters was unsolicited and came as something of a surprise. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, president of the Rainbow Coalition, said the crossover suggested "an ideological kinship" between Mr. Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, and Mr. North. Mr. North called Mr. Jackson's assertion "fear mongering."
MARYLAND -- Eighty-two percent of black voters in Maryland back the Democratic candidate for governor, Parris Glendening, preferring him 9 to 1 over his Republican opponent, Ellen Sauerbrey, The Washington Post reported. The newspaper said only 9 percent of black voters polled in a random telephone survey of 808 registered voters Oct. 8-11 backed Ms. Sauerbrey, whom white voters supported 46 percent to 44 percent for Mr. Glendening. Mr. Glendening courted black leaders, winning the early endorsement of Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore by promising expanded state aid and a renewed effort to stimulate economic development in the city. Blacks make up one quarter of Maryland's population. 
 NEBRASKA -- The Republican candidate for governor, Gene Spence, asserts that he has been abandoned by members of his own party because they do not think he is tough enough in opposing abortion. Mr. Spence, who trailed Gov. Ben Nelson by 44 points in a poll published over the weekend by The Omaha World Herald, said, "I'm all the Republican Party has, and they better get used to it."
GEORGIA -- Gov. Zell Miller is being attacked in television advertisements by his Republican challenger, Guy Millner, for trying to remove the Confederate battle flag's design from the state flag. Although Mr. Millner himself has called the flag debate divisive, the announcer in his new advertisements says of Governor Miller, "He thinks we won't remember his broken promises -- how he increased our hunting and fishing fees and even attacked our flag." Mr. Miller tried to remove the Confederate symbol in 1993 but met a strong backlash from whites and failed to win legislative approval.
RHODE ISLAND -- Seeking a House seat, Patrick Kennedy is running well ahead of his Republican challenger, Dr. Kevin Vigilante, according to a new poll. The survey of 369 likely voters gave Mr. Kennedy, a three-term State Representative from Providence, 52 percent to 37 percent for Dr. Vigilante of Pawtucket. Eleven percent are undecided.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: MAYOR;
Out of State, Giuliani Shows Party Loyalty

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 1

 BODY:
A week after his dramatic stretch across party lines to support Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani bolstered his Republican credentials today by campaigning for the party's candidates in predominantly Italian neighborhoods of Boston and Rhode Island. But everywhere he went, it was his endorsement of Mr. Cuomo that lingered on people's minds.
At Joe Tecce's Ristorante in Boston, a longtime political haunt, the elderly Joe Tecce himself watched Mr. Giuliani enter to stump for Ralph C. Martin 2d, the Suffolk County District Attorney. "Best job you ever did to endorse Cuomo," said Mr. Tecce, who went on to mangle the Mayor's name as Giuliano, as he predicted he would be New York's governor some day. 
 Moments later, Mr. Martin, standing next to Mr. Giuliani, became momentarily nonplused when a television reporter asked him, "Does this embrace make you the Mario Cuomo of Suffolk County politics?"
"Maybe in the reverse sense," answered Mr. Martin, a Republican who was appointed to his post by the Republican Governor of Massachusetts, William F. Weld, and is facing a Democratic challenge.
Even Mr. Giuliani's signature issue of law and order could not distract his listeners from politics. At a forum on crime sponsored by The Boston Herald, Mr. Giuliani spoke at length about his law-enforcement strategies. But most questioners sought to pin him down on where he stood within the Republican Party.
Ever more passionate about his decision to oppose State Senator George E. Pataki, Mr. Giuliani denounced excessive partisanship. "Even if the candidate of your party has the right philosophy but is an incompetent, let's say," Mr. Giuliani said, quickly adding that he was not speaking of anyone in particular, "it would be a mistake even to move your philosophy to elect someone who is an incompetent." He said it would cause a backlash against the party and its cause.
Further setting himself apart from conservative Republicans, Mr. Giuliani condemned Proposition 187 in California, a ballot initiative that would require the state's schools, hospitals and other institutions to deny services to illegal immigrants. And he spoke out against the "Contract with America," which was conceived by Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, and put 300 Republican candidates for the House of Representatives on record supporting both tax cuts and a balanced budget.
"I think it's a mistake to do something like that," Mr. Giuliani said. "I think it's a mistake to try to get a certain number of members of Congress to have to adhere to very rigid principles that they don't actually agree with. It's attempting to try to much more rigidly define Republicans and it sounded like the economic projections don't work."
While he was campaigning in Boston and across Rhode Island, Mr. Giuliani came under attack by Republicans home in New York.
A day after a Federal appeals court reversed the mail-fraud conviction of Armand P. D'Amato, the brother of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Armand D'Amato said he had been the subject of "a baseless prosecution comparable to the ones Rudy Guiliani brought against innocent people on Wall Street" as United States Attorney.
Reading a statement in front of the Federal courthouse in Manhattan, Mr. D'Amato said, "It is no coincidence that right after Rudy Giuliani became Mario Cuomo's campaign manager, commercials started to appear attacking me."
In between fund-raisers for Lincoln C. Almond, the Republican candidate for governor of Rhode Island, Mr. Giuliani said he would not respond to Mr. D'Amato.
But Mr. Giuliani, who has been trying to persuade fellow Republicans to distance themselves from Mr. Pataki, called for a "realignment" of the New York State Republican Party after Election Day and said that he would have a role to play. "I don't by any means intend to play the only role," he said. "I don't think any one person should control a political party. I think that's part of the mistake that was made here," he said, in a reference to Senator D'Amato, his political rival.
Governor Weld of Massachusetts, who like Mr. Almond served in the Justice Department with Mr. Giuliani, called himself both a Pataki backer and a Giuliani backer. "By and large Rudy has superb taste in politics and even Jove can nod," he said, a reference to Greek mythology suggesting that even the mightiest can make mistakes.

HEADLINE: Short of Cash, N.A.A.C.P. Stops Paying Its Employees

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, its reserves of cash depleted, has stopped paying most of its professional staff, board members of the nation's preeminent civil rights organization said today.
The furlough took effect on Monday, and although officials of the group said they hoped it would last no more than a week or two, it showed the depth of the financial crisis gripping the organization after accusations of financial abuses by some of its leaders. 
 The N.A.A.C.P., with a national staff of about 100 people and an annual budget of about $15 million, is facing a growing deficit that already exceeds $3.5 million, officials said. Major contributors and individual members, their confidence shaken by the group's widely publicized turmoil, have been reluctant to donate money to make up the gap.
The group's local affiliates are principally volunteer organizations that raise their own money and operate under independent budgets. They are not directly affected by the national group's financial troubles.
Officials at the organization's headquarters in Baltimore did not answer their telephones today, but at offices around the country members of the staff were continuing to work without pay.
"Basically, we are volunteering our time," said Rob Robinson, a staff member in the New York office. "While we are having financial difficulties, we recognize the job we do is important."
The only staff members who continue to be paid are those whose work is financed through special, restricted grants made for specific purposes, board members said.
Several board members voiced dismay at the furlough, saying that staff members were informed of it by telephone over the weekend and that little information was available even to board members.
The board members said that the group's executive committee decided on the furlough over the weekend, after auditors from the accounting firm Price Waterhouse recommended it.
The accounting firm, which is not the group's regular independent auditor, was brought in on an emergency basis to review the group's finances, the board members said.
They also said that the Ford Foundation, a major donor to the association, had agreed to resume financing for the organization's operations once Price Waterhouse's recommendations are put into effect.
Spokesmen for the Ford Foundation and Price Waterhouse declined to disclose any details of the arrangements, which board members said were intended to allow the N.A.A.C.P. to resume normal operations, begin paying off its accumulating bills, and most critically of all, increase its fund-raising activities.
But the board members conceded that raising money will be difficult.
In August, the N.A.A.C.P.'s board dismissed the organization's executive director, Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., after directors learned that he had approved the spending of hundreds of thousands of dollars to settle a threatened sexual harassment suit.
More recently, the syndicated columnist Carl Rowan renewed the criticisms of the group's leaders, asserting that William F. Gibson, the board chairman, may have misused his expense account, a charge that Mr. Gibson has denied.
Joe Madison, an N.A.A.C.P. board member in Washington who spent 10 years as a political organizer on the group's staff, said that the furloughs might hurt the group's efforts to get voters to the polls next week, but he said that he expected most of the staff to keep working.
More important, he said, is the group's efforts to restore its reputation, especially because the end of the year is the time when, for tax reasons, many individual contributors decide how much money to give to charities.
"What the N.A.A.C.P. needs to do is to restore a sense of confidence in its leadership," he said.
Mr. Gibson, the board chairman, has called for special audits of the spending of all top officials, but Mr. Madison said that in his opinion Mr. Gibson should resign. Mr. Gibson could not be reached for comment.
Hazel Dukes, another board member, said that staff members were bitter about their treatment and that she had apologized to those with whom she works in New York.
Another board member, who insisted on anonymity, said that senior staff members had a "heated meeting" with Earl Shinhoster, the interim leader, on Monday, complaining about the emergency measures.
Only a few days ago, Mr. Shinhoster and Mr. Gibson kicked off a nationwide appeal for support with a half-hour radio broadcast from the Pittsburgh headquarters of the American Urban Radio Networks, whose 250 stations are focused on African-American audiences.
The group's radio campaign, announced two weeks ago, takes as its theme: "Imagine an America without an N.A.A.C.P."
Attracting new members is critical to the group's success, since nearly three-fourths of the national group's annual budget comes from memberships and individual donations.
But it is the local branches, youth councils and college chapters, that actually sign up the members and funnel the money to the national headquarters. The national group focuses on politics, legal cases, and other activities that require a professional staff.

HEADLINE: Stock Offer Is Postponed At Flushing

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The Flushing Savings Bank said yesterday that it had indefinitely postponed its initial stock offering because of an investigation by the Federal Government into apparent voting irregularities by depositors and what the bank called "uncertain market conditions."
Flushing is a mutual savings bank, meaning that it is not owned by shareholders. Several other recent attempts by mutual banks to convert to public ownership have foundered. 
 Last week, for example, the Carver Federal Savings Bank in New York issued stock at $10 a share, only to see the price fall to $7.75 on the first day of trading.
During the last several years, many mutual savings banks have converted to public ownership, offering stock that jumped as much as 40 percent immediately after it was issued. This year regulators have forced savings banks to raise their issue prices to avoid such quick jumps.
Regulators have also forced the banks to cut back on the compensation given to their managers and directors. At the same time, because of higher interest rates, investors have soured on the prospects for the savings bank industry.
As a result, a handful of mutual banks have canceled planned offerings; Flushing is the biggest to do so.
"They got caught between the Government pushing prices up and up, while the market is saying thrifts are already overvalued," said Christopher Quackenbush, a principal with Sandler O'Neill, a New York investment bank.
Flushing, in its original offering plan begun last year, hoped to raise $63 million, but the Government forced the bank to raise the amount to $74 million. The bank held a second meeting of depositors in September to approve that higher amount.
The bank was required to complete its issue by Oct. 31, or ask for a third vote by depositors.
In a statement, the bank said, "Certain issues have been raised with respect to alleged irregularities in connection with proxies voted" at the depositors meeting. It said the Office of Thrift Supervision, a Federal agency, was reviewing the matter and the bank had hired an independent expert to conduct an investigation.
"Faced by the absence of a final resolution of the O.T.S. review and uncertain market conditions, the board has determined that it is in the best interest of the bank and the subscribers in the conversion not to proceed," the bank said in the statement.
Officials of Flushing did not return telephone calls seeking comment. A spokeswoman for Advest Securities, the investment banker for Flushing, declined to comment. A spokesman for the Office of Thrift Supervision declined to comment on any investigation.
Flushing, based in Flushing, Queens, has seven branches and total assets of $598 million.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
Excerpts From Candidates' Speeches in the Gingrich-Jones Race in Georgia

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from speeches by Representative Newt Gingrich, the House minority leader, who is seeking re-election in Georgia, and his Democratic challenger, Ben Jones, a former Representative. They provide examples of the messages each candidate is delivering in his standard campaign speech. Mr. Gingrich spoke on Oct. 24 to a Kiwanis Club in Duluth, Ga., and Mr. Jones spoke on Oct. 25 at Kennesaw State College in Cobb County, Ga. The speeches were recorded for C-Span and transcribed by The New York Times.
 
NEWT GINGRICH
 Now, let me be quite direct about this. We have, I think, a crisis of the system at two levels. One level is that we can't afford the current structure of Government unless we were to massively raise taxes and crush the private sector. The other problem you have is the current structure of Government doesn't work. So, you are paying too much for a system that's destructive. The problem in Washington -- and those of you who might have seen Tim Russert go at me on "Meet the Press" will appreciate where we're at -- the problem in Washington is that they start with an assumption: this Government can't be changed. Therefore, how do we get more out of the American people? And they either get more out of the American people by not sending them back their own money -- cutting entitlements, cutting Social Security -- or we get more out of them by raising taxes. 
 I start from a totally different perspective. And I want to share with you very candidly and get your reaction to it. Because this is at the heart of where I need your advice and I need your counsel. Because getting this country back on the right track is a heck of a lot bigger job than one member of Congress, or one President, or even an entire party. This is a job that is going to require all 260 million Americans to take some serious responsibility for their future. . . .
We have to recognize that American exceptionalism is real, that American civilization is the most unique civilization in history, that we bring more people of more ethnic backgrounds together to pursue happiness with greater opportunity than any civilization in the history of the world. And we just don't say that anymore. Let me be candid. Haitians have more to learn from America than Americans have to learn from Haitians. The same is true of Bosnia. As far as I'm concerned, this counterculture notion, this politically correct notion that, "Oh, gee, we shouldn't make any value judgments," that's silly. The Declaration of Independence is a value judgment. It says we are endowed by our creator with certain inalienable rights, among which are life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.
Well, if you think of that, it's the most radical statement of humanness in history. It says each of you is endowed by God. Not by the state, not by Government, not by the liberals, not by bureaucracy, not by lawyers; by God. And therefore, by the way, when you rape somebody, you're raping somebody who's been endowed by God. If you kill somebody, you're killing somebody who's been endowed by God. That's why this whole sense of safety is at the center of the American experience. But so is a sense of work. If you're not working, you are wasting something which has been endowed. So we've got to go back, I think, and have the moral courage to say: "Yeah, we're going to teach people to be American. We're going to teach people the values of work. We're going to teach people the systems that work. And we're going to renew the 300-year commitment to human opportunity."
Lastly, we have to recognize that the political class has failed. As George Will says brilliantly in a column yesterday, the objective fact is the political class across this country, from city council to county commission to state government to the Federal Government, has failed to be responsive to people the way it needs to be, and that we are going to have to literally go and look at, from the ground up, how to make it more open. You see it beginning to happen. City councils that are on local cable access is a good step. We're going to insist that the rules be changed such that if you file a bill or a conference report in Washington in print, you also have to file the conference report electronically so that at that second, anybody in the country who wants to can get a copy of it. And you begin to change the whole dynamics so insiders no longer have any special advantage.
 
BEN JONES
 My politics are pretty independent. It's easy, I think, in the political discourse just to divide everything up and say: "Oh, he's a Democrat. Tax and spend. Big social welfare programs. Da, da, da, da, da." Or: "I'm a Republican. Vote for me. I'll cut your taxes. Da, da, da, da, da." Well, it doesn't work that way and never has. It's true, I think, that the Democratic leadership is to the left of center. And I think that the Republican leadership, clearly, is to the right of center. But most Americans and most folks in both parties who consider themselves to be Democrats or Republicans are in the mainstream. Folks who just have to work for a living, pay taxes, raise kids, get them through school, take care of your health care bills and worry about crime in your neighborhood. And what we're looking for are solutions.
So I vote, myself, as pretty much of a mainstream legislator, independent. We put an emphasis on constituent service, and nobody did constituent services any better than we did when I represented the old Fourth District. And by that I mean helping people in their dealings with the Government. That's really the first job of a Congressional office. If you've got a problem with Social Security, the Veterans Administration, Environmental Protection Agency or the Highway Department, or the Food and Drug Administration, call your Congressman. That's what you're paying your tax money for.
I said when we went into our office that this isn't really a business, this is public sector, but I want it run like a business. And let us understand that taxpayers are not only our customers, they are also our employers. We work for them. And we tried not to forget that. And we had an extremely successful office in that way, responsive to the people. And we did the outreach things. We had export-import seminars. We had wetlands symposiums. We had small-business forums. We had Medicare seminars for senior citizens all over the district. We had symposiums for people who were looking for ways to fund their higher education, ways that they could get that support. So we were very pro active that way.
I had the best environmental record of any Georgia Congressman. I had the best record on real estate and home building of any Georgia Congressman. I think I had as good a record on civil rights and human rights as any Georgia Congressman. I'm pro-choice. If those things make me a liberal, I accept.
On the other hand, I support a balanced budget amendment, a pretty conservative position. My feeling is that had we had a balanced budget amendment in 1980, we wouldn't be $4.5 trillion in debt. We need that kind of fiscal discipline and restraint. I support a lower capital gains rate. I think that's good. That's good for savings, and that's good for investment, and that's good for the economy.
I supported the Persian Gulf war. And I think that was the right choice. It was not popular among a lot of my friends who are Democrats, but I thought that was the right choice at the time, and I was pretty hawkish about it, in fact.
I support capital punishment in a lot of cases, not just in some cases. I do believe it is a deterrent. And I think that with the situation that we have now in this country with crime and drugs, we have to be tough. And that's as tough as you can get. There were other things like that that made me not easily characterized politically, certainly not as some knee-jerk liberal.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CONNECTICUT GOVERNOR;
Cut-and-Spend Democrat Lags in Connecticut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 1

 BODY:
William E. Curry Jr., the State Comptroller who is running for governor of Connecticut as a "New Democrat," is the only one among the four candidates talking about creating ambitious new programs. "This is not about changing governors, but about changing government," he often says.
That message, however, has not been an easy sell for Mr. Curry, who has never risen above 28 percent in the polls in a state where 38 percent of registered voters are Democrats. 
 On a recent campaign bus tour of college campuses, he stopped at Capital Community Technical College and described his plan for a new trust fund that he said would guarantee college loans while costing taxpayers barely a penny.
The 80 students and professors listening clapped politely, but not passionately. Michelle Cassells, 19, a sophomore who lives in Hartford, was plainly not moved.
"That's all stuff we've heard before," she said. "Right now, it's just a matter of choosing the one who lies the least."
Like President Clinton, Mr. Curry is offering himself as a different sort of Democrat, a compassionate technocrat who will reshape government and expand services as he trims spending and cuts taxes. And Mr. Curry appears to be having the same trouble the President has in convincing voters that government can take on new challenges.
Still, while many Democrats are running away from the President, Mr. Curry has embraced him, inviting him here and welcoming him warmly when he arrived on Oct. 15. "It will help to be identified with him," Mr. Curry said recently.
But his Republican adversary, John G. Rowland, also said Mr. Clinton should visit more often. "We'd like President Clinton to stay until Nov. 8," he said, noting that he was eager to capitalize on voter disaffection with the President.
Mr. Rowland has broadcast an advertisement showing the two Democrats together, with a voice-over that says: "Connecticut can't afford another double-talking Bill."
While the election is more than a referendum on President Clinton, Mr. Curry's fate turns on the appeal of the same message of change that Mr. Clinton has used.
A cerebral candidate known for his verbosity, Mr. Curry speaks grandly about a "fundamental restructuring of the bureaucracy," "community empowerment" and altering "the basic distribution of power, opportunity and access."
The backbone of his campaign is a strong grass-roots field organization of unions and consumer, environmental and women's groups.
What Mr. Curry offers is this: a 25 percent cut in property taxes that involves establishing a dedicated account for use by towns and cities; state-guaranteed student loans administered by banks; using state-sponsored insurance buying pools to lower health-care costs, and fighting crime through tougher enforcement and more education and drug-treatment programs.
Mr. Curry's three opponents see very little new in this and dismiss him as just another tax-and-spend liberal. Critics question his pledge to reduce property taxes without raising other taxes. Even leading Democrats are skeptical that he can cut $1 billion from a state budget of roughly $9 billion.
Still, Mr. Curry attracted enough support to pull off a surprising primary victory over a party-endorsed candidate. And while Mr. Rowland has always led in the polls, Mr. Curry has narrowed the gap in the last two months to single digits from as many as 28 points.
If Mr. Curry defeats the better-financed, better-known Republican, it will be a major political upset. But for William Edward Curry Jr., such underdog struggles have been his mainstay.
Born in Hartford on Dec. 17, 1951, he was the son of a prominent Democratic Party activist who was the campaign manager for the first black elected to the State Legislature.
After graduating from Georgetown University and the University of Connecticut Law School, Mr. Curry won a primary in 1978 against a party-endorsed candidate for state senator and then defeated a veteran Republican incumbent.
In four years in the State Senate, he established a reputation as an abrasive media hound who fought for liberal causes and good-government measures. He proposed tighter environmental regulations, pushed a measure to force businesses to give six months' notice before closing plants and passed legislation requiring regular reviews of government programs to reduce bureaucracy.
Mr. Curry left the Legislature in 1982 to run for Congress. After he lost, he worked for two years as executive director of the nuclear weapons freeze movement's political action committee.
Returning to politics in 1990, he unseated the four-term Democratic State Comptroller, Ed Caldwell.
Now, Mr. Curry is in a four-way race for governor with Mr. Rowland; Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, who succeeds Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. as the nominee of A Connecticut Party, and Tom Scott of the Independence Party.
For the last two months, Mr. Curry has struggled with Mr. Rowland over how he will be defined to voters. The Republican has portrayed him as a liberal, while Mr. Curry has cultivated an image of being a hands-on manager.
Mr. Rowland, whose $3.3 million war chest is more than a third larger than Mr. Curry's, has saturated television with ads that trumpet Mr. Curry's votes as a State Senator for 17 tax increases and against the death penalty. At campaign appearances, Mr. Rowland has pointed to Mr. Curry's strong labor support, suggesting that he would be beholden to them if elected.
Mr. Curry has countered that the tax votes were long ago in a very different economy, and has said that he changed his position on the death penalty in the early 1980's.
And at a recent talk to the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the state's largest business group, Mr. Curry contended that his support from labor did not make him an enemy of business.
"I know how important my relationship is with this community," he said. "This is a relationship I will nurture."
Harry Kenworthy, a vice president of a manufacturing company, said he liked what he heard but still felt uneasy. "Folks generally perceive Bill as a very liberal guy," he said.
In an interview in September, Mr. Curry expressed annoyance at the liberal tag. He said that he had had substantial differences with liberal groups over the last four years, particularly on his support of a market-based health-care overhaul.
As Comptroller, Mr. Curry is generally credited with transforming a backwater office into a high-profile operation. He established an investigative unit that exposed a multimillion-dollar state furniture contract that was about to go to a high bidder. He also helped improve the state's computer billing operations.
Still, his record is not entirely unblemished.
Mr. Curry stunned many liberal legislators in 1991 by opposing Governor Weicker's plan to introduce an income tax to rid the state of a $1 billion deficit. Mr. Curry said he supported the principle, but not that particular version. He later issued budget analyses showing that it would not resolve the deficit, a projection that proved wrong.
Some legislators accused Mr. Curry of grandstanding, though he insisted it was a matter of wanting an income tax that would weigh less on working people. His actions so angered legislators that they voted to strip him of his power to issue official budget analyses.
While Mr. Curry now opposes repealing the tax -- a stark contrast with the positions of Mr. Rowland and Mr. Scott -- he has avoided focusing on this in the campaign. Instead, he has tried to shift the debate to the property tax, which many say is a heavier burden on the poor and middle class.
Mr. Curry has said that by the end of his first term as governor he will send about $1 billion back to the towns and cities in property tax relief, without any cuts in state services. But critics say they don't see how it can be done.
And despite Mr. Curry's pledge of fiscal conservatism, he has conceded that some programs would need more spending. To add beds for drug treatment would cost money, he said in an interview in September. A campaign leaflet promises to increase financing for state schools.
And Mr. Curry has said he would have honored the arbitrated agreements with state employees unions that Governor Weicker opposed, costing about $100 million.
While Mr. Curry has said that such money would come from savings elsewhere, his message of doing more with less has not yet caught fire. John F. Droney Jr., a former state Democratic Party chairman, blamed Mr. Curry's lack of money to advertise and predicted it would change this week with a media blitz.
But this problem may also be the same that the President is facing -- a deep distrust in the electorate about new government initiatives.
This morning on a talk-radio show, Mr. Curry fielded calls about his property tax proposal.
One caller complained that funneling state money to a dedicated account for local government would be prone to waste.
"It's the same old bureaucracy," she said.
Mr. Curry explained that local officials would monitor the fund and that the municipalities could get the money only if they reduced their property-tax rates.
"For senior citizens, for poor people, for working people, dollar for dollar, it's the property tax that hits them hardest," he said.
Another caller weighed in. "It sounds like rhetoric to me," he said.
Mr. Curry said last week that his message was reaching people, though he noted that complex ideas weremaking them a tough sell.
He said he has put out detailed proposals on crime and economic development, and they were barely noticed.
"Between the two of them, for all the months of work that went into them, literally, it might have gotten me a percent more recognition," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William E. Curry Jr., right, campaigning at an N.A.A.C.P. forum. (Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Class Notes

BYLINE: By Peter Applebome 

 BODY:
Very little is more in tune with popular fashion these days than the notion that private companies can provide public services -- from picking up garbage to educating children -- at higher quality and lower cost than public institutions.
Take the Edison Project, the high-profile, high-risk attempt of the media entrepreneur Christopher Whittle to revamp the nation's schools. But if Edison's struggle to survive the collapse or sale of the rest of Mr. Whittle's empire tells anything, it is that the prevailing "government bad, private enterprise good" formulation driving the nation's send-them-a-message politics can speak more to slogans than to solutions. 
 The appeal of private management in education rests on the notion that American schools are failing and that something radical is needed to save them.
"What's interesting to me is to hear people saying that we need to give more money and time to the people who are running things now," said Michael Moe, a financial analyst with Lehman Brothers, who follows trends in for-profit education. "The one thing I know for sure is that's not the answer. Just going back to basic principles of what works: basic capitalism works, competition works, accountability works, leveraging through technology works. And that seems to be a lot of what Edison is doing."
But many education experts, even many sympathetic to corporate involvement in education, think private management of school districts is better in theory than in reality.
One obstacle is the way the American corporate life style clashes headlong with the culture of public education. In fact, from his estate in the Hamptons to his corporate jets to his lavish corporate retreats to his largely empty corporate complex in Knoxville, Tenn., Mr. Whittle is a reminder that the perks like free parking and health insurance deemed proof of an imperial Congress are laughably picayune when compared with life at the upper echelons of corporate America.
Denis P. Doyle, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, thinks that taxpayers will balk at seeing education dollars go to Wall Street investors and six- and seven-figure corporate salaries.
"I think it's an absolutely futile quest," said Mr. Doyle, who is an enthusiastic supporter of many private-sector educational initiatives but is skeptical about for-profit concerns' running districts and schools. "The American public has no taste for making a profit on our kids."
Second, Mr. Doyle, among others, is skeptical that private enterprise can produce innovations and efficiencies that are superior to those being produced by nonprofit organizations, many of which are scrambling to come up with their own school reform models. Edison, after all, has spent $40 million since 1991 without opening a single school.
Mr. Doyle notes that for-profit concerns must not only pay taxes on earnings and property but also generate returns that will please their investors. As a result, he estimates, they are burdened with expenses that can exceed those of nonprofits by 30 percent to 50 percent.
"Venture capitalists are going to want a 15-to-20-percent rate of return," he said. "There's no way you can take that kind of profit out and compete with a not-for-profit provider."
A third question is just how much profit can be made to begin with. Almost everyone agrees that districts can be run more efficiently, and corporations are already playing a role in such efforts in areas from tutoring to school security to trash pickup to computer programs. But whether for-profit management can turn substantial profits -- when even the best private schools struggle to keep their budgets balanced -- is a very open question.
"Any good private-sector manager can do a better job of building maintenance, logistical things like buses and purchasing than the public schools in most places do," said Henry Levin, a Stanford University economist who founded Stanford's Accelerated Schools program, which works with troubled students in 700 schools. "But that's a small portion of the overall budget. I don't see anyone that's shown yet how you make a profit on public schools."
To their credit, Edison and Education Alternatives Inc., the for-profit concern recently hired to manage the Hartford public schools, are not saying that for-profit management alone is the answer. Instead, they say that at a time when radical approaches are needed, the management skills, the accountability and the access to capital that businesses can provide are an important avenue for producing innovation and change.
And many educators believe that only by coming up with radically different management models, like for-profit management, can education undergo dramatic change.
"Right now we have no incentives for schools to do a good job," said Eric Hanushek, an economist at the University of Rochester. "I don't know for sure that for-profit firms like Edison will succeed. But I think the bottom line is that 10 years from now we will have a variety of different ways of providing educational services, and I don't think there's any reason to think that a profit-making firm is incompatible with providing them."
It may turn out that Edison will be able to put a computer in every child's home, lengthen the school day and the school year, pay teachers more than they are paid now, provide "the best education in the world" for the same money public schools spend now and turn a profit that will thrill Wall Street. But most smart investors are well aware that politicians are not the only ones who have been accused of promising first and figuring out how to deliver later.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Continuing To Retreat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices continued falling in the credit markets yesterday, as investors reacted to economic reports that showed rapid growth, portending future inflation.
Although analysts say that the probability that the Federal Reserve will move to raise short-term rates again before the Nov. 15 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee is fading, traders are still worried about how aggressive the central bank will be in raising rates to fight inflation this year. 
 The most troubling issue is that the Fed has already raised interest rates five times this year, and the effect so far has not been telling, some traders say. It leaves investors wondering if last Friday's rally was only a brief vacation from the bearish trend that re-emerged yesterday.
Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said it was a tough day with a lot of volatility, and now, "We're back to where we were last week before the third-quarter G.D.P. on Friday and close to our recent high yields."
The long bond was back above an 8 percent yield even before the National Association of Purchasing Management released its report on business activity. It was expected to stay little changed in October from its 58.2 percent reading in September, but rose to 59.7, its highest level since December 1987, pushing bond prices down and yields up. The 30-year bond was off 29/32 , to 9323/32 , for a yield of 8.06 percent, up from 7.97 percent on Monday and the highest since last Wednesday, when it was also 8.06 percent.
Mr. Alexy said yesterday's market might be systematic of what the market goes through until mid-December. Prices fell early on "the dollar's weakness in overseas markets," he said. Then the purchasing managers' report pushed them further down.
Traders note that data on the manufacturing sector have regularly exceeded expectations in recent months, so they expected it would be tough to find buyers with yesterday's numbers. According to James Hale, MMS International fixed-income analyst, "Not only did the price index jump to 79.9 percent, but supplier delivery time also hit a six-year high at 64.7 percent -- a likely sign of inflationary bottlenecks developing." He said while employment did edge down, it was overshadowed by strength elsewhere in the data. "The report was unambiguously bearish for bonds," he said.
Today the Fed will give the market a glimpse of how it views the economy going into the F.O.M.C. meeting when it releases its so-called beige book report. Also due today is the Treasury's announcement of the size of the quarterly refunding, followed tomorrow by the key employment data.
"All of this will add up to a lot of pushing and shoving in the market," Mr. Alexy said, "giving investors no compelling reason to get involved.
In another exhibition of economic strength the Commerce Department said United States construction spending rose a larger-than-expected 1.6 percent in September, the biggest gain in six months.
The strength in the construction data was widespread, encompassing housing, commercial real estate and public projects. Analysts said the 1.6 percent increase was the biggest since March, when it was up 2.1 percent. "It is also the latest Government report to suggest the economy is growing by more than 3 percent -- a rate that some suggest could cause inflation to accelerate," Mr. Hale said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
New contenders for greatness in the world of solid-waste disposal.

BYLINE: By John Holusha 

 BODY:
THE two titans of trash have been displaced.
Although the expanding economy means more trash and more business for those companies that collect, haul, dispose of and, increasingly, recycle it, analysts are now favoring the second tier of solid-waste companies. 
 These include regional concerns that may have an opportunity for faster growth because their basic operations are still relatively small. Among the companies in this group are Sanifill Inc., USA Waste Services, United Waste Systems and Philip Environmental.
The two top-tier companies, WMX Technologies, formerly Waste Management, and Browning-Ferris Industries, have built nationwide businesses with annual sales in the billions of dollars. Both are in the midst of good years, with WMX's third-quarter earnings up 17 percent and Browning-Ferris's fourth quarter, which also ended in September, up 55 percent.
But investors seem to have noticed that both are trading near their 52-week highs, suggesting that further upward movement in their stock prices may be hard to achieve.
As an alternative, Hugh F. Holman of Alex. Brown & Sons has put a strong buy on Sanifill, a Houston-based company that at the beginning of the year had operations in 17 states.
"They are established in major markets across the country," Mr. Holman said, "and that is a big advantage. You have to pay up to enter a market and establish a landfill, but then you are in a position to make small, 'tuck-in' acquisitions to fill out the market."
Mr. Holman forecasts that Sanifill's earnings will increase sharply -- from 87 cents a share last year to $1.12 this year and $1.35 next year, which should produce a share price of $24 to $27, based on common price-earnings multiples. Recently, the stock has been trading at $22 to $23 a share. Yesterday it closed at $22.50, down 25 cents.
Much of that earnings growth is expected to come from acquisitions, as the solid-waste market evolves from one that was highly fragmented to one increasingly dominated by big, integrated companies.
In years past, many trash haulers were small trucking operations that served a few towns or parts of towns and emptied their loads at the county dump for a modest fee. But in many places, the county dump has been closed because it was unlined, allowing rainwater to penetrate the trash and leach unwanted chemicals into ground water.
The trend today is toward large, regional landfills equipped with multiple liners to prevent leaks and fluid-collection systems to treat the water before it is released. The companies that own them are in a position to offer a municipality a full range of services including collection, recycling and secure disposal that a small trucking company would find hard to match.
As a result, many smaller companies are selling to the most powerful integrated operator in the area.
United Waste Systems offers such services and is the pick of Paul R. Knight of NatWest Securities. He said the company was following a Wal-Mart strategy of focusing on suburban and rural areas where it could lock up the business, and leaving the highly competitive areas to others.
This gives the company flexibility in pricing. "Price escalators built into United Waste's local contracts," Mr. Knight wrote, "have raised prices 6 percent to 9 percent versus last year, and volumes have grown in excess of 35 percent" in Michigan, the company's largest market.
He has established a price target of $30 within 12 months. Recently, the shares have been trading at about $24 a share, closing yesterday at $23.875, down 37.5 cents.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Heating Oil Prices Surge With Crucial Season Near

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Heating oil prices jumped yesterday as traders looked ahead to a seasonal rise in fuel consumption. Other energy markets followed suit.
But for commodities as a whole, the strong gains in energy and also in copper futures were partly offset by steep losses in hogs and lumber. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose just 0.23 point, to 233.53. 
 On the Mercantile Exchange in New York, home heating oil for December delivery soared 1.32 cents, to 50.72 cents a gallon, the highest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since Aug. 4.
December crude oil rose 49 cents, to $18.68 a barrel, a 12-week high; December unleaded gasoline climbed 0.94 cent, to 59.80 cents a gallon, and December natural gas fell 1.4 cents, to $1.936 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Monday's expiration of the November heating oil contract shifted the market's focus to December deliveries and the cold months ahead, said Tom Curtis, director of energy research for Pegasus Econometric Group in New York.
Current United States supplies of petroleum distillates, which include heating oil and diesel fuel, are ample, he said. Over the last 13 weeks, growth in supplies outpaced growth in demand by nearly two percentage points. "But because now we're into the December contract, I think the perception of where we're going has changed," he said.
Crude prices were also supported by resurgent refinery demand on the Gulf Coast as pipelines damaged or shut down by floods in the Houston area in late October began to return to full capacity.
Consumption of crude oil in the United States typically rises in November as refiners restart units that were closed in October for seasonal maintenance, said John Saucer, an energy analysts with Smith Barney Inc.
Copper futures surged to a four-year high amid heavy buying from both dealers and speculators.
November copper rose 2.9 cents, to $1.268 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange of New York, the highest settlement for near-term deliveries since Oct. 26, 1990.
Hogs for December delivery plunged 1.17 cents, to 34.10 cents a pound, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as large supplies reasserted pressure on the market.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower as It Follows Stocks and Bonds Again

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar followed American stocks and bonds lower yesterday, as it did on Monday. Yesterday's drop came after a report showing brisk manufacturing activity fueled new worries about inflation.
The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen and the German mark when both stocks and bonds were driven lower by the monthly report of the National Association of Purchasing Management. 
 While manufacturing activity climbed, as expected, the markets were surprised by the gain in the price component of the report, which hit its highest level in six years. Investors, fearing inflation might erode the value of dollar-based assets, sold American stocks and bonds heavily.
"The fate of the dollar has rested very heavily on the fate of the Dow," said Richard Block, a dealer at Nationsbanc-CRT in Chicago. "The price component of the National Association of Purchasing Management index was higher yet again, and that continues to fuel inflation concerns."
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell as low as 96.49 yen after the report was released, just above a post-World-War-II low of 96.42 yen set in intraday trading on Oct. 25. The dollar was last quoted at 96.65 yen, down from 96.93 yen on Monday. The dollar fell as low as 1.4943 marks, before settling at 1.4956 marks, down from 1.5037 marks on Monday.
The dollar was also weakened against the yen after United States and Japanese officials said they had failed to reach an agreement on opening Japan's glass sector by an Oct. 31 deadline. Worries that the White House might advocate a weaker dollar to increase United States exports arose again.
 "The belief is that if trade tensions get worse the dollar is going to go lower," said David Durst, vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company. "That is why people were selling the dollar."
The dollar bounced off its lows, however, after Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, signaled greater optimism in the trade talks between America and Japan.
The dollar was weaker against most other leading currencies, falling to 1.2475 Swiss francs, from 1.2595 francs on Monday, and slipping to 5.1260 French francs from 5.1665 francs. But the dollar gained against the British pound, which eased to $1.6335, from $1.6355 on Monday.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
The Talks Are Quiet, But Skates Are Sharp

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
No new talks were held or scheduled yesterday in the National Hockey League as the owner-ordered shutdown began its second month. But several kettles continued to boil on the hot stove of an increasingly fragmented business.
In Toronto, the players' association announced rosters for a union-sponsored tournament, to be held next week, and prepared for a major membership meeting to be held there today. Participants in the union games will include Glenn Healy of the Rangers; Ray Ferraro and Benoit Hogue of the Islanders, and Stephane Richer and Claude Lemieux of the Devils. 
 In New York, the league headquarters delayed its expected announcement that more games will be canceled. So far, only 4 games of each team's 84-game regular season have been scrapped, although it is likely that at least 10 more will have to be killed.
The possibiilty of the season being slashed to 50 games was raised yesterday during a conference call among league general managers, according to The Canadian Press. There was no indication that such a step would be taken.
Also in the New York area, Mark Messier has resumed skating with a few of his Ranger teammates and said he may travel to Europe in December with Wayne Gretzky and a team of barnstorming stars.
In Russia, officials are preparing a Kremlin reception tomorrow for N.H.L. stars who once represented the former Soviet Union. Those players' tour of 5 games in 10 days will begin Friday night.
And in Anaheim, Calif., the league was excoriated for canceling medical insurance without telling the players. The words were predictable amid such a bitter labor confrontation. The only surprise was that they came from a high-ranking member of management.
The union-sponsored tournament will be held Nov. 10, 11 and 12 in Copps Coliseum in Hamilton, Ontario. Teams representing the United States, Ontario, Quebec and Western Canada will play with four skaters, instead of the usual five, and will play three 20-minute games per night against the other three tournament rivals. Players will also participate in a shootout contest.
The league offered no explanation for its decision not to announce the cancellation of games. As of last night, the Rangers had missed 15 games, the Devils 12 and the Islanders 10. The last official N.H.L. game was held last June 14, at Madison Square Garden, when the Rangers' captain, Messier, skated around the ice with the Stanley Cup. Messier, who spent time in Los Angeles recently with Gretzky, skated on Monday for the first time since then.
"I didn't forget how," he said. "I went for a little twirl." Gretzky spoke with him last week about joining a group that will play club teams in places such as Finland, Italy and Germany.
"I talked with Wayne a little about it," said Messier, who added that he is more interested in getting the N.H.L. season going with a new collective bargaining agreement. "But if this lockout continues, there will be lots of things that will take place."
One of them is this week, in Russia, where a tour of stars is being sponsored by Sun Microsystems of Mountain View, Calif., a computer company that does business in Russia.
An impressive group of players is scheduled to participate. Those players include Detroit's Sergei Fedorov, the most valuable player in the N.H.L. last season, who will be reunited with his former linemates, Pavel Bure of Vancouver and Alexander Mogilny of Buffalo.
Also featured are Darius Kasparaitis and Vladimir Malakhov of the Islanders; Aleksei Kovalev, Sergei Nemchinov and Aleksandr Karpovtsev of the Rangers and Aleksandr Semak and Valery Zelepukin of the Devils.
The tour will open with a game against Spartak on Nov. 4 and will conclude against Red Army, also known as Russian Penguins, on Nov. 14. At a Kremlin reception, the players, who left the former Soviet Union without permission, will be given Russian passports.
Edward Zander, an executive representing the corporate sponsors, said the players aren't being paid for the tour and that all proceeds will go to amateur hockey in Russia. However, an agent for one of the players, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said players have been guaranteed at least $10,000 each by someone involved in the tour.
Back in the United States, there are recriminations in some quarters over the league's decision to stop paying its players insurance premiums on Oct. 15. The league didn't tell the players, and Tom Kurvers, the former Islander now with Anaheim, learned of the situation only last week when he and his pregnant wife ended up in a hospital after a car accident.
Although the insurance will remain in effect if the players choose to make the payments, the league's tactics were questioned by Tony Tavares, president of the Mighty Ducks.
"It was not one of the league's shining moments," Tavares said. "I think it was mishandled and I let my feelings be known. It would have been nice if he had been told in advance that his coverage had been eliminated.
"We, as a league, should have found a better way."
Arthur Pincus, the league spokesman, said, "The N.H.L. will have no comment on statements by Tony Tavares." Pincus added that any N.H.L. player who wants insurance still has it. The cancellation of the league's insurance payments, he said, "is an economic decision that is common labor practice."

HEADLINE: Playwright's Tough Subject Draws Funny Offers

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
In "The Waiting Room," three women from different centuries are waiting to see the doctor: an 18th-century Chinese wife whose feet have been bound and deformed, a Victorian lady who has been too tightly corseted emotionally as well as physically and a contemporary American woman whose breast implants have led to cancer. Each has been abused in the name of beauty, or at least beauty as fantasized by a male-dominated society. Lisa Loomer's new play deals with everything from medical malpractice to misogyny, while crosscutting through time and space.
Wendy Wasserstein, who saw the play in its workshop last year at the Williamstown Theater Festival, described it as "dark but colorful." "It's not a polite humor and it has a political force," she said. "It's a play with an issue but it does not deal with it as an issue play." 
 "The Waiting Room," which was a success in its recent production at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, opened recently at Trinity Repertory Company in Providence, R.I. On her way from her home in California to Providence to consult with her director, David Schweizer, the playwright stopped for a short visit in her native Manhattan in order to talk to producers about a Broadway or Off Broadway production.
At breakfast before her meetings, Ms. Loomer revealed her own wry sense of humor. She said that at first she had set her play in purgatory, which, from her point of view, "is a short leap to a modern doctor's waiting room."
She continued, "The title addresses the literal waiting room and the state in which we all wait for things to change -- and certainly for things to change vis-a-vis cancer." One specific impetus for the work was her own mother's illness from breast cancer; she died before the play was finished.
Ms. Loomer said that since the play, she had become "the woman writer of the moment" in California. "Because we're talking about Hollywood," she added, "I mean the moment. Since I'm here now, that's probably not true any more."
On the strength of "The Waiting Room," she has been surrounded by offers to write sitcoms ("for comics who do jokes about a gynecologist's office"), screenplays and magazine articles about health and beauty. Drawing on her own partly Hispanic family background, she would like to write a Latino sitcom, and has already made two attempts, "Gloria," about a Puerto Rican talk-show host, and "East L.A.," which took place in an unemployment office. One offer she did accept was from Columbia Pictures to write the movie version of Susanna Kaysen's best-selling memoir, "Girl, Interrupted" about her two years in a mental institution.
For Ms. Loomer, who is in her 30's, it has been a logical rise from actress and standup comic to playwright and screenwriter. After studying theater at Brandeis University and the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, she acted Off Broadway and worked with a political comedy group at the West Bank Cafe. While studying acting with Wynn Handman at the American Place Theater, she grew tired of performing other people's monologues and began writing her own, signing them with invented names like Jane da Vinci. After emerging from her pseudonyms, she performed her original pieces in the American Humorist Series at the American Place.
To further her double career, she moved to Los Angeles (newly wed, she and her husband, a composer, live in Sherman Oaks). Her first play, "Birds," was done at the South Coast Repertory Theater. In the author's words, the play deals with "borders between family members and between countries; it's about a Mexican-American family that goes back to Mexico." Ms. Loomer's family now lives in Mexico.
In the style of magic realism, dead people often speak in her plays. "Don't they speak to everyone?" she asked. "That's not naturalism, but it's perfectly natural." In her work, she explores multiculturism from different, nonlinear angles. "If I were a painter," she said, "I might be a cubist."
It was while investigating women's health issues at the Women's Artists Group in Los Angeles that she began "The Waiting Room." That room was soon populated with visions from her fervid imagination, including Hygeia, the Greek goddess of health. She also found factual sources in her research into conventional and nonconventional treatments of cancer. June Kyoko Lu, an actress in the women's group, introduced her to the subject of footbinding, and went on to play the Chinese character, Forgiveness From Heaven, in both productions.
Ms. Loomer freely acknowledges Caryl Churchill as an influence. The fact that in "Top Girls" the English playwright merged characters from various historical periods gave her "permission to do something crazy like this," Ms. Loomer said. In California, "The Waiting Room" provoked discussion and even arguments among theatergoers. "I think that people bring their own lives to the theater," she said. "What rings true for them they embrace. What doesn't ring true or disturbs them, they don't see, tune out or become uncomfortable with."
After one performance, she overheard a theatergoer tell a friend that she had had a difficult time with the play because someone close to her had just died "and cancer is not funny."
Ms. Loomer responds: "This play clearly comes out of my own experience. I don't think cancer is funny at all. I think people are funny, and sometimes even people with cancer are funny. It's the collision of needs that produces humor." When her mother read her plays, she would say, "Do you think people would really find this funny?," but then would end up laughing with her daughter. It was, said Ms. Loomer, "laughter of shock and at the same time a recognition of truth."
Last year, "The Waiting Room" was named as a runner-up for the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, which goes annually to a play written by a woman in the English-speaking world. At the awards ceremony in London early this year, Ms. Loomer read three monologues from her play. Afterward, Diana Rigg complimented her on her writing and suggested she also consider a second career as an actress.
Might she perform one of the roles in her play? "At this point, acting is a luxury for me," she said. "With all due immodesty, there are people who can do the parts as well or better than I can. But there are things I have to write that no one could write for me."
