HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
New Baseball League Offers Profit Sharing for Cities and Players

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Offering partnerships in the form of an innovative profit-sharing and equity plan for cities and players alike, its founders launched the United Baseball League yesterday, intent on succeeding where virtually every other new rival sports league has failed.
"We think we're going to succeed because of a confluence of factors," Bob Mrazek, a former five-time Congressman from Long Island, said yesterday. He cited "cities that yearn to have major league caliber baseball, investors who want to participate in a new structure and design for owning a team and enough major league players who are going to choose to play in an entrepreneurial and nonconfrontational atmosphere in this new league." 
 Speaking candidly at a news conference at the Parker Meridien Hotel in midtown Manhattan, Mrazek added: "If we have made a serious miscalculation with respect to those components, then we're going to have a serious problem. But we like to think those factors are unique in the history of baseball right now and that's why we believe we're going to succeed."
Major League Baseball hasn't had competition since the Federal League lasted for two seasons 80 years ago. The World Hockey Association, the American Basketball League and the American Basketball Association failed as rivals to the National Hockey League and the National Basketball Association. The All America Football Conference, the World Football League and the United States Football League fell before the might of the National Football League.
Only the American Football League succeeded, and then only by forcing a complete merger with the N.F.L.
The United Baseball League will take its turn in an environment that has grown hostile because of the nearly three-month-old players' strike against Major League Baseball. But it is that hostility the new venture will rely on in its quest to stock itself with as many major leaguers as possible and operate a 10-team league beginning in 1996.
"People are looking for alternatives to the traditional baseball that has produced the kind of disaster it did this year," said Richard Moss, the player agent, who with Mrazek and two other men have created the league. "I think a lot of people view the fact that there wasn't a World Series this year as a violation of public trust. They think there's something better."
Major League Baseball said little in reaction to the announcement of its potential rival. "We'll just wait and see what happens with it," Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said in a statement, then declined to add to it by telephone.
"We're not here to prod the old establishment and it's not our intention to replace it," Moss said. "We're here to coexist with it. We will compete just as Ford competes with General Motors. By starting fresh and not being bound to antiquated practices, we will be able to have a much healthier atmosphere."
The United League will try to make baseball better by offering cities that agree to build or adapt existing stadiums -- perhaps the hardest sell -- a 15 percent share of pretax profits and a 15 percent equity share, as well as by offering players a 35 percent share of pretax profits and 10 percent equity.
The United League will try to make baseball better by offering fans cheaper tickets and by involving members of minority groups in significant numbers and significant positions.
"Minorities in the United Baseball League will be able to step from the batter's box to the owner's box," said Eric Vinson, vice president of the United States Trust Company and one of several black members of the league's management company.
The former major league outfielder Curt Flood, also a member of the management company, said: "We need an alternative league. America deserves an alternative league. I wish there was one when I played." A minute later, he added: "I need an alternative league. Baseball's owners have shut me out for 25 years."
The league's organizers did not cite specific cities for their teams because none has been placed, but they appear to hope to have teams in Nassau or Suffolk County on Long Island, San Bernardino, Calif., Washington, Orlando or Jacksonville, Fla., Vancouver, British Columbia, and Mexico City or Monterrey, Mexico.
"The seat of our national government should deserve a baseball team," said Tom McMillen, a former N.B.A. player and Congressman from Maryland, who is a member of the league's management company.
The organizers emphasized that the league is not a strike league. Mrazek said he began working on the project more than a year ago with John Bryant, a Texas Congressman. They brought Andrew Zimbalist, an economist, into it last December and much more recently added Moss, who five years ago worked on the creation of a new league.
Player agents naturally would like a competing league because competition could only benefit their clients. But some agents who were asked yesterday talked about the animosity that has emerged from the labor dispute.
Jim Bronner talked of the "acrimony that's going to exist the rest of this winter and with some carry-over effects" and added, "Unless there's a significant difference in salaries, I think they would prefer to play in the other league."
Tom Reich said: "There are players who will make decisions for the new league, if it lives, for reasons in addition to economic. I don't think anybody connected to this sport will ever forget what has happened before and during the baseball crash of '94, nor should they ever forget. There's a tremendous residue of bitterness from this, greater than collusion."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The logo to be used by the United Baseball League, a new endeavor that expects to start in 1996 season. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

INDUSTRY: SIC7011 HOTELS & MOTELS (56%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Off the Menu

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant 

 BODY:

A Home for Saltimbanco
The marathon lease negotiations have been concluded, and work is now starting on Saltimbanco, the long-awaited restaurant of Mario, Marco and Mauro Maccioni, whose father, Sirio, owns Le Cirque. The restaurant, which will open next year, will be in Fisher Park, a mid block oasis behind 1345 Avenue of the Americas, near 54th Street. 
 It is intended to be a casual Italian restaurant featuring Tuscan specialties. These dishes will be the province of Egidiana Maccioni, an excellent cook who is Sirio Maccioni's wife and the mother of Saltimbanco's owners. A full-time chef will also be hired. As for when Saltimbanco will open, the elder Mr. Maccioni said the designer, Adam Tihany, promised May. "But I think September," Mr. Maccioni said.
 
Poiret Closes
 Poiret, a French bistro that opened in 1987 at 474 Columbus Avenue (near 83d Street), has closed. Michael Weinstein, the president of Ark Restaurants, which owned Poiret, said business had dropped off since 1991. In the bistro's place, the company has installed a wholesale bakery that has yet to be named.
"It made no economic sense for us to keep buying bread and pastries for our restaurants," Mr. Weinstein said. The bakery begins selling retail next month, with tables sharing the space with a French oven.
Did the timing of the Poiret closing have anything to do with Ark's purchase of Lutece? "Not at all," Mr. Weinstein said. "We've had those ovens on order for four months. And as a matter of fact, now that we have Andre Soltner and Eberhard Mueller in our organization, it's a shame we haven't kept Poiret going so they can help us."
 
Return of Gaslight Club
 Today, after a 12-year absence, the Gaslight Club is reopening. It is taking over some of the space occupied by La Mere Poularde, the grandiose and troubled French restaurant at 109 East 56th Street. Jerry Hurych Jr., the president of the new Gaslight Club, belonged to the old one and decided to revive it, he said, because former members "yearned for a return to those great years of exquisite food, elegant service."
La Mere Poularde, now in Chapter 11, will continue as a restaurant in its main dining room and will cater the food for the club. The Gaslight Club will be open to the public for lunch Monday through Friday, and for dinner Monday through Saturday, with a continental menu.
 
Open for Thanksgiving
 This year a number of restaurants that have been closed for Thanksgiving in the past will be open.
"If you are going to own a restaurant called Home, I guess you have to be open for the holiday," said David Page, the owner and chef at Home, 20 Cornelia Street (near Bleecker Street); (212) 243-9579. The restaurant will be serving dinner from noon to 10 P.M. The four-course dinner featuring various birds is $35, or $50 including wine. Tax and gratuities are extra.
The Gotham Bar and Grill, 12 East 12th Street, (212) 620-4020, will be serving a four-course, prix fixe dinner, $58 ($30 for children 12 and under) plus tax, beverages and 18 percent service charge, from 2 P.M. to 9 P.M. Matthew's, 1030 Third Avenue (61st Street), (212) 838-4343, will serve a $40 three-course dinner from noon to 8 P.M. The price does not include beverages, tax or gratuities.
A copious Italian Thanksgiving dinner is planned at Fresco, 34 East 52d Street; (212) 935-3434. The four-course dinner, which begins with the restaurant's excellent pizza, is $45 ($25 for children under 12), beverages, tax and tips additional. It will be served from 1 to 8 P.M.
Thanksgiving dinner is a tradition at Gage & Tollner, 372 Fulton Street, in downtown Brooklyn, but this year Edna Lewis, the former executive chef, who is now 78, will return to cook for the holiday season. Her Southern-style Thanksgiving dinners, $29.95 for adults and $15.95 for children under 12, will be served from noon to 9 P.M. For reservations: (718) 875-5181.

HEADLINE: America Can't Afford More Huddled Masses

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Indecent Proposition in California" (editorial, Oct. 25) would have had a shred of credibility if you had any record in recognizing the negative impact immigration is having on cities and states.
In an era of sharp cutbacks in government services, and when entitlement programs soak up ever greater portions of government budgets, the net burden of high levels of immigration can no longer be supported. The sentiments of Emma Lazarus's anthem -- to send us your huddled masses -- are simply no longer economically possible or desirable.
American incomes have been stagnant for the last 20 years. The taxpaying population is in revolt and any new taxes to support transfer payments and new social programs are not politically feasible. The impact of population growth on cities and states is demonstrable.
California estimates that the net cost of illegal immigration to the state's taxpayers is more than $3.5 billion. In New York City, the school population has grown by more than 20 percent in the last three years, a phenomenon that is almost entirely immigration-driven.
While immigrants do contribute to the economy, their net impact is negative, especially if they cannot enter the more skilled professions. As welfare reform becomes more urgent, the competition and friction between illegal immigrants and citizens who must integrate into the work force at lower skill levels will become more intense.
The country can no longer support the present legal immigration of 700,000 people annually, let alone illegal immigration levels that push total annual immigration into the millions. Quality of life and environmental and economic realities dictate that even our current population of 260 million consumes too much of the earth's limited resources.
A halt to illegal immigration and a reduction of legal immigration are urgently needed. If both can be accomplished, the natural birth rate of the United States will eventually reverse our population to more sustainable levels.
You place misty-eyed ideology before hard reality in attacking California's Proposition 187. Some of its provisions may be unconstitutional, but its real import is that it is placing the question of out-of-control immigration policy squarely in the center of public discourse where it belongs.
 
JOHN V. HUMMER
New York, Oct. 26, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 273 words

HEADLINE: America Can't Afford More Huddled Masses;
Unworkable Proposal

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Indecent Proposition in California" (editorial, Oct. 25) cites many good reasons for opposing the drive to bar illegal aliens from public services. But your critique, focused like most others on policy issues, ignores the basic point that this whole discriminatory proposal is unrealistic, and should be rejected as unworkable. 
 It would not work because the administrators of hospitals, schools and other social service agencies lack the means to identify specifically who is "illegal" among all their clients.
Most of the suspected illegals can present legitimate-residence "documents" of some kind, which they have borrowed from friends or bought from counterfeiters. The social administrators have to accept these at face value -- just like the business employers who are hiring illegal workers nominally proscribed under the 1986 immigration law.
To be sure, if we had a system of formal and secure identification cards -- including signature, photograph, fingerprints, Social Security number and holographs as a kind of enlarged Social Security card -- the illegals could be sorted out, and indeed quickly deported whenever they surfaced.
Furthermore, few would try to cross the border, or overstay a visa, in the face of such a control.
But the American public at present seems too worried about some supposed "invasion of privacy," and about the $2 billion to $3 billion cost of ID cards, to adopt such a system that would really regulate immigration in a comprehensive way.
 
EDWIN P. REUBENS
New York, Oct. 26, 1994
The writer is a professor emeritus of economics at City College, CUNY.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Cheap and Chic in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By RUTH REICHL 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
RIOTS, fires, earthquakes, recession. This city has been pretty badly battered in the last couple of years. Faced with the end of the halcyon 1980's, local restaurateurs went around moaning, lamenting the big-money days and wondering if the good times would ever come back. But as catastrophe followed catastrophe something remarkable happened here: The most successful restaurateurs stopped looking backward and started facing reality. If people were reluctant to spend money, they would simply charge less. And do it with style.
This change of attitude has created a virtual restaurant revolution. Many of the old favorites march on, but some have closed to be replaced by new and less expensive places. 
 The Bistro Garden, a venerable Beverly Hills institution, shut its elegant doors and was reincarnated as a fast-food souffle joint a couple of miles down the road in the Century City Marketplace. One of the city's most famous chefs, Michel Richard, turned part of his upscale Citrus into an earthy, affordable bistro. When you reserve a table, you have to specify in which part of the restaurant you want to be seated. And two other chefs, Wolfgang Puck and Celestino Drago, are busy opening inexpensive spinoffs of their big-deal restaurants.
But the most interesting new restaurants in Los Angeles are those that have closed only to reopen in new incarnations. They look the same. They taste the same. But the names are new, the menus are new and, most important, the prices are new. To a person accustomed to paying New York City prices, in fact, the numbers printed on these menus look like mistakes.
The new food in Los Angeles is more than merely a bargain; it also has a new spirit. In the face of the recession, food has become fun. It has silly names like "Tra La La" and "Whatcha Whatcha Want." It has outrageous combinations like scallop, apple and spinach salad with bacon vinaigrette. And it has colors that vibrate off the plate. When a dish of bright green spinach risotto framed by intense red beet risotto arrives at the table, you know you're in Los Angeles.
Here is a look at some of the restaurants that are setting the new Los Angeles style. Each has opened in the last year.
 
 
The Best Bargain

"Pasta for $6.50? How does he do it?" people ask as they wander into this big, elegant room, sink into the comfortable chairs and look at the thick cloths and beautiful dishes that cover the tables at Alto Palato. "He" is Mauro Vincenti, owner of the fabulously expensive Rex, which occupies a landmark Art Deco building downtown, and former owner of Pazzia, which once occupied this space.
It's a good question. Who else could offer a $6.50 plate of pasta like his spaghetti alla sorrentina? It is a bowl of beautifully chewy strands of al dente spaghetti topped with a bright green zucchini sauce. The flavors are understated and delicious with the true taste of Italy. All the food here has it, from pappardelle al ragu ($8) to a remarkable veal stew in red wine with grilled polenta ($12). There is even a grilled rib of beef for two with roasted potatoes and grilled tomatoes at $11.50 a person. The thin-crusted pizzas are superb and inventive, the gelato is a dream and nowhere in Los Angeles can you get a better cup of espresso. Even the service is special.
How does he do it?
 
ALTO PALATO, 755 North La Cienega Boulevard; (310) 657-9271; entrees, $11.50 to $17.
 
 
The Most Fun
 Fred Eric is the bad boy of Los Angeles chefs. He trained with Joachim Splichal (Patina, Pinot, the long-lamented Max au Triangle), but then went on to create some of the city's silliest food at Flaming Colossus, a club, and the Olive, a record-industry hangout known for its attitude, noise and outrageous food. Having his own restaurant, Vida, has not slowed Mr. Eric down one bit. Just reading the menu is an indication that you are in for a wild ride.
Here is where you will find "Tra La La," which turns out to be a sort of salad of crisp artichoke hearts filled with goat cheese with a basil salsa. "Whatcha Whatcha Want" has been lamentably retired from the fall menu; it was a simple plate of capellini in a chunky tomato and grilled vegetable stew. But the puns roll on: "Ty Cobb" is "crispy duck on a warm spinach salad with the traditional toppings of Cobb salad made in Thailand" and it is terrific.
So is the "Okra Winfrey Creole gumbo." Smokey the fish is, despite its name, a rather complicated smoked bass in various sauces. What's "New Yorkshire"? Steak, potatoes and Yorkshire pudding, of course.
There's an impressive and inexpensive wine list and a big buzz in the room. Vida has become a hangout for Hollywood's youngest and hippest producers, who appreciate the puns, the experimental architecture and the affordable food. This may be Los Angeles's unstuffiest restaurant. Not bad for a place in the staid Los Feliz district.
 
VIDA, 1930 Hillhurst Avenue; (213) 660-4446; entrees, $12 to $17.
 
 
Cheap Chic
 In the early 80's Michael Roberts helped define Los Angeles style, continually moving the border of what was possible a little farther toward the edge. As chef and owner of Trumps he was fearless, putting caviar onto fried plantains and turning tostadas into dessert.
Now, he has gone into partnership with Kevin Costner and moved to Pasadena. Their sprawling Twin Palms has the air of a slightly decaying Southern country club, all peeling white paint verandas and lazy ceiling fans. It is as gorgeous as a spread in an architecture magazine: you want to get your suitcase and move right in. It certainly doesn't look like a place that sells $3.50 appetizers and cassoulet for $9.75.
Mr. Roberts does not seem to have lost his sense of humor -- he is the architect of that scallop, apple and spinach salad with bacon vinaigrette. But most of the food on the huge menu is more familiar. There are pizzas and burgers and sandwiches and stews. The prices are reasonable: the rotisserie chicken with roasted garlic, wilted escarole and gratin potatoes is a hefty plate for $9.50.
To begin there are terrific crisp artichokes served with deep-fried caper berries and olives and sprinkled with cheese. But the best appetizer is a rich brandade of salt cod and mashed potatoes, topped with crisp slices of toast, generous enough to make a meal and so delicious it is easy to see why the $3.75 plate is so popular. "I sell more salt cod than anybody on the West Coast," Mr. Roberts says. "These days people in Los Angeles have a real sense of adventure."
 
TWIN PALMS, 101 West Green Street, Pasadena; (818) 577-2567; entrees, $7.25 to $15.50.
 
 
A Healthy Bargain
 Are you ready for fat-free food? Los Angeles is. People have been lining up to eat at Gratis since the day the restaurant and takeout store opened in the Brentwood section of the city. There is usually a wait to pick up food, and customers are given silent beepers that vibrate when their order is ready.
The menu is completely vegetarian; some of the food is actually edible. The soft tacos with black beans, chili and cilantro-lime dressing are an awesome amount of food that is good enough to elevate eating beyond mere guiltlessness. But the pizza was gummy and the veggie cheese burger was one of the worst things I have ever tried to swallow. As for potato salad, there is probably a way to make a fat-free version, but Gratis has yet to discover it.
The most famous dish at Gratis, I am told, is the triple-layered chocolate cake. (The restaurant swears it, too, is fat-free.) And you know what? It's pretty good. Good enough to warrant picking up one of those beepers.
 
GRATIS, 11658 San Vicente Boulevard; (310) 571-2345; entrees, $4.50 to $7.95.
 
 
Most Colorful
 If you can't get reservations at Spago or Chinois on Main, don't despair: Wolfgang Puck Cafe doesn't take reservations. You may have to wait, but you won't have to suffer the humiliation of reserving a table and then cooling your heels while celebrities waltz right in. Here it is strictly first come, first served.
Open just a few weeks, the cafe that America's most famous chef named for himself is a rainbow of tiles, ceramics, paints and patterns layered in dizzying, dazzling profusion. It is a room in which it is almost impossible to feel depressed.
The food, fast versions of hits from Puck's other restaurants, has no trouble competing with the setting; it is the most colorful food I have ever seen.
A bright orange bowl of butternut squash soup is swirled with a puree of red peppers. Salmon is a slab of pink on a bed of grilled vegetables so gorgeous it practically begs you to eat it. Linguine with scallops and spicy Chinese black-bean sauce has multicolored peppers sprinkled through the dish. Even meatloaf, which comes wrapped in bacon and perched on an enormous pile of mashed potatoes, is framed by bright, tiny tomatoes.
The most expensive item on the menu is the smoked salmon pizza ($14.50), with cream cheese, chives and slices of smoked fish. This "Jewish Pizza" is what Mr. Puck sends out to his special customers at Spago, where it has never been on the menu and is usually crowned with caviar.
 
WOLFGANG PUCK CAFE, 1323 Montana Avenue, Santa Monica; (310) 393-0290; entrees, $9.50 to $12.50.
 
 
Italy, in Technicolor
 "Why cook?" asks the takeout menu at Il Pastaio in Beverly Hills. At these prices it is not a bad question.
Celestino Drago runs the hugely successful Drago in Santa Monica. But his newest restaurant serves only salads, antipasti, pastas and risotto, and no dish on the menu costs more than $12; few exceed $10.
In the window of the simple room a woman stands making pasta. She works quickly, deftly folding a mixture of lobster and zucchini into mezzelune and stuffing tortelloni with a pumpkin mush. She turns out green and white tagliolini for the Sicilian pesto, which is made with nuts and tomatoes. Ribbons of black and white pasta run through her fingers; after they are dried they will be tossed with tiny, sweet clams and bright green leaves of arugula.
This is also the home of the world's most colorful risotto. The green is so green, the red so red, it is hard to believe that these colors exist in nature. "I can never resist this spinach and pea risotto," said a woman at the next table, scooping up a forkful of bright green. Who can blame her?
 
IL PASTAIO, 400 North Cannon, Drive, Beverly Hills; (310) 205-5440; entrees, $7.50 to $12.
 
 
Most Exciting
 John Sedlar practically invented nouvelle Southwest cuisine when he opened the restaurant St. Estephe, and blended his New Mexican roots with his classic French training. He expanded the repertory with his next restaurant, Bikini, allowing his cooking to resonate with Italian, Asian and South American influences. Alas, the restaurant was too expensive and too experimental, and after it was damaged by the earthquake, Mr. Sedlar shut it down.
He has just reopened the sleek, modern room as Abiquiu. The food, which is much more affordable, is rooted in New Mexico but still takes fliers into foreign territory. His chile relleno Bangkok, for instance, is filled with Thai shrimp and topped with a spicy peanut sauce.
But the best dishes are the ones that simply refine Southwestern cuisine. Nobody makes a better tamale than Mr. Sedlar, whose Santo Pasqual is filled with chicken and topped with a clear, sharp pumpkin-seed and chile sauce. His tuna zozobra is rubbed with sharp spices and served on bright green-chile mashed potatoes. On the simpler side, trout is served with bacon, eggs and skillet hashed browns.
There are lots of gorgeous desserts, including an exotic banana split. But the best is the Zuni corn souffle with passion-fruit cream. A treat at $6.
 
ABIQUIU, 1413 Fifth Street, Santa Monica; (310) 395-8611; entrees, $12 to $18.
 
 
La La Land
 Eclipse is like a joke about Los Angeles come to life. In the front of the crowded room three bodyguards circle nervously, talking into their watches and fiddling with their earpieces. The owner, Bernard Erpicum, trimmed down and more nervous-looking since his days as the all-powerful maitre d'hotel at Spago, confides that they are guarding the oil and real estate mogul Marvin Davis.
And there he is, solid as a tank, sitting at the front table. It is clearly the best seat in the house. As soon as the Davis party departs, Steve Martin et al. take their place.
With a Spago-trained chef, a Spago-trained owner and a site that was once the industry hangout Morton's (which has moved to larger quarters across the street), Eclipse came into the game with quite an edge. At the moment it is incredibly hot; people wait endlessly for one of the tables in the crowded dining room or on the (less desirable) patio.
The house specialty is whole fish baked in the wood-burning oven. The menu even offers surf and turf. The chef, Serge Falesitch, is not breaking any new ground here, but it is clear that few people come for the food. The question is this: With entrees priced from $17 to $29.50, will Eclipse survive in the lean new Los Angeles world of restaurants?
 
ECLIPSE, 8800 Melrose Avenue; West Hollywood; (310) 724-5959.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Living Section last Wednesday about low-price restaurants in the Los Angeles area referred incorrectly to the Bistro Garden in Beverly Hills. It remains open.

HEADLINE: Five Years Later: Eastern Europe, Post-Communism -- A special report.;
East Europe Still Choking on Air of the Past

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
One place to measure the disheveled state of Eastern Europe's environment these days is a great electronic scoreboard in Usti nad Labem, a Czech town on a bend of the Elbe River.
New sensors are sniffing the bad breath coming off the local factories and on the scoreboard, the people of Usti can track the gases they inhale as if following an important sports event. 
 "We still get about 20 types of harmful substances," said Zdenek Cerny, a former army officer in charge of the monitors. "Suddenly half the town may get pains in the joints. Or skin problems. When these chemicals interact, it creates a kind of nerve gas."
Usti's air and its color-coded scoreboard showing the ups and downs of nine different gases is even bringing it fame. Air quality specialists from Japan, the United States and Western Europe have flocked here like tourists visiting a chamber of horrors.
"When they have just 10 percent of what we get," Mr. Cerny said, "they think they have a disaster."
The scene is repeated across Eastern Europe as new Western computers probe the haze over Budapest in Hungary or the dust and soot over Cracow in Poland and Sofia in Bulgaria. The onset of capitalism has not cleaned the region's foul air, soil or water. But its instruments are now measuring it.
The stark message of the sensors is that almost five years after the collapse of Communism, the region's environment continues to decay. Chemical works, smelters, coal mines and power plants are still infusing air and water with waste far surpassing international standards and causing severe health problems. Toxic dumps go on poisoning ground water and cities keep on spewing their raw sewage into rivers.
What's more, capitalism is bringing its own problems -- more traffic pollution, less public transportation, more plastic foam, more clashes between environmentalists and the peddlers of consumerism.
There have been some gains. Factory emissions have dropped, perversely the result of a sputtering economy in which many plants have closed or slowed production. But the enormous task of installing filters, scrubbers and treatment plants has barely begun. And energy still comes largely from highly polluting brown coal.
"Achievements?" a discouraged World Bank consultant wondered aloud. "They are few, rather fragile and very dispersed."
The main reason for this slow pace is that regional leaders insist that given the urgency of economic recovery, the environment must wait. This policy decision underscores a fundamental question facing Eastern Europe as it continues its transformation. Should anti-pollution devices, fines and taxes be further postponed in order to protect factories and jobs? Or will this bring more health and clean-up costs in the future, not only to restore the havoc of the past but also the new damage still being caused today?
"The modern notion that development and environmental protection should go together has not reached here," said Lutchezar Toshev, the head of Bulgaria's environmental group Ecoglasnost.
In theory Communism, with its strict central planning, had more power than free-wheeling capitalism to avoid or prevent damaging nature. Yet with its squandering of raw materials and energy, the economic artifice made in Moscow produced exceptional levels of pollution that maimed many of its citizens.
In the end, it was this poisoning that provided a rare platform for challenging the state when other forms of protest were not tolerated. The environmental devastation became a powerful catalyst as citizens' groups formed throughout the East, spurring broader protests before the fall of Communism. Almost inevitably, in 1989 the new leaders had to commit themselves to an urgent clean-up. And the West, looking on aghast as scientists and film crews swarmed over the badlands of Eastern Europe, praised itself for doing better and promised to help.
But progress fell far short of goals, and many questioned why much of the almost $1 billion offered by the West for environmental improvement was not disbursed.
Blame is passed around. Western experts say that environment ministers have no clout, that their staffs are inept or keep changing, and that lobbyists are inexperienced or easily discouraged.
Many Easterners say that the West dallies, is overly demanding and spends too much on experts dwelling in expensive hotels, instead of giving aid.
"Look at Kozlodui," said Radost Patera at the Bulgarian energy ministry, speaking of a nuclear plant deemed among the world's most dangerous. "Kozlodui gets more foreign visitors than our famous Rila monastery."
 
 
Regulation
Lax Rules Attract Western Plants
 A popular argument in the West is that the transition to more modern, cleaner and more efficient technology will inevitably cut pollution. Results so far have been mixed. Several nations have copied the strict environmental regulations of the West, but the main problem is enforcement.
"Inspectors are not well-trained and not motivated," said Erica Bassin, a Canadian legal researcher. "And fines are low. There is little incentive to comply."
In Hungary, for instance, eight giant Western corporations are already producing chemicals, plastics, detergents and cars, using the nation as a hub for exports to the east. Hungarians say there is no mystery about what draws these companies. A senior manager at a Hungarian chemical company called Borsodken, which has formed joint ventures with several foreign partners, said, "Foreigners come here because of cheap labor, because of lower environmental demands and the lower health and safety standards in the workplace."
Dorog in northern Hungary looks like a typical small industrial town: old stone houses and vegetable gardens coexist with dreary high-rises. But Dorog has no typical mayor in Anna David, a determined, 60-year-old pediatrician. Noting that Dorog's children had three times more asthma and bronchitis than the national rate, she blamed the local factories, and in 1988 she founded an environmental group.
In 1990, when Dorog held its first free elections since 1945, it elected her. With a private American grant, she hired a municipal environmental inspector. "You have to watch them all the time, the Hungarians and the foreigners," she says, complaining that the Richter-Gideon chemical plant, which has been acquired by Elf Aquitaine of France, so far is still not treating its waste water.
She worries more about Dorog's toxic-waste incinerator, the only one in Hungary. Built in 1985, the incinerator was bought in 1990 by SARP, a subsidiary of France's Compagnie Generale des Eaux.
"That French company thought it could do what it wanted," she says. "We fought for a year because of their pollution. We almost closed it down."
One recent day at the incinerator, on the edge of town, where the air stings like tear gas, an official conceded that the plant's carbon monoxide emissions were 50 percent higher than the norms. "We are trying to improve," he said. "We will have to change the oven."
Dr. David wants the entire incinerator to move because the prevailing winds blow its dioxin emissions right over the town.
An official of French company said: "We're in the line of fire. They should be looking at the sulfur and the carbon monoxide coming from the local coking plant or from the chimney on every house."
 
 
The Water
Famed Rivers Become Sewers
 A fitting place to gauge what happens on land is in the water, and the main barometer is the Danube, the continent's grandest waterway, fed by myriad tributaries. The river is also the main transmission belt for waste, running the gantlet of discharge from eight countries as it sweeps through Central and Eastern Europe on its way to the Black Sea.
Istvan Ijjas heads a regional study group and has been taking the Danube's pulse for several decades. Asked about changes in the past five years, he said Czech, Slovak and Hungarian tributaries were carrying smaller amounts of dangerous heavy metals because factories have slowed down or closed.
"The drop is only small," he said. "We still have all the toxic heavy metals in the Danube." The run-off from fertilizer has diminished since its price was no longer subsidized, he said, but the load of detergents heavy with phosphates is growing.
More troubling, he went on, was the Danube's rising level of bacteria and viruses. He blamed cities that have expanded sewage collection without building treatment plants. From Bratislava to the Black Sea, towns use the river as an open sewer, in the process contaminating ground water. Budapest alone, beneath its seven magnificent bridges, expels the raw waste of two million people, treating only 25 percent. In Western Europe, waste water treatment is mandated by governments.
On the northern plains, rivers like the Oder and Neisse still move heavy with waste. German engineers said that the Elbe has improved since many old East German industries were closed. But the Vistula, Poland's main artery and principal dumping ground, is still deteriorating. Polish specialists said that because of the flushing of Silesian coal mines, the Vistula is now saltier than the Baltic Sea, into which it empties. The latest survey by the World Health Organization concluded that the water drunk in much of Eastern Europe is unfit for consumption.
It also noted that the poor air and water quality contributed to the region's high rates of lung diseases like emphysema, asthma and tuberculosis, as well as hepatitis, lead contamination and low birth weight and birth defects.
 
 
Acid Rain
Where Pollution Killed the Forests
 On the high plateaus where the German, Czech and Polish borders meet and tree stumps look as if they have been ravaged by fire, foresters have been planting new and hardy seedlings. Yet few young firs are surviving. In the valleys below, a phalanx of power plants and industries driven by brown coal are still spewing sulfur and soot, as they have done for more than three decades. This region, dubbed the Black Triangle, is one of the world's biggest makers of acid rain.
These were once dense woods, but even the Soviet Army had to move its tanks and find new camouflage as the foul air killed the tree cover.
In Berlin, Michael Roder, a Government environment official, recently recalled some curious Soviet-think. Instead of dealing with the pollution, he said, planners asked East German biologists to breed trees that were smoke resistant.
"They experimented for 20 years," he said. "In the end, the sulfur always killed the trees."
Along a 350-mile stretch, foresters are now trying to restore 300,000 acres of lost trees and prevent the rest from dying. They say these mountain forests are needed to retain water and snow, which now plunge down the hillsides, causing erosion and flooding in the spring and water shortages in the summer.
Along the Erzgebirge, the mountain range that divides Germany and the Czech Republic, Czech workers are spreading calcium to balance the soil. Specialists say it has become so acid that even the aluminum trapped in the clay is released, further poisoning plant roots and groundwater.
In Poland, Andrzej Szujecki, a former forestry professor and now deputy minister of environment, says he favors natural cleansing and regeneration. "But this will take decades," he said.
While forest death so far had been worst in the southwest, he was now troubled that for the first time, trees were dying farther east, in the Beskid Mountains.
In July, when the European Commission released its report on forest damage in 35 European countries, Czech and Polish trees headed the list, with over 50 percent of conifers and deciduous trees having lost more than one-fourth of their needles or leaves.
The airborne sulfur not only kills the conifers, which normally live for a century. Doctors say the sulfur attaches to tiny soot particles that penetrate human lungs where it mixes with water to form a potent acid, damaging the tissues.
According to the International Energy Agency in Paris, recent industrial decline has reduced energy demand by about 20 to 25 percent in the region and thus diminished the dust and fumes coming off the power plants. But specialists say the noxious load in the region is still enormous.
The answer to many of the region's troubles, many agree, is to replace its filthy energy sources, but policies differ. In Germany, instructions have been clear: by 1996, the remaining coal-fired power plants in the industrial basin of former East Germany must either have devices to minimize sulfur emissions or close.
In Poland the road is far longer. American aid has helped build a sulfur treatment plant near Cracow and Dutch utility companies have donated one at Belchatow. But once operating, these scrubbers will clean only a small portion of the coal that accounts for more than half the country's fuel.
The Czechs, despite enormous and continuing controversy, aim to finish a Soviet-designed nuclear power plant at Temelin. Vladislav Bizek, deputy minister of the environment, said that in four years the country could obtain 40 percent of its energy from nuclear power instead of today's 20 percent. Today, 75 percent still comes from polluting coal and brown coal.
Physicians and planners also worry about the coal pollution people generate in their homes. In winter, when a sour fog makes East European cities look like they belong in an old black-and-white movie, much soot comes from thousands of domestic heaters, stoves and boilers. While environment ministries everywhere signaled the need for a large-scale switch to natural gas, only a few towns have started.
In any energy discussion, Western advisers hoist the banner of energy saving. Many reckon that simple measures could save between 10 to 25 percent. But achieving this is proving tough.
The European Union is financing a center in Budapest to promote energy saving. It sends manuals to industry and practical hints to customers along with the meter readers. Its television spots, wrapped in rock music, say "You pay twice" -- for energy and for repairing the environment.
Ian Brown, the Briton who heads the center, says changing people's habits is difficult because of a deeply rooted sense of entitlement.
"Energy has always been extremely cheap and people see it as a social good," he said. "People have no notion that they are part of the problem, that they can do something. They think everything is up to the Government." In reality, governments may be as much a part of the problem.
 
 
The Mindset
For Some, More Is Still Better
 How the missionaries of Western ways can run into obstacles is illustrated by the black eye that bankers recently suffered in Bulgaria. A team of specialists from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development spent almost a year on a plan to cut sulfurous brown coal fumes. Bulgaria, studies showed, could easily cut about 12 percent of its energy consumption by reducing waste in industry and power plants. The London-based bank, which uses Western government funds for projects in the former Eastern bloc, was ready to act.
In July, a team from the bank, armed with the energy savings plan and a loan, called on Nikita Shervashidze, the Minister of Energy in Sofia. But the minister, indignant, said he would never sign such a plan, a team member recounted. He said Bulgaria needed more energy, not less. He wanted new transmission lines and a new power plant. The bank, in consternation, sent more envoys. In the end the team had to leave, a year's work lost.
"That's the old-style thinking," the team member said, furious.
At the minister's office, an assistant explained: "Mr. Shervashidze wants to sell more electricity so the utilities can make money. He wants to keep the coal mines open. We have 32,000 miners and the unions are very strong."
 
 
The Options
Is East Europe Losing a Chance?
 The assumption among the Western bankers and business executives who are helping to shape the region's economic transformation is that the former East bloc should mimic the West. Most powers-that-be in the region agree, judging by their eagerness to seek membership in of the European Union.
But many environmentalists -- scientists and economists among them -- question the race to simply catch up with the West and copy everything it has to offer. Already they worry that their culture and traditions are being swept aside by the new ideology of consumerism.
"We have a lot of discussions about whether it is possible to avoid the Western model of overconsumption, whether we can avoid its excesses," said Vladislav Bizek, the Czech deputy minister of the environment. "We should at least get our consumers into good habits before they pick up the bad ones."
Some Eastern Europeans even believe in a "third way" between Communism and capitalism. Specifically, they argue that the transition in Eastern Europe provides an opportunity to do things differently. For example, they say that Governments should now decide to build more railroads and fewer roads and license only products that can be recycled, contain the least chemicals or are otherwise the least environmentally harmful.
They argue that the governments must act quickly because it is now that people are eager to buy new cars, photocopiers, washing machines and refrigerators. Once factories are churning them out to meet expanding demand, it will be far more difficult to impose new ecological standards.
So far, however, this debate is at best theoretical. "The market is winning," said Zsuzsa Foltanyi, a Hungarian biochemist and coordinator of The Energy Club, a collective of environment groups. "There seems no room for laws that can shape the behavior of the producer or the consumer. Anything goes."
In Prague, which brims with tourists, environmentalists complained of the garbage, the fancy new packaging, cans, plastics, foils and plastic foam that have produced a new kind of waste that may take a lifetime to decompose. The old Communist recycling systems for bottles, metals and paper have collapsed almost everywhere.
Andras Lukacs, a geophysicist who heads the Clean Air lobby in Budapest is among those deploring the arrival of the West's car culture. In Hungary and Poland, freedom has brought 50 percent more cars, fulfilling longtime dreams of their owners but also clogging up the narrow streets, blowing leaded exhaust and thickening the haze.
Mr. Lukacs said that in the cities, auto emissions, including lead and nitrogen oxides, are so bad that they are offsetting improvements gained by the drop in industrial pollution. Use of unleaded gas is not mandatory and despite pressure from environmentalists, even new cars are not required to have catalytic converters.
The rush for the automobile is already eroding the vast network of trains, trams and buses, one of Communism's positive legacies. "It's one of our biggest frustrations," said Mr. Lukacs. "In every city the number of cars is growing and public transport is being reduced." In Budapest trams and buses carried 1.9 million passengers in 1989 but fewer than 1.5 million in 1993. In east Berlin, a tram ticket today costs 14 times what it did under Communism. Berlin had 300,000 cars in 1989. Today it has more than half a million.
Green parties complain that as the East bloc turns its new leaf, Western donors and Eastern decision makers alike ignore well-known ways to recover like introducing renewable solar or wind energy or using less abrasive chemicals in agriculture.
Hartwig Berger, spokesman of the Green Party in Berlin, was among the pessimists. "There was a chance for fundamental change in the East, a chance for a new beginning," he said, "but so far it has been squandered."
 
Five Years Later
 Further reporting on Eastern Europe after communism will examine the lessons learned from the outbreak of ethnic violence that engulfed the Balkans. Previous articles explored the successes and pitfalls of introducing jcapitalism to countries long accustomed to state-run economies, and the challenge of forging a united Germany after years of enforced political and economic servitude in the east.

LENGTH: 1232 words

HEADLINE: Shades of the Go-Go 80's: Takeovers in a Comeback

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The deals are not as big, the fees are not as fat and the personalities are not as flamboyant. Still, corporate takeovers are back.
With two months to go until the end of the year, 1994 is on track to be the second-biggest year for mergers and acquisitions in history. As of Oct. 31, deals valued at $284.4 billion were announced, according to the Securities Data Company, a Wall Street research firm. That is just shy of the $292.9 billion announced in all of 1989. The record is $335.8 billion in 1988. 
 Having spent the early 1990's increasing profits by cutting costs, corporations are now looking to increase their revenues. And expansion by acquisition appears to many to be the easiest way to do it.
"People are saying: To grow my business I need to consolidate, I need more clout, I need to invest in a different region, I need a certain technology or I need a certain program skill," said Mike Overlock, who headed the mergers and acquisitions department of Goldman, Sachs & Company in the 1980's and is currently co-head of the firm's investment banking department. "And they are prepared to invest in that."
The Quaker Oats Company was the latest to jump on the merger bandwagon, announcing yesterday that it was acquiring the Snapple Beverage Corporation of East Meadow, L.I., for $1.7 billion, a deal that would form the third-largest United States soft-drink concern. [Page D1.]
The acquisition is one of several takeovers in the food industry this year, including the purchase of Borden Inc. by the investment firm Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company. But other industries have been even more active. The telecommunications, health care and pharmaceuticals industries have been the most active, while the consolidation of the military and aerospace industries has grabbed some of the biggest headlines.
In addition, the hostile takeover, which seemed to have disappeared along with the junk bond pioneer Michael R. Milken, has also returned. Nearly 8 percent of the takeovers this year have been either hostile or unsolicited, compared with 1 percent to 3 percent in the early 1990's.
But unlike the merger activity of a decade ago, which was dominated by rapacious and in many cases previously unknown raiders puffed up by Mr. Milken's high-risk financing, the current spree is dominated by large corporations seeking strategic alliances.
"What you see today are sophisticated companies paying a premium to acquire other companies, but having a rationale," Mr. Overlock said.
The rationale may be for a company to position itself to exploit the advent of a new technology, as when U S West Inc. and Airtouch Communications Inc. merged their cellular phone businesses. Or it could be an effort to gain economies of scale as the landscape shifts in industries like health care, pharmaceuticals and military contracting. The Northrop Corporation did this when it bought the Grumman Corporation.
Many of the buyers, including Sandoz A.G., Roche Holdings and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., are foreign companies taking advantage of the weak dollar to make their expansions in the United States more affordable.
Whether the activity will lead to heavy job losses and layoffs varies with each deal. In a case where a company is expanding its empire, the need for layoffs may be minimal. But when two industry giants merge, many of the advantages of the deal come from eliminating the overlaps between the two companies.
For example, since completing their merger earlier this year, Grumman and Northrop have announced that the combined company will shed more than 9,000 jobs. The combination of Paine Webber Group Inc. and Kidder, Peabody & Company will result in the elimination of perhaps more than 2,000 jobs.
"Given that companies in the last several years have been downsizing without making acquisitions, it's very hard to know" about the extent of job losses, said Steven N. Kaplan, a professor of finance at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business. "I wouldn't necessarily point to acquisitions as an evil in terms of jobs, given what companies have been doing on their own."
Many companies have become so acquisitive that they have initiated takeovers, even when their targets were unwilling. Earlier this year, the General Electric Company began a hostile offer for the Kemper Corporation, which turned out to be unsuccessful when the Conseco Corporation made a higher bid. (Yesterday, Conseco scaled back its $3.25 billion offer and asked Kemper to accept $2.96 billion -- about the same as the G.E. offer.) In August the American Home Products Corporation began a successful unsolicited bid for the American Cyanamid Company.
"You have a lot of Fortune 100 to 500 companies, who even in the 80's weren't inclined to think about taking unilateral action, now thinking that tactically this is a pretty good time," said J. Tomilson Hill, one of the biggest participants in takeovers in the 1980's who is now a general partner at the Blackstone Group, which specializes in defending against hostile takeovers.
One reason is that the will to fight off a hostile bidder with exotic anti-takeover defenses has declined. Because stock prices are relatively high, many chief executives believe that their companies are reasonably valued and any premiums over their companies' current stock prices appear attractive.
In addition, many of the hostile deals begun this year have involved companies that were already engaged in merger or takeover negotiations. That was the case when Northrop successfully outbid the Martin Marietta Corporation for Grumman, and with the Union Pacific Corporation's current attempt to outbid Burlington Northern Inc. for the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation.
When a company is already a takeover target, initiating a hostile takeover seems less ruthless than the predatory offers made during the 1980's, when as much as 25 percent of all deals were hostile.
"What was amazing about the 80's was the depth and breadth of the hostile pressure," Professor Kaplan of the University of Chicago said. "There is no comparison this time."
One reason is the lack of inexpensive financing. What fueled the efforts of corporate raiders like Victor Posner and Robert Campeau were junk bonds and bank loans.
Now, the junk bond market will not support such deals. Banks are increasingly willing to finance takeovers, fueling the increase in hostile deals, which require cash offers, but they are more careful to loan money to established enterprises.
"Bank financing is probably more readily available than it has been in the last three or four years," said David C. Wittig, the co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Salomon Brothers.
Unfortunately for Salomon, which led the securities industry in takeover work during the first nine months of this year, the fees earned from mergers and acquisitions are about half what they were in the boom years of the 1980's. Some analysts believe that is because Wall Street firms bid down prices in order to get work when takeover activity was slow during the early 1990's.
But Mr. Wittig said investment banks earned fat fees in the 1980's because they were often offering services that commanded lucrative compensation, like floating junk bonds and providing bridge loans.
"The advisory portion of the fees are basically unchanged over the last five years," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE OVERVIEW;
VOTERS DISGUSTED WITH POLITICIANS AS ELECTION NEARS

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
Heading into Tuesday's election, voters are profoundly alienated from their elected representatives and from the political process and confess to a deepening powerlessness and pessimism over the future of the nation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Disgust with Congress is near the recorded high, and more than 60 percent of those polled were unable to name an elected official they admired. 
 The public has not appeared so disconsolate since 1979, when the nation was gripped by economic stagnation and Americans were taken hostage in Iran. Now people say they are frustrated and cynical and feel that life has veered out of control.
"I don't feel the people of this country have any control over what's going on, even if we voted-in the person we wanted," said Debra Flesher, a 35-year-old mother of four in Greenfield, Ind.
"The country is so big and there are so many issues and everyone has a different point of view," she added. "It's hard to have a safe neighborhood anymore. Even the media doesn't have control because bad is what sells. Like the Simpson case -- that's what people want to see."
Mrs. Flesher was one of the respondents who agreed to a follow-up interview after taking part in the nationwide telephone poll of 1,429 adults, taken Oct. 29 through Nov. 1. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Asked about "the way things are going in the United States," 43 percent said they expect things to be worse five years from now. And most people fear that the next generation will be worse off than they are.
In the poll, crime emerged as a stark symbol of fear and powerlessness. Twenty-three percent of those surveyed identified crime as "the most important problem facing this country today." Economic concerns ranked second, with 18 percent calling them the nation's most pressing problem. Health care, which ranked second in September, has plunged to fifth place, tied with drugs.
Other sources of anxiety that emerged include a fear by a quarter of Americans that some close relative will lose his job in the next year, and a concern by 4 of 10 about their safety, saying there is an area within a mile of their homes where they would be afraid to walk at night.
Most voters hold fickle if not contradictory notions about Congress. But their overall regard for the institution continues to plummet, with the number who disapprove up 10 percentage points since September.
Three-fourths of the people surveyed disapproved of the job Congress is doing, just about the same level as disapproved in July 1992, when disgust with Congress peaked at news of the House bank scandal. Only 20 percent said they approved of the job Congress was doing.
Voters still gave their own representatives a break, compared with the rest of Congress, but anger at their elected officials is mounting.
The last two months of campaigning have clearly soured the electorate; the number of those who disapprove of their own representatives has doubled to 33 percent since September. At no time since The Times and CBS News started asking this question in 1977 have voters registered greater complaints about their own representatives.
Fifty-six percent approve of their elected officials, but only about a third think their own representatives deserve re-election. When asked about Congress as a whole, only 12 percent think most members of Congress deserve re-election, while 82 percent want Congress to start from scratch with all new people. Yet more than half said that even if all new people were elected, the Government would not work any better.
Joseph Hivko, 74, a retired printer in Chicago, holds some of these seemingly contrary views. His representative is Dan Rostenkowski, the former chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, who was indicted last summer on several charges of corruption. Mr. Hivko said he thought that the entire Congress should be replaced with "young blood," but he wants to keep Mr. Rostenkowski.
"He's doing a lot for Chicago, a lot of breaks through the Government," Mr. Hivko said.
Three-fourths of respondents could not name their own representatives in Congress. And by a margin of 2 to 1, they could not name one public official they admired.
"I can't think of anybody who has gone into office and is doing what they had committed to doing," said Pat Butler, 36, a sales representative in Fayetteville, Ga. "They find out once they get in that they can't do that much.
"Most of the politicians are in office too long and they are very close with the lobbyists and special-interest groups, and they get away from the people," she added, volunteering, like many of those interviewed, that she strongly supports term limits.
Two-thirds of all Americans said they felt as if they did not have much of a say in what the Government did. This is the highest level of helplessness measured since The Times and CBS News began asking this question in 1990. Nearly three-quarters said most members of Congress did not understand their needs.
"They're not the same type of day-to-day people as you or me," said Tim Fithian, 25, a night warehouse worker in Hayward, Calif. "They're in a completely different world. They aren't someone you would want to socialize with."
In a year when many politicians, including President Clinton, have blamed their political woes on the press, most of those surveyed said they had at least some confidence in the news they get, whether from television, radio or newspapers. But most people said they thought the media "gets in the way" of solving the country's problems and makes things appear worse than they are.
By a margin of nearly 3 to 1, those surveyed said they usually get most of their news from television and about half said they tune into political talk shows on television or radio sometimes or frequently. But the poll showed no relationship between voters' sources of news and their level of cynicism, pessimism or alienation from the political process.
Instead, two-thirds of those surveyed said that if Americans were unhappy with their elected officials, they "have themselves to blame."
By a margin of 5 percentage points, registered voters said they expected to vote more Republican than Democratic this year. This is statistically insignificant, given the poll's margin of sampling error and because such a general question cannot accurately predict results of local races. But there are other indications that Republicans may hold some advantages going into Tuesday's balloting.
Fifty-four percent of all Americans view the Republican Party favorably, while only 44 percent view the Democrats favorably. In another measure of voter alienation, those surveyed were equally divided between those who said the Democrats favored the rich and those who said the Democrats favored the middle class or the poor.
By a 2-to-1 margin, people believe that Government should be less involved in solving national problems, which is generally the Republican approach. But 57 percent think the country needs a new political party.
In bad news for the Republicans, 71 percent of voters have never heard of their much-promoted "Contract With America," the party's main blueprint for what it wants to accomplish in the next session of Congress, should it take control.
The poll contains mixed news for President Clinton, whose approval rating among all Americans stands at 43 percent, with 48 percent disapproving.
His recent foreign policy ventures have earned him higher praise than he has heard in some time.
"I'm glad he didn't hesitate on Iraq," said Tom Travers, 50, who served in the Air Force and was a documents-control worker in Aurora, Colo., until his recent layoff. "And on Haiti, he did the right thing. If people in these countries want democracy, we should help them accomplish that."
Yet the public remains largely "uneasy" over Mr. Clinton's "ability to deal wisely with a difficult international crisis," and voters still do not give him credit for improving the economy, with 56 percent disapproving of his handling of the economy while nearly that same number think the economy is performing well.
More people think, wrongly, that his budget actually raised the deficit than think he reduced the deficit. In the fiscal year that ended in September 1992, the deficit was at a high of $290.4 billion. In the fiscal year that ended in September 1994, the deficit had fallen to $203.4 billion. Mr. Clinton took office in January 1993.
Asked how she felt about the deficit, Shirley Ranolls, 54, of Stark, La., said she was vastly more concerned about "how to raise these kids right and keep them out of trouble.
"The whole world is getting worse and worse," she added. "My son has a good job, but it's hard for him to make it. The more he makes, the more it takes. He can't seem to get ahead."
 
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday through Tuesday with 1,429 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. Of these, 1,156 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for blacks, it is plus or minus eight percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
Corporate takeovers are back, but without some of the flash and excess of the 1980's. This year is likely to be the second biggest for mergers and acquisitions, after $335.8 billion in 1988. Companies that slashed costs in the early 1990's are now looking to increase their revenue, and acquisition is an easy way to do it. [Page A1.]
 
Manufacturers are beginning to raise prices as the recovery picks up speed, the Federal Reserve said in its September survey of regional economies, known as the beige book. [D1.] 

In a job discrimination case, Supreme Court Justices signaled their disapproval of an employer's defense that an employee deserved dismissal for other reasons. [A22.]
 
Seven food industry groups sued to stop the Agriculture Department from testing ground beef for bacteria. [A23.]
 
Banks put up $100 million to help New York City co-ops. [B3.]
 
Markets
 
The Clinton Administration moved to shore up the dollar, buying a billion or so dollars on the world's currency markets. Though the effort succeeded in reviving the dollar, there were signs that the weakness of the dollar would continue. [D1.]
 
Stock prices fell for a third day. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 26.24 points, and the S.& P. 500 declined 1.91 points. [D10.]
 
Treasury prices slid, dragged down by the falling dollar and fears of inflation prompted by the Fed's beige book report. [D20.]
 
Coffee prices plunged. Sugar and crude oil prices rose. [D21.]
 
Companies
 
Quaker Oats agreed to buy Snapple Beverage for $1.7 billion. A merger would create the third-largest nonalcoholic beverage marketer in North America. [D1.]Snapple, once a Wall Street favorite, has soured for many. The proposed takeover confirms the riskiness of a stock that has soared on expectations that rapid growth can continue. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
 
Pepsico is spending $50 million to jazz up Doritos, even though the chips are country's biggest-selling snack food. [D1.]
 
Steven Hoffenberg, the New York financier, agreed to settle the two most significant civil fraud suits against him. [D1.]
 
Conseco reduced its offer for Kemper to $2.96 billion -- about the same as an earlier bid by General Electric. [D5.]
 
First Data agreed to buy Card Establishment Services for $500 million in stock and the assumption of $180 million of debt. [D5.]
 
A Federal judge allowed a lawsuit against Bausch & Lomb to proceed as a class action. The ruling failed to faze investors. [D5.]
 
Trader Horn, an electronics chain, filed for bankruptcy. [D5.]
 
Unions at San Francisco's two daily newspapers went on strike, halting production and delivery. [B12.]
 
International
 
Banca Commerciale Italiana offered $1.15 billion for control of Banco Ambrosiano Veneto. [D2.]
 
Panama's new Government plans to sell stakes in state-run industries, reduce import tariffs and revise labor laws. [A7.]
 
Today's Columns
 
Why isn't an improved economy helping Clinton's popularity? Other issues may be obscuring the good news. And some argue an expansion's benefits have been undermined by the sense that the workplace is harsher. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
Miller Lite tries its fourth campaign in three years. The commercials portray viewers unexpectedly finding themselves transported inside their TV sets. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D23.]

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Stumps for Candidates But Watches Where He Goes

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 2

 BODY:
To hear his advisers tell it, this is Bill Clinton's mission as he begins his final cross-country charge of the fall campaign: define the choices, rally the faithful, fill the coffers and help those Democrats who want to be helped.
But these are his instructions: never, never, never stray south of the Mason-Dixon line. 
 With six days to go before the election, Mr. Clinton is spending his evenings in halls like the Rhode Island Convention Center here on behalf of candidates like Myrth York, the Democrat who hopes to be the state's next governor. By week's end, he will have carried his exhortations to New York, Iowa, Minnesota, California, Michigan, Delaware and Washington.
But in Tennessee, Oklahoma, Florida and Texas, where the Democrats are facing some of their toughest Senate and statehouse races, Mr. Clinton will nowhere be seen. Even as the White House maintained today that his resurgent popularity had given the party new momentum, his itinerary reflected a view that there remained much of the country where Democrats were better off if the man from Arkansas stayed at arm's length.
"We go where we're invited," a senior White House official said today with a shrug. With voter antipathy toward Mr. Clinton still running fierce across the South, that has left his autumn march confined to fewer than a dozen states across the Northeast, Midwest and the West Coast where candidates believe that the President can make a positive difference.
Missing from the ranks of candidates that Mr. Clinton will try to help in the coming days are some of his party's leading figures, including Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas, Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, and Representatives Jim Cooper of Tennessee and Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, both of whom are seeking to maintain the party's hold on open Senate seats. Instead, Mr. Clinton will spend the final days before the election in the frequent company of statehouse candidates like Ms. York and Bonnie Campbell of Iowa, and Senate hopefuls like Helen Wynia of Minnesota and Ron Sims of Washington, who all are running behind in the polls and are hardly household names.
For the White House, the calculation has been frustrating but simple. Rather than risk alienating voters elsewhere, Mr. Clinton is limiting his stops to states like this one, where he can mobilize Democratic loyalists.
As in every other state he is scheduled to visit, a majority of Rhode Island's voters cast their ballots for Mr. Clinton in the 1992 Presidential campaign. And at a stop this afternoon near here in Pawtucket, Mr. Clinton found the kind of unrestrained support he sought as several hundred senior citizens at a Portuguese Social Club took in his warnings that Republican campaign promises would leave that party no choice but to cut back on Social Security benefits.
"We're moving forward," the President declared to loud applause. "You be thinking on Tuesday: 'I'm in control. I have a remote control on America's movie. I'm going to go into a polling place and I'm going to push forward. Maybe I'll even push fast-forward. But I certainly won't push reverse.' "
As Mr. Clinton repeated that message here in radio and television interviews via satellite with stations in Iowa, Connecticut and Massachusetts, his advisers portrayed his choice of venue as almost incidental. "The President's role in the final week is to travel around the country and help define the choice between Republicans and Democrats," said Joan Baggett, the White House political director.
At the same time, the White House issued a three-page fact sheet in an effort to substantiate its assertions that Mr. Clinton's trips had begun to have an effect on the Democratic fight to maintain control of the House and the Senate. Titled "A Week in Politics Is an Eternity," the document pointed to recent gains by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and other candidates for whom Mr. Clinton has campaigned, and it said that recent good economic news and the President's trip to the Middle East would underscore what should matter most to voters: "The nation is at peace, and the economy is growing."
With some recent national polls showing a surge in Mr. Clinton's approval ratings, one senior White House official said today: "I think the danger that voter anger at the President could cause the defeat of a local candidate is gone."
