HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S. Spree Bolsters The Dollar

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration went on a billion-dollar global buying spree today to prop up the value of the dollar. It succeeded, at least for now, in reviving the currency after it had fallen to a new post-World War II low against the Japanese yen.
But other nations did not appear to join in the effort, and there were signs late in the day that the markets were questioning a declaration by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that the "movements in the dollar are inconsistent" with the strength of the American economy. 
 At the end of the day in New York, the dollar was quoted at 97.63 yen, up from the postwar low of 96.12 yen in early trading and 96.65 yen on Tuesday. The purchases also drove the dollar as high as 1.5217 German marks from 1.4956 marks on Tuesday. The dollar was last quoted at 1.5138 marks.
But traders said they thought the weakness of the dollar would continue unless there were even stronger indications that the Federal Reserve was about to raise short-term interest rates again, making the dollar more attractive to overseas investors.
The effort to shore up the currency, directed by the Treasury, came at a politically crucial time for the Administration, both at home and abroad.
The weakness of the dollar -- and the underlying message that the markets fear the Fed has not moved quickly enough to choke off the threat of inflation -- could undermine President Clinton's effort to convince voters that he should be given credit for deft management of the economy. Midterm Congressional elections are next Tuesday.
The effort also comes just before meetings with two groups of countries that are among America's largest trading partners. This month, President Clinton plans to meet with Asian leaders in Jakarta, Indonesia. A second meeting is to follow in December with Latin American leaders in Miami.
Some market analysts viewed today's move as exquisite timing, a step that took traders by surprise and succeeded in sending the dollar bouncing back strongly. But others saw it as a doomed effort to stop a flood with a hastily constructed dam made of sticks. These analysts predicted that the billion or so dollars purchased today with reserves of foreign currency held by the Fed -- the exact amount cannot be precisely gauged for weeks -- will be washed away in the $1 trillion generally traded each day in the world's currency markets.
Indeed, that is what happened after the three previous big interventions by the Fed this year. While most rescues have succeeded for a time, currency traders who bet in the past against the Fed and other central banks have usually won.
Mr. Bentsen repeated a theme today that he has sounded several times in recent weeks: Classic economic theory calls for a strong economy to be reflected in a strong dollar, and, in time, the speculators betting against the dollar will lose.
"I believe that recent movements in the dollar are inconsistent with the fundamentals of a strong investment-led recovery in the United States and the greatly enhanced ability of U.S. firms to compete around the world," Mr. Bentsen said this morning. His statement came just as the dollar buying spree began in what traders estimated as bursts of $50 million or more. The Treasury, following its usual practice, did not publicly confirm that it had ordered an intervention.
"This Administration is committed to sound economic policies that expand the economy's capacity and sustain recovery with low inflation," Mr. Bentsen added. "Continuation of recent foreign-exchange trends would be counterproductive for the United States and the world economy. A stronger dollar will reduce inflation pressures, improve American living standards and promote investment."
Administration officials acknowledge that a one-day intervention may not have much lasting effect. But it can have significant shock value, they say, and sometimes prompt a market turnaround, as it did in the summer of 1993.
So far this year, officials point out, the dollar has fallen only about 4 percent against the yen, well within its normal annual fluctuation in value. But it is a fluctuation at a historic low, and that fact alone tints the political import of a decline, no matter how small.
Government officials refrained from explaining why they chose today to intervene. As usual, traders were eager to offer their own theories concerning the continuing decline of the dollar: some blamed the Fed, some blamed the snail's pace of trade talks with Japan, and some simply blamed speculators.
The most widespread explanation concerned the Fed and inflation.
"The markets are losing confidence in the Fed's inflation-fighting ability," said Michael Strauss, the chief economist of Yamaichi International (America), a currency trader. "The numbers have been strong, showing the economy is accelerating into the fourth quarter. And there is a loss of confidence that the Fed, maybe for political reasons, has not sent rates up fast enough. They are behind the curve."
Those fears were fueled somewhat on Tuesday, when an index of monthly business activity compiled by the National Association of Purchasing Management rose significantly, adding to fears of imminent inflation.
But another explanation focused on the inching trade talks with Japan over entry to the flat-glass market, one of the Japan's most protected industries. By itself, the market is economically insignificant in a $60 billion annual trade gap. Still, the failure to reach an agreement by a deadline earlier this week was seen by some traders as a sign that there would be no major progress on the Administration's trade agenda.
That would leave the Administration with only one option for making a big change in the trade imbalance: A stronger yen, which would make Japanese products more expensive, and thereby less competitive, in the United States.
The more immediate question, however, is whether the Treasury's move will be enough to scare off speculators who have been placing the dollar under continued attack. That may depend on whether other central banks, including Germany's Bundesbank, join the effort in coming days, or whether they sit on the sidelines to pressure the Fed to raise interest rates further.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Many Arab Lands Back Aid Bank

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration insisted today that its hopes of establishing a multibillion-dollar development bank for the Middle East were not dead and that many Arab countries were open to contributing to it.
Although Administration officials acknowledged that several Arab countries had not committed money to the bank, they said these countries had given a green light to the idea at a conference in Casablanca by setting up a study group on how to structure and finance the bank. 
 Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said the Administration was confident that Arab countries and Israel would eventually join the United States in financing the bank, which would lend money for dams, highways and other projects to develop the Middle East, help the emerging Palestinian authority and foster cooperation between Arabs and Israel.
Administration officials said Oman and Qatar said they would contribute to the bank; Kuwait said it was prepared to, and other nations said they wanted more time to decide. Some Middle East experts said that was a polite way of saying no.
Administration officials said they were particularly unhappy today with an article in The New York Times reporting that Arab nations had blocked plans to create the bank. It stated that Saudi and other Arab officials had said that they would not support the bank because of economic problems, including low oil prices.
At the conference, Suleiman Suleim, Saudi Arabia's Commerce Minister, and Morocco's Agriculture Minister, Abdelaziz Meziane Belfkih, suggested that the new bank was unnecessary because the region already had several development banks and underutilized funds.
But Mr. McCurry said that many Arab leaders supported a new bank during their speeches.
"It was a very important achievement that countries at the conference declared that they saw the creation of a bank as an important element of a strategy for economic cooperation in the region," he said, "and it was enormously important that the governments at the conference signed onto that."
State Department officials said the proposal for the six-month study was made by Secretary of State Warren Christopher and was not an effort by Arab nations to postpone forming the bank.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: MEXICO;
Government Joins Attack On Ballot Idea

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Putting aside years of cautious silence on American domestic politics, Mexico's Government and governing party are pushing angrily into California's debate over whether to cut off social services to illegal immigrants.
In a series of increasingly bitter complaints, the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has criticized proponents of an initiative regarding illegal aliens that is on the state's Nov. 8 ballot. 
 Mexican officials have contacted Hispanic-American groups working against Proposition 187, as the ballot measure is called, offering arguments and thoughts on strategy. They have prepared an advertising campaign to remind Californians of Mexicans' contributions to the state. Should the initiative pass, Mexican officials say they will hire lawyers to help fight it in American courts.
"Local political interests in California tend to blame Mexican workers for that society's problems," Mr. Salinas said to loud applause in his annual state of the union address on Tuesday. "Mexico affirms rejection of this xenophobic campaign, and will continue to act in defense of the labor and human rights of our migrant workers."
The proposition would strip illegal immigrants of their right to most government services, including education and non-emergency health care. It is supported by Gov. Pete Wilson of California and many other Republicans in the state, but opposed by the Clinton Administration and Democratic candidates in the races for governor and senator. Though support for the measure has slipped, opinion polls still show that it will pass.
Despite an early pledge of more direct support to the forces arrayed against the measure, the involvement of Mexican officials has remained largely rhetorical and concentrated on their side of the border.
But to many Mexicans, the campaign shows the Salinas Government to be standing up to politicians in the United States who have pushed for crackdowns on illegal aliens. That helps to offset an image of submission for which the Mexican Government was widely criticized in negotiations that culminated last year in approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The Mexican assault on the California proposition is also in keeping with the Salinas Government's expanding efforts to win political support among Mexican migrants to the United States. If Mexican officials have not been as active in California as they initially suggested, it might be because some Mexican-American leaders have warned that a higher profile could be counterproductive.
Yet to accusations of opportunism from their own political opposition, Mexican officials answer that their stand against Proposition 187 is an inevitable response to the changes taking place in Mexican-American relations.
For decades, they note, Mexican politicians were scrupulous in avoiding any hint of partisanship in American politics. But as Mexico and the United States become more integrated, they say, the political rules observed by the two countries are evolving, too.
"This is part of the new reality of this relationship," said the Deputy Foreign Minister in charge of Mexican relations with the United States, Andres Rozental, who first assailed the measure in a speech in Los Angeles more than two months ago.
"We were more forthcoming about U.S. interest in our electoral process in August," Mr. Rozental said in an interview, referring to the presence of hundreds of American observers for Mexico's presidential vote. "And in this reverse issue, it is not a matter of academic interest. This would affect the tremendous interests of hundreds of thousands of Mexicans in California."
Officials say the rising protest against the measure in Mexico also portends a conflict over the immigration question that is likely to deepen as other aspects of the relationship between the two countries improve. "Immigration is going to be the No. 1 issue between the United States and Mexico for the next few years," Mr. Rozental said.
Mexico has long argued that neither better fences nor more patrol agents along the border will stop undocumented migrants so long as there is the lure of jobs across the border.
The two Governments agreed to ignore the issue in negotiations for the trade agreement out of fear that it might jeopardize American Congressional approval of the accord. Since last year, however, Mexican officials have pressed harder for an American policy that would emphasize trying to manage the flow of migrant workers rather than trying to use force to block the entry of undocumented immigrants.
Like other opponents of Proposition 187, the Salinas Government predicts that the measure will have little effect on those migrants, arguing that they seek better-paying jobs rather than better quality in health care, education and other benefits that are also largely free in Mexico.
Mexican officials insist that if approved, the initiative would increase racial discrimination against all people of Mexican descent in California. They say that would be the inevitable consequence of the measure's requirement that teachers, social workers and others report any immigrants whom they suspect might be in the country illegally.
Already, they contend, anti-immigrant sentiments stirred by the election debate are leading to abuses against Mexicans by both the United States Border Patrol and ordinary Californians. The Salinas Government has responded with a flurry of diplomatic protests and the deployment of more than a dozen new officers to Mexico's nine consulates in the state. The Tijuana City Council voted recently to declare Governor Wilson persona non grata.
But so far, there is little sign that rising anger over the ballot measure among Mexicans seriously threatens the expanding economic ties between the two countries.

HEADLINE: Strike Prevents Delivery of San Francisco Daily Newspapers

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Employees of this city's two major daily newspapers, longtime rivals that have limped along under a joint operating agreement since 1965, went on strike Tuesday night as 2,600 reporters, editors, drivers, press operators and paper handlers walked off the job. They had been working without a contract for the past year.
The work stoppage at The Chronicle and The Examiner, the first at the newspapers since a 52-day walkout in 1968, began a day after the original Halloween strike deadline set by eight unions had been extended for a flurry of last-minute negotiations. But the talks failed, and while hundreds of thousands of papers for Wednesday were printed, few if any reached readers' hands. 
 "The racks are empty and the doorsteps are bare, and we think we can keep it that way," said Doug Cuthbertson, the head of the Conference of Newspaper Unions.
Throughout the day, pickets marched outside the Gothic-style offices that the newspapers share on Mission Street, while brawny security guards imported from Michigan by the newspapers' management videotaped their every move.
"On strike! Shut it down!" the pickets yelled. Supervisory personnel entering the building were taunted with shouts of "Scabs, go home!" and "Get a real job!"
There was scattered violence at several printing plants. James Hale, chief executive officer of the San Francisco Newspaper Agency, which handles advertising and distribution of the papers under the joint operating agreement, said five trucks had been destroyed and three people had been hospitalized, one whose skull had been cracked by a lead pipe.
At least two members of the teamsters' union were arrested outside The Chronicle's printing plant in Union City for trespassing and vandalism. The police, wearing riot gear and carrying batons, flanked protesters at the main printing plant in San Francisco.
The strike comes a week before elections for major state and Federal offices and on several volatile referendums, and on the eve of the crucial Christmas shopping season. The two sides are no longer talking, and no further negotiations have been scheduled. Mayor Frank Jordan called the strike "a loss to the city and to all the individuals involved."
Wages are the major issue, with the unions demanding a 3.5 percent annual raise and management offering a 2.46 percent annual raise over four years. Also in dispute is management's effort to cut the jobs of what it says are more than 150 redundant teamster drivers over several years, and to replace the young boys and girls who deliver the papers by foot and bicycle with adults in cars.
"We run one of the most overstaffed delivery systems in the country," said Richard Jordan, a management negotiator, who is not related to the Mayor. "Allowing it to stay that way will inevitably lead to the closure of the newspapers."
An official from teamsters' Local 921, Adele DeCampli-Cirkelis, countered that management's real objective was to replace union employees with "part-timers who get sub-standard wages and no benefits."
Both parties have been getting ready for a strike for some time. Newspaper executives learned the art of printing newspapers, installed chain-link fences with barbed wire tops around loading docks, and imported lawyers from the Nashville firm of King & Ballow, which represented the owners of The New York Daily News and The Chicago Tribune in previous newspaper disputes.
On the other side, the unions printed cards for Chronicle and Examiner readers wishing to cancel their subscriptions.
The newspaper agency has vowed to put out both papers throughout the strike -- a task that, with technological improvements, is far easier than it once was. But striking reporters belittled the product in advance. "You might have an Examiner that looks like an Examiner, but it's really a shell of a paper," said Steven Chin, an Examiner reporter and spokesman for the Conference of Newspaper Unions.
The unions have already produced the first issue of a newspaper they have called The San Francisco Free Press. It came complete with a column by Herb Caen, The Chronicle's nearly indestructible columnist. "For better or for worse, strikes and San Francisco go together," Mr. Caen wrote in what was one of the least chipper of the thousands of columns he has written since 1939.
In the background of the strike were two venerable San Francisco traditions: the strength of labor unions and the economic weakness of the newspapers, which were less aggressive than many other major metropolitan papers to follow readers to the suburbs.
At a rally outside the papers' editorial offices on Monday night, speaker after fiery speaker referred to San Francisco as a "strong union town," invoking storied local labor names like Tom Mooney, Harry Bridges and Michael Casey to rally the troops. But even Mr. Caen conceded things had changed. "This was the best union town in the country," he wrote. "Now unionism is in decline and all the major sideshows have become a thing of the past."
The dispute could presage a restructuring or eventual merger of The Chronicle and The Examiner. Most scenarios have the Chronicle, more popular and owned by the local Thieriot family, being swallowed up by the Hearst Corporation, the far wealthier owner of the more economically anemic Examiner.
Since the companies are private and their books are closed, no one knows just how much the two newspapers make, though it appears to be far less than most newspapers make under similar joint operating agreements. The two share all revenues equally, meaning that the morning Chronicle, with a paid circulation of 526,824, effectively subsidizes the afternoon Examiner, whose circulation is a mere 120,549, according to figures by the Audit Bureau of Circulation.
"The evolution would seem to be toward one newspaper," said John S. Reidy, a newspaper analyst at Smith Barney in New York, who called the strike "sort of like a death wish" for the unions.
"It would be most prudent not to think about striking when there's clear evidence of stress for the owners in the present economic circumstances," Mr. Reidy said. "It just doesn't seem like a market that's suited to a morning and evening paper."
He said that was true even under a joint operating agreement, or J.O.A.
John Morton, a newspaper analyst with Lynch, Ryan & Jones in Washington, agreed. "All the J.O.A. has done is allow them to keep a dying newspaper in business," he said. "There will not be an Examiner in 2005, but long before then there will be some kind of rationalization of the situation."
Outside a distribution plant in the China Basin section of San Francisco, a Chronicle sports writer, Tom FitzGerald, was not thinking such dire thoughts. "I always wanted to know what it would be like to be a Major League baseball player," he said. "But I hope we settle before the baseball players do."

HEADLINE: Ireland and Britain Praise Clinton's Ulster Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Ireland and Britain today praised the Clinton Administration's decision to increase economic aid to Northern Ireland as a step toward advancing peace there.
The White House announced late Tuesday that the President had decided to raise aid to Northern Ireland to $30 million a year over the next two fiscal years, up from the $20 million a year that was planned. 
 In addition, the Administration said the President would be the host of a conference next April in Philadelphia that would seek to increase American trade with Northern Ireland as well as the adjoining counties in the Republic of Ireland. The conference will bring together business executives and Government officials from the United States, Ireland and Northern Ireland.
Ireland's Prime Minister, Albert Reynolds, told Irish radio today, "The new package will certainly be welcomed in the places that have been devastated by the violence over the past 25 years."
In Belfast, a spokesman for the British Government said the President's "generous package" was "very welcome."
In announcing the aid package, White House officials said the stepped-up aid and trade should help reduce high unemployment in Northern Ireland, one of the factors that fueled the searing tensions between Catholics and Protestants.
The White House said, "The United States wants to do its part to insure that peace brings to Ireland new opportunities for job growth and economic prosperity."
As part of its aid efforts, the Administration said Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown would travel to Belfast in November to attend a conference organized by Britain. Mr. Brown's role will be to identify opportunities for increased business.
With its announcement, the White House sought to show not only that it was thoroughly engaged in pushing Irish peace talks forward, but also that it had worked quietly to get the warring sides to lay down their arms. Both the Irish Republican Army and Protestant paramilitary groups have declared cease-fires.
Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, voiced confidence today "that the potential for further U.S. investment is probably greater now than at any time in recent history."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: BROADCASTER;
Election Jitters in Limbaughland

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
These are busy days for Rush Limbaugh, tending the far-flung precincts of talk radio as the nation lurches toward the midterm elections, or, as Mr. Limbaugh calls them, "Operation Restore Democracy."
Around the country, there are defecting Republicans to scold, like Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, whose endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came just as Mr. Cuomo "was on a train ride to Palookaville." In Massachusetts, there is the sudden, distressing comeback -- "How can that be?" -- of Senator Edward M. Kennedy in his race against the Republican, Mitt Romney. Not surprisingly, there are pre-election jitters and questions among the troops, from Jerry in San Diego to Mary Alice in Troy, N.Y. 
 Mr. Limbaugh tries to buck them up and calm them down in these last days before what he predicts will be "one of the most massive moves to the right" in a long time. "I told you that in the last two weeks you'd see the dominant media culture do what they can to rescue not just Clinton, but Democrats as well," Mr. Limbaugh says. "This is not the time to be depressed. This is the time to remember the weapon that you have, and that is the vote."
This is a big moment in the world of talk radio, which has its impresarios in virtually every city, from Bob Grant in New York to Mike Siegel in Seattle, and which has become for many Americans an echo chamber for their discontent. And if Larry King's CNN program functioned as a nominating process for Ross Perot, Rush Limbaugh may be a kind of national precinct captain for the Republican insurgency of 1994.
If there ever was a campaign season tailor-made for the medium, this is it: angry, anti-Washington, anti-incumbent, with some of the most renowned liberals -- and favorite targets on conservative talk radio shows -- fighting for their lives.
Andrew Kohut, director of the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, describes the talk radio audience as "the hood ornament of the national mood" -- more conservative, more anti-government than most voters, but very much reflecting the tone of the times.
The genre, of course, has legions of critics, who variously accuse it of coarsening the public debate, stoking the mistrust of the Clinton Administration and feeding a vehemently anti-Congress mood. But like it or not, some analysts say, talk radio may be fulfilling some of the functions of traditional political institutions -- parties, unions or civic groups -- for its audience, particularly in the heat of a campaign. It is playing the role, in other words, of a mediating institution that gives people a sense of connection in politics when other institutions do not.
"They tune into a community of similar attitudes and discontent," Mr. Kohut said, "and they reinforce one another's views about how bad things are in Washington." Or, as one woman began her conversation with Mr. Limbaugh last week, "Rush, I AM ANGRY!"
It may not have the human texture, the connective tissue of relationships that existed in the old party organizations, but then neither does much of modern culture. "That's the poignant fact of politics in our age, that people feel like they do have a relationship with Rush Limbaugh," said Harry Boyte, a senior fellow at the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota who is a scholar of democracy and citizenship.
That much is clear on the electronic hustings, in the final days of the 1994 campaign: Patrice, in Massachusetts, begins her call, "Next to my husband, Rush, you're my best friend," before going on to ventilate her disappointment in the Kennedy-Romney race. Jeanette, in Spokane, Wash., who would like to vote for the Republican, George Nethercutt, in his race against the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, but hates Mr. Nethercutt's support for fetal tissue research, asks plaintively, "Rush, aren't there times in your life when you have to stand with principle over party loyalty?"
Mr. Limbaugh replies, instructs, ventilates. He struggles to explain the conservative rifts over Proposition 187, the California ballot initiative that would bar illegal immigrants from most government services. And, like any other good political chieftain, he looks ahead to the days of power, warning his listeners of the need to hold "feet to the fire" in the new Congress.
No less than David Broder, veteran political columnist for The Washington Post, speculated this week on how Mr. Limbaugh will cope in the next few years as Republicans move from Clinton-bashing to an agenda for governing.
Mr. Limbaugh, who declined a New York Times request for an interview, both revels in his political role on the air and, from time to time, backs away from it. "I don't have any power in the Republican Party at all, don't want any," he said last week after a long discussion of divisions within the party as it heads toward 1996. "But I have just been suggesting as a commentator and an analyst and a public figure and a concerned citizen that you guys had better come up with a list of things you believe in, your principles, your vision for America, and stick to it."
The party certainly takes Mr. Limbaugh and his conferees seriously. The talk radio constituency tends to be attentive to politics and very likely to vote: the most recent Times Mirror poll found that 64 percent of those who regularly listen to talk radio said they had thought about the coming elections; just 35 percent of the nonlisteners had.
Mr. Limbaugh's producer says the show is carried by 659 radio stations with an audience of 20 million a week. The latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll found that 50 percent of Americans say they tune in at least occasionally to political call-in programs on radio and television.
Republican strategists also credit Mr. Limbaugh and other conservative talk show hosts with maintaining a barrage of criticism of President Clinton, particularly on the Whitewater affair, and balancing what they contend is a liberal bias in much of the mainstream press.
In general, Republicans in Congress and in the campaign committees conduct "mass faxing" operations to radio talk show hosts around the country, with talking points and updates on floor action on Capitol Hill (although Kit Carson, Mr. Limbaugh's producer, dismisses the idea that the Limbaugh show can be shaped by faxes.)
The Democratic National Committee also sends out talking points to "friendly" talk show hosts, but Democratic officials, like many analysts, see that medium as heavily conservative. "There's not a whole lot of persuasion going on, not a whole lot of conversion," said Jim Whitney, a spokesman for the Democratic National Committee. "There may be some mobilizations, but there aren't a whole lot of folks listening to talk radio who haven't figured out whether they're going to vote Democratic or Republican."
Michael Harrison, editor of Talkers Magazine, a trade publication for talk radio, agrees that "talk radio hosts really reflect and amplify more than they influence." It is less a political force in and of itself, he adds, than simply the forum where political discussion occurs.
Mr. Limbaugh begins each show with a countdown: the number of days since the Clinton economic plan went into effect (known in Limbaughland as the Raw Deal); the number of days left of the Clinton Administration (known as "the hostage crisis") and the number of days until the midterm elections.
The edge to much of talk radio dismays many people in politics, in both parties. "The basic problem is the total breakdown of anything that resembles civility, and the fact that the battle is fought not for people's minds but for their emotions," said Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who is retiring.
Moreover, much of the work of politics and parties is building consensus around common goals among people who may have very little else in common. "The problem today is that sounding off on talk shows has none of that quality of public work," said Mr. Boyte, the University of Minnesota scholar. "You get to vent. You get to whine, basically. When civic life or mediating institutions are replaced by electronic communications, people don't get any of the gritty flavor of life, or making a contribution."
Still, much of the electorate is well beyond the point of seeing any nobility in politics. In the age of anti-politics, the people who thrive -- Ross Perot, Rush Limbaugh and other "outsiders" -- may be those who do not talk like politicians, with all their qualifications, their hard choices, their need to compromise.
Politicians rarely get "megadittos."

HEADLINE: Justices Appear to Favor Employees on a Job-Discrimination Issue

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
In an unusually lopsided Supreme Court argument today, the Justices signaled their strong disapproval of permitting employers to escape liability for discrimination by coming up with belated evidence that a former employee filing a discrimination suit deserved dismissal for other reasons.
Several courts have recently ruled that employers who find such evidence have a complete defense to that employee's complaint of discriminatory treatment under Federal civil rights law. Evidence in these cases typically includes a previously undiscovered infraction of work rules or an exaggeration on a long-ago employment application that would have justified dismissal had the employer known of it. 
 The validity of this defense, known as the after-acquired evidence doctrine, has become one of the most hotly debated areas of discrimination law.
But the Court made the question look easy today. The argument was not so much a debate between lawyers as a series of declarations by Justices across the Court's ideological spectrum that the doctrine undermines the basic premise of Federal civil rights law.
"This is a statute that says, 'Thou shalt not discriminate,' and you are turning that around," Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said to R. Eddie Wayland, the lawyer for a Nashville publishing company that dismissed a 62-year-old secretary on the basis of an asserted staff reduction while at the same time hiring a 26-year-old.
After the secretary, Christine McKennon, filed a lawsuit under the Federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act, the employer discovered that she had taken home some confidential documents some months earlier in violation of company policy. On that basis, two lower Federal courts, accepting the employer's assertion that it would have fired Ms. McKennon had it known of the infraction, awarded judgment to the company.
Mr. Wayland's argument that an employee who could have been dismissed for a legitimate reason suffers no "tangible economic injury" by being dismissed for a discriminatory one was challenged by Justice Antonin Scalia.
Justice Scalia countered by offering himself as an example of a "thoroughly incompetent employee" whose employer learned of his incompetence only after firing him because of his age. "Why is that not an injury?" he asked, adding: "The more incompetent I've been, the less likely I am to get a later job, and the more I've been injured."
At another point, Justice Scalia commented that "it would be rather risky to bring such a suit" if any employee filing a discrimination complaint was subject to an extensive examination of his competence and conduct.
Justice Sandra Day O'Connor told Mr. Wayland, "I don't see how your rule implements the goal of the statute at all." The relevant inquiry, Justice O'Connor said, was what the employer knew and did on the date the discriminatory action occurred.
Mr. Wayland replied, "It is also a goal of the statute not to reward bad employees."
Mr. Wayland said employees who engage in misconduct had "no one to blame but themselves" when the misconduct causes them to forfeit an otherwise meritorious discrimination case.
The lawyer arguing the appeal for the employee in this case, Michael E. Terry, told the Court that if later evidence showed an employee to have merited dismissal for legitimate reasons, the correct approach was not to erase the employer's liability but to limit the worker's remedy.
Such an employee might forfeit the right to reinstatement and continued pay, Mr. Terry said, but not to back pay. He said that an employer who had been injured by an employee's misconduct could sue for civil damages or seek criminal prosecution.
There was considerable discussion among the Justices about how the back-pay eligibility should be calculated in such cases. But it was not clear whether the Court would address that issue in its eventual decision.
The Clinton Administration appeared on behalf of the employee, Ms. McKennon. Irving L. Gornstein, an assistant solicitor general, told the Justices that the critical issue in a discrimination case "is what actually motivated the employer at the time of the adverse action." Evidence acquired later does not change the "historical fact" of a violation of the civil rights laws, he said.
The Administration's brief said that as use of the after-acquired evidence doctrine had spread, "employers now routinely embark upon extensive, post-discharge investigations" intended to uncover "some theoretically valid" justification for a discriminatory discharge.
The Equal Employment Advisory Council, an employers group, took strong exception in its brief to the Administration's assertion, saying that it unfairly characterized the situation. The Chamber of Commerce of the United States filed a brief saying that 30 percent of all job applicants "materially misrepresent their credentials and qualifications" and that the after-acquired evidence doctrine gives employers a useful tool to combat the problem.
While this case, McKennon v. Nashville Banner, No. 93-1543, was brought under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, the Court's decision will also apply to the basic Federal employment-discrimination law, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, on which the age discrimination act was modeled. Title VII bars discrimination on the basis of race, sex, religion and national origin.
Ms. McKennon's appeal came from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, one of several courts to have adopted the after-acquired evidence doctrine as a complete bar to employer liability. Other Federal courts view later-acquired evidence as relevant only to the remedy.
The Supreme Court has been watching developments in this area for some time. Last year, it agreed to hear an appeal brought by a woman whose victory in a sex-discrimination case had been overturned because she had failed to reveal on her employment application a conviction for drunken driving. But the case was settled before the Supreme Court could decide it.

HEADLINE: Fed Report Said to Point To Rate Rise

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
With unemployment falling most places and every region of the American economy growing, manufacturers are beginning to raise prices, the Federal Reserve said in a report released today. Private economists interpreted the report, prepared with contributions from each of the 12 regional Fed banks, as another sign that the central bank is likely to raise interest rates again soon.
Today's report on the health of regional economies, known as the beige book, pointed to accelerating economic growth in the regions surrounding Minneapolis, Chicago, Dallas and Philadelphia, and steady growth almost everywhere else in the country. The only conspicuous exception to the Fed's overall optimism lay in New York State and the Connecticut and New Jersey suburbs of New York City. The region's economy continued to recover in October but the pace of that growth slowed, the Fed said. 
 The Fed, in its September report, had said that economic developments in its New York district "were by and large more favorable in recent weeks." But in today's report, the central bank warned that sales had fallen short of retailers' expectations in the region and growth in housing sales had faltered.
"District economic growth slowed somewhat in recent weeks," the report said. The Fed attributed the slowdown to higher interest rates and to planned or actual job cutbacks by the financial industry, the New York City government and big companies like I.B.M.
Further interest rate increase could hurt the region more. The Federal Reserve cannot hold down interest rates in only one region to accommodate slow growth there. Because financial markets are national, everyone would borrow in that region and the competition for loans would drive rates back up to the national average.
The overall report today was very upbeat about the health of the national economy, suggesting that the Fed will soon raise short-term interest rates in an effort to prevent the economy from growing too quickly, which feeds inflation.
"There's nothing in there to discourage the Fed from wanting to slow things down, and a lot to encourage the Fed to do so," said Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Federal Reserve officials have been worried that rapid economic growth could lead to shortages of materials and skilled workers, pushing up prices and inflation. As a result, they have already raised short-term interest rates five times this year. The central bank's top policy makers are scheduled to meet again on Nov. 15 to decide whether another increase is needed, and it is possible they could act earlier.
So far this year, the Fed has pushed up its target for the Federal funds rate -- the borrowing cost banks charge each other for overnight loans -- to 4.75 percent from 3 percent. The Fed has also raised the discount rate, which it charges banks for overnight loans, to 4 percent from 3 percent.
The Fed released its report today several hours after the Commerce Department said that the index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in September after rising five-tenths of 1 percent in August. Separately, new orders for manufactured goods, which had climbed 4.7 percent in August, fell two-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Critics of the Federal Reserve's rate increases cited the two reports from the Commerce Department as evidence that the economy was slowing and that inflation was unlikely to be a threat in the foreseeable future.
"On the whole, the leading indicators demonstrate that the economy is not overheating, but is slowing down to a sustainable rate of expansion," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
But financial analysts called both figures unsurprising. They argued that increases in the leading indicators and in factory orders were so large in August that a leveling-off in September was to be expected.
Sung W. Sohn, the chief economist at the Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company in Minneapolis, noted that new orders for transportation equipment and other durable goods rose during September. Only a small drop in orders for nondurable goods like oil and tobacco held down the overall figure for new orders.
Orders for durable goods are a better indicator of the overall economy's health and are likely to alarm the Fed more than the overall figure may reassure it, Mr. Sohn said.
By contrast, Mr. Jasinowski noted that prices for raw materials and new orders for consumer goods -- two of the 11 indicators of the leading index -- fell in September.
Also slipping in September were the money supply in 1987 dollars and manufacturers' unfilled orders for durable goods. Six indicators rose in September: building permits, an index of consumer expectations, average weekly initial claims for state unemployment insurance, stock prices, delays in business deliveries and new equipment orders.
One indicator was unchanged: the average workweek for manufacturing workers, at 42 hours.

HEADLINE: Bank Plan Would Rescue Co-ops Hurt by Recession

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Throwing a financial lifeline to scores of cooperative apartment buildings in New York City, a consortium of banks has put up $100 million to help rescue co-ops that were hit hard when the real estate market collapsed in the late 1980's, and to help new buyers obtain mortgages.
Officials estimated that the program could involve 6,000 to 7,000 apartments in 150 to 200 buildings. Many are in middle-income buildings in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn that were brought to the brink of collapse after their sponsors went bankrupt when apartment sales fell far short of expectations. 
 In many of the buildings, most of the apartments are still rent-stabilized units with tenants who pay less than the market rate and by law cannot be evicted.
Much of the money in the program will be used to refinance mortgages on buildings whose fragile finances and low ownership levels have kept them from getting new mortgages and have all but frozen apartment sales. The refinanced mortgages will mean lower interest rates and thus, lower maintenance payments for apartment owners.
The fund will also finance loans for repairs and in some cases make mortgage loans for buyers of individual units. The State of New York Mortgage Agency, also known as SONYMA, will insure the mortgages, providing a cushion for banks in case of default.
"The program will do more than rescue" the co-ops, said Michael D. Lappin, president of the Community Preservation Corporation, a nonprofit consortium of 53 banks that is a source of community redevelopment lending. "It will also help open up one of the the best sources of home ownership opportunities for working-income families in New York," he added.
Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens, who was among the first elected officials to sound the alarm about the mounting defaults in co-op buildings, praised the new program. "This will be good for Queens and a lot of other neighborhoods," Mrs. Shulman said. "It will help stabilize neighborhoods."
Over the last several years, Mrs. Shulman put pressure on banks to renegotiate loans on several large co-op complexes in Queens, so that the buildings would not go into default and the apartment owners would not lose their investments.
The trouble for many co-ops started when the real estate market began unraveling in the late 1980's. In many cases, when building owners had decided to convert the complexes to co-ops, the owners had taken out additional mortgages on the buildings to turn an easy profit.
The unsold apartments had been put up as collateral, and the sponsors expected that the profits from the sale of apartments would cover the mortgage payments, property taxes and operating costs.
But when the market collapsed and apartment sales stopped, some sponsors began to fall behind and many went into personal bankruptcy. In 1991, at the height of the crisis, the State Attorney General Office, estimated that sponsors were in default in at least 400 buildings -- more than 10 percent of the co-op buildings in New York City.
In most cases the banks took over the unsold apartments, sold them at auctions and worked out new payment schedules for the buildings.
At the same time, most banks tightened their lending policies, virtually eliminating new loans for any buildings that had less than 80 percent of their apartments owned by resident shareholders. That move put a freeze on apartment sales, and kept co-ops from refinancing their mortgages or getting loans for capital improvements.
Though the program will aid hundreds of buildings, eligibility requirements will keep some of the most vulnerable co-ops out. Mr. Lappin said that to qualify, a co-op would need to have sold 40 percent of its apartments. Although their exact numbers are not known, hundreds of other co-op buildings still have ownership levels of 25 percent or less.
Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, called the program significant despite its limitations.
"The program will not cover every co-op that needs help," said Ms. Rothman. "The focus is on buildings that can be helped more easily and quickly. But hopefully it will help restore an atmosphere where lending to co-ops is seen as a good investment again."
The banks are making this mortgage money available after considerable political pressure from people like Mrs. Shulman. One advantage to the banks is that that these loans will help them satisfy the Federal Government's mandate that banks make more loans in moderate- and low-income neighborhoods.
One of the first buildings to be assisted with the new program will be a 111-unit building on Nagle Avenue in the Inwood section of Manhattan that was converted to a co-op more than 10 years ago. It is legally a cooperative, but more than half the residents are still tenants.
For more than three years the co-op's board of directors has been searching for a bank to refinance its mortgage and provide a loan for a new roof. An additional blemish in the view of lenders is that the co-op's sponsor has defaulted on the unsold apartments there.
"We're stuck," said Rita Henley-Jensen, president of the co-op. "We couldn't get any bank to lend us money because there are not enough owners in the building. But apartments can't be sold because no one can get mortgages. We don't even qualify for a loan so the roof can be repaired."
Through the program the co-op on Nagle Street will refinance its existing mortgage, bringing its debt down from $1.8 million to $1.2 million. The building will also get a $200,000 loan for a new roof and other improvements. When the work has been completed the co-op members hope to start selling apartments again.
"This is a nice building," said Ms. Henley-Jensen. "It is buildings like ours where most families can afford to buy apartments."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Follow Dollar In Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slid yesterday, as they have every day this week, following the dollar's plunge to a post-World War II low against the Japanese yen and the Federal Reserve's latest "beige book" report suggesting that inflation could accelerate.
A weakening dollar causes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities to become less attractive to foreign investors, and as a consequence the yield on the long bond was pushed very close to a three-year high. 
 But the market managed to recoup some of its losses, as the Fed intervened in the currency markets to buy dollars to shore up the currency's price. The price of the 30-year bond was down 11/32 , to 9312/32 , for a yield of 8.09 percent, up from 8.06 percent on Tuesday. Shorter-maturity bills were nearly unchanged.
Don Hays, director of investment strategy at Wheat, First Securities in Richmond, said the market was caught in a vortex, waiting for the Nov. 15 meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee. He described the way the market waffled along yesterday, with a new round of statistics, noting that most of the volatility came from market speculators and large traders. Most of the retail trade remained on the sidelines, he said.
"We think the market right now has major, major support at a price to yield 8.10 percent, and we saw it bounce off that level twice today," Mr. Hays said. "The fundamentals are all saying the Fed will raise interest rates, but there are a few signs that they may not have to move more than once this year."
For instance, he said, yesterday's leading economic indicators index was flat, along with a downward revision of last month's data. "These are leading indicators, not lagging, and they suggest that there is some economic weakening on the horizon," he said.
"When you look at the price component, you can see the new orders for consumer goods actually down," Mr. Hays said. "That's a big item."
Some market participants believe the Fed, which considers the economy to be very healthy, is likely to use the beige book report to set interest rate policy at its meeting on Nov. 15. The report suggested that inflation could accelerate because more manufacturers were raising the prices of raw and semi-finished goods as the economy grew.
The supply of bonds is also likely to play a role in yield movement for the near term. Yesterday the Treasury announced that its quarterly refunding next week would include $29 billion in new 3-year and 10-year notes. With $12 billion of 37-day cash management bills and $27.2 billion of the regular weekly supply of bills, the total swells to $68.2 billion in new securities for sale.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's auction, the 3-year note was being offered at a price to yield 7.33 percent, and the 10-year note was being offered at a price to yield 7.95 percent.
The Commerce Department's report on manufacturers' orders yesterday showed a modest decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in factory orders in September, in sharp contrast to the surge of 4.7 percent in August. But analysts said the overall trend remained strong, so yesterday's report should not detract from the healthy economic picture.
Elsewhere, the corporate bond market expects to see the pricing of a large credit-backed offering today. John H. Nash, an analyst with MCM/ Corporate Watch, a new-issues research firm, said Banc One would be pricing about $2 billion of credit card-backed securities through Bear, Stearns & Company.
"It will be the second-largest credit card-backed issue ever," Mr. Nash said, "eclipsed only by Citicorp's Choice Credit Card Master Trust back in December 1992, which sold $2.18 billion of credit card-backed securities."
He said he expected the deal to be done, despite rising interest rates, noting that there were few quality issues and there was little corporate supply.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why isn't a better economy helping Clinton's popularity?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AS President, George Bush took the rap for the recession. Why isn't President Clinton benefiting at the polls from the economic recovery?
Maybe he is. William Nordhaus, an economist at Yale University, believes that Mr. Clinton is, in fact, getting his share of the credit, but the cheers have been lost in the roar of general disapproval about other issues. Factoring out the benefits he should be enjoying because of the good economic news, Mr. Nordhaus says, "Clinton is the most unpopular president since Truman." 
 Others think that the state of the economy -- like the risk of being mugged in a big city -- is largely in the eye of the beholder. "Symbols are salient," argues Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. And few, presumably, are as salient as the mass layoffs by industrial titans that are now standard fare on the evening news.
Still others argue that the psychological benefits of the economic expansion have been undermined by a sense that the workplace is becoming harsher and less forgiving. "Growing average wages were a sort of safety net," says Frank Levy, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. That safety net, Mr. Levy notes, no longer exists.
The Nordhaus explanation, based on the long-established statistical relationship between Presidential approval ratings and a variety of economic indicators, has the charm of simplicity. Since Herbert Hoover, the popularity of all Presidents has been influenced by the state of the economy, Mr. Nordhaus argues. President Clinton is no exception. What is different about this President is that he is widely disliked for other reasons. Or, to put it another way, if unemployment and inflation were higher, he would be even more unpopular.
That explanation does not please President Clinton's fans -- or, for that matter, economists who suspect that people's sense of the health of the economy is only loosely linked to the numbers. "Even in a nasty recession," notes Richard Thaler of Cornell University, "90 percent of the work force has jobs."
In fact, polls show that many Americans don't even believe the recession is over. The real question, then, is what makes the majority feel optimistic or pessimistic about their own prospects when current news has little direct bearing on their incomes.
Ms. Tyson finds all this frustrating. Worries about job security, she contends, do not mesh with the reality. "Job tenure rates haven't noticeably changed," she points out.
The American economy has been creating and destroying jobs at a ferocious rate in the last few years. But, then, it has always created and destroyed jobs at a ferocious rate. What has changed is the visibility of the job shuffle.
By this reasoning, the truth shall make us anxious: Satisfaction with the economy will vary with the media's interest in corporate restructuring and the industry-specific threat from international trade. President Clinton may thus have shot himself in the foot by focusing so much attention on the pace of economic change and the vulnerability of some American businesses to foreign competition -- without being able to influence either very much.
Mr. Levy doesn't think it is necessary to slip this far into pop psychology to explain the discontent. Rising wages have long been the norm across careers as well as generations, he notes. Thus, not only could workers expect to earn substantially more than their parents, they could expect to earn substantially more as they grew older. But all that changed with the stagnation of the last two decades: The inflation-adjusted earnings of the average male who was 30 in 1972 grew just 11 percent by 1992.
That alone, Mr. Levy says, is not enough of an explanation. He notes, however, that workers have been hit by a double whammy in recent years: stagnating wages are now accompanied by wider variations in individual incomes from year to year.
Indeed, Peter Gottschalk of Boston College and Robert Moffitt of Brown University found that fully half of the rise in income inequality across the 1980's can be traced to "transient inequality" -- the rise and fall of individuals' earnings as they changed jobs or rode the roller coaster of overtime, shortened hours and incentive pay. Those numbers suggest that people's gut reactions have been accurate: Risk in the job market is rising without much gain in earnings as compensation.
The President's party usually loses seats in the midterm election, Ms. Tyson notes, because "Administrations can't really deliver up to expectations in two years." But, if the economy remains on track, Presidential popularity typically rebounds, she goes on, both because Presidents have more time to make a difference and because more realistic expectations take over.
The likelihood of a political rebound may be modest consolation for President Clinton, whose name is mud in spite of a booming, inflation-tame economy. But it may be his only consolation in this season of political discontent.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGNS;
Race for Governor: Cuomo Recounts Tough Times

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:

CANDIDATE -- Mario M. Cuomo
 
PRODUCER -- The Garth Group, New York City 

ON THE SCREEN Mr. Cuomo sits at a desk in what appears to be his executive office, talking to the camera in shirt sleeves, his hands clasped in front of him.
 
SCRIPT -- Cuomo: Some of the toughest times in recent history -- two recessions, AIDS, crack, violence -- have taught me what we need for the future and that's a high-tech economy, continued building of our infrastructure, a jobs-first approach to welfare, tough but smart law enforcement, fairness and hope for our children and the rest of us. Now the recession is behind us and we're moving forward with all of it. I'm asking for one more term to finish the job. Please vote for me on November 8.
 
ACCURACY -- It is true that the Governor has had to contend with the ravages of drug use, violence from guns, the AIDS epidemic and two national recessions. But the first recession did not hit New York State especially hard and had largely sputtered out by the time Mr. Cuomo took office in January 1983. The second national recession, however, was devastating for New York. While Mr. Cuomo is correct in saying it is now over, he fails to point out that it lasted longer here than in most of the country.
 
SCORECARD -- In its direct and simple appeal for votes, the ad, which was written by the Governor, seems an acknowledgement that he expects the race to go down to the wire. By focusing on his character, experience and vision of hope and high-technology, it attempts to elevate him above the campaign's unremittingly nasty tone. But the ad also underscores what Republicans consider his two greatest weaknesses: that he has served many years and that many bad things happened during those years. JAMES DAO

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGNS;
Race for Governor: Pataki Says Tax Cuts Are Possible

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:

CANDIDATE -- George E. Pataki
 
PRODUCER -- Russo, Marsh & Associates, Alexandria, Va., and Sacramento, Calif. 

VISUAL -- This 30-second advertisement features excerpts of a Pataki stump speech, delivered in Long Island under blue skies. In a gray suit, standing next to his wife, Libby, and several Long Island politicians, Mr. Pataki gestures firmly with his arms and hands as he critiques Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's fiscal policies. As he delivers his final lines, the ad shows the crowd cheering its approval.
 
SCRIPT -- Mr. Pataki: "We have suffered under the highest tax burden any people in America pay. We have suffered under the highest job losses any state in America has faced. The time for suffering is over. The time for change is here. We represent that change. We are going to cut taxes and cut spending. Mario Cuomo said, 'You can't cut taxes like that. You can't cut spending like that.' Let me tell you something, Mario. You're right. You can't. But I will. And that's why we're going to win this race."
 
ACCURACY -- As he has throughout the campaign, Mr. Pataki misstates the state's rankings in tax burden and job losses, although the real figures should provide little comfort to Mr. Cuomo. Census Bureau statistics show that the state's tax burden, measured as a percentage of personal income, ranks 22d among states, while the combined burden of state and local taxes ranks second, behind only Alaska. One state, California, lost more jobs than New York during the recession, and Connecticut lost a greater proportion of its jobs.
 
SCORECARD -- Mr. Pataki has delivered this speech to virtually every audience in the last few months, and now he is broadcasting it for mass consumption. Because polls show that few New Yorkers have any sense of who Mr. Pataki is, the candidate appears in person in this ad, and the crowd reaction demonstrates enthusiasm for his candidacy.
But the ad does little to defend Mr. Pataki's proposal for $5.6 billion in tax cuts against the Governor's charge that such deep cuts are irresponsible and will simply pass the tax burden to local governments. Instead, it dismisses Mr. Cuomo's recalcitrance as simply a lack of will. And Mr. Pataki does so by referring to the Governor by his first name, a decision that some voters may consider disrespectful. KEVIN SACK

HEADLINE: Mr. Ames Exposed More Than Spies

 BODY:
It is now clear beyond doubt that Aldrich Ames turned the old cold-war game of spy versus spy into a total rout -- in the Soviets' favor. According to a Senate Intelligence Committee report, Mr. Ames managed to betray most U.S. and allied espionage operations in the Soviet Union from 1985 on.
His treachery resulted in the exposure and rolling up of over 100 spy operations, the "loss of virtually all of C.I.A.'s intelligence assets targeted at the Soviet Union," the deaths of at least a dozen prized Soviet agents and the exposure of other Soviet agents who were then forced to feed false information back to Western intelligence. 
 That the C.I.A. allowed a boozy bumbler like Aldrich Ames to gain extensive access to its espionage networks and to elude detection despite his brazenly sloppy practices is and will forever remain a monument to bureaucratic incompetence. In the committee's words: "gross negligence."
It would only deepen the tragedy if larger questions got lost in the uproar over Mr. Ames. There is, for example, the question of accountability. C.I.A. Director James Woolsey has merely reprimanded the officials responsible for the Ames debacle. There were more serious penalties available to him and he should have imposed them. The Director seemed oblivious to the message his tender treatment of his department's bunglers sent to future generations of C.I.A. managers.
The committee calls Mr. Woolsey's response "seriously inadequate." Those words apply equally to the quality of the agency's intelligence during the final stages of the cold war. It grievously underestimated the Soviet Union's economic problems during the 1980's and failed completely to anticipate its collapse, raising the question of what real value the country had been getting from all those spies in the years before Mr. Ames exposed them.
There are more recent instances of spying gone awry. In Haiti, the leader of the Fraph, a notorious gang of anti-Aristide thugs, was a spy on the C.I.A. payroll. The Fraph handed the Clinton Administration its most embarrassing setback when it created a disturbance that prevented U.S. troops from disembarking at Port-au-Prince. The C.I.A. man in the Fraph reportedly had informed the agency of the plan. What happened to that information?
The agency recently increased its investment in spying. One has to wonder, in view of the sorry historical record, whether this is an intelligent use of the taxpayers' money, and whether there are not more effective ways to gather intelligence in the post-cold-war world.
If people ask the right questions, some good might still come of the disastrous treachery of a senior operative who, in the Intelligence Committee's words, "caused more damage to the national security of the United States than any [other] spy in the history of the C.I.A." A thorough Congressional evaluation of the past performance and future mission of the entire intelligence establishment would be a good place to begin.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Liberals' Last Stand

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When a desperate President of the United States demeans his office by trying to frighten elderly voters with a rehashed old lie -- that the heartless Republicans must be secretly planning to slash Social Security benefits -- you know that the liberal philosophy is on the brink of electoral disaster.
When in deep trouble, perpetrate myths. Here are a few that are flying around the coming rejection of the leftist "Clinton Congress." 
 Myth #1. Anti-incumbent fever is sweeping the land and there just happen to be more Democratic incumbents.
On a summer's night many decades ago, at the triumphal Carnegie Hall debut of the violin prodigy Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist Mischa Elman said to the pianist Arthur Rubinstein: "Hot in here, isn't it?" To which Rubinstein replied, "Not for pianists."
It's not hot for Republican incumbents. Of G.O.P. senators up for re-election, I anticipate no defeats; of Democratic senatorial incumbents, at least seven are likely to be ousted by the votes of the divinely discontented. It ain't the incumbency, it's the tax-and-spend mindset that will be rejected at the polls.
Myth #2. Voters have turned irrational, refusing to tax themselves for what they want, "demanding the bacon and complaining about the pork."
That's the old Jimmy Carter, blame-the-public "malaise" bit. The truth is that a growing number of voters think government at all levels is spending their money unwisely and are upset about being taxed to the gills to redistribute income. Unstupidly, they believe the only way to cut the rate of spending increases is to cut the rate of taxation; rationally, they have decided that fear of deficits is the only discipline that works on legislators.
Myth #3. Clinton Democrats are not getting credit for reducing the budget deficit, as skinflints have long been demanding.
Two-fifths of the claimed drop in the 1995 budget deficit comes from the sale this year of S.&L. assets that the Government was forced to buy in past years. As projections for the sale of these assets goes up, the deficit comes down -- having nothing to do with Clinton economic policy. The irony is that the President whose Whitewater dealing was the sort that helped put an S.&L. under is now claiming credit for the sale of S.&L. assets our deposit insurance ran up red ink buying.
Myth #4. Republicans are criticizing each other already, and the coming majority is doomed to disarray.
When Republican mayors wander off the reservation to support state Democrats, that's budgetary payoff time; when wives and widows of past officeholders snipe at present candidates, that's a one-day filler; but when party figures disagree publicly on matters of policy, that's a sign of party vigor and strength.
Contrast the open Republican debate about aid to illegal immigrants with the Democrats' lockstep march toward a phony illusion of toughness on crime and welfare. Watch the few non-attack ads run by liberal candidates: see them climb into sheriff's cars to point with pride at new prisons, declaim against child molesters and welfare as we know it, tacitly acknowledging that costly compassion has gone out of style. Democrats are suddenly together -- pretending to be conservatives.
Myth #5. A Democratic "surge" in the final week will trim their expected losses to such an extent that the '94 results will be spinmeistered into a kind of Clinton victory.
Surge, shmurge -- races almost always get closer at the end, and there is a three-point polling bias for Democrats in midterms because of low turnout. But here's a curiosity of campaigning: If six Senate races are squeakers, the likelihood is that they won't average out and split three and three, but will go mostly one way or the other -- in my estimation, to the right.
If the surge notion takes hold, however, that's good. Not only will it energize the horde of overtaxed and underestimated Forgotten People to descend on the polls, the myth will make smug the Democratic precinct captains and chip off the bloc votes.
Then confident liberal candidates will make the apocryphal mistake of Gen. George Custer, who squinted up at a ridge at Little Big Horn and supposedly said: "Those look like friendly Indians."

HEADLINE: U.S. Embargo of Cuba Violates U.N.'s Wishes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The United States has asserted itself as the key player in the United Nations, utilizing it as a bulwark in creating multinational forces. The United States has prided itself on the cohesiveness of these coalitions. I do not want to debate its role in any of these actions; I merely seek to point out the hypocrisy of continuing an embargo against Cuba when the General Assembly last week voted 101 to 2, with 48 abstentions, to condemn the embargo. 
 The question is: Does America respect the wishes of the nations of the world as represented in the United Nations General Assembly, or not?
How can the United States continue to vote against allies like Spain, France and even its North American Free Trade Agreement trading partners, Canada and Mexico? The Clinton Administration must come to the realization that this continued embargo is more trouble than it is worth. A recent Associated Press article detailed how Mexico is investing in Cuba at a tremendous pace while the Caribbean countries continue to increase their trade with Cuba. Canada recently renewed foreign aid to Cuba. At the same time Cuba continues to open up its economy, with more and more private initiative in food and consumer goods.
If the United States can maintain most-favored-nation trade status with China, end the embargo against Vietnam and begin negotiations with North Korea, how can it not lift the embargo and normalize relations with Cuba?
The best place for the Clinton Administration to start is to restore family visits and remittances. Cuba should also be invited to the Summit of the Americas in Miami as a sign of good faith. In addition, the United States should give the green light to the Organization of American States, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to bring Cuba into these organizations.
 
RAYMUNDO DEL TORO
President, Cuban American
Committee for Peace
Linden, N.J., Oct. 27, 1994

HEADLINE: U.S. Embargo of Cuba Violates U.N.'s Wishes;
Preserve Health Care

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Following up on "Health Care, Cuba's Pride, Falls on Hard Times" (front page, Oct. 30) and the United Nations vote overwhelmingly in favor of lifting the United States embargo against Cuba, I urge our Government to rethink its Cuba policy. 
 After fighting a war with Iraq we did not forbid the sale of food and medicines to that country. Yet with the passage of the Cuban Democracy Act we tightened the United States embargo against Cuba to include the sale of food and medicines. All reports emanating from Cuba have indicated such a rapid decline in living standards that, as we recently witnessed, many Cubans were willing to flee the island in very rickety homemade vessels under extremely adverse conditions.
Having spent 16 years researching and writing about the Cuban health care system and its biotechnology capacity, I am distressed by the near-collapse of what was once the premier health care system in the third world and one that rivaled those of many developed countries.
Rather than embargo the sale of food and medicine, we should be helping the Cubans preserve what they can of this extraordinary health infrastructure. Moreover, the United States pharmaceutical industry would like to get a toehold in Cuba to avail itself of Cuba's capacity in biotechnology and biomedical research and development.
For humanitarian as well as economic reasons, the United States should rethink its Cuba policy and, at a minimum, lift the embargo, particularly on the sale of food and medicines.
 
JULIE M. FEINSILVER
Washington, Oct. 31, 1994
 
The writer is author of "Healing the Masses: Cuban Health Politics at Home and Abroad" (Berkeley, 1993).
