SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 2117 words

HEADLINE: Chilly Partners -- A special report.;
Saudi Arabia, Its Purse Thinner, Learns How to Say 'No' to U.S.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO with ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Defense Secretary William J. Perry was pitching hard, but Prince Sultan was unreceptive.
After a late-night banquet of roasted meats and exotic fruit juices at the Saudi Defense Minister's palace in Jidda last month, the talk turned to money. 
 The Americans asked the Saudis to pay a substantial part of the $500 million bill for the recent American troop buildup in the Persian Gulf and to base dozens of American tanks and planes permanently in the desert kingdom to save time and money in the event of another Iraqi threat.
But Prince Sultan argued that Saudi Arabia was hard up for cash, in part because it was buying billions of dollars of American military equipment. And in a rare breach of Saudi politesse, he suggested that the United States had taken advantage of Saudi Arabia's vulnerability during the last Persian Gulf crisis by overbilling Riyadh for its share of the cost.
Mr. Perry and his team have since concluded that the Saudis will be slow to open up their wallets and that the American proposal to store an armored brigade's worth of equipment is dead. The Pentagon has opened negotiations with the United Arab Emirates to keep the equipment there instead.
"The Saudis have a very nice way of doing things," said Joseph S. Nye Jr., Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs and a participant in the meeting. "They say, 'We'll consider it.' It is not their style to say no. But when you listen to the answers you don't hear yes. They gave a very gracious answer that I thought was no and others thought was no."
That attitude reflects the strains in a complicated and sometimes contradictory relationship with an oil-rich kingdom that has been made cash poor by the 1991 war against Iraq, lower oil prices, a decade of budget deficits and arguably the most generous welfare state in the world.
For decades Saudi Arabia has been Washington's most dependable oil supplier and its most important ally in the Gulf -- secretly financing the contra rebels in Nicaragua for the Reagan Administration, playing host to half a million American troops to help the Bush Administration fight the war against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, and working behind the scenes with the Clinton Administration to move the gulf Arab states closer to Israel.
The relationship, reconstructed in interviews with Administration and Saudi officials, lawmakers and independent experts, is so important that President Clinton regularly chats with King Fahd on the phone and American Cabinet officials line up to visit him.
That trend was capped at a sprawling Saudi military base last Friday by the first face-to-face meeting between Mr. Clinton and the King. The King was gratified that a man young enough to be his son asked for advice on the Middle East peace effort, and told aides afterwards that unlike President Bush, whom he admired but found rather distant, "I can feel the warmth of the personality of this President."
Yet the Saudis wield so much power over Washington that they can snub President Clinton by rejecting his choice of Ambassador and force the Pentagon to scratch plans for ambitious military exercises merely by expressing reservations.
And the clash between the Administration's goals -- preaching fiscal restraint and economic reform while at the same time pitching billions of dollars in sales -- has sent mixed signals to the Saudi kingdom.
 
The Consumer
Buy Now, Pay Later
 
 
It is hard to overestimate the importance of Saudi Arabia to the United States military.
The kingdom has become the largest single customer for American military contractors, now that the Pentagon isn't buying much. With $30 billion in orders since 1990, it has almost single-handedly kept alive the M1-A2 tank lines of General Dynamics in Ohio and the F-15 fighter plane lines of McDonnell-Douglas in Missouri.
But the Administration got a surprise warning last December when the Saudis approached Washington with a blunt and embarrassing message: Riyadh was so short of cash that it could not meet its payments and asked Washington to help reschedule its debt.
Tortuous negotiations over the next three months at the Saudi Embassy in Washington and at the palaces in Riyadh and Jidda produced only temporary relief: an agreement with five of the largest American military contractors to stretch out $9.2 billion due over five years instead of two.
As part of the arrangement, the Administration came up with a plan to stop American suppliers from selling the Saudis more military equipment. It has refused to approve any new Saudi purchases, and about 15 deals proposed by American companies have been turned down.
With much higher military bills coming due next year, the Pentagon last week dispatched a high-level team to Saudi Arabia to open a new round of lengthy negotiations.
Lieut. Gen. Thomas Rhame, the head of the Defense Security Assistance Agency, the arm of the Pentagon that oversees weapons sales, told Saudi budget planners: commit to a payment schedule or face further delays or possible cancellation of the orders for planes, tanks and Patriot missile batteries rolling off American assembly lines.
"This building has acted very responsibly in seeing itself as the protector of the Saudi alliance over the long term, rather than as an arms merchant in the short term," Mr. Nye said.
While the Pentagon acts as an important middleman in brokering arms sales to the kingdom, senior generals see the permanent basing of enough American military equipment to support a brigade as even more crucial to the alliance.
But just as the Saudis have consistently refused to sign a cooperative military agreement with the United States, they have resisted attempts to store American armor and military equipment on their soil.
Under pressure from conservative Islamic groups who opposed the American presence, King Fahd turned down a request from the Bush Administration to build a permanent American base in the kingdom after the Persian Gulf war.
Even the recent Iraqi movement of troops to the Kuwaiti border failed to sway the Saudis. This time around, the decision to say no was based as much on the price tag attached to the plan as on the political sensitivity.
The Saudis were even reluctant to hold joint military exercises with the United States, in part because they cost so much. In early October, Lieut. Gen. Richard I. Neal, the deputy commander of the United States Central Command, shelved plans to hold major air and land exercises in the kingdom and moved them to Kuwait instead. And Pentagon planners have found themselves questioning every maneuver in Saudi Arabia for fear that they will not be reimbursed.
 
The Merchant
 
 
The President As Pitchman
 
 
As Pentagon officials urge Saudis to stay a sound financial course, they chafe at the Administration's other campaign, the promotion of American business in the kingdom.
Almost from the day he became President, Mr. Clinton has played the role of salesman. Warren Christopher's first trip as Secretary of State included a stop in Saudi Arabia where he asked King Fahd to buy American commercial jets. Two phone calls from Mr. Clinton to the King and two cabinet-level visits later, the King promised to buy $6 billion in planes from the Boeing Company and the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation.
Similarly, it was Mr. Clinton's lobbying via Mr. Christopher and others that persuaded the King to give AT&T a $4.1 billion deal to double the Saudi telecommunications capacity by 2000.
It is mega-deals like these that have convinced Commerce Secretary Ron Brown that the doomsayers on the Saudi economy are wrong. "There has been unnecessary alarmism" by "some unsophisticated people," said Mr. Brown, who has made two trips to Saudi Arabia to help clinch the deals.
"We have full confidence in their economy and their ability to meet their obligations." But eight months after Mr. Clinton announced the jetliner agreement at an unusual White House ceremony, the Saudis and the plane manufacturers are deadlocked over how to finance the deal.
Even Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen does not seem to agree wholeheartedly with Mr. Brown's boosterism. When Mr. Bentsen visited the kingdom last month, he came armed with position papers stating that the Saudi budget deficit was too high and that the Saudis did not understand the depth of their economic problem.
Although he praised the King for his 19 percent budget cut last year and his pledge to cut the same amount next year, he urged him to eliminate the cradle-to-grave welfare system that spares his subjects income taxes but gives them interest-free home loans, free electricity, free health care, college educations and discounts on air fares and telephone service.
"I made the King understand that he wasn't alone, that we had some tough choices in our budget, but had done so successfully and it was having a remarkably good effect on our economy," Mr. Bentsen said in an interview.
But Mr. Bentsen's subsequent public statements about what he had told the King in private infuriated King Fahd, who made no secret of his displeasure. "The Saudis were embarrassed," said one White House official. "They get uncomfortable that these issues are raised at all."
 
The Deal
 
 
The Customer Is Always Right
 
 
That concern over Saudi sensitivities has inhibited the Clinton Administration at times from making many demands of its closest ally in the Persian Gulf.
Earlier this year, Saudi Arabia backed secessionists in southern Yemen in their civil war against the Yemen Government in the north, while the Clinton Administration took a more neutral position. Even the Saudis' secret transfer of armored personnel carriers and financing of the rebels' purchase of sophisticated MIG-29 aircraft from Bulgaria prompted no protest from the Administration.
But after the south lost, the Saudis suddenly felt surrounded by enemies -- Yemen in the south, Iraq in the north and Iran in the east. At the Saudis' request, Thomas M. McLarty, then the White House chief of staff, was dispatched on a mission to the kingdom.
"I assured him the basic premise of the relationship is that a threat to the security of the region is a threat to U.S. interests," Mr. McLarty said.
To help maintain the relationship, Mr. Clinton last February quietly withdrew the nomination of Edward W. Gnehm as Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. Mr. Gnehm, an Arabic-speaking career foreign service officer, had been outspoken on human rights and democracy issues as Ambassador to Kuwait during the gulf war; the Saudis wanted someone close to the President.
The Saudis easily approved Mr. Clinton's next choice, Ray Mabus, the former Mississippi Governor who had no Middle East experience but who knew Mr. Clinton well.
"I'm not a professional diplomat, but I do think the fact that I can pick up the phone and call the White House can be very valuable," Mr. Mabus said in a telephone interview from Riyadh.
The Ambassador's relationship with the Saudi royal family has become so close that the King received him recently in his robe and slippers in his private quarters. "You're a member of the family now," a State Department official quoted the King as telling the Ambassador.
It is this kind of intimacy that contributes to the Administration's inclination to allow the Saudis to call the shots.
Although Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser, has defined the stated goal of American policy around the world as enlarging democracies and markets, democratizing the Saudi Kingdom has never been high on Washington's agenda.
From the Administration's viewpoint, opposition to the royal family springs not from democrats but from reactionaries who favor more rather than fewer restrictions.
The issue is so sensitive that Administration officials apologized to the Saudis in late September after a State Department spokesman told reporters that the Administration "does have serious concerns about human rights" because of recent arrests in the Kingdom.
Mr. Christopher has praised the kingdom for working behind the scenes to move the Middle East peace effort forward, and has credited the Foreign Minister, Prince Saud, for urging Saudi Arabia and its five Arab gulf partners in late September to partly lift the economic embargo against Israel.
"The Saudis are a very steady friend," Mr. Christopher said in an interview. "They have a very conservative country which is very supportive of the United States, whether it is the peace process or the congruity of our position towards Iraq and Iraq. In every respect I regard the relationship as excellent."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton met King Fahd in October for the first time, and the Saudi King later spoke of the President with warmth, though relations between their nations have been somewhat strained. SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1715 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
MCA's Impatience With Wary Parent

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT with ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
The top two executives of MCA Inc. arrived in Japan with a bold proposal to invest in an American television broadcast network. They left feeling, to use the words of one of them, as if they had been "treated as children" by their corporate parent, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. And the bad feelings persist nearly two months later.
MCA's 81-year-old chairman and chief executive, Lew R. Wasserman, and 59-year-old president and chief operating officer, Sidney J. Sheinberg, had made the 14-hour flight to Osaka on Sept. 17 for the meeting. They were appalled by the welcome they received the next morning. Matsushita's president, Yoichi Morishita, appeared two hours late -- and only after lower-level Matsushita executives had made clear that they would not consider the proposal. 
 "I don't see any smiling faces," Mr. Morishita reportedly said upon arriving. "I see you have been told."
Mr. Sheinberg, tired and exasperated, retorted, "Mr. Morishita, you are going to go down in history as the man who lost billions of dollars for your company." Several people familiar with the details confirmed this account of the meeting.
The sharp exchange, and Matsushita's rejection earlier this year of an MCA plan to build a Universal Studios theme park in Japan, each involved basic disagreements about business strategy. MCA argued that both plans were crucial for it to keep pace with entertainment conglomerates like the Walt Disney Company and Time Warner Inc.
But deeper emotional issues were involved as well: Both the outspoken Mr. Sheinberg and the patrician Mr. Wasserman were insulted by the way their foreign bosses said no.
"It is very distressing," Mr. Sheinberg said in an interview last week. "I did not feel that we had been treated as adults. I felt that we had been treated as children. Our people were totally demoralized. Matsushita doesn't understand that as the head of a company I have to keep the troops motivated."
All of this can be read as a cautionary tale about the corporate and cultural differences inherent in global mergers. In other respects, the issues are specific to these two companies and the people who run them.
After Osaka, Mr. Sheinberg and Mr. Wasserman insisted on a meeting in San Francisco, threatening to quit unless they were given greater autonomy. The meeting on Oct. 18 was an occasion to voice sentiments that might normally indicate two sides can no longer cooperate. Still, it may be that neither parent nor child has any alternative but to keep their dysfunctional family together.
Matsushita, which makes consumer electronics equipment, desperately wants the films, TV shows and music that its American subsidiary pumps out. Losing MCA's management would destabilize the company that Matsushita acquired in 1990 for $6.1 billion. And selling MCA, as Matsushita is said by people close to the company to be weighing, would be a painful defeat for its long-term agenda and a blow to its pride.
For their part, Mr. Wasserman and Mr. Sheinberg preside over a glamorous empire featuring Universal Pictures, Universal Studios theme parks in Hollywood and Orlando, Fla., and music labels that include Geffen Records and MCA. The two men's combined years at the company -- Mr. Wasserman has run MCA Inc. since 1946, Mr. Sheinberg has been president since 1973 -- give them stature and influence in Hollywood that would be impossible to duplicate elsewhere.
"Right now, our positions are rather apart, but we are convinced that our policies based on Matsushita tradition are right," Tsuzo Murase, who heads the Matsushita committee that oversees MCA, said last week in a telephone interview from Osaka, the most extensive public explanation the company has given on the matter. "We have exchanged our opinions, but we cannot find the compromising point."
Though the Matsushita executives who engineered the acquisition are no longer in power, the company's management remains firm about wanting Mr. Wasserman and Mr. Sheinberg to run MCA. But the Americans are confused by MCA's owners. "Why did they want us to stay, if they were not going to listen to us?" Mr. Sheinberg asked.
Mr. Wasserman, a tough but courtly executive who is one of the country's longest-reigning corporate chairmen, is said to be as angry as Mr. Sheinberg, though far more guarded. He declined to be interviewed for this article.
There were seeds of trouble in the 1990 deal, which was arranged by Michael Ovitz, the head of the Creative Artists Agency. Mr. Ovitz analyzed the entertainment industry for Matsushita and identified MCA as the best acquisition target, but Mr. Sheinberg and Mr. Wasserman did not meet with Matsushita's then-president, Akio Tanii, and Masahiko Hirata, the executive vice president overseeing the deal, until fairly late in the negotiations.
At the time, as now, Matsushita's management exemplified a traditional Japanese approach of making decisions slowly and carefully, after coming to a management consensus. MCA is typical of the fast-paced American approach, where top executives often make quick decisions and act upon them immediately.
Certainly the Texas-born Mr. Sheinberg, a lawyer by training, has a decisive, if blunt, style that even admiring associates say can sometimes border on abusiveness. That manner may have lost him some credibility with his Japanese superiors, one executive who has worked with Japanese companies said.
But for all his bluster, Mr. Sheinberg has also shown a capacity to build long-term business relationships. Aside from his association with Mr. Wasserman, there is his role as mentor and friend to the film maker Steven Spielberg and the entertainment entrepreneur David Geffen. It was Mr. Sheinberg who made the $550 million deal for Geffen Records in 1989 in just four days.
The following year, Mr. Sheinberg played a crucial role in completing the sale to Matsushita. Seeing the consolidation in the entertainment industry, Mr. Sheinberg was eager to merge with a wealthy corporation that could finance MCA's growth.
Thus, it came as a shock in 1991, when Matsushita quashed MCA's first move under the new owners: a proposed $600 million acquisition of Virgin Records. After that, Mr. Sheinberg minded the store for two years, without seeking other deals.
At the same time, events occurred that did not favor the MCA-Matsushita relationship. The father of the merger, Mr. Tanii, left his post in 1993 in the wake of a corporate scandal. Meanwhile, Japan's "bubble economy" was bursting.
For several years, MCA's management prepared volumes of material and held a series of meetings with Matsushita, leaving Mr. Sheinberg hopeful that MCA would make an equity investment of about $50 million for 20 percent of a Japanese theme-park venture that other companies would be invited to join.
"There are not that many things that are as special to MCA as its theme parks," Mr. Sheinberg said. "It was as if we were bringing our favored child to Mom and Dad's family house."
At a meeting in Osaka in June, however, Matsushita's new management spurned the child. Instead, for reasons Mr. Sheinberg said were not fully explained, Matsushita ruled that MCA should merely present itself to Japanese investors as the manager of the proposed theme park, rather than an owner.
Mr. Sheinberg grudgingly acquiesced, but he is bitter, believing Matsushita strung him along. He believes it was a relatively small investment for potentially high returns in a business in which MCA has had stunning success.
Mr. Murase, the Matushita executive who directly oversees MCA, said: "Matsushita's main business is electronics and the project is a sideline for us. If the bubble economy had not collapsed, maybe the situation would have been better. In all of Japan, everybody is suffering from diminished asset value. It is not the situation to be aggressively spending money."
Indeed, what comes through in comments from Matsushita's management is an exasperation with MCA's desire for deals the parent company feels are unnecessary.
The network proposal is such a case. Mr. Sheinberg and Mr. Wasserman had requested a special meeting with the 58-year-old president, Mr. Morishita, to discuss MCA's interest in buying 25 percent of a American television network. (Foreign companies cannot own more than 25 percent of a United States broadcaster.) The plan was a project of Mr. Wasserman, who developed it with Rand V. Araskog, the chairman of the ITT Corporation, which seeks to enter the broadcasting business.
And so, when Mr. Morishita arrived late to the meeting only to say "I see you've been told," the Americans were outraged at what they perceived as imperious treatment.
Matsushita officials, who say they regret that their guests were offended, offer a different interpretation. Mr. Morishita arrived late, Mr. Murase said, because he had been attending a special board meeting convened that morning to consider this "sudden proposal." The board meeting ran longer than expected.
Mr. Murase said the board rejected MCA's plan because it was uncertain about the future of the television networks in an era of shifting entertainment technologies. It also wondered if there would be enough profit in network-TV production, since Universal's own TV business is far from MCA's strongest division.
Matsushita also feared a backlash. "When Sony bought Columbia Pictures, the American media all said Sony bought American culture," Mr. Murase noted. "We do not want to take actions that would cause extra controversy."
To Mr. Sheinberg, "it was not just what they did, but the style," he said. "The meeting was not called to hear our presentation, but to tell us all the reasons for turning the deal down," he added.
Mr. Sheinberg said that Mr. Morishita apologized at the Osaka meeting and again in San Francisco, when Mr. Sheinberg and Mr. Wasserman threatened to quit.
No one involved is willing to predict what will happen, just as no one on the outside can imagine Mr. Sheinberg and Mr. Wasserman leaving jobs so intertwined with their professional and personal identities.
As for their bosses in Osaka, "we really hope we can recover the past good relationship," Mr. Murase said. "We are thinking about how to recover the mutual trust."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: COMPTROLLER;
Candidates Lament Tone, But Attack Just the Same

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WOODBURY, L.I., Nov. 3

 BODY:
They lamented the bitter tone of the campaign and insisted that they wanted to talk more about issues, but the two candidates for New York State comptroller fired off a steady stream of personal attacks tonight in the last of six televised debates.
H. Carl McCall, the Democratic incumbent who three days ago appeared with supporters accusing the Republican, Herbert London, of engaging in racial attacks, was silent on that issue tonight. But he opted instead to rip into his opponent for what he portrayed as Mr. London's stand against abortion rights and gun control. 
 For his part, Mr. London defended his tactics of recent weeks, which have drawn fire from both Republicans and Democrats, and said he was only trying to defend himself in a fight Mr. McCall started.
"I have been criticized for trying to answer the blatant lies that have appeared in Mr. McCall's ads," he said as the half-hour debate began here at News 12 Long Island, a local television station. "When I have done so, I have been charged with race baiting. Now you have to understand who precipitated the issues."
After the debate, Mr. London did say he regretted the use of the words "Kill the Jews," which appeared in one television ad for his campaign that was never broadcast but was released to news organizations. McCall supporters have accused Mr. London, who is Jewish, of trying to suggest that Mr. McCall, who is black, is anti-Semitic.
Mr. McCall, who was appointed comptroller by the Legislature last spring, focused his message in the debate on the newspapers that have endorsed him in recent days, and continued to charge that the comptroller's job was not the first choice of Mr. London, who had run for the Republican nomination for Governor.
"It is true," Mr. McCall said. "For many years, Mr. London, Professor London has been pursuing this idea of being governor. He said he did not want to be comptroller."
But Mr. London said that after losing the nomination for governor, he decided he wanted to be comptroller to influence the state's fiscal policies, especially to reduce taxes. Questioning his rival's credibility, Mr. London continued to charge that Mr. McCall has politicized the office, that he lacks independence and that the state's investments have suffered under his tenure.
"The role of comptroller is a role of independence," he said. "It does have something to do with fiscal integrity. It does have something to do with telling the truth. Mr. McCall fails in the last category."
On several more substantive issues, there was little controversy. Both men agreed that the state should take over escalating Medicaid costs. Both men expressed reservations about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, with Mr. McCall saying he was concerned how it would affect state debt and Mr. London saying the real solution to high utility rates is competition among power producers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: H. Carl McCall, left, and Herbert London met in their final television debate on Long Island yesterday. There was rancor over personal attacks, but little controversy over the issues, like Medicaid costs and state debt. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: WEST VIRGINIA;
The Race That Invective Forgot

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARDING HILL, W.Va., Oct. 28

 BODY:
Without a calendar, one could hardly guess that an election was in the offing.
On this brilliant autumn afternoon in the russet foothills of the Appalachians, Senator Robert C. Byrd was doing what he does best: waxing poetic about the glories of his state while he inaugurated something else in his name, the Robert C. Byrd Highway. 
 In a campaign season marked elsewhere by high-decibel invective against power and privilege, the Senate race here is tranquility itself, with Mr. Byrd, ever courtly and meticulous in his three-piece suits, floating effortlessly toward his seventh term.
Since he became chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee in 1989, Mr. Byrd has surpassed his goal of becoming "West Virginia's billion-dollar industry." He has in fact steered $1.5 billion to his home state, most of it for roads. And so his visits home are not campaign events so much as victory laps.
As he stood here, slicing a yellow ribbon to open a 12.7-mile segment of the new four-lane highway to Elkins, in the northeastern part of the state, his target was less the Republican who wants his job than those whom he describes as the "muddle-headed critics" in Washington who deride him as the "king of pork."
"On Tuesday, Nov. 8, you're going to have an opportunity to talk back to those critics in Washington," he reminded the crowd. "Tell those critics what you think of the West Virginia infrastructure."
A few protesters were on hand, but they were against extending the highway an additional 114 miles through the scenic mountains to Virginia, not necessarily against Senator Byrd. Kevin Woodcock, a 34-year-old graphic artist holding a protest banner, said he would have to "dig down way deep" before voting against the incumbent. "I'm a Democrat," he said simply. So are two-thirds of the state's voters and almost all of its elected officials.
The 76-year-old Mr. Byrd seems completely immune to the political Zeitgeist that is running this year against Democrats and incumbents and in favor of term limits. He was first elected to the Senate in 1958 and has served longer there than any other current Democrat, and only four years less than Strom Thurmond, the 91-year-old Republican from South Carolina.
The secret to his longevity?
"He is our greatest economic asset," said Don Marsh, retired editor of The Charleston Gazette.
In this hardscrabble mountain state, which ranks higher in many poverty indexes than in self-esteem, Senator Byrd revels unabashedly in bringing home the bacon.
"All roads, they say, lead to Rome," he told a rapt audience at the Logan Country Club the other night. "They haven't seen anything yet. All roads lead to Logan."
Having brought thousands of Federal jobs to the state, he has a good head start on transplanting the entire Government to West Virginia. Already to his credit: a new F.B.I. Identification Center, the Treasury Department's Bureau of Public Debt, an I.R.S. processing center, a Fish and Wildlife training center, a Coast Guard computer operations center, and a branch of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. Dozens of other projects, including scholarships, locks and dams, and research centers, bear his name.
His office does not keep -- or at least does not distribute -- a master list of everything that Mr. Byrd has won for his state. "It would be a full-time job to keep it current," said an aide, Ann Adler.
Still, people here are fully aware of all he has accomplished.
"His campaigning was done in Washington," said Bob Phalen, president of United Mine Workers District 17, in southern West Virginia. Mr. Phalen said the state had been beaten down for so long by outside interests' extracting its rich natural resources that it was proud and grateful for what Senator Byrd could extract from Washington.
"People think it's their due," said Evelyn Harris, chairman of the political science department at the University of Charleston.
The Senator plays on this theme with his audiences. He reminds them that while they may receive a little something extra from Washington, they give, too. "You, the Federal taxpayers of this country, have invested $7 billion -- that's billion with a B -- for the mass transit system in Washington," he said in Logan. "Now that's pork."
"What I'm doing" in contrast, he said, "is spreading good seed that will bear fruit a hundredfold," ending West Virginia's isolation, spurring development and keeping the state's youth from looking elsewhere for jobs. "Prosperity flows along concrete rivers," he said.
But his inspiring the state with optimism only partly explains why Senator Byrd is so revered here. An orphan who grew up dirt poor, he is a self-made man, up from the coal fields, and his story gives others hope that they can make it too.
"He's a real class act," said John Skidmore, 41, one of the few Republicans in Logan, who brought his son Andrew, 14, to hear Mr. Byrd at the country club.
"He is one of a final breed of orator," said Mr. Skidmore, who despite his Republican allegiance acknowledged that he would vote for the Senator.
Speaking of Republicans, there is one running against Mr. Byrd. He is Stan Klos, a 40-year-old restorer of public buildings who is a newcomer to politics.
Mr. Klos said he was deliberately keeping a low profile in hopes that Democrats would not turn out on Election Day, thus allowing him to slip through.
The reason he is running, he said, is that the state, despite its infusion of cash, "still ranks first in unemployment, third in poverty and fifth from the bottom in life expectancy, proving that government, no matter how powerful, can't create jobs and prosperity."
But Mr. Klos said he would not campaign against the Senator. "How far out in left field can he be," the challenger said, "if he can bring $1.5 billion to the state?"

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: NEW YORK LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR;
McCaughey, the G.O.P. Stealth Candidate

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
It was 9:30 A.M. and Elizabeth P. McCaughey, the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor, had already downed a hamburger and two bagels and given the family chihuahua a bath. This was, after all, a big day.
The woman billed as her ticket's policy expert said she is usually buried in documents. "Do you ever look at this one?" she said at one point, holding up the Annual Statistical Report from 1992 of the New York State Department of Social Services. "It's a gold mine." 
 But on this day, her job was political. After months of being nearly invisible, she was on a statewide tour to say that a vote for B. Thomas Golisano, the Independence Fusion candidate for governor, was a vote for "four more years of economic decline." Her mission: to help stem a decline of her ticketmate, State Senator George E. Pataki.
"I know we've both tried very hard to get the message out," she said Sunday on a tiny plane over central New York. "I certainly have been working very hard."
Then, after a brief silence, she looked up from her papers and began a new conversation, an explosion of facts that was her favorite way of chatting: "Nineteen percent of all TB cases are drug resistant," she said, as if to underscore her commitment to the issues rather than politics of the campaign. "That means they are fatal."
Where Mr. Pataki tends toward the stiff and the scripted, Ms. McCaughey (pronounced McCoy), 46, leans toward spontaneous candor, which the Pataki campaign has taken steps to stamp out. Where Mr. Pataki dwells in the vague, Ms. McCaughey -- who earned a spot on the ticket for her published critique this year on the Clinton health care plan -- is often so specific that her listeners' eyes glaze over.
Now, as Mr. Pataki faces criticism for failing to define himself or his beliefs, some Republicans think that Ms. McCaughey could help voters connect with the ticket. The political newcomer exudes a wide-eyed optimism about what Republicans could achieve, which some think could be contagious.
"She believes in the tooth fairy, honey," said Fran Werner, the Queens County Republican chairwoman, who said the Pataki campaign has underused Ms. McCaughey. "She is starry-eyed and bushy-tailed talking about politics. She thinks the whole world is going to see the light. But the whole world isn't seeing the light about Betsy McCaughey. To me, this is one of the biggest mistakes of the campaign."
And after months of working on policy positions that she concedes have not become a part of the campaign, she has become more visible. She has an advertisement on television; she spent a weekend going across the state attacking Mr. Golisano, and on Wednesday, she stood beside another Elizabeth, Mr. Pataki's wife, to defend the candidate's support for abortion rights.
Republican officials and strategists say it is not unusual for a candidate for lieutenant governor to play only a small role in a gubernatorial campaign.
Ms. McCaughey's low profile, however, has been noticeable given the fanfare with which she was chosen as the running mate last spring. A scholar at the conservative Manhattan Institute, she was billed as the ideal combination of brains and glamour: the daughter of a factory worker who won a scholarship to Vassar, she earned a doctorate in constitutional history from Columbia and now counts as friends Henry Kissinger and Laurence Tisch, the CBS chairman.
Still, she became a Republican only two years ago, and Ms. McCaughey was chosen for the second spot on the ticket largely because of the mini-celebrity she earned earlier this year. She sat with a copy of the President's 1,342-page health care plan, then dissected it brutally in The New Republic and The Wall Street Journal, saying it would limit access to health care.
After the Republican convention, she and Mr. Pataki stumped for a few days, then she virtually dropped out of sight. Most speculation has been that her colorful spontaneity -- she has, for instance, compared herself to Barbie, and Mr. Pataki to Ken -- did not fit into a campaign that has taken few chances and said little about what it would do if elected.
That control was on display in September when Ms. McCaughey called a news conference to release a study on taxes and job loss in New York. When a reporter asked how she would cut spending, Ms. McCaughey said confidently, "Let me give you some examples."
She went on to say that New York could save over $150 million by reducing the cost of administering welfare to children and families. As a way to save money on Medicaid, the single largest burden on local governments, she has suggested increasing payments to doctors, to encourage them to take on more poor people as patients. She has also looked at reforming workers' compensation, home relief, and Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield, as well as tighter rules on work release for prisoners.
Her statements now are less prescriptions for change than detailed diagnoses, but she said she is deep into developing plans for after Election Day. "We have to be prepared to govern, not just campaign," she said as the plane buzzed toward the first stop of the day, in Cortland.
Ms. McCaughey, who is divorced, is dating Wilbur Ross Jr., the lawyer and investor, who is a financial contributor to the Cuomo and Moynihan campaigns. She has three daughters.
Her day on the stump was long, with stops in Cortland, Elmira and, finally, Jamestown, where Mr. Lundine was once the mayor. She was greeted by small, enthusiastic crowds, who nonetheless had their share of questions about what a Pataki governorship would mean to them.
"I wish it wasn't all ending in 10 days," she said at one point. "I guess I'm a much more social person than I thought. I used to spend 10 to 12 hours in my office. But I like traveling the state, shaking hands and listening to what they have to say."
On the way back to the city, as the twin propellers droned on the flight from Jamestown, she suggested a game of hangman using movie titles. One title stumped her and Neville Bugwadia, her assistant from her days at the Manhattan Institute.
"We're getting hung, Neville," she said. "And we're the ticket that believes in the death penalty."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elizabeth P. McCaughey, left, the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor of New York, is a font of statistics, and some say the Pataki ticket's hidden weapon. She was joined in Manhattan Wednesday by Libby Pataki, the wife of the candidate for governor. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Detroit Sets Truck Records As Vehicle Sales Jump 8.9%

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Drawn by the fresh curves of some 1995 vehicles and the reduced prices on 1994 models, customers continued to flock to new car dealerships in October, buying 8.9 percent more cars and light trucks than were sold during the brisk period a year earlier, the auto makers reported today.
During October, the first month of the 1995 model year, sales of cars rose 2.9 percent, to 738,221, while sales of light trucks -- pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles -- rose 18.8 percent, to 525,285. 
 "This is a continuation of steady growth -- not boom, not bust," said John Casesa, the auto industry analyst for Wertheim Schroder in New York. "I know the market is in agony about whether we're going into recovery or recession, but I think the auto market shows we're continuing a modest recovery."
Buyers continued to climb out of cars and into trucks; the Big Three domestic auto makers set light-truck sales records for October. But the apparent weakness of car sales in October was exaggerated by production constraints. Because they were switching over to new compact sedan models, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation had few vehicles to offer in that popular segment.
And the General Motors Corporation, which has had the greatest difficulty converting its plants to 1995 model production, was short of midsize and small cars. In October, Chevrolet's car sales plunged 27.3 percent, to 75,684. The drop was mostly a result of a shortage of its redesigned Cavalier small cars, which are assembled in a G.M. plant at Lordstown, Ohio. Chevy sold 27,542 Cavaliers in October 1993; it sold 3,098 last month.
Such production constraints contributed to the Big Three auto makers' loss of three percentage points of car market share last month, while the Japanese auto makers gained almost two points.
To combat the strong yen, the Japanese companies continued to emphasize sales of the cars they assemble in North America, cutting back on their imports.
In that vein, the Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would invest $450 million to more than double capacity at its assembly plant in Cambridge, Ontario. By August 1997, Toyota said, the plant will produce 200,000 small Corolla cars a year, up from 85,000 now.
By the time the expansion is complete, Toyota plans to have hired 1,200 more workers at the plant, which now employs 1,000, and to have stopped importing Corollas from Japan.
Some industry analysts were not so sanguine about the October results. The chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, Tom Webb, said in a statement that the seemingly strong results belie "a certain uneasiness we sense in the market."
He added: "With interest rates on the rise, it will become increasingly difficult to escape the affordability dilemma created by rising vehicle prices and stagnant household income. We don't expect sales to fall off a cliff, but it's time for analysts to rethink those rosy forecasts for 1995 and beyond."
Dealers, however, said they saw little evidence the market was softening. "We're very, very busy," said Bill Curtin, a salesman at Al Packer Ford in West Palm Beach, Fla., which posted its best October sales in 17 years.
Some dealers, particularly G.M. dealers, worried that they could not keep pace with the demand. "We can't keep enough trucks on the lot," said Tony Christensen, a salesman at Gus Paulos Chevrolet in West Valley City, Utah. Customers who choose to order, he said, face a wait of up to three months to receive a Suburban or Blazer sport utility vehicle.
"Customers don't like to wait that long," he said.
The seasonally adjusted selling rate for cars during the month was 7.1 million, the same as in September. The rate for light trucks was 6.0 million, compared with 5.6 million in the previous month. A year earlier, the rate for cars was 7.1 million, and the rate for trucks was 5.3 million.
Those rates are likely to jump in the next two months as the auto makers straighten out their production problems and dealers' stocks rise, said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, an automotive consulting firm in Rutherford, N.J. "The fundamentals are still strong, and stocks are still tight," she said.
Luxury car makers continued to struggle for sales in October. Sales by the Honda Motor Company's luxury division, Acura, dropped 15.9 percent, to 7,649, and sales for Toyota's luxury division, Lexus, fell 13.7 percent, to 6,174. One notable exception was Mercedes-Benz. Its sales jumped 18.3 percent, to 5,856.
In the race to be the best-selling car in the United States, the Ford Taurus finished the month narrowly ahead of the Honda Accord, 316,041 to 313,851.

HEADLINE: Home Sales Rise, Even as Rates Do Too

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Strong labor markets are helping the nation's housing industry defy gravity, keeping it strong even as mortgage rates climb to three-year highs, a Government report showed today.
New single-family home sales in the United States rose an unexpected 2.6 percent in September to the highest level in six months even as mortgage rates climbed to two-year highs, the Commerce Department said. Separately, the Labor Department reported that first-time claims for unemployment insurance dropped last week for the third consecutive decline. 
 On a seasonally adjusted basis, claims fell 3,000 last week to 321,000 after decreasing by 1,000 the previous week to 324,000. The four-week moving average for jobless claims, a less volatile gauge of labor markets, edged up to 324,750 from 324,250. Analysts had expected the week's claims to rise by 1,000.
"If you have the income, you're buying the house," said Carey Leahey, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York. "Rates are a lot less important."
They must be, because the rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to a three-year high this week of 9.05 percent, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported today, and the rate on the average adjustable-rate mortgage rose to 5.91 percent this week from 5.88 percent a week earlier.
The Labor Department is scheduled to report on Friday how the job market fared in October and the unemployment rate for the month.
"The economy is actually accelerating in the fourth quarter," said Brian Wesbury, chief economist at the Chicago investment firm Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson.
 Many analysts said the new data made it almost certain the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates a sixth time this year -- most likely at a Nov. 15 policy meeting -- even though there have been few signs of higher inflation.
The Commerce Department said home sales rose in the Northeast and South but declined in the Midwest and West. The September gain -- to 703,000 at a seasonally adjusted annual rate -- followed a revised 7.9 percent gain in August to 685,000, previously reported as an increase of 9.7 percent. September's level was the highest since 722,000 in March.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Fairly Steady On New Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were reasonably steady yesterday, although the yield on the long bond edged up to a two-and-a-half-year high. Investors remain concerned that inflation could accelerate, causing them to lose value on fixed-income investments.
Yesterday's report showing new- home sales in September were the highest in six months, even as mortgage rates climbed to two-year highs, added to their concerns. 
 The 30-year bond slipped 2/32 , to 9310/32 , for a yield of 8.10 percent, up from 8.09 percent on Wednesday and still at the top of its trading range. One factor that stemmed bonds' slide was that the dollar was steady with the Fed again in the market buying dollars to shore up the currency's value.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's quarterly refunding, the three-year note was trading at a price to yield 7.34 percent and the 10-year to yield 7.95 percent.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisors, said trading was cautious ahead of today's employment numbers, which the consensus says should be up about 230,000.
"I'm expecting something slightly less," Mr. Battipaglia added, "with the unemployment rate unchanged." Anything less than the consensus would be very good near term for bonds, he said.
On Nov. 15 the Fed will hold its Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Coming after next week's elections "will clear the plate for the Fed and allow it to do a 50-basis-point rate hike," Mr. Battipaglia said. "What is unfolding is that the economy is growing smartly, with inflation showing a tendency to whip here and there. And the thinking may be that another half-point now may be the right tonic for the economy, with the side benefit being support for the dollar."
In the morning, debt futures slid to the day's lows with the cash market trailing, following an unexpected 2.6 percent rise in the September new- home sales to 703,000. The market forecast had been a drop to 680,000.
While the home sales were well above forecasts, the downward revision for the prior month took some of the sting out of the latest report. Other data for the September period, starts, permits, and existing-home sales, had already tipped off the market to the resilience of the housing industry in this the year of rising interest rates, so the impact on the market was minimal, traders said.
Neither did the market find much inspiration from other economic news yesterday -- jobless claims and chain store sales data. Chain store sales were a little on the soft side, according to analysts, but still close to expectations. Initial claims fell 3,000, to 321,000, for the week ended Oct. 29,, just slightly lower than expected.
Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, the Republic of South Africa announced yesterday that it had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $2 billion in debt, marking its re-entry into the international capital markets. Standard & Poor's rates the country's debt at BB, two notches below investment grade.
The republic's first offering under the shelf registration is expected to be a global deal in dollar-denominated securities through Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Swiss Bank Corporation as joint lead managers.
And as rates steadied yesterday, the Banc One Corporation priced for sale $2 billion of fixed-rate securities backed by credit cards. The Columbus, Ohio, banking company issued the securities in three maturities, two- , three- and four-year notes, through Bear, Stearns & Company.
Asset-backed securities have found plenty of buyers amid a decline in corporate bond sales this year. According to MCM/Corporate Watch, corporations have sold $108 billion of debt in the first nine months of the year, down 52 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.
Underwriters priced the senior debt to yield from 7.292 percent for a two-year to 7.947 percent for a four-year, while the subordinated debt was priced to yield from 7.497 percent for a two-year to 8.148 percent for a four-year. The senior debt is rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, while the sub debt is rated A-2 and A, respectively.

HEADLINE: Auto and Retail Issues Lead Climb in Stocks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Led by automobile and retailing issues, stocks edged up yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 Index to their first gains in four days.
Even so, the market's performance was erratic, prompting concern that the rise in interest rates has sapped many investors' confidence. 
 "We've been living with this type of market for six months," said John Brooks, director of sales and marketing at the Notley Group in Atlanta. "People are a lot more nervous than they are saying they are."
The Dow industrials, which initially fell as much as 3.7 points, rose 8.75, to 3,845.88, adding most of its gain in the last 10 minutes of trading. Shares of Sears Roebuck & Company, the Walt Disney Company and the General Motors Corporation led the advance, in part because of better-than expected sales reports. Disney stock advanced 1 1/8, to 40.
Among broader stock market indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 1.40, to 467.91 after losing 1.91, to 466.51, yesterday.
The Nasdaq Combined Composite Index rose 0.28, to 772.10, after being up as much as 1.71, at 773.53. Declines were posted in the Intel Corporation, down 5/8, to 61 7/8; U S Healthcare Inc., off 1 5/8, to 44 1/8, and the Microsoft Corporation, down 3/8, to 62 5/8.The MCI Communications Corporation advanced 3/8, to 22 3/4; Price/Costco Inc. was up 7/8, to 16 3/8, and Tele-Communications Inc. had a gain of 3/8, to 20 3/4.
Shares of auto companies rebounded after being "blown apart over the last month" amid concern about profitability in G.M.'s North American operations and the car maker's future sales, said Jay Ferguson, market analyst at Ferguson, Andrews & Associates in Charlottesville, Va.
Yesterday, that concern eased after G.M. said it sold 1.3 percent more cars last month than it did a year earlier. Shares of G.M. rose 7/8, to 39 1/8; Chrysler edged up 1/2, to 48, and Ford added 1/2, to 29 5/8.
Robust sales among retailers buoyed their shares.
Shares of Best Buy, which gained 26 percent, soared 3 3/8, to 42; Ann Taylor, with a 20 percent rise, jumped 1 1/4, to 44 1/4; the Limited Inc. rose 1 3/4, to 20 3/4; Gap Inc. added 2 5/8, to 36 1/4; Sears, Roebuck spurted 1 1/8, to 49 1/2, and the Dayton Hudson Corporation skyrocketed 4 3/8, to 81 7/8.
"Retailers that specialize in or are very strong in home-oriented merchandise did exceptionally well, on the whole," said Kurt Barnard, publisher of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report.
Bank stocks gained as investors bet that the demand for capital would continue to grow as the economy rebounds.
"The economy has reached the point now that if it continues to expand, you're going to see companies having to borrow money," said Paul Mackey, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds who follows the industry.
The BankAmerica Corporation jumped 1, to 43 1/2; the Bankers Trust New York Corporation was up 5/8, tot 64 3/4, and the Nationsbank Corporation rose 5/8, to 49 1/2.
Advancing stocks equaled decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, where about 285.2 million shares traded hands as of 4 P.M. The three-month average volume is 292 million shares.
The Amex Market Value Index added 0.39, to 454.57.
Investors were reluctant to place big bets on stocks before today's October employment report, traders said. If the report shows signs that the economy is expanding too fast, the Fed's policy-making committee may be more likely to vote to raise interest rates at its meeting Nov. 15.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Warm Weather Slowed Retail Sales in October

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Mother Nature seems determined to keep merchants guessing about their prospects for the all-important holiday sales season, which officially begins the day after Thanksgiving.
The nation's chain stores said unseasonally balmy weather in several parts of the country contributed to slowing sales in October, the same reason they gave for September's weak performance. 
 But analysts dismissed October's plodding pace, retaining their optimism that the holiday season, when most retailers realize the bulk of their profits for the year, will bring strong sales.
"If the weather in September and October inhibited demand for wool sweaters, it tells you absolutely nothing about business in November and December," said Edward A. Weller, a retailing analyst for Robertston, Stephens & Company.
Mr. Weller and many other analysts are counting on broader economic trends like low unemployment rates and increases in disposable income to drive holiday business. The estimates for sales growth during the holiday season range from 5 percent to 8.5 percent higher than last year's level.
Retailers, on the other hand, are not waiting for brisk business to materialize. Several are already offering promotions and decking their halls with holly.
Food Emporium is already selling Christmas candy, Toys "R" Us issued its first coupon book during the first week of October and the Express store on West 57th Street in Manhattan was hanging large glass ornaments in its windows yesterday.
"That's just Retailing 101," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retailing analyst for Salomon Brothers. "They've been promoting for the holidays since September, but that's nothing new."
The Salomon Brothers Same-Store Sales Growth index, a weighted average of sales increases reported by 22 large retailing companies, climbed just 3.8 percent in October. Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least one year, are considered the best measure of a retailer's performance because they factor out the impact of new stores, which have uneven sales patterns.
The first week of November has also been unusually warm in the Midwest and Northeast, and weather forecasters have predicted a warm weekend. If retailers are correct and warm weather discourages sales, which is a matter of some debate in the industry, this month is not off to a great start.
"All in all, I'm remaining cautious about the holiday outlook, because October certainly didn't show results that would make me jump up and down," said Susan Silverstein, a retailing analyst for Gruntal & Company.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the largest retailer in the United States, said sales in its discount stores that had been open at least a year climbed 4.9 percent, lagging behind their usual growth pace. The J. C. Penney Company's comparable-store sales also increased less dramatically than usual, rising 4.5 percent.
The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, which has outperformed its competitors all year, was the clear winner in October, posting an increase of 20 percent in comparable-store sales. Sears, Roebuck & Company's stores also outpaced the pack, producing an increase of 7 percent in same-store sales that was largely a result of strong sales of hard goods like appliances, snow blowers, shovels and car batteries.
But most companies, including the May Department Stores Company, Dillard Department Stores Inc. and the Kmart Corporation's discount stores that posted sales increases above 3 or 4 percent used heavy markdowns to increase sales. Or, like Ann Taylor, they accepted a slightly lower profit margin on their original prices.
"Those companies that played it tight on inventory got lower sales volumes, but their margins were surprisingly good," said Jeff Edelman, a retailing analyst for C. J. Lawrence.
The stock prices of many retailers rose yesterday on the expectation that in spite of weak sales increases, some retailers expect strong profits. Gap Inc., which had a comparable-store sales increase of only 2 percent in October, was hinting yesterday that most analysts had underestimated its third-quarter earnings, and its stock climbed $2.625 a share, to $36.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Shares of the Limited Inc., which owns Limited, Express and Victoria's Secret, climbed $1.75, or almost 11 percent, to $20.75, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Fed Intervenes for a 2d Day And the Dollar Ends Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen and other leading currencies yesterday after the United States Government entered the foreign-exchange markets to prop up the value of the dollar for a second day.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which acts as the Treasury's agent in the foreign-exchange market, bought an estimated $1 billion yesterday, the same amount thought to have been purchased on Wednesday, traders said. Neither the Treasury nor the Fed normally comments on such interventions. 
 Traders said the Government bought dollars for a second day to underline its commitment to keeping the dollar strong. Many expect the Fed to add muscle to the purchases by raising interest rates, perhaps today.
"People are starting to believe that the U.S. is serious about defending the dollar," said David Durst, a currency options trader at Bear, Stearns & Company. "If the Fed follows this with a rate increase, the dollar will turn around."
Higher rates would ease traders' concern that the Fed has acted too slowly so far this year to control the inflation that often accompanies economic growth. Those concerns have dragged down the prices of Treasury bonds for much of this year. Currency dealers have been following the bond market to gauge foreign demand for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them.
The Fed started buying dollars just after 11 A.M. in New York and made its last purchase around 1:20 P.M., traders said. Other central banks did not assist the Fed yesterday or on Wednesday, they said.
"The Fed just kept buying, wave after wave," said Karl Halligan, vice president for strategic trading at CF-CIC Bank New York. He said the Fed wisely waited until London, the world's largest foreign exchange market, was closing; trading volume was then dwindling, giving the purchases more punch. "It was a smart move by the Fed," Mr. Halligan said.
In New York, the dollar jumped as high as 98.26 yen as the Fed bought, its highest level since Oct. 17, and up from a post-World War II low of 96.12 yen set in intraday trading early yesterday. The dollar settled at 97.72 yen, up from 97.63 yen on Wednesday. The dollar rose as high as 1.5247 marks before finishing at 1.5187 marks, up from 1.5138. The British pound fell to $1.6165 from $1.6225.
But the dollar failed to rise further on the Fed's efforts, in part because Treasury bonds remained weak.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Divergent Prices Recorded For Soybean Meal and Oil

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Soybean meal prices plunged yesterday while soybean oil prices surged.
Other commodity markets were relatively quiet. Gold prices fell, while crude oil moved briefly above $19 a barrel. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities slipped 0.69 point, to 233.92. 
 On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybean oil for December delivery surged 53 cents, to $26.87 for 100 pounds; December meal tumbled $1.10, to $158.50 a ton, the lowest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since Aug. 26, 1987.
The divergent prices of soybean products reflect their different uses. Most soybean oil is consumed by people either as a cooking product at home or in processed foods. Soybean meal is fed to livestock to increase the protein in their mostly corn diet.
Demand for soybean oil has grown steadily in recent years as food makers, restaurants and home cooks have increasingly shunned tallow, butter and tropical oils in favor of vegetable oils with low saturated fat content.
"If you look at a package of crackers now or cookies, you don't see the coconut oils or palm oils," said Joel Karlin, research analyst with Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago. "That's helped domestic demand."
Gold prices declined as expectations grew that the Federal Reserve would move to increase short-term interest rates this month to slow inflation. Gold is a traditional hedge against inflation. On the Commodity Exchange of New York, the December gold contract fell $1.10, to $384.40 an ounce.
Crude oil prices finished slightly lower yesterday. Crude oil for December delivery rose above $19 on the New York Mercantile Exchange before ending at $18.90, down 3 cents.
Unleaded gasoline for December delivery fell 0.57 cent, to 58.95 cents a gallon. Home heating oil for delivery in December rose 0.22 cent, to 51.42 cents a gallon.
Prices were damped somewhat by news that Colonial Pipeline's network of pipelines near Houston, which was washed out in flooding late last month, was restored yesterday.
Colonial's 5,300-mile pipeline system carries two million barrels of petroleum products a day -- or about one-sixth of the United States supply -- and is a key supply point for the Northeast.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Hear Ye! Hear Ye! Four Days of Talks Scheduled

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Negotiators for baseball's striking players and owners agreed yesterday to the most ambitious schedule of bargaining sessions since they began working toward resolving their labor differences.
In a joint scheduling session with Bill Usery Jr., the mediator, in Washington, representatives of the two sides agreed to meet in the Capital next Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday. 
 Usery will hold discussions separately with each side next week before the joint sessions to establish an agenda for the meetings.
Usery was not in his office yesterday, and Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, who was in his office in Milwaukee, said only that negotiations would resume late next week, probably Thursday. He said he was waiting to hear from Usery today.
But a person familiar with what transpired at the meeting in Washington told about the bargaining schedule.
The only time since negotiations began last March that negotiators have met on four successive days was in the first week of August, but at none of those sessions was the core issue -- the owners' demand for a salary cap -- a topic of discussion.
They spent one meeting on a drug program and scheduling, another on the clubs' failure to make a $7.8 million payment to the players' pension and benefit plan, and two meetings on the players' ideas on revenue sharing.
The two sides, sometimes with bargaining subcommittees, met on three consecutive days the following week and four of five days, including Aug. 12, the day the players walked out. Since then, the meetings have been sparse.
Usery began the day yesterday meeting with the owners' negotiating team. He had met for two days last week with union officials, then saw them again Tuesday. After Usery's session with the management group, Donald Fehr, Gene Orza and Lauren Rich of the union joined them to discuss the resumption of joint talks.
Meeting with him yesterday were Richard Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive; two lawyers, Chuck O'Connor and Rob Manfred, and five club owners and executives -- Jerry McMorris of Colorado, John Harrington of Boston, Stan Kasten of Atlanta, Dave Montgomery of Philadelphia and Wendy Selig-Prieb of Milwaukee.
Selig said the same group plus Stu Meyer, formerly of the St. Louis Cardinals, will represent the clubs in the joint sessions next week,
At one of the sessions, the owners are expected to present a new proposal, which would be the first since they formally put their salary-cap plan on the table June 14. Barring a change in what negotiators have told the clubs, the owners will withdraw the $1 billion guarantee as part of their plan to give the players 50 percent of their revenue for salaries and other costs.
The change is necessary because of the drastic change the strike has created in the owners' economy. Instead of an anticipated $1.78 billion in revenue in 1994, the clubs will end up close to $1.2 billion.
The owners have not removed the salary cap from the table because that is the plan they intend to implement if they declare an impasse and unilaterally change the terms and conditions that were part of the expired collective bargaining agreement.
Initially, the clubs had been expected to take that step by Nov. 1, but they encountered problems that would have made it risky for them to implement their own rules without a serious challenge from the union. Then the Clinton Administration asked Usery, a veteran mediator, to become involved, and his presence insured further delay in the owners' declaration of impasse and implementation.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Downhill After the Los Angeles Riots

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
"Am I losing my mind? Am I sick?" worries John Boyz (James Le Gros), the unemployed, 30-something narrator of Peter McCarthy's brave but misguided contemporary satire, "Floundering." The Los Angeles riots have barely subsided, and John, who lives in Venice Beach, is haunted by what he calls a "pervasive feeling of doom." His edgy mood is made worse by his morbid habit of obsessively replaying his own homemade videotapes of the riots. Prominently featured in those videos is Merryl Fence (Nelson Lyon), a Los Angeles police chief who suggests a monstrous caricature of the real-life Daryl F. Gates.
John seems almost eager for disaster to strike, and on one especially terrible day it finally does. In the space of a few hours, he discovers that the Internal Revenue Service has put a lien on his savings account, his unemployment compensation has run out, and his brother has fled a drug rehabilitation clinic. Seeking solace from his girlfriend, Jessica (Lisa Zane), he finds her in bed with another man. 
 John begins losing his grip on reality, and as he does, the movie slips back and forth between reality and fantasy in a way that thoroughly mixes them up. Voices in John's television set address him. His dead parents appear at his bedside and advise prayer. John's descent accelerates when he joins some crack-smoking revolutionaries in front of his apartment building, takes a toke on a pipe, and winds up passed out on the sidewalk for hours while pedestrians gleefully strip him of his valuables. But somehow he is able to muster one last burst of spirit.
The movie, which has several frank sex scenes and profanity, eventually turns into an exhilarated daydream in which the poor and downtrodden of Los Angeles have miraculously organized into a revolutionary army, and John finds love with a woman he has kidnapped. The late-blooming love story seems tacked on and completely out of character.
"Floundering," which opens today at the Quad, is the directorial debut of Mr. McCarthy, a producer associated with such cult favorites as "Repo Man," "Sid and Nancy" and "Tapeheads." The movie, which includes vivid cameo performances by John Cusack, Ethan Hawke and Steve Buscemi, as well as appearances by rock performers like David M. Navarro, Exene Cervenka and Zander Schloss in acting roles, wants to be something like the slacker generation's answer to "Easy Rider."
In the movie's vague but impassioned us-and-them view of Los Angeles, the "us" are symbolized by a Hispanic woman who supports her family collecting soda cans in John's neighborhood. Representing "them" are the fulminating police chief whom John fantasizes assassinating and a smug businessman friend who refuses to lend him money.
Almost everybody in "Floundering" has a pet theory about what's wrong with Los Angeles and a drastic remedy for curing the city's ills. Mr. McCarthy's screenplay includes so many speeches on the subject that the film often takes on the emotionally frustrated tone of a radio talk show. Because the speechifying lacks the cutting comic edge that distinguishes good satire, "Floundering" too often blubbers when it should be viciously funny.

FLOUNDERING
 
Written, produced and directed by Peter McCarthy; director of photography, Denis Maloney; edited by Dody Dorn and Mr. McCarthy; music by Pray for Rain; production designer, Cecilia Montiel; released by Strand Releasing. HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Rural Social Commentary With a Difference

BYLINE: By CHARLES HAGEN 

 BODY:
The images that Doris Ulmann made in the South in the 1920's and 30's occupy a curious position in the history of documentary photography. Ulmann's subjects, among them the mountain people of Appalachia and the blacks of the Gullah region of South Carolina, were staples of socially concerned photography during the New Deal era, whether Margaret Bourke-White's sensationalist reportage for Life magazine or the more measured documentary work of Walker Evans and other photographers working for the Farm Security Administration.
But Ulmann's soft-focus portraits, presented in richly expressive prints made using the platinum process, are distinctly unlike the sharp, detailed images favored by her contemporaries. A diverse selection of Ulmann's powerful but rarely seen images, at the 292 Gallery in SoHo, is a pleasure to see for its own sake, and also valuable as a challenge to the widespread notion that only the sharp-focus approach of Modernism is appropriate for social analysis and critique. 
 Ulmann was born in 1882. She took up photography at 20, studying first with Lewis Hine and later with Clarence H. White. The influence of both men can be seen in her later work, which combines Hine's interest in social issues with White's use of soft focus, dramatic lighting and fine printing to heighten emotional impact.
Ulmann's husband was an orthopedic surgeon, and among her first projects were series of portraits of leading physicians at Columbia and Johns Hopkins universities, as well as pictures of important editors of the day. Gradually she became interested in traditional rural communities, and after 1927 she began to travel the mountain areas of Kentucky, Tennessee and North Carolina with John Jacob Niles; Ulmann photographed the people while Niles collected their traditional folk songs.
Ulmann brought her experience as a portraitist to these pictures, posing the hill folk in typical costumes and often including simple props to indicate the quality of the people's lives. One old woman, dressed in a long gingham dress, stands in front of a spinning wheel as tall as she is; in another picture a woman sits in the doorway of a bare wooden shack, peeling potatoes; in a third, a woman poses with a basket of apples in her lap.
What makes Ulmann's pictures extraordinary is her assured control of lighting and gesture. In a later photograph that may have been taken on the coast of Alabama, the faces of two men pushing a crate of oysters are hidden in shadow, while the oysters themselves glow with light; in another, a man in overalls and a floppy hat sits in a doorway, hands relaxed in his lap, while behind him a bright window can be seen beyond the shadowy interior.
Ulmann's sitters offer themselves to the camera with remarkable dignity, and the photographs portray them with respect, treating them neither as victims nor heros. Instead, Ulmann's subjects were presented as representatives of a way of life threatened by the encroachment of the modern world.
In that light, her work can be seen as a counterpart to Edward S. Curtis's mammoth project in the early years of the century to photograph all aspects of American Indian life. The two photographers shared romantic attitudes toward their subjects, and both tried to preserve images of cultures they feared were on the brink of extinction.
No matter how well intentioned, such preservationist projects risk being patronizing, with photographers implicitly pretending to know what's best for the people being photographed. What saves Ulmann's pictures, though, is her attention to the human beings at their heart: whatever her beliefs may have been about the plight of the culture, she never lost sight of the people in front of her lens.
Before and after her death in 1934, Ulmann's pictures were included in books on folk crafts and the like. But neither Ulmann's soft-focus style nor her undogmatic approach fit in with the prevailing styles of the 1930's, which tended to regard poor Southerners as victims of economic oppression; partly as a result, her pictures fell out of fashion. Only in recent decades have they have come back into view.
Today, as in the 1930's, most documentary photographers rely on the seeming transparency of photographs to give their images the authority of reality. Ulmann's images openly acknowledge their status as pictures, consciously shaped to record scenes in a particular way; with the certainties of Modernism no longer accepted without question, her quietly respectful and unabashedly appealing photographs take on a surprising degree of interest.
Doris Ulmann's photographs remain on view at the 292 Gallery, 120 Wooster Street (near Prince Street), in SoHo, through Dec. 3.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 1933 Doris Ulmann portrait of a woman in Brasstown, N. C. (292 Gallery)

HEADLINE: Indonesia's Phony Cleanup

 BODY:
Indonesia's rulers see this month's Asia-Pacific economic summit meeting as a terrific opportunity to improve an international image stained by repression in East Timor and other serious human rights abuses. How much more flattering to display a statesman-like President Suharto playing host to his counterparts from the U.S., China, Japan and a dozen other countries and touting the opportunities of the world's fourth-most-populous nation and one of its most vibrant economies.
Both images of Indonesia are true. But its crude effort to shove all human rights problems out of camera range only highlights the repressive character of the regime. 
 The effort, called "Operation Cleansing," began last spring under the guise of a drive against street crime. Since then it has been broadened to target "economically and politically motivated criminals" like academics, journalists, independent labor organizers and human rights activists, halting in its tracks the limited liberalization President Suharto proclaimed several years ago.
Three leading news magazines were shut down in June. Muchtar Pakpahan, leader of Indonesia's largest independent labor union, is currently being tried on patently political charges. George Aditjondro, a leading academic, was interrogated two weeks ago on criminal charges of "insulting a government body or authority" for remarks he made at an academic seminar in August.
President Clinton has proclaimed human rights a theme of his foreign policy, and U.S. law mandates a link between basic worker rights and the special trade privileges Indonesia currently enjoys. Yet the Administration has sent mixed signals about whether it will raise human rights issues during Mr. Clinton's one-on-one meeting with Mr. Suharto or at working sessions of the Asia-Pacific meeting.
If Washington fails to do so, it will reinforce the impression created by the President's retreats on human rights in China and Commerce Secretary Ron Brown's aggressive promotion of business profits at the expense of other values. It will also encourage other countries with serious human rights problems to do as Indonesia does and simply sweep its critics off the streets.
