HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE FELL AGAIN IN OCTOBER TO A 4-YEAR LOW

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The job market improved in October as the unemployment rate eased to 5.8 percent, another four-year low, and hourly wages rose by the largest amount in more than a decade, the Labor Department reported today.
Payroll gains were relatively modest, though, with the economy adding 194,000 jobs last month, well below the quarter of a million jobs added during a typical month this year. California, which has lagged far behind the rest of the country, was particularly impressive, with unemployment dropping to 7.7 percent from 8.3 percent. Employment in New York and New Jersey was virtually flat. 
 Some economists detected worrisome signs of inflation in the figures, the last important economic indicators reported before Election Day. Bond prices fell sharply as investors seemed convinced that the Federal Reserve was now even more likely to increase interest rates to quell rising prices. [Page 41.]
Stocks dropped, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 38.36 points. [Page 42.]
Still, the news again inspired boasts by the Clinton Administration and other Democrats hoping to contain off-year election losses on Tuesday by convincing dubious voters that the economy is better than they thought.
President Clinton, traveling the country this week campaigning for Democratic Congressional and gubernatorial candidates, took credit for the five million jobs that have been added since he took office in January 1993. "We have delivered what the American people have long wanted," Mr. Clinton said.
Former President George Bush disputed that assertion. Stumping for Republicans in Nebraska, he argued that the Democrats did not deserve credit because "we handed the new Administration an economy that grew."
As politicians jockeyed for advantage, some economists expressed misgivings about certain elements of today's report.
The rise in earnings of seven-tenths of a percent, while satisfying to workers who have not shared in the recent prosperity, raised fears that labor costs might be about to ratchet up. Other analysts suggested that the jump might be only a one-month statistical fluke. A second straight surge of this magnitude would be highly worrisome to those who fear that inflation is rising.
Separately, an index designed by a research arm of Columbia University to predict inflation rose smartly again last month, reflecting in part a further rise in the proportion of the population with jobs. The share of eligible people at work reached the highest level since 1990.
Speculation intensified that the Federal Reserve would move to raise short-term interest rates by more than half a point at its Nov. 15 policy meeting. The price of fixed-income securities retreated, pushing the yield of the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction, up to 8.15 percent.
Some analysts argued that the Fed had been too slow in acting to rein in the economy's growth, which they contend is fueling inflation.
"The Federal Reserve has shifted gradually from a pre-emptive strategy to contain inflation to a more reactive strategy that merely monitors inflation," said John H. Makin, a scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute.
But whether or not the Fed has slipped "behind the curve," today's figures seemed to increase the pressure for strong action, especially in light of recent weakness in the international value of the dollar.
Economists noted that not only did hourly and weekly earnings leap, but the length of the factory workweek also continued to hover at levels not seen since World War II. In October, the workweek rose by 6 minutes, to 42.1 hours.
For the entire private sector, the workweek expanded 18 minutes to drive the index of aggregate weekly hours up 1 percent.
The increase in payroll jobs last month was 194,000, somewhat less than expected and the smallest gain since January. But analysts noted that this was on top of an upward revision for September and a large upward revision for August. In addition, the Labor Department disclosed that its annual match-up of survey results with records kept by each state indicated the existence of 760,000 more jobs in March than had been previously thought.
More than a quarter of the revision in the benchmark calculations -- an exceptionally large seven-tenths of 1 percent -- involved California, officials said.
Payroll gains in October covered a wide front, with factories adding 40,000 jobs, retailing 51,000, business services 32,000 and health services 27,000, the report also showed.
Among the highlights of the Labor Department's survey of households, from which the unemployment rate is calculated, were a 290,000 drop in the ranks of the newly jobless (less than five weeks) and an increase of 185,000 in those idle 15 weeks or more.
This lifted the average duration of jobless spells to 19.6 weeks, from 19.2 weeks in September. When asked about such a situation at a mature stage of the business cycle, Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, said, "We're still seeing the effects of corporate restructuring combined with very rapid technological changes and international trade."
The national rate of 5.8 percent compared with 5.9 percent in September. The jobless rate in the West fell to 6.7 percent from 7 percent while it remained unchanged in the Northeast at 6.2 percent. The jobless rate in the South also remained level at 5.7 percent and the Midwest held steady at 5 percent.
California by itself added 239,000 jobs, enabling its unemployment rate to drop six-tenths of a point for a second straight month, to 7.7 percent. A department official said military contractors, which are big employers in the state, had stopped hemorrhaging jobs for the first time since major cutbacks began.
Among demographic groups, the report showed the jobless rate for adult women was down three-tenths of a point, to 5 percent.

HEADLINE: ARMS TRAFFICKING TO BOSNIA GOES ON DESPITE EMBARGO

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Even as the United Nations discusses lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia and Herzegovina, the embargo appears to have become largely a fiction, openly flouted.
Helped by the ready availability of arms and military components in the former Soviet bloc countries and by an apparent American readiness to turn a blind eye, Croatia is now building or assembling everything from battle tanks to MIG-21 fighter aircraft and acting as the main conduit for the flood of weapons reaching Bosnia. 
 "What I need, I get," the Croatian Defense Minister, Gojko Susak, said in an interview. "The arms market is saturated, so saturated you would pay three times the price if you got things legally."
Mr. Susak described buying arms in countries including Poland, Bulgaria and Russia as "an open market" and said Croatia was now providing the army of the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government with antitank weapons and ammunition for mortars, cannons and machine guns.
The effect of this increase in the arms available to the Bosnian Muslim and allied Bosnian Croat forces has been evident in the last week in two successful offensives against the long-dominant Bosnian Serbs. The first offensive burst through Serbian lines east of Bihac in the northwest; the second resulted in the capture of the town of Kupres in the west central part of the country.
An arms embargo imposed on the former Yugoslavia in 1991 froze the Bosnian Serbs' weapons superiority in place because Serbs controlled the Yugoslav Army and dipped into its arsenal to supply the Bosnian Serbs.
The Serbs used this advantage to take 70 percent of Bosnian territory, routing the nascent Bosnian Army and terrorizing Muslim civilians.
Their superiority in artillery and tanks remains but now appears to have been offset by the success of the Bosnian Government in providing basic weapons to a large army operating in a mountainous terrain where mobility can outweigh armor.
"The Bosnian Army has doubled in size over the past year to about 164,000 men, all in uniform and equipped, against about 102,000 Serbs," said Paul Beaver, a military analyst at Jane's Defense Weekly in London. "They have obtained Russian-made rocket-propelled grenades from the former East Germany, Chinese antitank weapons from Pakistan and ammunition from Iran."
Since the American-brokered Muslim-Croat federation in Bosnia was formed in March, most of the weapons reaching Bosnia have come through Croatia, a country with more than 1,000 islands, several remote airstrips and a number of land routes into Bosnia.
The United States appears to have pursued a policy of turning a blind eye to this arms trade, which has had the effect of advancing one element of American strategy in the Balkans: achieving a balance of power in Bosnia to create conditions favorable to a peace settlement.
For example, Mr. Susak said the American military attache at the embassy in Zagreb, Col. Richard Herrick, had attended a recent demonstration of Croatian air power. Among the aircraft on show were 12 MIG fighter planes -- Croatia had no more than four when the embargo was imposed -- and several MI-24 armored assault helicopters that fired guided antitank missiles. Croatia had none of these helicopters or missiles when the embargo took effect in 1991.
Colonel Herrick declined comment. An official at the American Embassy in Zagreb, who confirmed Colonel Herrick's presence at the military exercise, said, "Yes, of course we're aware of circumvention of the embargo." She then corrected herself, saying the State Department had no verified reports of violations. Asked if the United States had done anything about possible violations, she declined comment.
Mr. Beaver of Jane's Defense Weekly described the American approach to Croatian arms imports as "not quite connivance, but almost."
Mr. Susak said Croatia was now assembling MIGs at a factory just outside Zagreb and already had about 20 aircraft. He added that tanks were being manufactured in Slavonski Brod, and mortars and rocket launchers at plants in other towns.
At the Duro Dakovic factory in Slavonski Brod, the success of Croatia in getting what it needs for its weapons industry is evident. The gleaming green hulls of five M-84 battle tanks stood recently, waiting for turrets and 125-millimeter cannons to be installed.
When Yugoslavia broke up in 1991, the tank plant was paralyzed because more than 70 percent of the components assembled there came from republics other than Croatia, the plant's managing director, Antun Milovic, said.
But by diversifying its own industry, and by buying essential military components in the former Soviet bloc, Croatia has now returned the tank plant to operation, and Duro Davkovic executives said prewar production levels of 100 to 150 tanks a year could soon be met.
Mr. Susak and Mr. Milovic said Croatia aimed to export tanks to Kuwait next year under a contract that had been interrupted when Yugoslavia collapsed.
Apart from East Europe, the other major source of arms in trafficking valued at about $500 million in the last two years appears to have been Muslim countries. Mr. Beaver and other analysts estimated that Iran alone had provided at least 1,500 tons of ammunition that reached Bosnia through Croatia.
Last week, Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic of Bosnia and Prime Minister Nikica Valentic of Croatia were in Teheran, where they agreed to set up a commission that would meet twice a year to strengthen economic and political ties among Iran, Croatia and Bosnia.
Although Croatia and Bosnia are clearly cooperating -- in the import of arms and on the ground in the capture of Kupres -- there are limits to their partnership. Mr. Susak said Croatia was not providing tanks or artillery to Bosnia, a decision that is perhaps not surprising, since Bosnian Muslims and Croats were at war with each other last year.
Thus a lifting of the arms embargo remains important to the Bosnian Government, because it would mean emancipation from dependence on Croatia and because it would provide access to the tanks and artillery the Bosnian Army still needs.
On Thursday the United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution calling for a lifting of the embargo on Bosnia. Though the General Assembly has no enforcement power, the United States has drafted a resolution for the United Nations Security Council calling for an automatic lifting of the arms ban on Bosnia in six months.
The Bosnian Serbs still have an estimated 600 pieces of heavy artillery against about 100 for the Muslims, and a marked superiority in tanks. A counterattack against recent Bosnian gains is possible.
"We cannot accept the status quo," Mr. Silajdzic said in a recent interview. "That is why we want the lifting of the embargo: to gain strength and negotiate from a balance of power."

HEADLINE: Pope Visits Sicily Amid Alarm Over the Mafia

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CATANIA, Sicily, Nov. 4

 BODY:
On his first trip since poor health forced him to cancel a journey to the United States, Pope John Paul II tonight began a weekend visit to Sicily, where alarm is growing over threats to priests from the Mafia.
The 74-year-old Pope, who broke a thigh bone in a bathroom fall in April, emerged unaided from his plane here, without the cane he has often used since his fall. But he seemed uncertain of his footing as he descended the few steps to the tarmac. As is usually the case on papal trips inside Italy, he did not kneel to kiss the ground. 
 The visit here, initially scheduled for last April but postponed because of his fall, was shadowed from the start by the tense yet sometimes ambiguous relationship between the Roman Catholic Church and the Mafia, which the Pope has often condemned.
Only a day before John Paul arrived in Sicily, a Catholic priest in Palermo, the Rev. Mario Scifo, went into hiding because of threats against his life. Father Scifo had given an anti-Mafia sermon that led many in his congregation to leave the church in fear of mob reprisals.
The priest told reporters he had received an anonymous telephone call after the sermon saying, "Sooner or later, someone will put a bomb in your church."
In an open letter to the Pope marking his visit, the Archbishop of Catania, Luigi Bommarito, said today: "The open, painful and bloody plague of the Mafia remains in our social fabric and in our flesh, returning like a bitter blow with its arrogance, its tentacles and its recurrent works of death."
When the Pope addressed thousands of Sicilians gathered in Catania's cathedral square tonight, he responded with what seemed an appeal to fight back against the mob's influence.
Most Sicilians "wish to leave behind them the corruption exercised by the few to the detriment of the many," he said. "There is no time or room for sitting silently by or fearful mediocrity. At the present historic moment, there can be no room for fearfulness or inertia.
"Too many times, the people of Catania have suffered the humiliation of being seen as residents of a degraded and violent city, dominated by crime. "Catania, rise up again in light and justice!"
The Pope is to spend two full days in Sicily at Catania and Siracusa before returning to Rome on Sunday.
Catania is one of Sicily's main ports and, like other cities on the island, is dominated by organized crime. Anti-Mafia campaigners here are hoping the Pope's visit will galvanize people anew to combat the mob.
"The Pope is coming to Catania and Siracusa and finds two cities preyed upon by fear, annihilated by endemic evils -- Mafia violence, unemployment, usury -- and by a 'culture of emptiness' that has stripped many people of the will to fight," wrote Giuseppe di Fazio, a commentator for the local newspaper, La Sicilia.
"His message, 'Do not fear,' is a challenge to all of us," he said.
While the Pope has inveighed in the past against organized crime, his appeals have seemed only to irritate the mob: last year several churches in Rome were bombed and investigators blamed organized crime.
There is close interest here, too, in the Pope's health.
While his address to people in Catania tonight seemed written for a passionate delivery, the Pope's voice seemed tired.
John Paul had been scheduled to visit the United States last month but canceled the trip on the ground that his recovery from a hip operation last spring was slower than he had expected.

HEADLINE: A Safer Russian Army

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has made remarkable headway in its efforts to help Russia dismantle its nuclear forces. Washington's engagement in this enterprise has reached levels that would have been unthinkable just a few years ago. The U.S. has built housing for former Soviet missile controllers; Pentagon officials now give virtually the same briefing on U.S. nuclear policy to Russia's Parliament as they give to Congress.
Unfortunately, Washington has not yet given equal attention to the need to downsize Moscow's non-nuclear forces. U.S. cooperation is essential to reduce Russia's army to a level that Russia and its neighbors can live with. 
 Russia currently has 1.1 million people under arms. It cannot afford to maintain a force that size. Draft-dodging has reached epidemic proportions as recruits recognize that the army cannot provide them three square meals a day, never mind a timely paycheck. Yet even with its defense spending in free fall and arms procurements near a standstill, Moscow's defense bill still drives up its budget deficit, and threatens new inflationary pressures.
To generations that grew up fearing the Soviet threat, that may sound like good news. Yet while the armed forces must shrink, letting them collapse uncontrollably is risky. A collapse would put thousands of troops on the street, freeing them to engage in mischief in newly independent republics. It would also embitter career officers and help fuel a nationalist resurgence. The obvious course is for Russia to reduce its armed forces in an orderly way. But even that will meet strong political resistance unless the U.S. takes concrete steps to reassure Russia about its security.
Russia's vaunted air defenses, for example, have sprung leaks. The Defense Ministry may thus be tempted to keep more fighter planes than it can afford. The U.S. could ease Russian fears by offering to integrate Moscow into the Western air traffic control network. It could also invest in housing and job training for officers mustered out of the armed forces -- much as it has invested in those who manned Russia's nuclear arsenal. That would help minimize the prospect of a nation full of unemployed and potentially unruly soldiers.
Above all, the West should resist any immediate temptation to include Poland and the rest of Eastern Europe in an expanded NATO. Russian military planners are certain to view any such expansion as a serious regional threat and will be even less inclined to shrink their forces.
No U.S. official is better positioned to encourage a broadened dialogue on Russia's conventional forces than the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John Shalikashvili. In the aftermath of Vietnam, when morale in America's armed forces hit bottom, he tasted the bitterness the Russian army is now experiencing. General Shalikashvili further understands the risks of an expanded NATO -- a move that would commit his troops to the defense of Eastern Europe but inspire a recidivist backlash in Russia. He should take the lead in discussing a Russian military build-down.

HEADLINE: Observer;
O Rare Newt Gingrich

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Republicans last ran both houses of Congress during the two-year term 1953-55. Before that they had one other two-year term: 1947-49. Before that? You'd have to search back in the Bronze Age when most Americans knew who Herbert Hoover and Al Smith were.
Sixty years of losing tends to lower politicians' hopes. This is why there is real excitement about the Republicans' chances of winning both Senate and House next Tuesday. 
 A whole Congress under Republican control is one of those rarities like a full solar eclipse. It makes people feel special to see one in their own lifetime.
Even Democrats probably won't be too devastated if Republicans produce this spectacular trick. A Republican Congress would break the monotony, and -- Democrats might as well face it -- eternal Democratic control has produced a monotony that's starting to push their party into utter pointlessness.
Even the Democratic Senate leader, George Mitchell, who was probably a cinch for re-election, couldn't bear to face another six years, so quit. It's said he will even accept a job as water bearer for the bumbling tycoons who own major league baseball if that's what it takes to put the Senate behind him.
Democrats may also take perverse cheer in a Republican win. The two modern occasions when Republicans did control Congress turned out happily for Democrats. The first resulted from the off-year elections of 1946, which produced what was called "the meat Congress."
In 1946, like 1994, the country was in an unusually peevish mood because, for one thing, of soaring meat prices. At the grocery beef was over $1 a pound, an astonishing price in an age when the dollar was still real money. The end of wartime wage and price controls had produced price inflation while wages lagged, and Americans voted their spleen.
What they produced was the most conservative Congress since the 1920's. Richard Nixon and Joseph McCarthy came to Washington. Republicans immediately proposed to cut taxes, slash spending, end business and labor regulation and repeal such New Deal measures as Social Security and the labor law.
Such was the Republican Congress which Harry Truman immortalized in his 1948 campaign as "that good-for-nothing, do-nothing 80th Congress." Truman's campaign returned him to the White House and Democratic control to the Capitol.
Actually the Republican 80th was far from Truman's "good-for-nothing" Congress. In a remarkable act of two-party harmony, it laid the foundations of the foreign policy that carried the country successfully through 40 years of cold war.
Republican obstruction of Truman's domestic program also laid the foundation, however, for Republican defeat in 1948. This will be much noted and long written about by all wizards of political journalism if Republicans win next Tuesday.
The parallels between the widely disliked Truman of 1946 and the widely disliked Clinton of 1994 are so obvious that all masters of the political pronunciamento will be powerless to resist dilating ponderously upon them.
The next Republican Congress was a byproduct of General Eisenhower's big Presidential victory in 1952. Its immediate political result was to thrust the Communist-hunter Joseph McCarthy front and center in the national spotlight.
The bureaucracy in which he prowled in search of Reds was now a Republican responsibility. His forays inevitably brought him into conflict with his own White House. Congressional Republicans began to choose up sides, and Eisenhower fumed while McCarthy, overestimating the power headlines could give him, recklessly courted a fight with the White House.
It came, and it destroyed him, and it titillated the entire country. It also set Republican against Republican. By the end of Eisenhower's first two years the Republicans in Congress looked more like an opposition than a governing party.
Eisenhower had needed the help of politically shrewd Democrats to get bills passed while Republicans, thanks largely to McCarthy, had often looked like Eisenhower's enemy. Opposition seemed to have become their unshakable habit.
By 1955 Eisenhower may even have been pleased to see the Congress turned back to the Democrats and the Texans Sam Rayburn and Lyndon Johnson. Eisenhower was born in Texas. He and Texans understood each other.

HEADLINE: A Cashless Economy Would Make Larger Tax Cuts Possible

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In elections throughout the country, and particularly in New York, the most contested issue is which candidate can propose the most generous and feasible tax cuts. 
 One way to make tax cuts feasible is to make inroads into the extensive "underground economy." Unreported cash transactions have been estimated at more than $1 billion a year in the New York metropolitan area alone. The sales and income tax losses are undoubtedly substantial.
Debit cards could greatly reduce the amount of currency in circulation and could make a real impact on the underground economy. The cards, which deduct money from a prepaid account, are already available for telephone charges, vending machines and subway fares.
With the enhancement of security by use of a personal identification number, the debit cards would have several beneficial effects. They would reduce street crime, since stealing a debit card without the PIN would be worthless; they would reduce the incentive for robbery or employee theft, since less cash would be available from a store or other vendor, and they would provide easier tracking of revenue for tax purposes.
As the public increased its use of debit cards, more businesses would accept them. The extensive acceptance of credit cards proves that most businesses will adapt if the public demands it. With people carrying less cash, if any, the underground economy will shrink and tax revenues will rise without rate increases.
 
GLENN NEWMAN
Brooklyn, Oct. 28, 1994
 
The writer was a deputy commissioner, New York City Finance Dept.

HEADLINE: 2 Executives and Their Spouses Killed in Crash of a Helicopter;
William F. Emswiler, Barbara White Emswiler

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
William F. Emswiler, an executive of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, and his wife, Barbara, were among those killed in a helicopter crash in Mexico on Tuesday. They were residents of Fairfield, Conn.
Their deaths were confirmed by the State Department yesterday. 
 Mr. Emswiler, 50, joined Perkin-Elmer, a maker of scientific instruments based in Norwalk, Conn., as a vice president and chief financial officer in 1992. He had worldwide responsibility for the billion-dollar company's finances, taxes, internal audits, business development and information services.
Among his previous positions was treasurer of the American Home Products Corporation and partner Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm.
A native of Baltimore, he graduated from the College of the Holy Cross with a bachelor's degree in accounting and economics.
Barbara White Emswiler, 48, who was a nurse in the Fairfield school system, was born in New London, Conn. She graduated from the University of Connecticut School of Nursing.
They are survived by two sons, Jon A. and Jeffrey E., and a daughter, Karen M., all of Fairfield. Also surviving are Mr. Emswiler's mother, Marie S. of North Palm Beach, Fla., and three brothers, Joseph M. of New Roads, La., James P. of Guilford, Conn., and Barry J. of Herndon, Va.
Barbara Emswiler is survived also by her mother, Virginia B. Payton of Stamford, Conn.; her father, Paul D. White of Vista, Calif.; a sister, Carolyn W. Norton of Griswold, Conn., and a half-brother, Michael P. White of Spokane, Wash.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2514 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Coffee Bars;
Landlords Savor the Smell of Coffee Bars

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
THERE'S a building on Madison Avenue in the 40's whose owners tell a decidedly non-90's tale. A few months ago they put a 2,100-square-foot space on the market for an annual rent of $60 a foot, figuring that this would be a starting point for negotiations.
That it was. A couple of bids trickled in at $60. Then a coffee house, fearing that other tenants might grab the space, offered $65. A rival coffee house promptly offered $70. The rival will get the space -- provided a third coffee house does not bid even more. 
 "They just keep jacking up the rent," said the building's bemused leasing agent. "The space will be rented for a lot more than the landlord ever thought to want."
That scenario is being repeated all across Manhattan, as a tsunami of coffee houses, coffee bars and espresso bars (the terms are used interchangeably in the industry) sweeps through the borough, leaving inflated rents in its wake.
There's a coffee house in the West 30's that's paying an annual rent of $95 a square foot for a space that, the building's owner concedes, would command no more than $75 for any other use. Another coffee house in the East 50's is forking over a hefty $230 a foot on a block where comparable spaces are going for $175 to $200. On Third Avenue, a coffee house is paying $140 for a mid-block space that brokers say would normally rent for about $110.
"I haven't seen anything like this since Benetton came into town in the late 70's," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in the New Spectrum real estate brokerage. "In the last 18 months, the coffee houses have almost single-handedly hiked up New York rents."
Richard Seligman, a senior managing director at Edward S. Gordon Company, the brokerage concern, reports the same phenomenon. "They're consistently paying 10 to 15 percent more than the market would normally demand," he said.
It doesn't take Juan Valdez to discern the reason: The inexorable law of supply and demand is bearing down. No new space has been built in New York for several years. But in the last year coffee behemoths like Starbucks, based in Seattle; Brothers Gourmet Coffee, based in Boca Raton, Fla., and Timothy's, based in Toronto, have all opened numerous outlets in Manhattan. New entrepreneurial firms like Coopers Coffee and New World Coffee are going head to head with them. Even bookstores and department stores are doing double duty as coffee houses; Barnes & Noble has cafes run by Starbucks in several of its superstores, and New World Coffee just signed an agreement with Saks Fifth Avenue to run cafes at several of its suburban stores.
Phillips/Norwalk, a real estate consulting firm in Westport, Conn., counted only 55 coffee houses in New York last spring. Its president, Lee Phillips, guesses that the number has more than doubled since -- and he still thinks the city is nowhere near saturation.
"Manhattan, with its heavy pedestrian traffic, is particularly conducive to coffee bars, yet it still has the lowest ratio of coffee bars to office workers of any city," he said.
Indeed, New York is one of the last cities to embrace the coffee bar trend. Coffee bars have been social staples in Europe and the Middle East for centuries. In the United States, the trend started in Portland, Ore., and Seattle, then moved east through Chicago before landing here a year or so ago. Last year the Long Beach, Calif.-based Specialty Coffee Association released a study saying there were about 5,000 coffee houses in the country, up from just 200 in 1989. It forecast that by 1999 there would be 10,000.
"Already I believe that was too conservative," said Ted R. Lingle, the association's executive director.
So why so late to hit Manhattan? "I think coffee operators felt they couldn't afford Manhattan rents, and Manhattan landlords didn't want tenants who are riding a fad," Mr. Lingle said. "Now everyone realizes it's not a fad, which will end. It is a trend, which may wax and wane, but won't disappear."
WHAT New York coffee houses have lacked in timeliness, they have made up for in speed of market penetration. Dennis L. Boyer, the head of Brothers Gourmet Coffee, remembers the reaction he got when he took his company public last year.
"People on Wall Street kept asking, 'What is this business about coffee bars?' " he said. "Now they're already asking, 'Is the market saturated?' "
Apparently Mr. Boyer doesn't think so: He just opened a coffee bar at 147 West 40th Street and has already leased several more sites in New York.
Ramin Kamfar, co-owner of Manhattan-based New World Coffee, tells a similar tale.
"My partner was talking about opening coffee bars three years ago and everyone said, 'Nah, no New Yorker will stand in line to pay $3 for a cup of coffee they can get for 70 cents at the deli,' " he said. "Then we looked at Chicago, where even secretaries were lining up to buy cappuccinos, and decided everyone was wrong."
In February 1993, New World opened a tiny coffee bar just south ofthe upscale Jefferson Market on Avenue of Americas, near 10th Street, a store that is still among its most profitable. It has since leased 13 other sites.
The new breed of coffee house is not to be confused with coffee shops, which offer full meals and table service. Those are mundane places where coffee is simply an after-meal beverage that comes in two varieties, regular and decaf.
The new coffee houses are expensively appointed, rich with ambiance. And while many do serve pastries and sandwiches, their emphasis is on specialty coffees in dozens of flavors and strengths and degrees of foamy milk. They are not after the lunching crowd, although they certainly welcome them. Instead, they are after people looking for an alternative to mediocre deli coffee for a quick refresher and to alcohol-service bars for meetings and hangouts.
Anyone who thinks the difference is specious should talk to Marvin Haas, chairman of Chock Full o' Nuts. For decades Chock was the quintessential coffee shop, a chain whose U-shaped counters were filled with people looking for a cheap but high-quality sandwich and an excellent cup of coffee. The once thriving chain closed its restaurants in 1983.
"We could serve 100 people at lunchtime, while a fast-food chain could serve 600," Mr. Haas said. "The economics just weren't right anymore." Now, after a decade of relying on revenues from institutional food-service clients and sales of coffee beans and spices, Chock is jumping back into the restaurant fray with -- surprise! -- new-style coffee houses.
It has a spacious one on Madison Avenue near 49th Street, in a location that the company has leased since 1958. Last month it opened a smaller store on Second Avenue near 66th Street, and last week it opened two stores in the West 40's. Within the next 12 months Mr. Haas expects to open 15 more.
All are high-tech-looking places that rely on self-service and provide many types of coffee and food. There is still at least one reminder of the past -- the cream cheese on datenut bread that was the old Chock Full o' Nuts's signature sandwich.
Chock's flagship Madison Avenue store is right next door to an Au Bon Pain, another coffee-and-light-food operation that, the uninitiated would assume, would provide formidable competition. But coffee houses seem singularly unafraid of one another. In fact, they've been known to open new branches not only across from competitors, but across from themselves. Chock just opened a 2,500-square-foot cafe on the 43d Street side of 1114 Avenue of the Americas, the W. R. Grace building, and a 300-square-foot take-out space on the 42d Street side of the same building.
And when Starbucks, the industry's biggest player, opened a store on DuPont Circle in Washington, it was so successful that it opened another a couple of blocks away.
Weren't they afraid of cannibalizing their own sales?
"Are you kidding?" asked Laura Moix, a Starbucks spokeswoman. "We have two stores across the street from each other in Vancouver, and they're both doing well."
ONE reason for the willingness to crowd together is that, unlike, say, record stores or apparel shops, which can draw traffic from many blocks away, coffee houses rely primarily on walk-by trade. They are the ultimate impulse buys.
"It is the visibility and the traffic counts that are the most important things to a coffee house, not how close the next one is," said Faith H. Consolo, a vice president with the Garrick-Aug Associates brokerage firm.
Of course, there is a bit of a Catch-22 in this, in that high-traffic, high-visibility locations are attractive to retailers other than coffee bars. And some landlords still prefer to go with more tried and true types of tenants -- say, apparel stores.
Coffee bars, they say, are "wet" operations, which generate smells -- albeit smells that most people find appealing. Because the trend is so new to New York, they are often run by relatively unproven operators, making them high-risk tenants. And, if they are not run properly, they can attract a somewhat seedy customer who does not enhance a building's image.
"IN a location where you already have a lot of foot traffic, you can usually get a better type of tenant," said Anthony E. Malkin, president of W&M Properties, one of the few building-management companies not pursuing coffee house tenants.
Most prefer to cash in on the coffee-house bonanza, and look for ways to minimize the downside. Some will only rent to known players like Starbucks. Others will insist on letters of credit or other guarantees. Still others will rent to newcomers only if it seems they have done their homework.
"A lot of these new people do spend six months in Seattle and really research this industry," said Bruce A. Spiegel, senior vice president of Rose Associates, which owns many Manhattan buildings. "They seem like good risks."
At least one landlord is leaving nothing to chance: The Durst Organization is building its own coffee bars in 1133 and 1155 Avenue of the Americas, two buildings it owns on 44th Street. Both will be managed by Cafe Un Deux Trois, a nearby restaurant, and will serve food that is cooked at the restaurant. But the Dursts will own the bars.
"We see this as providing a service to the tenants, and the only way we can be sure they will get good service is if we retain control of the space," said Douglas Durst, a vice president of the organization.
Mr. Durst is onto something that has helped coffee bars persuade risk-averse landlords to overcome their fears. They provide a nice amenity for tenants in office buildings. And they are wonderful generators of traffic -- read customers -- for nearby stores.
In fact, it is that last attribute that has made landlords, if not the shops themselves, worry about concentrating too many coffee houses together.
Rockefeller Center Management just rented 690 square feet of streetfront space on the 49th Street side of 30 Rockefeller Plaza to Cafe Duomo, an Italian-style coffee bar that will serve and sell only products from Italy. Rockefeller Center agreed to rent the space only on the proviso that Cafe Duomo offer no take-out service.
"Our concourse-level coffe bars are generating traffic for the other stores down there," said Alan L. Stein, a senior vice president of Rockefeller Center Management. "You don't want someone intercepting those customers upstairs."
You also don't want someone keeping away a larger tenant in the future, added Kate D. Coburn, the center's vice president for retail. She has a 3,000-square-foot space in 30 Rockefeller Plaza that she is hoping to rent to a full-service coffee shop; she would not have rented to Cafe Duomo if it had served enough food to siphon off customers from that prospective tenant.
"It was important that Cafe Duomo be aimed at tourists and passers-by who want a quick stop, not at office tenants who want takeout coffee or lunch," she said.
For their part, coffee bars seem to good-naturedly accept landlords' restrictions, or desires to shoehorn them into small or out-of-the-way places. They are far more flexible than most retailers: A coffee bar can squeeze into 350 square feet, confining itself to specialty coffees, a few biscotti and a couple of bar stools. Or it can expand to 2,500 feet, providing tables and sandwiches.
Indeed, since most coffee house operators own more than one store, they can create their own synergies. For example, many of the stores that Chock Full o' Nuts expects to open will be too small to handle a lot of on-site baking and food preparation. But the new 43d Street store has room to bake enough for several.
"We'll use it as a commissary for our smaller locations," Mr. Haas said.
And coffee houses often thrive in spaces that other retailers shun.
The two coffee houses that Mr. Stein wants to protect are operating in parts of the concourse below Rockefeller Center that had been low-traffic areas before. Both are doing lines-out-the-door business, primarily from Rockefeller Center tenants, and both are taking more space.
A Pasqua coffee house just rented a problematic space at 450 Lexington Avenue, Sterling Properties' elegant landmarked building on 45th Street.
"SURE we would have preferred a designer leather-goods store," said Amy Strong, Sterling's director of retail leasing. "But the store doesn't have great windows, and a lot of upscale retailers do not like the mixed high traffic near Grand Central Station. We wouldn't have put in a deli, we'd have left the space empty first, but this coffee house looks like a piece of art."
But coffee houses are not milksop tenants. Most are seeking niches and have ground rules for where they will or will not go. Some -- Coffee Station is an example -- like being inside office buildings, preferring the captive and weather-impervious audience of a large tenant population. Others -- Coopers Coffee fits in here -- concentrate on residential areas, preferring the seven-day and evening traffic those provide.
Some -- Chock Full o' Nuts is one -- insist on serving a lot of food. Others -- Cafe Duomo is typical -- feel coffee and maybe some biscotti is enough. Yet others -- like New World -- are pushing the sale of coffee beans as much as the sale of $3 cups of latte.
Operators like Starbucks and Brothers, which are bean wholesalers, are also looking at their coffee hosues as vehicles for expanding their wholesale trade.
Scarcely two months after opening his first New York coffee bar, Mr. Boyer of Brothers already is talking about doing cross-promotions for coffee-by-the-cup and coffee-by-the-pound, and of economies to be derived from getting double duty out of distribution centers and other facilities.
"We feel the synergy will let us establish ourselves as New York's premier coffee brand," he said.
Unfortunately for Mr. Boyer, others in the ever-growing host of players in the coffee game are chasing that title, too. For them, it means a fierce competitive battle. But for landlords it continues to mean but one thing -- a rich, hearty cash windfall.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Once-Sliding Agriculture Is Making a Comeback

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
FOR hundreds of years, Connecticut, like much of America, was farm country -- until the 50's, when city folk began pouring into its villages, wealthy suburbs and developing subdivisions, and hundreds of office buildings created an urbanized state.
Only about 400,000 of Connecticut's 3.2 million acres is farmland today. But 1.7 million acres of forest and 50,000 acres of shellfish grounds bring the total amount of agricultural land to more than 2.1 million acres. 
 By the 70's the state was faced with a seriously eroding agricultural base, fueled by the rapid spread of residential and commercial development. An aggressive agricultural preservation program was begun that has come into maturity in the 90's, bringing agriculture back into the economic mainstream.
Connecticut has emerged as the leading agricultural state in New England, producing revenues of nearly $800 million in 1993, and exporting over $70 million in agricultural products to 30 countries.
"Connecticut Grown -- by the State That Thinks Like a Business" is the slogan of the State Department of Agriculture. Last spring a task force was formed to develop more effective market strategies and technological improvements for the industry in partnership with the academic and private resources within its borders, among them Yale, the University of Connecticut, Pfizer, Bristol-Myers, and DeKalb Genetics.
A major step was an acquisition program begun in 1978 under which the state has since bought, for about $70 million, the development rights to more than 154 farms totaling almost 24,000 acres. The program is voluntary, giving the farmer an alternative to selling out to developers and insuring his continued ownership of the land but restricting it permanently to agricultural use.
A modification of the program last year permits outright purchase of farms by the state, aimed at buying farms in foreclosure that can be resold to one or more farmers. "We bought the first one last year for $2.2 million," Mr. Filchak said. "It was appraised at $4 million."
The state also sponsors farmers' markets. Three opened in 1986; now there are 155 in 38 of the 169 municipalities, providing profitable outlets for the farmers and economical fresh produce for consumers.
"We have changed from dairy-based farms to greenhouses, nurseries, shellfish, wineries, mushrooms, Christmas trees and hydroponically grown produce," said John J. Filchack 3d, Deputy Commissioner of Agriculture. "Small vegetable growers with up to 25 acres are pooling their resources with larger growers to market their products. We are one of three top oyster producers in the country. Most of our egg production goes to mainland China and our breeder chickens are sent all over the world."
The decline in dairy farming was caused in part by federally fixed milk prices and the sale of hundreds of acres of pasture to real estate developers during the 80's. Today, new opportunities in an increasing variety of agricultural disciplines and the movement of local farming into the electronic age are attracting college students.
"Enrollment since 1992 increased from 550 to 850," said Dr. Kirklyn Kerr, dean of the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources of the University of Connecticut, a $2 billion state system of 10 campuses based at Storrs. "About 20 percent come from farm backgrounds, 80 percent have limited exposure to farming or an interest in fields related to farming -- animal science, nutrition, biotechnology, aquaculture."
ONE of the state's newest projects is the intensification of the relationship between the university, its Cooperative Extension Service and farmers. Plans are under way for an 11,000-square-foot building for the extension service on the university's Torrington campus.
"Litchfield County in particular is heavily involved in agriculture," said Bruce Wilbur, administrative service officer for the Cooperative Extension Service and its eight offices around the state. "Our mission as the outreach arm of the university is to take research information and make it available on a practical level to the farmer and the general public. We are involved in food handling and food safety, nutrition, conservation, environmental issues, land-use planning and zoning, as well as farming."
Ralph Gold, a 60's graduate of the university's College of Agriculture, has a 400-acre dairy farm in Cornwall that has been in the family since 1723. Mr. Gold is a a member of the planning committee for the new building and is a founding member of the Litchfield Agricultural Center.
"Zoning is a real dilemma," he said. "In 30 years time Litchfield will be like Fairfield. People move here for the picture-quality life close to New York, but they are intolerant of the noise and odor that takes place for a few hours, a day, even a week, that gives them the quality of life for the rest of the year. Connecticut has right-to-farm laws, but the reality is that if the farmer is severely harassed he gives up."
Mr. Wilbur, the extension officer, said, "Towns often don't have the resources or expertise to know what their options are in land use. We get involved in zoning issues and try to moderate problems."
"BEING on the Torrington campus," he said, "will give us access to the university's telecommunications system, connecting us via satellite throughout the country and the world. We will be able to transmit information rapidly to more than 300 extension agents and faculty members in offices and campuses around the state, carry on discussions by electronic mail and develop means for farmers to tap into the system directly, using an easily understandable menu."
The current office in a turn-of-the century building on West Street in Litchfield, about seven miles southwest of Torrington, was acquired in the 50's by a group of county farmers who felt the need for a one-stop location where a variety of agricultural services were available. Outgrown and outmoded, the building was sold in September for $350,000 to the Greater Litchfield Preservation Trust, which will make improvements and offer it for rent. Proceeds from the sale will go toward the cost of the new building in Torrington.
Dr. Adriane R. Lyon, director of the Torrington campus, looks forward to a new partnership. "We see this as enabling on both sides," she said. "They will have access to our library and other amenities, we will have access to their sophisticated communications equipment during their off-hours."
About 450 day and evening students attend academic classes in the single building on the 190-acre campus. Many are past traditional college age and an influx of another few hundred students over the next five years is expected.
"We have not yet chosen a site on campus, nor a building style," said Fritz Farquhar, a planning consultant. An architect will be hired later to design the building, for which unofficial estimates range from $750,000 to $1 million.
"We recognize that the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources must focus on helping agriculture as it relates to an urban state," Dr. Kerr said, "through the environment, waste management, water quality, open space -- things that benefit the producer, the consumer and Connecticut's quality of life."

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Sizing Up Airline Seating

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
IF you were crammed into economy-class seats all summer with the rest of us, you discovered airlines are no more generous with their leg room than with their peanuts. There may be an inch of hope on the horizon in the new twin-jet Boeing 777, but don't hold your breath: The 777 will not make a commercial debut until next summer, and it is a protean plane, one with an interior that can be rearranged quickly, so what you see on the charts may not be what you get.
Seating in the main cabins of major United States airlines continues to get tighter as competition intensifies. As John McDonald, a spokesman for Trans World Airlines said, schedule and price are the bottom line for air travelers, and extra space will attract new customers only when bottom lines are equal. "The market won't support it," Mr. McDonald said. "Comfort is one thing everyone talks about, but you still see 300 people crowded aboard a charter 727 to San Juan." This would be more than twice the capacity on a scheduled flight. 
 The major United States airlines say the standard coach-class seat pitch, or measurement from one spot on a seat to the same spot in the next row, is now 30, 31 or 32 inches. The airlines do not agree when this small space became standard; most estimate four to five years ago. Ed Perkins, editor of the Consumer Reports Travel Newsletter, which has been surveying seat pitch every two years since the late 70's, said that the standard was 34 to 36 inches when he began. The crowding began in earnest in the 90's, he concurred. Two airlines said that a safety rule that went into effect in the fall of 1992, requiring more space around the overwing exits, caused most airlines to compensate by pushing the rest of the seats tighter together. My measurements in the last two years indicate it's a rare occasion when you get 32 inches of space.
 
Reasons for Crowding
The course followed by T.W.A. illustrates how the economic squeeze mashes your knees.
In January 1993, T.W.A., then still in Chapter 11 reorganization, began to offer economy-class seating with more space, which it called Comfort Class. The space was created by removal of 3 to 40 seats, depending on the plane. On T.W.A.'s trans-Atlantic 747's, the pitch, which had been between 31 to 34 inches, went to a maximum of 36 inches, a minimum of 34 inches. On the 767's, where the old pitch was 31 or 32 inches, it went to 33 or 34 inches.
A year ago, J. D. Power and Associates of Agoura Hills, Calif., which annually rates business travelers' views, gave T.W.A. top place for customer satisfaction among airlines used for flights of more than 500 miles. Power said the survey was based on more than 23,000 travelers. Seating comfort accounted for 14 percent of overall satisfaction, the same level as scheduling, flight accommodations and aircraft interior, exceeded by on-time performance, which contributed 16 percent. (November was also the month that T.W.A. emerged from Chapter 11 reorganization, although its financial troubles continue.)
But after 16 months of Comfort Class, T.W.A. began to pull back. In April, ads announcing six extra flights between New York and Los Angeles and New York and San Francisco showed asterisks for two of its flights. The note said: "Extra legroom in Comfort Class not available on these flights." Although the line continues to use the title Comfort Class, the 36-inch pitch is disappearing. It was gone from all 10 747's serving Europe before the summer season, where the pitch shrank to 33 or 34 inches.
According to Mr. McDonald, the airline is reconfiguring all of its planes into two-class service, eliminating its Ambassador business-class seats by mid-1995 and absorbing most of this space into the main cabin. By that time, Comfort Class will be a matter of two or three inches' extra space, not five, and the asterisks will be gone.
 
Two Airlines That Tried
Innovation in the area of seating may not pay. Last summer, six-year-old Carnival Air Lines saw a way to make money by selling a little more space. It created Coach Plus, a plan to sell a seat with an empty seat next to it at a price above coach but below first class. The price for the test case was $159 for a ticket between Westchester Airport and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The week after Carnival announced its idea, according to Gabriel Gabor, the company spokesman, Continental came out with a fare of $79 on its New York-south Florida routes. "We figured no one would be interested in our plan," Mr. Gabor said. "Coach Plus never got off the ground."
Last fall, Ultrair began flying between New York and four Florida cities, offering 34-inch seat pitch on 727's. This line took a heavier blow: It folded in July, citing heavy competition in the New York-Florida corridor. (Atlanta-based Valujet, which started a year ago, offers 31-inch seat pitch and is still flying.)
 
The Roomier Boeing 777
The Boeing 777, now undergoing test flights, offers extra cabin width, compared with the planes it is designed to compete with. The two first lines scheduled to fly it say they will not stuff an extra seat in each row, which may be a help.
The 777 will be flown commercially first by United, which plans to put its initial three planes on a route to Europe -- United will not say which one -- on June 7. British Airways will be the second with passenger use, in September, also on a trans-Atlantic route.
The 777 cabin is 19 feet 3 inches wide, 10 inches narrower than the 747 but 5 inches wider than what Boeing calls the "trijets" it is intended to replace, meaning the McDonnell-Douglas DC-10 and MD-11 and Lockheed's L-1011, as well as the Airbus A-340 and A-330, all wide bodies that accommodate two aisles in economy class. The extra five inches on the 777 can be used to squeeze in 10-abreast seating, or if seating is kept 9 abreast, as in the competing widebodies, the space can be added to seat or aisle widths.
According to Donna J. Mikov, a spokeswoman for Boeing, airlines will be able to rearrange the interior of the 777 in 72 hours to switch from three to two classes or adjust the seat pitch. Ms. Mikov said the airlines might add extra space for long hauls, or subtract it for short trips.
For space-hungry consumers, all this means that the 777, even with nine-abreast economy-class seating, will not automatically offer more space. Passengers would be well advised to ask how many seats there are on the plane. Boeing says the upper limits are 328 seats in three classes; 400 in two classes and 440 in an all-economy arrangement.
According to Joseph P. Hopkins, a United spokesman, the airline will put in 303 passenger seats. In economy class, 235 seats will be arranged 2-5-2; the seat cushions will be 18 1/2 inches wide, and the pitch will be "31 or 32 inches."
British Airways, according to John W. Lampl, its spokesman, would put 281 seats in. In the main cabin, the 193 seats will be arranged 3-3-3 with a pitch of 32 inches and a cushion width of 18 inches. In both cases, the seat width, which Boeing says will be the widest in any economy-class cabin, will be what provides any added comfort; the seat pitches are the same old thing.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Terence Neilan

 BODY:

San Blas Islands
Q. We will be cruising the southern Caribbean in December and will be going to the San Blas Islands. Information about them seems hard to come by. Can you help? -- Marcy Johnson, Fresno, Calif. 
 A. The archipelago, which extends in a narrow strip off northern Panama, is made up of what the guidebooks say are 365 islands. The Kuna Indians, to whom the islands are home, put the number at 378.
The islands range in size from relative specks with a couple of coconut palms to those with hundreds of Kuna, who exercise internal autonomy over the archipelago. They have their own economic system, language, customs and culture, with distinctive brightly colored dress, music and dance. If you are tempted to take photographs of them be aware that it is customary to pay about 25 cents for each picture.
One of the most sought after Indian artifacts is the multi-layered applique mola, the most famous of Panamanian traditional handicrafts, which is worn by women and often sewn onto the front and back of a colorful short-sleeved blouse. A high-quality mola can cost anywhere from $50 to several hundred dollars.
Some of the islands are uninhabited. The capital is El Porvenir, where the airport is situated. From there boats go out to the other islands, many of which offer good fishing, swimming and snorkeling.
There are only a handful of hotels and restaurants on the islands, with two of the most popular places the 14-room Hotel Anai, (507) 39-3025, on nearby Wichub-Wala island, ($55 a person for three meals and a guided boat tour of the islands) and the 21-room Hotel San Blas, (507) 62-5410, five minutes away by boat on Nalunega ($37.50).
Several airlines operate 10-seater planes between Panama City and Porvenir, including Ansa (507) 26-7891 and Aerotaxi (507) 64-8644. All flights leave Panama at 6 A.M., arriving at 6:30 A.M. Return flights leave the next morning at 7 A.M., although day trips can be arranged on Sunday through a hotel or with one of the many travel agencies in Panama City. Round-trip fares are $50.
Chadwick Travel Service, Post Office Box J, Balboa, Panama, (507) 52-2741, fax (507) 28-1409, offers round-trip fare to Porvenir, accommodation at the Anai, meals and a tour of the island for $110 a person. For two nights at the Iskardup Ecoresort the price is $266 a person based on a minimum of six passengers. The tour runs to Dec. 15.
Other agents include Jungle Adventure, Post Office Box 871254, Zona 7, Panama, (507) 69-6017, fax (507) 69-1604, and Eco-Tours de Panama, Post Office Box 465, Panama 9A, Panama, (507) 63-3076, fax (507) 63-3089.
 
Seeing Asia from Hong Kong
Q. We will be visiting Hong Kong each April for the next five years to stay with friends. We would like to see other parts of Asia, even Australia, while we are there and wonder if we should book our trips from New York or wait till we get to Hong Kong. -- Frank Carucci, New York, N.Y.
A. The decision rests with so many variable factors, from where precisely you want to go and at what time, to the type of accommodations you are looking for, that the best course is probably to contact tour operators here and there and make a choice.

 A Swiss Christmas
Q. My husband, 8-year-old son and I will be spending the last two weeks of the year in Zurich but would like to spend a few days at Christmas in Zermatt, ideally at a hotel with a special dinner and other activities. Can you suggest somewhere? -- C. B., Atlanta
A. According to the Swiss National Tourist Office most hotels require a minimum two-week stay at Christmas, and in general it is very hard in winter, Switzerland's peak season, to find a hotel that will accept guests for under a week.
In case of a last-minute cancellation, however, and particularly if you are prepared to travel to Zermatt for Christmas dinner and then go back to Zurich the same night, it is worth contacting one of the following. The address for all the hotels is simply Zermatt, 3920 Switzerland. The dialing code for Switzerland is 41 and the code for Zermatt is 28.
Mont Cervin, 66 11 22, fax 67 28 78.
Zermatterhof, 66 11 00, fax 67 48 42.
Monte Rosa, 66 11 33, fax 67 11 60.
Alex Schlossshotel Tenne, 67 18 01, fax 67 18 03.
Julen, 67 24 81, fax 67 14 81.
Prices for two with breakfast and dinner at Christmas run from $238 to $541 a night, calculated at 1.2 Swiss francs to the dollar.
 
Sapporo Snow Festival
Q. I have wanted to attend the famous Sapporo Snow Festival in Japan for many years. Can you tell me the date of next year's event and if there are connecting flights to Sapporo from Tokyo? -- M. Coughlin, Los Altos, Calif.
A. The Sapporo festival, which will take place next year from Feb. 6 to 12, has grown to be the biggest and most famous of its kind in Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost island, although it is only one of many winter festivals held there at that time of year.
Teams of snow sculptors from around the world compete to produce the most fantastic snow and ice creations at four festival sites: Odori Park, Makomanai, Nakajima Park and Susukino. At night the parks glow with thousands of white lights. The White House, the Statue of Liberty and the Paris Opera House have been among snow carvers' subjects. The event attracts about two million visitors, according to Japanese tourism officials.
From Tokyo there are about 30 flights a day to Sapporo on Japan Air Lines and Japan Air System. The flight takes about 90 minutes.
 TERENCE NEILAN

HEADLINE: CHARLES MURRAY

 BODY:
Charles Murray says that what he is peddling is social science porn ("Daring Research or 'Social Science Pornography' "? by Jason DeParle, Oct. 9). I pray that it will not turn into sociological poison. The moral conclusions do not follow from his data. People who have lower I.Q.'s deserve more of our help, not less.
His data are clearly in error; the American economy has grown in years that our collective I.Q. is said to have declined, while the economies of white-only societies have collapsed (Eastern Europe) or are lagging. Rapid-growth economies are largely nonwhite. 
 Murray is positioned as the courageous champion of an unpopular truth. I fear that these kinds of arguments will turn out to be all too popular falsehoods.
 
AMITAI ETZIONI
President, American
Sociological Association

HEADLINE: SUNDAY: November 6, 1994;
Lots More Drag Queens

 BODY:
As tobacco queens fade from sight, drag queens are becoming increasingly evident. Whether these trends are connected is a subject for sophisticated social science.
In the simpler realm of economics Alex Heimberg, a.k.a. Miss Understood, has started a business in Manhattan called Screaming Queens. He provides drag queens for parties. Their role is to amuse and entertain, like adults-only clowns. The cost runs from $125 on up, and some clients are as straight as Rush Limbaugh. "A women in New Jersey had us come to a party at a country club for her husband's 40th birthday," says Heimberg. "We put a wig on him and sang 'Girls Just Wanna Have Fun.' They're going to be talking about us for years." 
 Among Heimberg's freelance crew are Dolores ("Carmen Miranda goes to 14th Street"), Varla Merman ("the illegitimate daughter of Ethel Merman and Ernest Borgnine") and himself ("an outer space goddess.") They do smoking and nonsmoking events.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 18; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1147 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
The Bloopie Awards!

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
TIME ONCE AGAIN for the coveted Bloopie Awards, recognition of Madison Avenue solecisms that sends thrills of Schadenfreude through the ranks of advertising copywriters.
Because the top of this column gets the lowest rating (the audience increases as we approach Prime Space), we begin with the least important award, "For the most egregious abuse of the comma." Push the envelope, please: 
 We have a five-way tie, or quintuple dead heat, as racing fans say. CBS erred in a spot for the mini-series "Scarlett." (That's the sequel to "Gone With the Wind," but CBS says Ted Turner's outfit, which owns that film, won't let CBS use the title in its ads; this column, however, is keenly aware of its First Amendment rights.) The network printed on screen: "Frankly my dear, I don't give a damn" as a voice-over intoned, "It was the most controversial statement of its time."
Let us set aside the affected pronunciation of controversial as con-tro-VER-see-ul -- the preferred form is con-tro-VERSH-ul -- and zero in on the statement that first used the word damn in movies. The Hays Office would never have permitted it, Will Hays once told me, had not Clark Gable, playing Rhett Butler, de-emphasized the profanity, delivering the line as "don't GIVE a damn."
The CBS line has no comma after the sentence adverb frankly, although the "Gone With the Wind" screenplay has it with the comma, and an exclamation mark to boot: "Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn!" (In Margaret Mitchell's novel, she never used the frankly: "He drew a short breath and said lightly but softly: 'My dear, I don't give a damn.' ") In direct address, the name or its substitute (as in my dear or my fine feathered friend) must be set off by commas.
The comma is also needed in Sherlock Holmes's famous line "Elementary, my dear Watson." Holmes, however, never spoke that line, at least not in Arthur Conan Doyle's stories. (Basil Rathbone did use the phrase when he played Sherlock Holmes in movies.) With the comma for direct address, the familiar saying would also answer the question "What school did you go to, darling?" Without that comma, dear reader, the copywriter has made a mistake.
As has Toyota in this line: "To us, a successful business shouldn't just try to make a profit, it should try to make a difference as well." That's a comma splice: two complete sentences incorrectly joined by a comma. Toyota could have used a semicolon after "profit," or put a period after that word and started a new sentence, or added a conjunction: "profit, but it should try. . . ."
Catching Toyota on the test-track turn is Mercedes-Benz, with its "Technologically speaking it had no rivals. . . . Even standing still the S 320 easily leaves other cars behind." Both Technologically speaking and Even standing still are used as introductory participial phrases that cry out for punctuation to separate them from their sentences' main thoughts. Also, nothing in the first sentence has to do with speaking, and the result is a dangling modifier; it should read "Technologically, it had no rivals," or "Technologically speaking, we are sure it had no rivals" (though Toyota can rival it on comma splicing any day).
Not to be outdone by foreign rivals, the Ford Citibank credit card, in conjunction with Hertz and Texaco, offers an ungrammatical rebate: "To apply see your Ford or Lincoln-Mercury dealer." An introductory infinitive phrase, like To apply or To run up a whopping bill, calls for a comma to separate it from the main clause, especially when misreading is possible. The comma should be left out only if the infinitive phrase is the subject of the main clause, as in "To apply is to get rejected."
Fifth entry is "The Coca-Cola Company in collaboration with Franklin Heirloom Dolls, authorizes their first-ever heirloom collector doll." The comma after "Dolls" requires a balancing comma after "Company"; you could get away with no commas at all, but if you're going to start down the comma road in this instance, you need both.
In the non-comma bloopie group, the winner is Attends, the incontinence product: "Attends' patented Perma-Dry fibers pull in wetness faster than other leading retail brands to help protect you." This is a misplaced modifier; for clarity, it should read "To help protect you, Attends'. . . ." Also, I'd put another s after that apostrophe, though some authorities disagree; the possessive should sound like Attends-ziz.
In the field of word choice, an ad writer for the realty division of The New York Times Magazine wins the coveted bloopie: "Whether it's a city tower . . . manor house . . . or seaside cove, it's here for you to dream on. And one day (soon, perhaps) to act on." The writer was reaching for a parallelism -- dream on and act on -- but dream on is a different idiom, something you tell a copywriter when he tells you he thinks he will one day be a poet. We dream about and dream of; nobody ever dreamed on Jeanie with the light brown hair.
And now -- in Prime Space, with readers breathless with suspense -- we come to the Most Horrendous Solecism of 1994, submitted by Thomas Luskin of Bayside, Queens. By virtue of the prestige of the sponsors, it is the Super Bloopie.
It goes to 87 Nobel laureates -- in chemistry, economics, literature, medicine, physics and peace -- who signed an ad titled "A Call to Reason" in support of measures to control population growth.
"The survival of mankind, and of the earth which sustains all of us, are in serious jeopardy," it begins, and is proudly signed by wreathed worthies from Christian Anfinsen to Geoffrey Wilkinson. Linus Pauling signed it, too, though he is dead.
Let us not nitpick about mankind, a word embracing male and female that is being replaced by humankind. And there are those who will let the Nobel laureates get away with the which when that is better to introduce a dependent clause not set off by commas. No; the inescapable root problem here is subject-verb disagreement.
The simple subject is survival. That takes the singular verb is. Everything between the word survival and the verb is falls in the domain of prepositional phrases, not part of the subject of the sentence. Only if the subject had been repeated -- "The survival of mankind and the survival of the earth" -- could you correctly use the plural are.
The Nobel laureates, or their petition copywriter, would do well to study the similarly constructed statement posted at the entrance to Busch Gardens amusement park in Virginia: "Clothing with suggestive or explicit language or insulting statements is not allowed." Although explicit is a foolish euphemism for "obscene," the sentence's simple subject -- clothing -- leaps over the intervening phrases to agree with the singular verb is. You can learn plenty at amusement parks.
One thing about the language dodge: a cat can look at a king.

LENGTH: 601 words

HEADLINE: The Oversold Society

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott; Stuart Elliott is the advertising columnist of The New York Times.

 BODY:

A NATION OF SALESMEN
The Tyranny of the Market
and the Subversion of Culture.
By Earl Shorris.
352 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $23. 
FROM the selling of diaper service to your parents to the selling of a funeral service to your survivors, your life, particularly if it is an American life, literally begins and ends with sales.
Indeed, the writer Earl Shorris, a former advertising executive who helped the Ayer agency sell automobiles for General Motors and long-distance calling for AT&T, asserts that "selling has become the determinant activity in the United States." The sale -- "the wedding of information and desire" -- has become so intrinsic to the character and culture of the nation, he contends in this thoughtfully argued book, that a new man, Homo vendens, has evolved, reflective of America's condition as an "oversold" society.
The breadth of Mr. Shorris's occasionally lyrical, always unconventional survey of salesmanship is impressive, starting at the start, as it were, with the snake in the Garden of Eden, which sells Eve on biting into the apple as assiduously as any Fuller Brush man or Avon lady would sell a whisk or a lipstick centuries later. It continues through the years until it arrives at Michael Milken plying his trade on Wall Street.
"A Nation of Salesmen" details the abrupt shifts in attitudes about selling in America's history, from the days when a nascent political democracy seemingly required economic democracy, in the form of consumerism, to assure its manifest destiny. Decades later it was the salesman's booster mentality that put the roar into the Roaring Twenties, followed by the bitterness of "a generation bankrupted by salesmen," which put the depress into the Depression. The postwar world was transformed first by television -- "as if a salesman had been placed between Americans and life" -- and then by human salesmen like Lee Iacocca, Donald Trump and Mr. Milken, all of whom Mr. Shorris deftly skewers.
Politicians -- who sell by making policies conform to voters' desires rather than by making products conform to consumers' desires -- do not escape his barbs: if voters found one aspect of Bill Clinton "most unpalatable, it was the suspicion that the Democratic candidate was a salesman, 'Slick Willie.' Apparently, they could live with the rest of his foibles."
And many of Mr. Shorris's former colleagues on Madison Avenue will squirm as they read his opinions of what he once did for a living. Advertising "is not immoral, except as waste is immoral," goes a typical passage. "It is closer to bad art than to good business."
The book is thankfully free of cant and stereotype about selling, particularly the belief that all who sell are by nature guilty and all to whom they sell by nature innocent. To answer those who maintain that salesmen manipulate their customers by creating desire, he outlines how selling can only exploit desires that already exist -- contradicting his former employer, Ayer, which after a series of reversals that left it "too desperate for subtlety" posted a sign in its main reception area reading: "We create your wants. We create your desires."
One aspect of "A Nation of Salesmen" that might disconcert readers is that each chapter begins with a fictional depiction of a salesman plying his trade. While some of these musings are effective, they more properly might have appeared in another kind of book. Another distraction comes in spotting a mistake like referring to Robert Bork as David.
But those are minor reservations about an important work.
So, are you sold yet?
