SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1030 words

HEADLINE: Rise of the Blue Helmets

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis; Paul Lewis, who was the United Nations bureau chief for The New York Times for seven years, now covers international economics.

 BODY:

THE UNITED NATIONS, IRAN, AND IRAQ
How Peacemaking Changed.
By Cameron R. Hume.
269 pp. Bloomington:
Indiana University Press. $29.95. 
LIKE a similar but more famous event in Boston over 200 years before, the tea party Javier Perez de Cuellar gave on Jan. 16, 1987, proved a harbinger of dramatic political change in the world. In his 38th-floor United Nations office overlooking Turtle Bay, the Secretary General used the occasion to plead with the United Nations representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China, the five members who had permanent Security Council seats and a veto on decisions, to sink their differences and take decisive action to end the murderous war between Iraq and Iran, then entering its seventh year.
His carefully timed appeal fell on fertile ground. In Moscow Mikhail S. Gorbachev had just come to power, easing cold war tensions. Meanwhile, after cynically ignoring the war while selling arms to both sides -- during the conflict's first five years, Iraq and Iran together accounted for 78 percent of China's arms exports, 68 percent of France's, 51 percent of Britain's, 33 percent of the Soviet Union's and 31 percent of America's -- the five big powers were now worried that the struggle might spark a wider Middle East conflagration.
Sir John Thompson, Britain's man at the United Nations, responded to the Secretary General's appeal by promptly inviting his colleagues from the United States, France, China and the Soviet Union to a series of secret meetings held in the drawing room of his Beekman Place residence.
Over the next few months the P-5, as the permanent members are informally known, drafted a resolution that in ensuing years was to serve as a model for United Nations action aimed at dampening conflicts around the world. Adopted by the Security Council in July, Resolution 598 demanded an immediate cease-fire between Iraq and Iran, the withdrawal of both sides' forces from occupied territory, the insertion of peacekeepers between them and a negotiated settlement to their quarrel.
It is the thesis of "The United Nations, Iran, and Iraq," a ground-breaking book written by a rising star of the American diplomatic service who was himself intimately involved in the Beekman Place negotiations, that these meetings marked the beginning of the present renaissance in the United Nations' fortunes.
Resolution 598 did not, in fact, bring a quick end to the Iraq-Iran war, which dragged on for another year. But its important truth, Cameron R. Hume argues, was what it showed the P-5 -- that after 42 years of cold war paralysis they were capable of exercising their common responsibility under the United Nations Charter for curbing wars and other threats to peace around the globe.
That discovery, he says, enabled them to bring Namibia to independence; resolve longstanding civil wars in Central America and Cambodia; impose punishing trade embargoes on errant nations like Iraq, Yugoslavia, Haiti and Libya; and most spectacularly of all, launch the 1991 gulf war that drove Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. Ironically, Iraq's decision to invade Iran in 1980 became the catalyst for its defeat in 1991.
SUCH achievements led to an explosion in United Nations peacekeeping, so that today the United Nations has 70,000 blue helmets serving in 18 different operations at an annual cost of over $3 billion.
As Mr. Hume writes: "Soon after the council first met in 1945, it became a place for divisive public arguments rather than for solving conflicts through collective action. Then, starting in 1985, changed Soviet policies and improved superpower relations made cooperation within the council possible. In 1987 the council's permanent members cooperated to seek an end to the Iran-Iraq war. By 1990 such cooperation was an established practice, making possible for the first time the use of the U.N. Charter's progression of steps for collective security."
Mr. Hume, who is now back at the United Nations as a top political adviser to Madeleine K. Albright, the United States' chief delegate, guides the reader through the complex diplomacy that surrounded the Iraq-Iran war, showing how the great powers came to recognize that ending the conflict was in their interests. He then carries the story forward, relating how the P-5 expanded their cooperation into other areas, creating in theprocess a powerful new institution that meets almost daily at United Nations headquarters in New York and serves as the Security Council's driving motor. And he provides a detailed concluding account of the negotiations that lead to the authorization of Operation Desert Storm by the Security Council.
The Security Council has no difficulty authorizing classical peacekeeping operations where blue helmets monitor a truce between belligerents anxious to make peace. But the United Nations Charter also foresees members placing their armies under Security Council command to impose peace on warlike nations.
At the end of his book Mr. Hume asks a pertinent question about peacekeeping's future that he does not answer. Is authorizing individual nations to use force, as in the gulf war and now Haiti, the closest the council can realistically get these days to creating a permanent peace enforcement system as foreseen in the United Nations Charter? The tentative answer must be that the big powers show as little appetite for placing their forces under United Nations command now as they did during the Iraq-Iran war, when the United States rejected Moscow's call for a United Nations fleet to protect Persian Gulf shipping, preferring to do the job itself. Since that time the United States, Russia and France have all asked the Security Council to authorize private military interventions in Somalia, Haiti, Georgia and Rwanda, when they felt their interests or prestige were at risk.
A Security Council blessing may now be necessary to give legitimacy to such operations. But the practice of United Nations intervention that has grown up since the Beekman Place meetings is far removed from the system of enforced collective security that the charter's authors envisaged.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (89%);

HEADLINE: FILM;
A Romanian Director Tells A Tale of Ethnic Madness

BYLINE: By ANNETTE INSDORF; Annette Insdorf is head of the film division of the School of the Arts at Columbia University.

 BODY:
Lucian Pintilie couldn't simply bask in the glow of the reception for his film "An Unforgettable Summer" at the Telluride Film Festival, in Colorado, in September. The Romanian film maker was incredulous that he couldn't smoke indoors. For someone who had just made a film about tolerance and freedom -- or the lack thereof -- no-smoking policies were a reason to grumble.
Then again the 61-year-old Mr. Pintilie (pronounced pin-teel-YEE-ay), whose film opens in New York on Friday, has been known as someone who does what he wants. After becoming one of Romania's leading directors of theater, film and television, in 1972 he was deemed subversive and unemployable by the Communist Government, which suspended his stage production of Gogol's "Inspector General," a satire of governmental bureaucracy. 
 "I was told, 'If you want to continue working here, you have to change your conception of the world.' I answered, 'But I've just started formulating it.' " He leans forward and enunciates each syllable: " 'All I can do is develop it.' "
Mr. Pintilie lived and worked abroad from 1973 to 1990 with dizzying mobility, building a reputation as a director of theatrical productions like "The Magic Flute" in Italy, "Turandot" in France and "Carmen" in Wales. By 1990, a year after the collapse of the Communist regime, Romania was far more welcoming: Mr. Pintilie returned as head of national film production at the Ministry of Culture.
Just two years later his movie "The Oak," a darkly comic reaction to the fall of the regime, was acclaimed internationally. "Though sometimes baffling," wrote Vincent Canby in The New York Times, "the film is never boring. It begins as a nightmare and ends with a vague expectation of the break of day."
"An Unforgettable Summer" (in Romanian, with English subtitles) unfolds in 1925 at a ball in Romania, where the radiant Marie-Therese Von Debretsy (Kristin Scott-Thomas, from "Four Weddings and a Funeral") scorns the advances of a general, her husband's superior in the Romanian Army. Her rejection leads him to transfer the couple and their children to an isolated garrison on the Danube.
But, says Robert D. Kaplan, the author of "Balkan Ghosts: A Journey Through History," "Romania in the 1920's was like Germany," in that no one was certain about borders. This was the time of the Balkan Wars, with their unceasing ethnic conflicts, and soon Marie-Therese's husband is commanded to take Bulgarian villagers hostage to avenge the massacre of Romanian guards by Macedonian bandits (primarily of Bulgarian origin). When he refuses orders to kill the hostages, the family is sent to an even more remote post -- and the Bulgarians are executed anyway.
Yet at the conclusion of "An Unforgettable Summer," the narrator -- one of the children, now grown -- recalls the warm months of 1925 as a beautiful memory. "The irony was deliberate on my part," Mr. Pintilie says. "Maybe I'm even a bit perverse to begin the film in a light and playful way: people fall into the trap of thinking it's not a serious film.
"Then I allow myself the last sarcasm at the end: even if the child remembers it as 'unforgettable,' it's better not to have a summer like that."
ALTHOUGH MR. PINTILIE adapted the film from Petru Dumitriu's short story "The Salad," the tale has personal resonance. When the director left Romania, he was "older than the boy of the tale, 6 or 7 rather than 3," he says, "with the perception only of what is idyllic." And like the captain in the film, Mr. Pintilie is no stranger to absurd displacement. He was born in the region of Bessarabia, in a German village inhabited by Romanians, Ruthenians, Turks, Tartars, Jews, Ukrainians and Russians.
"There wasn't even a hint of racial tension," he recalls. "Everybody lived without being conscious of their differences." When he left, he spoke "a sort of Esperanto, a patchwork of languages that exasperated and enchanted everyone."
World War II ushered in what he describes as a paradise lost: "One night, German schoolteacher colleagues of my father's rang our doorbell; they were terrified, like escaped convicts. What an irony of fate that the first victims of ethnic cleansing I encountered were German!"
Curiously, "An Unforgettable Summer" seems to criticize an era for which Mr. Pintilie professes affection: "If there's one regime with which I identify, it's the bourgeois regime up to the arrival of the Communists. And I'm proud to belong to a people known for their tolerance."
In the film, Mr. Pintilie depicts what he sees as the bad aspects of the regime. "I believe that an artist should not be a hostage to his own political convictions," he says. "If the Romanians are shown as intolerant, at least once, it has to be discussed. Each person, in this ethnic madness, must clean his own doorstep."
He expresses surprise that the American press generally believes "ethnic conflicts always existed and that Communism prevented them from surfacing," as he puts it.
"There has always been this absurd and monstrous manifestation in history of fanning ethnic conflicts to reinforce power. In 'An Unforgettable Summer' the Bulgarian peasants have no consciousness of ethnic difference: they are executed simply because examples must be set."
Mr. Pintilie now plans to direct a contemporary film, followed by a sequel to "An Unforgettable Summer." It will depict Marie-Therese transformed into a possessive mother who chases young women away from her son. "I will start the sequel in two years," he says. "My life is programmed. I only hope God doesn't spit on my plans."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The director Lucian Pintilie, above, and, at right, Kristin Scott-Thomas and Claudiu Bleont in Mr. Pintilie's "Unforgettable Summer" -- Exiles all. (Photographs from MK2 Productions)

HEADLINE: Erosion Pact Could Help Other Beaches Around U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

 BODY:
AN $80 million pact by the Army Corps of Engineers to restore the beaches of West Hampton Dunes and modify the jetties in Westhampton Beach could set a precedent for similar accords between Washington and other shorelines.
The agreement not only benefits homeowners in West Hampton Dunes who suffered severe damage in the major storm in December 1992, but it will also protect Moriches Bay and low-lying mainland areas, as well as create a two-mile-long public beach in the Hamptons. 
 The beach, when coupled with Pike's Beach, which Southampton owns, and Cupsogue Beach County Park, will be a significant amenity on the South Shore, with more than 2,000 parking spaces, according to Mayor Gary Vegliante of West Hampton Dunes, president of the Barrier Beach Preservation Association. Mr. Vegliante added:
"This should help to answer the concerns of many people who do not live near the water who say, 'Why should the government pay for the protection of beach property?' They'll also be helping to preserve endangered and threatened sea birds like the piping plover and rare plants like the seabeach amaranth.
"The agreement works for the general public, environmentalists and property owners. It's a solution that could be applied in similar disputes all along the East Coast and in California." Mr. Vegliante said his village of 750 residents had fewer than 90 houses, down from 270 before the 1992 storm.
Among the winners in the agreement, although not party to the suit, are residents of Fire Island and other barrier beaches west of the Hamptons, according to Gerard Stoddard, chairman of the Long Island Coastal Alliance and president of the Fire Island Association.
"It may take as long as 10 years," Mr. Stoddard said, "but the river of sand that normally drifts westward past the Hamptons groin field should someday again start replenishing Fire Island. The people on Fire Island are not only relieved that this agreement is finally in place, but that the settlement recognizes it was a major mistake not to complete that groin field. The Government is beginning to realize that if it's going to fiddle around with inlets and put up groins it's got to deal with the results and maintain them just as it maintains its highways, roads and bridges."
Mr. Stoddard noted that the settlement was in line with recommendations by the State Coastal Erosion Task Force. That panel has urged government agencies to correct problems created by interfering with natural coastal processes and that the work provides such public benefits as recreational areas, parking and restrooms.
Supervisor Fred W. Thiele Jr. of Southampton said although he was not a party to the pact he was pleased that "the long overdue settlement had finally been reached."
"The loss of the beaches along Dune Road have kept a lot of tourists out of Southampton over the last two years," Mr. Thiele said. "We're looking forward to their coming back and to a return of equity for the homeowners in that area, which was so adversely economically impacted."
The agreement, which settles a $200 million suit by homeowners in West Hampton Dunes, was filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last week and signed by officials of the Army, State and Suffolk County.
The final settlement includes a provision calling for the Army to build "an interim storm-damage-protection plan" that the State Environmental Conservation Department had proposed. That project calls for restabilizing beaches in West Hampton Dunes to a depth of 420 feet from the center of Dune Road to the Atlantic at high tide at an initial cost of $30.6 million. The Federal portion of the initial cost is $21.4 million, and the non-Federal cost is $9.2 million, of which the state will pay 70 percent and the county 30.
An east-west dune line will be constructed from the last jetty of the Westhampton Beach groin field to Cupsogue County Park. The northern end of the line will be a minimum of 100 feet south of Dune Road, allowing for the reconstruction of houses in the 100-foot zone, according to John J. O'Connell of the law firm of Stein, Zauderer, Ellenhorn, Frischer & Sharp in Manhattan, who represented the homeowners.
The project also provides for 30 years of maintenance by the Army at $1.5 million a year, according to Peter Shugert, a spokesman for the New York office. Mr. Shugert aid the plan consisted of re-establishing the beach to the west of groin No. 15 at nine and a half feet above sea level, backed by a 13-foot-high dune.
The plan also includes shortening groins Nos. 14 and 15 at the western end of the line of jetties. An additional groin, or jetty, will be constructed between Nos. 14 and 15, and the compartments between Nos. 11 and 15 will be filled with sand.
Mr. Shugert said the tapering of the groin system was to encourage the littoral drift of sand to provide material west of the groin field.
The Army had planned to install 21 jetties in the late 1960's and 1970's in a hurricane-protection program. The final six jetties, which would have completed the project to a downdrift point of closure, were canceled because of political and budget problems in Suffolk.
There has been no construction work on the groin field since the early 70's, and substantial sectors have been filled as they trapped the sand that naturally drifts from east to west. But the shore immediately after jetty No. 15, lacking drifting sand, was vulnerable to scouring by tides and storms.
The problems created by the unfinished field came to a head in the winter of 1992, when a half-mile-wide breach opened at Pike's Beach in West Hampton Dunes, washing away nearly 200 houses, Dune Road and utility services linking the village to the mainland.
The Army has refilled the breach and plans to resolve the problems created by the jetties. The work is to begin at the end of next year and take about a year to complete. It is to provide protection against a 44-year storm, meaning, Mr. O'Connell said, the beach would be able to survive a storm about four times the intensity of the December 1992 storm.
The Army has also promised to revive a dormant study of erosion between Montauk Point and Fire Island Inlet. The corps now estimates that the study will take 10 years.
The settlement agreement also provides for Suffolk County to pay $4 million to West Hampton Dunes to cover legal fees for the suit and for infrastructure repairs. Mr. O'Connell said the property from the southern side of Dune Road to the southern toe of the dune line, a distance of 190 feet, would remain in the hands of the property owners. The county will own the area south of that line to the ocean as a public beach, and the public will have access to the area through Cupsogue Park, Pike's Beach and six pedestrian crossings to be built along Dune Road.
The settlement, Mr. O'Connell said, will provide homeowners with the complete restoration of their property and property values. At present, he said, the property is viewed essentially as valueless because of the erosion.

HEADLINE: How the Candidates For Statewide Offices See Major Issues On Election Eve

 BODY:
The political races of '94 are almost run, and along the way, the candidates have spoken hundreds of thousands of words -- in speeches, debates, mailings and advertisements. Often, though, dialogue on the issues of governing has been overshadowed by discussion of other matters, some substantive, others less so. 
 Here is a look at the key issues in the four statewide races -- for Governor, Comptroller, Attorney General and United States Senator -- and what the major candidates have said about them.
 
ISSUES: RACE FOR SENATE IN NEW YORK
 
Daniel Patrick Moynihan
 
Personal: Democrat. Senator, elected 1976. Served in the administrations of four Presidents -- Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and Ford.
 
Views On Qualifications For Office: A self-described "Al Smith Democrat," he offers nearly four decades in public life, three terms in the Senate, and the chairmanship of the Senate Finance Committee, wielding power over taxes, Social Security and trade -- half the Federal budget.
 
On Abortion: Supports a woman's right to abortion. Of Ms. Castro's financing proposal, he asked, "Does anybody really think that makes a difference?" and noted that the states pay the cost of Medicaid-financed abortions.
 
On GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade): He is a staunch advocate of the international agreement, which is one of President Clinton's highest legislative priorities and would lower tariffs by an average of 40 percent to promote exports around the world. He calls it "the largest tax cut in history and the culmination of 60 years of American trade policy."
 
Bernadette Castro
 
Personal: Republican. Former chief executive of Castro Convertibles
 
Views On Qualifications For Office: Calls herself a "Christine Todd Whitman Republican," and says she would offer an alternative to Mr. Moynihan's approach to government, including holding the line on taxation.
 
On Abortion: Says she supports a woman's right to abortion and Medicaid financing for poor women; however, she says those who oppose abortion should be allowed a check-off on their Federal tax returns stipulating that none of their payments go to finance it.
 
On GATT (the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade): Says she is favorably inclined toward GATT, although she fears that the agreement might lead to a loss of manufacturing jobs, especially for unskilled workers.
 
ISSUES: RACE FOR GOVERNOR
 
Mario M. Cuomo
 
Personal: Democrat. Governor, elected 1982. Lieutenant Governor, 1979-82.
 
Views On Economy And Taxes: Has called for a package of tax cuts that would be worth up to $1.7 billion, but has not disclosed details about how long he would take to cut taxes by that amount, how he would structure the reductions and how he would pay for them. Favors reducing the top income tax rate from 7.875 percent to 7 percent for single people earning more than $13,000 but less than $50,000 a year and for married couples earning more than $26,000 but less than $100,000. In addition, would increase the state's credit on the income tax for those who pay a large proportion of their income in property taxes, and would cut the state's tax on utility revenues, known as the gross receipts tax, from 4.25 percent to 2 percent. Would insist that the savings be passed along to ratepayers and not kept by the utilities.
 
On Crime: Opposes the death penalty on moral and practical grounds, but supports a referendum that would give voters a choice between the death penalty and his preferred maximum sentence of life imprisonment without parole. Supports life without the possibility of parole for third-time violent felons. Favors banning assault weapons, with provisions to allow collectors and target shooters to own them under certain circumstances. Favors eliminating the state law requiring prison time for second felony offenders, saying that more drug treatment is needed for many such criminals.
 
On Welfare: Would gradually expand his program to force many welfare applicants to search for work before they are placed on the rolls. Would expand the Child Assistance Program, which gives some welfare mothers financial incentives to pursue child support orders from fathers and to find work. Would expand the state's workfare program. Would require children of welfare recipients to go to school and to live at home. Would expand fingerprinting of welfare recipients to the entire state.
 
On Abortion: Supports abortion rights and Medicaid financing of abortions without restrictions.
 
On Education: Would revamp the state's education aid formula to drive more money to New York City, which has 37 percent of the state's students and receives less than 35 percent of state aid. Favors special schools for the state's brightest students. Supports reducing state regulations over schools and offering them more local control. Would abolish the Board of Regents and give the Governor the authority to appoint the Education Commissioner. Would allow parents to choose among several public schools for their children.
 
George E. Pataki
 
Personal: Republican. State Senator, elected 1992. State Assemblyman, 1984-92. Mayor of Peekskill, 1981-84.
 
Views On Economy And Taxes: Has proposed a tax-cut package that would be worth $5.6 billion by the fourth year. Says it could be financed by cutting waste in state government agencies, keeping growth in the state budget to the rate of inflation, and revenue growth of 6 percent a year. Has not provided detailed plans for spending cuts. Would reduce the top income tax rate from 7.875 percent to 5.9 percent, while raising the annual income for the top tax bracket from $26,000 to $50,000 for married couples. Would keep the bottom rate at 4 percent. Would replace the current $1,000 exemption for dependents with a tax credit of $200 for each dependent. Would raise the earned income tax credit for lower-income working people to 20 percent of the Federal earned income tax credit immediately rather than waiting until 1997, as is required under a law passed this year. Has called for a variety of cuts in business taxes, but has not actually proposed any specific measures.
 
On Crime: Favors the death penalty for murderers. Would end parole and work release programs for violent felons. Would require mandatory prison terms for those who use a weapon in the commission of a felony. Favors an absolute ban on assault weapons. Supports more prison construction if it is needed to house felons. Opposes rescinding the state law that requires prison time for second-time felons, even if their crimes were nonviolent.
 
On Welfare: Would require more welfare recipients to work in public sector or community service jobs like cleaning highways and government buildings. Would threaten welfare families with the loss of their benefits if their children do not attend school. Would increase use of managed care in the Medicaid program. Would eliminate certain services provided by the state's Medicaid program, but has only identified a few. Supports statewide fingerprinting of welfare recipients and other measures to combat fraud.
 
On Abortion: Says he unequivocally supports abortion rights, but acknowledges that he has changed positions on the issue twice. Favors a state law requiring notification of the parents of girls under 16 who seek abortions. Opposes Medicaid financing of abortions unless it includes mandatory counseling on birth control.
 
On Education: Would cut the Education Department bureaucracy, but has not said how or by how much. Supports abolishing the Board of Regents and giving the Governor the authority to appoint the Education Commissioner. Would allow parents to choose among several public schools for their children. Favors increasing state aid to schools, but refuses to say if he believes the state's education aid formula is fair to New York City.
 
B. Thomas Golisano
 
Personal: Independent-Fusion. Founder, in 1971, of Paychex Inc., a Rochester company that prepares payrolls for small businesses.
 
Views On Economy And Taxes: Says the state's business climate is ruinous principally because of a state and local tax combination that he says is 45 percent higher than the national average. Over the next 10 years, he says, the tax burden must be reduced to no more than 5 to 10 percent above the national average, which would produce a tax cut even more dramatic than Mr. Pataki's. Wants to cut spending by about 50 percent over a decade, but beyond targeting welfare and Medicaid, has not been specific about where the cuts would come from.
 
On Crime: Proposes what he calls a "holistic approach" to crime, primarily by improving the state economy. Beyond that, proposes tougher sentencing for violent criminals and more emphasis on rehabilitation in prison, and would sign the death penalty into law. Has talked about decriminalizing certain drugs, but now says he wants to study the issue.
 
On Welfare: Says the state attracts welfare recipients because its welfare benefits are too generous compared to those of other states. Proposes cutting benefits substantially to match other states', as well as slashing administrative costs. Wants to reduce benefits for welfare recipients who have more than one baby, and to structure benefits to encourage teen-age mothers to live at home, rather than in subsidized apartments.
 
On Abortion: Supports abortion rights
 
On Education: Supports a sliding tuition at state colleges and universities, based on the applicant's ability to pay, as well as greater local control of schools.
 
ISSUES: RACE FOR COMPTROLLER
 
H. Carl McCall
 
Personal: Democrat-Liberal. Minster, United Church of Christ. State Senator from Manhattan, 1975-79. Deputy delegate to the United Nations, 1979-81. Citibank vice president, 1985-93. New York City Board of Education president, 1991-93. Appointed Comptroller, 1993.
 
Views On The Office: Sees audits as "management tools" to save money in state and local government. Would like to expand the Comptroller's role in the budget process by giving him the authority to approve revenue projections. Wants to use the pension fund to help finance job creation while still insuring a good return on investment.
 
Debt Reform: Prime sponsor of a debt-reform package that would limit the state's total debt and restructure the way money is borrowed. It would allow the Governor and Legislature to approve billions in debt without voter approval - the amount would be tied to the total personal income in the state - but would also end fiscal gimmicks like "back-door borrowing,' in which public assets are sold to a governmental authority that can issue bonds on its own.
 
Their Ideas For Government: Advocates lower taxes, especially on businesses, state takeover of local Medicaid costs and consolidation of governmental service. Also wants to expand audits of school districts. Wants new rules that would prohibit state spending untile a budget is passed.
 
Herbert London
 
Personal: Republican Conservative-Right to Life. John M. Olin professor of humanities at New York University, where he was dean of the Gallatin Division for 20 years. Conservative Party candidate for New York City Mayor, 1989. Conservative Party candidate for Governor, 1990.
 
Views On The Office: Has called the Comptroller's job a "think tank" for changing government and advocating for tax cuts. Wants to use the office to re-examine governmental structure and efficiency, including overlapping local jurisdications. Believes that the Comptroller should have a larger role in forcing the Legislature and Governor to deliver more responsible budgets.
 
Debt Reform: Opposes Mr. McCall's proposal. Says its debt ceiling is too high and believes that voters should approve all debt related to capital projects for the state and its authorities.
 
Their Ideas For Government: Advocates lower taxes and creating a better enviroment for business. Has spoken in favor of greater privatization of governmental services, a Medicaid takeover, increased competitive bidding and the introduction of school vouchers, starting with special education.
 
ISSUES: RACE FOR ATTORNEY GENERAL
 
Karen S. Burstein
 
Personal: Democrat. State Senator, 1973-78; member, State Public Service Commission, 1978-80; executive director, State Consumer Protection Board, 1980-83; president, State Civil Service Commission, 1983-87; New York City auditor general, 1987-90; Family Court judge in Brooklyn, 1990-April 1994.
 
Views On Role Of Attorney General: Maintains that the Attorney General is not a "super prosecutor" whose mission is to fight street crime. But has promised to be a "crusader" on domestic violence by helping to coordinate prevention efforts in the state. Has also said that she will focus on civil rights cases, environmental crimes and fraud against consumers and the elderly.
 
On Abortion: She is a longtime supporter of women's rights, including the right to abortion, and says that she would vigorously enforce abortion laws, including a new Federal law giving state attorneys general broader authority in guaranteeing access to abortion clinics.
 
On Death Penalty: Opposes the death penalty, arguing that it does not deter crime, but says she would enforce it if it were to become law in New York State.
 
Dennis C. Vacco
 
Personal: Republican. United States Attorney for the Western District of New York, 1988-93; chief of the grand jury bureau, Eric County District Attorney's office, Erie County, 1978-82.
 
Views On Role Of Attorney General: Believes that the Attorney General ought to be given a greater role in combating crime. He has promised to lobby the Governor and the State Legislature for tougher anti-crime laws.
 
On Abortion: Is personally opposed to abortion, but says that he, too, would work to enforce abortion laws.
 
On Death Penalty: Favors it and says he will work to persuade the Governor and the Legislature to adopt a death-penalty law.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%); 

COMPANY: SENATE (US) GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS & TRADE (72%); GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS & TRADE (55%); 

ORGANIZATION: SENATE (US) GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS & TRADE (72%); GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS & TRADE (55%);

HEADLINE: How the Candidates For Statewide Offices See Major Issues On Election Eve

 BODY:
The political races of '94 are almost run, and along the way, the candidates have spoken hundreds of thousands of words -- in speeches, debates, mailings and advertisements. Often, though, dialogue on the issues of governing has been overshadowed by discussion of other matters, some substantive, others less so.

ISSUES: RACE FOR SENATE IN NEW YORK
 
Daniel Patrick Moynihan
 
Personal: Democrat. Senator, elected 1976. Served in the administrations of four Presidents -- Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and Ford.
 
Views On Qualifications For Office: A self-described "Al Smith Democrat," he offers nearly four decades in public life, three terms in the Senate, and the chairmanship of the Senate Finance Committee, wielding power over taxes, Social Security and trade -- half the Federal budget.
 
On Abortion: Supports a woman's right to abortion. Of Ms. Castro's financing proposal, he asked, "Does anybody really think that makes a difference?" and noted that the states pay the cost of Medicaid-financed abortions.
 
On GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade): He is a staunch advocate of the international agreement, which is one of President Clinton's highest legislative priorities and would lower tariffs by an average of 40 percent to promote exports around the world. He calls it "the largest tax cut in history and the culmination of 60 years of American trade policy."
 
Bernadette Castro
 
Personal: Republican. Former chief executive of Castro Convertibles
 
Views On Qualifications For Office: Calls herself a "Christine Todd Whitman Republican," and says she would offer an alternative to Mr. Moynihan's approach to government, including holding the line on taxation.
 
On Abortion: Says she supports a woman's right to abortion and Medicaid financing for poor women; however, she says those who oppose abortion should be allowed a check-off on their Federal tax returns stipulating that none of their payments go to finance it.
 
On GATT (the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade): Says she is favorably inclined toward GATT, although she fears that the agreement might lead to a loss of manufacturing jobs, especially for unskilled workers.
 
ISSUES: RACE FOR GOVERNOR
 
Mario M. Cuomo
 
Personal: Democrat. Governor, elected 1982. Lieutenant Governor, 1979-82.
 
Views On Economy And Taxes: Has called for a package of tax cuts that would be worth up to $1.7 billion, but has not disclosed details about how long he would take to cut taxes by that amount, how he would structure the reductions and how he would pay for them. Favors reducing the top income tax rate from 7.875 percent to 7 percent for single people earning more than $13,000 but less than $50,000 a year and for married couples earning more than $26,000 but less than $100,000. In addition, would increase the state's credit on the income tax for those who pay a large proportion of their income in property taxes, and would cut the state's tax on utility revenues, known as the gross receipts tax, from 4.25 percent to 2 percent. Would insist that the savings be passed along to ratepayers and not kept by the utilities.
 
On Crime: Opposes the death penalty on moral and practical grounds, but supports a referendum that would give voters a choice between the death penalty and his preferred maximum sentence of life imprisonment without parole. Supports life without the possibility of parole for third-time violent felons. Favors banning assault weapons, with provisions to allow collectors and target shooters to own them under certain circumstances. Favors eliminating the state law requiring prison time for second felony offenders, saying that more drug treatment is needed for many such criminals.
 
On Welfare: Would gradually expand his program to force many welfare applicants to search for work before they are placed on the rolls. Would expand the Child Assistance Program, which gives some welfare mothers financial incentives to pursue child support orders from fathers and to find work. Would expand the state's workfare program. Would require children of welfare recipients to go to school and to live at home. Would expand fingerprinting of welfare recipients to the entire state.
 
On Abortion: Supports abortion rights and Medicaid financing of abortions without restrictions.
 
On Education: Would revamp the state's education aid formula to drive more money to New York City, which has 37 percent of the state's students and receives less than 35 percent of state aid. Favors special schools for the state's brightest students. Supports reducing state regulations over schools and offering them more local control. Would abolish the Board of Regents and give the Governor the authority to appoint the Education Commissioner. Would allow parents to choose among several public schools for their children.
 
George E. Pataki
 
Personal: Republican. State Senator, elected 1992. State Assemblyman, 1984-92. Mayor of Peekskill, 1981-84.
 
Views On Economy And Taxes: Has proposed a tax-cut package that would be worth $5.6 billion by the fourth year. Says it could be financed by cutting waste in state government agencies, keeping growth in the state budget to the rate of inflation, and revenue growth of 6 percent a year. Has not provided detailed plans for spending cuts. Would reduce the top income tax rate from 7.875 percent to 5.9 percent, while raising the annual income for the top tax bracket from $26,000 to $50,000 for married couples. Would keep the bottom rate at 4 percent. Would replace the current $1,000 exemption for dependents with a tax credit of $200 for each dependent. Would raise the earned income tax credit for lower-income working people to 20 percent of the Federal earned income tax credit immediately rather than waiting until 1997, as is required under a law passed this year. Has called for a variety of cuts in business taxes, but has not actually proposed any specific measures.
 
On Crime: Favors the death penalty for murderers. Would end parole and work release programs for violent felons. Would require mandatory prison terms for those who use a weapon in the commission of a felony. Favors an absolute ban on assault weapons. Supports more prison construction if it is needed to house felons. Opposes rescinding the state law that requires prison time for second-time felons, even if their crimes were nonviolent.
 
On Welfare: Would require more welfare recipients to work in public sector or community service jobs like cleaning highways and government buildings. Would threaten welfare families with the loss of their benefits if their children do not attend school. Would increase use of managed care in the Medicaid program. Would eliminate certain services provided by the state's Medicaid program, but has only identified a few. Supports statewide fingerprinting of welfare recipients and other measures to combat fraud.
 
On Abortion: Says he unequivocally supports abortion rights, but acknowledges that he has changed positions on the issue twice. Favors a state law requiring notification of the parents of girls under 16 who seek abortions. Opposes Medicaid financing of abortions unless it includes mandatory counseling on birth control.
 
On Education: Would cut the Education Department bureaucracy, but has not said how or by how much. Supports abolishing the Board of Regents and giving the Governor the authority to appoint the Education Commissioner. Would allow parents to choose among several public schools for their children. Favors increasing state aid to schools, but refuses to say if he believes the state's education aid formula is fair to New York City.
 
B. Thomas Golisano
 
Personal: Independent-Fusion. Founder, in 1971, of Paychex Inc., a Rochester company that prepares payrolls for small businesses.
 
Views On Economy And Taxes: Says the state's business climate is ruinous principally because of a state and local tax combination that he says is 45 percent higher than the national average. Over the next 10 years, he says, the tax burden must be reduced to no more than 5 to 10 percent above the national average, which would produce a tax cut even more dramatic than Mr. Pataki's. Wants to cut spending by about 50 percent over a decade, but beyond targeting welfare and Medicaid, has not been specific about where the cuts would come from.
 
On Crime: Proposes what he calls a "holistic approach" to crime, primarily by improving the state economy. Beyond that, proposes tougher sentencing for violent criminals and more emphasis on rehabilitation in prison, and would sign the death penalty into law. Has talked about decriminalizing certain drugs, but now says he wants to study the issue.
 
On Welfare: Says the state attracts welfare recipients because its welfare benefits are too generous compared to those of other states. Proposes cutting benefits substantially to match other states', as well as slashing administrative costs. Wants to reduce benefits for welfare recipients who have more than one baby, and to structure benefits to encourage teen-age mothers to live at home, rather than in subsidized apartments.
 
On Abortion: Supports abortion rights
 
On Education: Supports a sliding tuition at state colleges and universities, based on the applicant's ability to pay, as well as greater local control of schools.
 
ISSUES: RACE FOR COMPTROLLER
 
H. Carl McCall
 
Personal: Democrat-Liberal. Minster, United Church of Christ. State Senator from Manhattan, 1975-79. Deputy delegate to the United Nations, 1979-81. Citibank vice president, 1985-93. New York City Board of Education president, 1991-93. Appointed Comptroller, 1993.
 
Views On The Office: Sees audits as "management tools" to save money in state and local government. Would like to expand the Comptroller's role in the budget process by giving him the authority to approve revenue projections. Wants to use the pension fund to help finance job creation while still insuring a good return on investment.
 
Debt Reform: Prime sponsor of a debt-reform package that would limit the state's total debt and restructure the way money is borrowed. It would allow the Governor and Legislature to approve billions in debt without voter approval - the amount would be tied to the total personal income in the state - but would also end fiscal gimmicks like "back-door borrowing,' in which public assets are sold to a governmental authority that can issue bonds on its own.
 
Their Ideas For Government: Advocates lower taxes, especially on businesses, state takeover of local Medicaid costs and consolidation of governmental service. Also wants to expand audits of school districts. Wants new rules that would prohibit state spending untile a budget is passed.
 
Herbert London
 
Personal: Republican Conservative-Right to Life. John M. Olin professor of humanities at New York University, where he was dean of the Gallatin Division for 20 years. Conservative Party candidate for New York City Mayor, 1989. Conservative Party candidate for Governor, 1990.
 
Views On The Office: Has called the Comptroller's job a "think tank" for changing government and advocating for tax cuts. Wants to use the office to re-examine governmental structure and efficiency, including overlapping local jurisdications. Believes that the Comptroller should have a larger role in forcing the Legislature and Governor to deliver more responsible budgets.
 
Debt Reform: Opposes Mr. McCall's proposal. Says its debt ceiling is too high and believes that voters should approve all debt related to capital projects for the state and its authorities.
 
Their Ideas For Government: Advocates lower taxes and creating a better enviroment for business. Has spoken in favor of greater privatization of governmental services, a Medicaid takeover, increased competitive bidding and the introduction of school vouchers, starting with special education.

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD;
Geography Put Back In the Future

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GOSS 

 BODY:
CLARK UNIVERSITY in Worcester, Mass., has seen the future and it is geography.
Long ago abandoned as a separate discipline by many colleges, which incorporated it into subjects like global studies, geography has a new life in the new age.
"Environmental issues are becoming dominant on the heels of the cold war," said Dr. Roger Kasperson, the Clark provost -- and a geographer by training. Clark is creating an Environmental School "to reconcile economic development and economic growth with environmental issues," he said. 
 "As national security becomes dominated by environmental questions, we need to produce an educated person with a depth of knowledge in environmental issues that students currently don't get," Dr. Kasperson added.
The school, which is in the final stages of approval from faculty and trustees, is to begin with 50 students in the fall of 1995. Students will receive a standard liberal arts education while also pursuing "almost a second major in environmental sciences and policies," said Dr. Kasperson. Students who choose an accelerated program can also study for a fifth year and earn a master's degree.
The curriculum aims to avoid the "consciousness-raising" tone of some similar courses and to focus on "producing an education that is more rigorous and substantive than has existed in the past," he added. So some courses will have input from the humanities department, examining human interaction with the environment and emerging environmental ethics and values.
Since Clark created a graduate school of geography in 1921, it has awarded more doctorates in that area than any other school in the country.
"The increased interest in global and environmental issues," said Dr. Kasperson, "has given a real shot of adrenaline to geography."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Social Security: The Issue They Chose To Ignore

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
PESSIMISM may be this year's most important public attitude. And that will be true whether or not it leads voters to punish the Democrats.
The belief that the future is going to be worse than the present has historically been a negative for the stock market, and one market indicator, based on the Conference Board's consumer confidence index, is close to giving its first sell signal since shortly before the 1987 crash. 
 That indicator is based on how people think the economy will be in six months. But the pessimism goes much deeper than that. In the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, 57 percent of Americans say they think the next generation will be worse off than the current one. In 1990, the figure was 36 percent.
Just why people are so pessimistic about the outlook for their children and grandchildren is not easy to answer. But one part may be the fear that the political system will be unable to come to grips with long-term problems facing the country.
The most visible example of that is the health care deadlock. But it is possible to argue that the health care cost crisis, like that of energy 15 years ago, will eventually be solved by market forces. The entitlements mess is something else again.
There are few politicians who do not realize that the budget deficit cannot be brought under control without attacking middle-class entitlements, of which Social Security is the most important. But they fear even mentioning the fact.
Both Democrats and Republicans have been accused of planning to do something responsible. Both have indignantly denied it.
But the most depressing aspect of the campaign and entitlements came from the Republicans' Contract with America, put together by Newt Gingrich, the would-be speaker of the House. It promises to raise Social Security benefits for the better off by reducing taxes on such benefits for those with substantial incomes. The taxes, part of last year's deficit reduction plan, slanted benefits a bit toward those who really need them, which is the direction almost every expert thinks is needed. But Mr. Gingrich is going for quick political popularity.
Social Security is a prime example of the dangers of a good marketing campaign. It was sold as a pension plan by Franklin Roosevelt, and that is still how many see it, figuring they contributed to it and therefore deserve to get their money back.
In fact, it is and always has been a transfer program, taking money from working people and giving it to the retired and disabled. View it as a transfer program, and the idea of providing benefits only to those who need them is obvious. But the political system is unable to act. And the public grows more pessimistic each year. When asked about the effect of President Clinton's hard-won deficit reduction bill, 24 percent of Americans say it raised the deficit, while only 17 percent think it lowered it.
To long-term bears on the dollar, the entitlements gridlock is argument No. 1. To pay its bills, they say, America eventually must debase the currency.
For now, the gridlock probably has been good for the stock market. Retirement savings are on the rise because many doubt Social Security will be there for them, and a lot of that money ends up in stocks. But that may not last. Bear markets often come along with weak, unsuccessful Administrations.

HEADLINE: Ticketmaster's Mr. Tough Guy

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
PERHAPS the only thing not in rancorous dispute in the ticketing business these days is this: ticketmaster wanted the business and Ticketmaster got the business. In the pugnacious world of selling entertainment and sports tickets, Ticketmaster is the winner and still ambitious champion.
It is the company that figured out how to sell tickets quickly by phone and at retail outlets. It cultivated the music industry and other contacts so that it would have tickets to sell. It then bound the stadiums, halls and other sites to long-term exclusive contracts that kept rivals out in the cold. 
 Most important, it shared the revenue from ticket service charges so that the sites would make more money if Ticketmaster, rather than the sites alone, sold the tickets.
As a result, Ticketmaster enjoys the exclusive rights to be the outside sales agent for nearly two-thirds of the nation's 10 million seats at major halls. A handful of rivals, like Dillard's in Phoenix and Protix in Madison, Wis., scramble for the rest.
Ticketmaster's reward: last year, it handled more than $1.3 billion worth of tickets, collecting $191.1 million in service and other charges from what is far and away the biggest markup in the business.
The Public Interest Research Group, a consumer advocacy organization, recently contended that Ticketmaster's fees added almost 30 percent to the face value of an average ticket. Ticketmaster says the group's estimate is too high because its sample is too small; the company says its service charge adds 14 percent to the cost of the average ticket.
Ticketmaster is a company marked by what supporters call grit and critics call guile -- and the Government may yet call monopoly.
The simmering uneasiness with Ticketmaster's market dominance reached a head this summer, when the rock group Pearl Jam accused the company of anticompetitive practices and canceled its summer tour. Pearl Jam demanded that the Government investigate Ticketmaster as a possible monopoly.
Suddenly, promoters, agents and other entertainers joined Pearl Jam's crusade. Congress held hearings. The Justice Department began an antitrust inquiry, which is continuing. A rash of class-action suits against Ticketmaster, accusing it of monopolistic practices, including exorbitant service charges, followed.
Whether a company's broad reach constitutes a monopoly is a complex legal and economic question, complicated further in Ticketmaster's case by the fact that unlike, say, the old Bell telephone system, Ticketmaster has relatively little control over supply -- the tickets themselves.
But for critics, the issue is clear-cut. "It's really very simple," said Kelly Curtis, Pearl Jam's manager. "Ticketmaster said, 'If you don't like us, go someplace else.' But we found out that there wasn't anyplace else."
Robert Sacks, a lawyer for Pearl Jam, said, "The genius of Ticketmaster was in converting what was a pain in the neck, selling tickets, into a profit center by tacking on high service charges. If you're a stadium, that's fantastic. But who gets hurt by that? The fans."
Nonsense, except he does not say nonsense, said Frederic D. Rosen, Ticketmaster's profane president and chief executive. "If we do have a lot of market share, guess what?" he asked. "We earned it! And if we earned it, it's something to be proud of. Proud of!"
Tired of the bad publicity, Mr. Rosen is fighting back by allowing a rare look inside Ticketmaster, a privately owned company whose services millions use but whose inside workings few have ever seen.
How the company became the market leader is pretty much the story of Fred Rosen, who convinced Chicago financier Jay Pritzker a dozen years ago that he was the man to revive the moribund Pritzker property known as Ticketmaster.
Mr. Rosen's charming, earthy, blustery personality has both amused and alarmed the world of entertainers, agents, promoters and, most of all, "the buildings," industry argot for the executives at performance sites like the Great Western Forum in the Los Angeles suburb of Inglewood and Radio City Music Hall in New York that are Ticketmaster's principal clients.
A native New Yorker and son of an advertising executive, Mr. Rosen is a 50-year-old former corporate lawyer whose knack for dealmaking at Ticketmaster won the financial backing first of Mr. Pritzker and then, last year, of Paul G. Allen, the billionaire cofounder of the Microsoft Corporation, who bought 80 percent of Ticketmaster from Mr. Pritzker.
During a recent visit to his Wilshire Boulevard office, Mr. Rosen seemed restless. His inflamed appendix had been removed only days before, yet he couldn't stop pacing the hallways lined with old movie posters. Tieless but wearing a blue dress shirt, Mr. Rosen delivers the nonstop patter of Ed Koch, the former Mayor of New York, filtered through the about-to-explode voice of Al Pacino. Even a mild question about Ticketmaster's squabbles with Pearl Jam can provoke an intense answer.
"You know what I believe all this really is?" asked Mr. Rosen, his two index fingers stabbing the air. "It's jealousy and envy. Nobody knew this was a good business. And nobody took the time to do it correctly."
Many of Ticketmaster's clients seem satisfied. Michael R. Rowe, executive vice president at the Meadowlands Sports Complex in East Rutherford, N.J., was typical, saying Ticketmaster's service had been excellent during the course of its five-year contract, which expires next year. "I'm very pleased," he said.
What is beyond dispute is that Ticketmaster and Mr. Rosen worked hard for the dominant market position. Here in Los Angeles, where Ticketmaster is headquartered, if someone wanted the convenience of buying a ticket with a credit card over the telephone or at an outlet in a record or department store, it would be difficult to avoid going through Ticketmaster.
Indeed, if someone wanted to hear Placido Domingo, the opera singer, this week, or cheer for the Los Angeles Lakers against the New York Knicks next week, or take her children to Walt Disney's World on Ice next month, and, above all, if she had wanted one of this year's hottest tickets -- one of the 16,000 that sold out in 13 minutes -- for the Eagles' concert last May, then Ticketmaster is the only game in town.
IN Southern California alone, Ticketmaster has access to 12,000 events and has 175 retail outlets. And the consumer pays for that convenience, as much as $1.75 a ticket for Disney on Ice to $6.25 for the Grateful Dead. By contrast, Advantix, a ticketing service in Cleveland, typically charges $2 a ticket for a similar range of events.
The story is the same in the rest of the country. To be sure, Ticketmaster is far from dominant in every state and region. It is especially weak in the Sunbelt and border states, for example, where it started its expansion much later.
But in 1991, Ticketmaster had exclusive contracts with sites holding 45 percent of the nation's seats, according to Pollstar, an industry magazine. Today, Ticketmaster has such contracts with halls and arenas representing 63.2 percent of the country's 9.9 million seats, according to the latest Pollstar data. And even this figure does not tell the whole story: Ticketmaster, on a nonexclusive basis, sells tickets for some of the remaining 36.8 percent as well.
If Ticketmaster has by far the biggest share of the pie, it has little to do with how much filling is inside.
Every site controls its own inventory of tickets and sells the bulk of the tickets directly in group or other advance sales, said Mr. Rosen. "We, as a service company, control nothing," he said.
"Take the Hollywood Bowl," he continued. "By the time that they're through with season tickets, Monday night plans, Tuesday night plans, Wednesday night plans and Thursday night plans, probably 12 percent of their dollar sales are going through Ticketmaster."
Indeed, Ticketmaster sold only 51 million tickets last year through operations it directly owns and another 10 million through licensees.
Mr. Rosen goes out of his way to play down Ticketmaster's share. In Congressional testimony this summer, he contended that Ticketmaster handled "less than 2 percent" of 1.5 billion tickets sold in 1993.
That huge overall figure came from numbers compiled by Marketdata Enterprises Inc., a Valley Stream, L.I., research firm whose study was commissioned by Ticketmaster. But more than two-thirds of that national figure comes from museums, amusement parks, state parks and county fairs, where Ticketmaster and other computer services sell few tickets.
A smaller, more reasonable figure, of 178 million tickets -- from professional sports like football and events at arenas, auditoriums and theaters -- would indicate that Ticketmaster's market share was closer to 37 percent today.
That said, most tickets are low-priced and can take weeks to sell, like those for the Laserium at Griffith Observatory here or the Debussy Trio at the Orange County, Calif., Performing Arts Center.
The rare act that sells out in minutes -- like Elton John or the Rolling Stones -- carries a high service charge that helps subsidize the majority of slower sellers, or at least that is the Ticketmaster argument.
Even when the ticket is free, Ticketmaster imposes a service charge. At the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, for example, a Ticketmaster licensee charges $3 a ticket when issued in advance (down from $3.50 last year). "It's a good cause, but I can't get my phones or computers for free," said Paul d'Eustachio, the president of Ticketmaster in Landover, Md.
Mr. Rosen's overall strategy was to latch on to as much supply in as many different places as he could. That way he could afford to build an infrastructure of telephone rooms and ticket outlets staffed full-time throughout the year.
But first he had to defeat Ticketron, the dominant ticket service in the 1980's. When Mr. Rosen became chief executive of Ticketmaster in 1982, he convinced Mr. Pritzker that Goliath was vulnerable.
"Fred wooed venues very cleverly and energetically," Mr. Pritzker said. "And Ticketron had a problem. They didn't have a Fred Rosen."
TICKETRON also had a reputation for selling expensive computers from the Control Data Corporation, Ticketron's parent, to major arenas and stadiums, but then neglecting customer service when the computers broke down.
If Ticketmaster could offer better computer performance -- and at less cost to the hall -- it could grab market share, Mr. Rosen reasoned.
One problem, however: ticketmaster had inexpensive Digital Equipment computers costing $50,000 or so that had to compete with Ticketron's Control Data mainframes costing $1 million or more.
Of necessity, Ticketmaster programmers, headed by Peter Gadwa and Albert Leffler, who founded the company in 1976, somehow had to leverage Ticketmaster's cheap computers with some clever software. They did. With an elaborate computer program, now numbering more than 1.5 million lines of code, they were able to make a computer that normally served 50 telephone operators serve 1,000 or more.
"We were able to make a P.T. boat act like an aircraft carrier," said Mr. Gadwa, director of programming in Ticketmaster's Tempe, Ariz., office.
At the same time, Mr. Rosen was cajoling halls and arenas into granting Ticketmaster long-term exclusive contracts of three to five years or more. In contrast to Ticketron, Ticketmaster would provide computer terminals and other equipment at little or no cost.
Ticketmaster would make its money from what it called "convenience" charges. Ticketmaster and the hall would negotiate proportional (that is, higher) service charges for customer tickets, where Ticketron typically charged flat service charges of $2 or less.
Mr. Rosen's strategy dovetailed nicely with a new trend: higher concert ticket prices. Since the mid-1980's, prices for even superstar acts typically were $25 to $35 a ticket; but in recent years, and especially this summer, they have ranged from $50 to $100 and for the rare act, like Barbra Streisand, $350.
What's more, entertainers have been less willing to share concert revenue with the halls and arenas, sometimes demanding nearly all of the take instead of the traditional arrangement of turning over as much as 40 percent. The sites, in turn, wanted to make up the concert revenue they had lost. They were all ears when Mr. Rosen suggested raising service charges.
Ticketmaster's ascent was complete when Ticketron, after several money-losing years, failed to find a buyer to rescue it in 1991. The Justice Department reluctantly cleared the liquidation of Ticketron's assets, most of which Ticketmaster bought.
Mr. Rosen's transformation from giant-killer to giant was underscored last year when Mr. Pritzker sold most of Ticketmaster to Mr. Allen. (Mr. Pritzker retains a stake in the company, while Mr. Rosen gained a stake. Mr. Gadwa and Mr. Leffler, the co-founders, were bought out.)
THE sale price was based on a value for the company of $325 million. The value was unusually lush: twice the fiscal 1994 revenue and 54 times operating profit.
Results for that fiscal year, which ended Jan. 31, were distorted by extraordinary items related to the sale to Mr. Allen. Although Ticketmaster Holdings Group Ltd. lost $1.9 million during the period, on an operating basis it had a profit of $6 million compared with the year-earlier $7.5 million, according to Mr. Rosen. Full-year revenue totaled $191.1 million, up 11 percent from $172 million the year before.
It is with this backdrop that Ticketmaster's most recent troubles started in June, when Pearl Jam wanted to mount an inexpensive summer tour for its young fans.
The band sought to limit ticket prices to less than $20, and planned to lower its own take to $18. Pearl Jam therefore wanted Ticketmaster to settle for under $2 for its service charge. But Ticketmaster balked at the low fee and wanted the band to lower its take slightly.
Frustrated with other Ticketmaster actions (the band contended the company threatened to organize a boycott of concert promoters against it, a charge Mr. Rosen denies), Pearl Jam canceled the tour.
The band promptly brought its complaint of monopolistic practices with the Justice Department.
Pearl Jam is planning a summer tour next year but must still decide how to sell tickets nationally without Ticketmaster. It is considering a mail-order ticketing system, details unknown, according to Mr. Curtis, the group's manager.
THE new scrutiny of Ticketmaster has heartened competitors. "History repeats itself," said Laurence F. Schwartz, founder of Hill Arts and Entertainment Systems, which sells ticketing software to Ticketmaster rivals. "Ticketmaster, with 1970's technology, defeated Ticketron, which had 1960's technology. And people like us, with our more advanced technology, will defeat Ticketmaster by the year 2000."
But Michael Green, a Wayne, N.J., entrepreneur who is trying to develop a nationwide computerized ticketing service, said he sees little incentive for Ticketmaster to modernize its computer system. 'Why spend the money when they already own the market?" he asked.
For its part, Ticketmaster denies that it is technologically backward. But executives acknowledge that it may have to move to what is known as "open architecture," a hardware and software arrangement that allows computer equipment made by different manufacturers to "talk" with Ticketmaster.
It would, for example, allow home computers, automated teller machines and shopping-mall kiosks to tap into Ticketmaster data bases. Someday, that might allow a consumer to dial up Ticketmaster's computer, look at a seating plan for a concert hall, pick out tickets and order them.
Ticketmaster's present arrangement is closed architecture, a legacy of its cheap computer/clever software days. Mr. Allen, the majority owner and co-founder of Microsoft, is sure to be a major force for modernization.
Whatever the case, Mr. Rosen is already restless. "We've become a nation of whiners," he said. "Let's just all compete."
 
 
 
COMPUTERS AND ENVELOPE STUFFERS
 WHAT Ticketmaster does is more complicated than might first appear. Of the 61 million tickets it sold last year, only 40 percent were ordered over the telephone. The rest were sold at 2,800 retail outlets, like record and department stores. In the largest cities, as few as 10 percent of the sales for hot concerts may be by phone.
Sales at outlets, which take only cash, are a boon to Ticketmaster. Such transactions do not require the labor- and telecommunications-intensive efforts of processing and clearing credit cards. An outlet sale can thus take seconds, while a phone sale can take three minutes or more.
But as ticket prices rise, more people are buying by phone and credit card, raising Ticketmaster's costs. Indeed, one reason that Ticketmaster cites for imposing a charge for each ticket (rather than a cheaper per-order charge) is credit-card costs. Even though a $10 ticket costs the same to process as a $100 ticket, the higher-priced ticket is more likely to be rejected by the credit-card issuer or found to be charged on a stolen card.
Except for the computers, little of the Ticketmaster transaction is automated. Ticketmaster staffs phone lines with 3,200 to 4,000 operators at peak periods.
While much of the data associated with the transaction, such as a customer's name and address, are stored in computer data bases, the actual tickets are stuffed into envelopes by hand to reduce error.
"Getting it right before it leaves our hands saves us a lot of aggravation in refunds, phone time and angry customers," said W. David Anderson, vice president, telephone sales and service. (Ticketmaster says its error rate is 1 percent, but that another 7 percent of orders are lost or delayed in the mail.)
It is just such labor costs that persuaded major arenas like the Meadowlands in New Jersey to hire Ticketmaster rather than handle sales themselves.
"I'd need 200 phone operators who really knew what they were doing, but would not think it was odd that I needed them only 8 days during the summer," said Karen T. Sullivan, director of box office operations at the Meadowlands.

HEADLINE: At Wind River, Cautious Steps Toward Capitalism

BYLINE: By DOUG McINNIS; Doug McInnis is a freelance writer based in Casper, Wyo.

DATELINE: ETHETE, Wyo.

 BODY:
WHEN Patrick Goggles sees tourists streaming through the Wind River Indian Reservation to Yellowstone National Park, he sees money -- money that isn't flowing to his Northern Arapaho tribe. Tourists spend $1.6 billion a year in Wyoming, and the Arapaho are moving only belatedly to extract the tourist gold that Anglo businesses just outside the reservation have mined for generations.
As general manager of the Northern Arapaho Trust, which manages the tribe's investments, Mr. Goggles oversees a venture that includes a small group of retail and service businesses that serve tourists and tribal members alike. These enterprises sometimes lure tourists traveling to and from Wyoming's biggest draws -- Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks -- but not often enough, and Mr. Goggles wants to lure more. 
 One familiar route is probably not open to the Arapaho. Tribes in more populous states, like Connecticut, Florida and California, have cashed in on big-time casino gambling. "The odds always favor the house," observed Mr. Goggles. "It would be pretty hard to screw up gaming."
But in Wyoming, the nation's least populous state, the Arapaho would have a tough time attracting enough customers to make it work. While Wyoming gets plenty of visitors, they are often families on their way to national parks, not high rollers with money to burn. So while the Arapaho have some small gaming operations, they have settled on tourism as the most likely vehicle to generate jobs.
And that is the crying need. Despite publicity that might indicate otherwise, gambling has not proved a cure-all for most tribes. "A majority of the tribes are not getting wealthy because of gaming," said Manley Begay, executive director for the Project on Indian Economic Development at Harvard University. Most tribes "are very poor, with unemployment reaching in some areas to 90 percent."
The big obstacle is the lack of a capitalist tradition. In other communities, budding capitalists can tap the experience of many business managers. But on a reservation with few college graduates and few tribal members with experience running a business, there is often no one to ask for advice. "Our problems are worse because we don't have this business tradition," said Anne McIntosh, chairwoman of the trust.
Mr. Goggles, whose Arapaho name is "Strong Bear," is trying to build that tradition. He is part of an emerging class of Indian executives whose job is to speed the creation of Indian-owned businesses, while helping to educate their tribes in the ways of market capitalism. And the Arapaho have certainly made some missteps and had some growing pains along the way.
Mr. Goggles is largely self-taught, having earlier held positions at tribal businesses and in the tribal political structure. At 42, when many managers have M.B.A.'s, Mr. Goggles is completing work at the University of Wyoming for a bachelor's degree in political science, with a minor in business.
Twenty-five years ago, there were only a handful of Indian business managers, Mr. Begay said. Today, Indian businesses bring in billions of dollars annually, and though the number of Indian managers is growing, he said "there is still a long way to go in being able to have a crop of Indian managers you can dip into any time you feel like it."
As a result, tribes must still turn to outsiders, although they prefer Indian managers, because, Mr. Begay said, "it promotes sovereignty and it's part of nation-building."
Strong managers also increase the odds that Indian-owned ventures will succeed. Success is essential because tribes like the Northern Arapaho have little capital to play with. A serious misstep could prove disastrous. The neighbors of the Arapaho on the reservation, the Eastern Shoshone tribe, invested roughly $5 million in high-risk derivatives and took a multimillion-dollar loss. As a result, Shoshone tribal leaders had to tap savings accounts to cover tribal operating expenses this year.
DEPENDING on the assets of a region, the best fit may be manufacturing, farming, ranching, tourism, mining, service industries, gambling or something else. So tribal leaders must select the right businesses, then make them work. And the Arapaho believe much of their future lies in tourism.
Mr. Goggles says his tribe can cash in on outsiders' fascination for Indian art, souvenirs and traditions. "They want to see, they want to buy, they want to touch Arapaho," he said. "They want T-shirts and caps. We can market our culture."
At the Wind River Reservation, Mr. Goggles' job is to help build enterprises that will slice the tribe's 70 percent unemployment rate, and cut deeply into their dependence on public assistance. "What we're talking about for the Northern Arapaho Nation is economic independence and self-sufficiency," he said.
 The tribe has a sizable asset in the reservation itself, which it shares with the Eastern Shoshone tribe. The reservation covers some two million acres, an area larger than Rhode Island and Delaware combined. It stretches across high-plains ranch and farm land until it disappears into the cloud-covered Wind River mountains at the Continental Divide, which forms part of the reservation's Western boundary. The area's beauty has long been appreciated by tribal members and visitors alike, but now the Arapaho want to turn this beauty into jobs.
The goal is an economic infrastructure that will serve tourists and residents of nearby towns -- as well as the tribe's 6,200 members.
In 1988, to aid business development, the Arapaho took the unusual step of placing tribal businesses in the trust, which is separate from the sometimes contentious politics of the Arapaho's governing counsel. In 1991, the trust sold $2.1 million in bonds to increase its capital.
THE Arapaho own a grocery, a convenience store, a truck stop, small-scale gaming operations, a laundromat, a screen printing company and a construction concern. These businesses provide 85 jobs, and generate $7.5 million in annual revenues. The trust doesn't disclose profits, but Mr. Goggles said all but one venture, a convenience operation, are making money.
Soon to be started is a reservation tour service. Under consideration are a dozen more enterprises, including a trading post, a recreational vehicle park, a hunting outfitter's service, a fast-food outlet, and expanded gambling operations. The tribe also hopes to attract some industrial plants.
The tribe is trying to reinvent the commercial legacy that was lost when the Arapaho were forced onto the reservation in the late 1800's. The Arapaho and other Great Plains tribes once traded buffalo robes, meat and other commodities for farm goods supplied by agricultural tribes on the edge of the Plains. But confinement to the reservation and near extinction of the buffalo largely ended that culture, said Colin Calloway, an associate professor and specialist in Indian history at the University of Wyoming. "Once on the reservation," he said, "Indian people were not supposed to leave without a pass."
Reservation life also fostered a debilitating history of public assistance. Many new employees of tribal businesses have never worked in conventional jobs and cannot adjust to the working world. Some find that service-industry wages cannot compete with government benefits. But the tribe shows considerably more patience with new employees than most private businesses would, because turning lives around is the ultimate goal of Arapaho capitalism.
"I definitely want to make a profit," said Ms. McIntosh, the trust's chairwoman, who is a rancher by training. But, she said, "my main goal is to provide a higher standard of living for the reservation." She estimated that 40 percent of problem workers become productive workers for the tribe's businesses.
From the beginning, the Arapaho have moved cautiously. So far they have avoided debacles of the magnitude that hit the Eastern Shoshone. Mr. Goggles will not comment on the Shoshone derivatives investment other than to say the Arapaho never invested in anything as risky. The tribe stuck to "T-bills, Ginnie Mae's and C.D.'s," he said.
Even so, capitalism has provided nasty jolts, including the closing of a clothing factory and a video store. The factory was hurt by short production runs, and a high turnover of workers who found wages of $4.25 an hour could not compete with public assistance. The venture ultimately failed because it relied on a single client that went out of business.
"We weren't big enough," Mr. Goggles said. "If you're going to get into the cut-and-sew business, you've got to have a huge volume or you'll be eaten alive. Basically, we were eaten alive."
The failure was an expensive lesson. The factory was financed through a bank loan guaranteed by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. When the plant closed, the trust could have let the Government absorb the loss. Instead, the trust paid off the balance of $280,000 -- to keep the trust's integrity and its credit rating intact, Mr. Goggles said. The factory has since been converted into a profitable bingo hall.
Some remaining businesses have learned the hard way. The tribe's convenience store paid for orders that were not delivered in full and for perishable items whose expiration dates were the day after they were delivered, trust officials said. Employees have since been trained to check vendor deliveries carefully, and the tribe has contracted with a convenience-store chain to train Indian managers and provide expertise in inventory control, customer service and security.
FOR the future, Mr. Goggles and the tribe's business leaders must walk the tightrope that all young enterprises face -- growing without losing money. Profits are essential because they provide funds to open new ventures.
For a tribe with massive unemployment, jobs cannot come fast enough. On a recent day, two single mothers approached Mr. Goggles about jobs at the tribe-owned truck stop. He had none to offer.
But Mr. Goggles is optimistic that the tribe can cash in on its lands, its culture and its scenic location to create a variety of businesses that will put hundreds of tribe members to work and land a substantial piece of the area's tourist trade. "I can capture a portion of that business," said Mr. Goggles. "As a matter of fact, I already do. It's just that I want more."
