HEADLINE: The Very Quiet Behemoth of the Philanthropic World

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: CHEVY CHASE, Md.

 BODY:
THOUGH other philanthropies are better known, the Howard Hughes Medical Institute is actually the leviathan of the nonprofit world, and C. F. (Terry) Wolfe is the man who minds the money.
No wonder he keeps a pie-sized Bayer aspirin on his desk. "You just have to cross out the zeros," he said. Otherwise, he has discovered, "you'd lose perspective." 
 His is a daunting task. With $7.5 billion in assets, the Hughes institute is the world's largest philanthropy, larger than the Ford Foundation or Harvard University. And given its do-it-yourself philosophy, its chief investment officer has more to do than many conventional money managers.
The institute takes the view that the best way to manage its hoard is in-house. That means Mr. Wolfe, and his three deputies, do not parcel the money out to a dozen pricey Wall Street hands or follow the herd by plowing the funds into a market index.
In the face of all the choices that must then be made, Mr. Wolfe tries to keep a cool head. Disclaiming any special skill as a stock picker or market timer, Mr. Wolfe describes his role, played out on the ground floor of the institute's gleaming new $55 million headquarters, as that of a conductor.
"I just try to orchestrate things," said Mr. Wolfe, 55, a native of Mt. Carmel, Pa., who took over as chief investment officer on May 1 after 30 years at I.B.M.
At the time, the Hughes institute was at something of a crossroads. Started in 1953 by the billionaire to promote medical research, the institute owned but one asset for more than three decades: the Hughes Aircraft Company. Mr. Hughes had donated it to the institute, but retained control as the institute's sole trustee. So, the institute spent years defending itself against charges from the Internal Revenue Service that its real purpose was to serve as a tax dodge.
By the time Mr. Hughes, a filmmaker and aviator as well as reclusive industrialist, died in 1976, the aircraft maker was more valuable than his estate. But only a small fraction of its profits was going to medical research, and the institute was tight-lipped about the projects it did bankroll.
Under pressure from the I.R.S. and in an effort to diversify, the institute sold the aircraft company to General Motors in 1985 for $5.2 billion in cash and stock. Two years later, the institute settled its long-running feud with the I.R.S. in exchange for being allowed to remain a tax-exempt "medical institute," a designation that obligates it to give away only 3.5 percent of its assets each year, rather than the more stringent 5 percent required of foundations.
ONCE the nest egg was diversified, the institute's professional money managers have been crucial in making sure that the institute can fund its philanthropic goals. The institute has also been making more of an effort in recent years to shed some of the secrecy of its past, not the least of which was agreeing to give a reporter a glimpse into how it manages the money.
Mr. Wolfe, who startled colleagues with enthusiastic comments about foreign markets just weeks into the job, seems comfortable with that effort at openness. At the same time, he has no intention of tampering with a formula that has enabled the institute to move ahead of other philanthropies in sheer size. Thus, he keeps the portfolio broadly diversified, devoting about 60 percent of it to equities, 30 percent to fixed-income securities and 10 percent to riskier ventures like venture-capital situations, corporate buyout funds and oil, timber and other partnerships.
That type of cautious asset allocation has paid off. For the six years 1988 through 1993, Hughes averaged gains of 12.9 percent on its mixed portfolio of stocks and bonds, handily surpassing its goal of five percentage points more than the inflation rate, or 9 percent. It even beat the 12.5 percent averaged in those years by balanced mutual funds tracked by Morningstar. This year, the Hughes portfolio eked out a five-tenths of 1 percent gain through Sept. 30, not bad when compared to the 1.9 percent lost by the balanced funds in the Morningstar group.
Far be it from Mr. Wolfe, however, to shun the adventure of a calculated plunge. "We do make bets," he said. "We tend to make micro-bets." By that, he means commitments to trends, industries and "things we understand," but not bets on market direction as a whole.
For instance, the institute for some time has favored capital equipment, technology and other companies involved in enlarging the nation's infrastructure while playing down the consumer sector. As a result, Hughes is overweighted in technology (14 percent vs. 8 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500 index), level in energy (11 percent) and severely underweighted in consumer stocks (6 percent vs. 12 percent).
What most distinguishes Mr. Wolfe is tight management and attention to detail, according to Wall Streeters who knew him during a 30-year career at I.B.M., where he climbed to chief investment officer in September 1993 and oversaw $36 billion of retirement money.
"Discipline is a big thing with me," said Mr. Wolfe, a graduate of M.I.T. and Harvard Business School who prides himself on being able to measure risks and root out the cause of variations in performance.
"He's from the old Harold Geneen school of keeping on top of every number," said Remi Browne, a managing director of Ark Asset Management in New York, referring to the legendary former chairman of the ITT Corporation. "He's a very fair but tough manager who at I.B.M. put a lot of needed quality-control structure in place."
For all the bouquets, Mr. Wolfe left his job at I.B.M. shortly after the new management team led by Louis V. Gerstner Jr., its new chief executive, arrived this spring and farmed out more pension funds to outside managers. Mr. Wolfe was eligible for retirement anyway, because of his age and tenure. So he retired after lining up the job at Hughes, where his do-it-yourself approach was quite at home.
The Hughes institute does employ a handful of outside managers to fill specialty niches, such as Nicholas-Applegate Capital Management in San Diego, and TCW Asset Management in Los Angeles. But 80 percent of the assets are handled in-house.
The biggest holding in the stock portfolio is still $650 million of the original General Motors Class H stock that the institute got when it sold Hughes Aircraft in 1985. The next biggest positions are the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the AT&T Corporation and the Federal National Mortgage Association, which together account for about 4 percent of all stock holdings.
The rest of the stock portfolio is scattered across some 135 equities around the globe, stakes ranging in size from $4 million to $70 million. Hughes tends to hold stocks for about three years, one or two years longer than the typical institutional manager, according to Mr. Wolfe. And it shuns the increasingly fashionable game of stalking underperforming companies that are vulnerable to outside pressure or hostile takeovers. "We are not management activists," he said emphatically.
JUNK bonds, puts and calls, Eurodollar futures and other derivatives have a place in the Hughes portfolio but below-investment-grade bonds are limited to 5 percent of the fixed-income portion and derivatives are never leveraged.
Mr. Wolfe, who divides his time between Washington and Westport, Conn., won't discuss his pay, but his predecessor, Graham O. Harrison, earned $415,000 plus $92,732 in benefits the year before he retired, the institute's filing with the I.R.S. shows.
One constraint Mr. Wolfe labors under is the need to make sure that the institute has enough cash and liquid investments like Treasuries on hand to be able to carry out its philanthropic mission. Just to meet the statutory minimum of 3.5 percent, the institute awards about $275 million a year to some 275 clinical researchers -- $1 million apiece on average -- around the country.
In fact, the institute has been donating closer to 5 percent a year, the rate that foundations are obligated to give away each year, if a program of grants for science education is also included. Without the need to generate all that cash, Mr. Wolfe said he would probably take a bit more risk.
Notably, the stock portfolio is light on medical issues, and none of the major American drug companies are in the top 25 holdings. Indeed, there is little discussion of investment possibilities between its scientists, whose work is largely confined to basic research, and Hughes officials.
"We don't mix the investment policy up with what our investigators are doing," said Dr. Purnell W. Choppin, a former vice president of Rockefeller University who has been the Hughes president since 1987. Hughes does share royalties from patents and licenses resulting from research it sponsors.
Mr. Wolfe will have to wrestle with one big issue fairly soon: what to do with 15 million shares of G.M. Class H, which until the end of February can be bought back by the automaker at $37.50, about 10 percent above the current price, or sold back to the company by the institute at $30. If neither side exercises its option, Hughes would be free to trade them along with another 5 million unencumbered Class H shares sitting in its portfolio.
Mr. Wolfe and his chief deputy on stocks, Lillian H. Blucher, are giving no hint of their strategy for the shares. His two other deputies are Ellen B. Safir, who has day-to-day charge of the bond portfolio, and Nina Scherago, who runs private investments.
As for personal investments, Mr. Wolfe said he and his wife Lillian, an architect, have put most of their money into mutual funds and some closed-end investment companies devoted to single countries, especially Mexico, Thailand and China. (He generally avoids buying individual stocks because of possible conflicts of interest.) As a rule, he thinks the typical 25-year-old investor should be 100 percent invested in stocks, a 55-year-old about two-thirds invested in stocks and a 70-year-old about 25 percent invested in stocks.
Beyond that, he advises individual investors to invest regularly, be patient, and not to try to outsmart the market. "Above all," he insists, "diversify."

HEADLINE: A Patriotic Pitch: Honda Is American

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
FOR years, the Big Three auto companies and the United Automobile Workers have tried to make patriotism part of the car-buying mentality of Americans. As a marketing pitch, the effect of showroom jingoism has always been debatable -- so has its economic logic.
Still, the idea that driving a Chevy or a Chrysler is a patriotic act, while owning a Honda or a Toyota is not, clearly appealed to some. And in their lobbying efforts and in their advertising, Detroit has long argued that buying American-made cars is good for the American economy and that buying imported cars is bad. 
 To support this marketing doctrine, the Big Three and the auto workers' union helped write Federal legislation, which went into effect last month, requiring stickers to appear on all new vehicles stating the percentage of domestic and foreign parts used to make them. Detroit is hoping that the new domestic-content labeling will sway more consumers to buy American cars.
Maybe, but guess who's wrapping itself in the flag with its current marketing drive? The Honda Motor Company of Tokyo. Lately, Honda has been promoting its American links and its beneficial effects on the United States economy with new print and broadcast advertisements.
Painting itself red, white and blue is nothing new for Honda or any of the Japanese auto makers operating in America. But Honda's campaign is a redoubled effort, aggressively taking the offensive on an issue that could be seen as a weakness. Though Honda disputes the Government's method of calculation, the domestic-content sticker says that 50 percent of the Accord is made in America. By contrast, the domestic content on the Pontiac Sunfire, a comparable model, is rated at 90 percent.
"There's always a 'buy American' undertow in the market that we must contend with," said Eric Conn, a Honda senior manager for automotive advertising. "We do an awful lot in the United States, and we don't get credit for it."
Besides, Honda has a pretty strong argument to make. In addition to employing 14,000 workers at its manufacturing complex in Marysville, Ohio, its American headquarters in suburban Los Angeles and its dealerships, Honda just happens to be the nation's leading exporter of vehicles.
This counterintuitive fact is illustrated in a new television ad, produced by Honda's longtime agency, Rubin Postaer of Santa Monica, Calif., showing right-hand-drive and left-hand-drive cars rolling off the assembly line in Marysville.
"Why do we do this?" asks the narrator. The answer: Shots of Japan and other export destinations appear on screen. The bottom line: Honda helps reduce the trade deficit.
In a two-page advertisement in the October 31 issue of Sports Illustrated magazine, a Honda sedan ("manufactured in America since 1982," the ad states) appears with a series of other icons of American popular culture including a double decker burger ("cooked up in America since 1855"), a pair of cowboy boots ("handcrafted in America since 1868"), a baseball ("played in America since 1845").
The ad copy describes some automotive manufacturing techniques, followed by the sentences: "What it all adds up to is the Accord. An excellent example of American quality for the last twelve years."
By implying that the Accord is as American as baseball and burgers, the Honda ads make the argument that America's enormous trade deficit with Japan and the issue of competitiveness are not simple cases of white hats and black hats. The TV ads, along with traditional Honda product advertising, have been scheduled mainly during weekend and Monday night football games.
THE Nissan Motor Corporation, which builds cars and light trucks in Smyrna, Tenn., has refrained from advertising that draws attention to its American roots. Don Spetner, vice president of public relations for Nissan, said the auto maker decided instead to focus its advertising on "product launches, brand image and dealer support."
But Nissan has undertaken direct-mail and lobbying campaigns to counter "buy American." In one brochure, Nissan said, "Labeling requirements are not an accurate indicator of the actual content of vehicles." Therefore, "Nissan believes Congress must corrrect the glaring flaws" in the Labeling Act.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Technology;
900,000 Striped Bass, and Not a Fishing Pole in Sight

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

DATELINE: TURNERS FALLS, Mass.

 BODY:
TO Josh Goldman, it's all very simple. On a display board, he draws one line, slanting upward -- that's the world demand for fish. Below that, a second line, slanting down -- the wild supply, steadily being depleted. The widening gap represents the fish the world will need from other sources. And for reasons he is eager to enumerate, he insists that traditional fish farming will be unable to fill that gap.
But Mr. Goldman says he has the solution, and with supreme confidence and the blinders of the true believer, he is out to prove it. 
 At age 31, Joshua N. Goldman has turned a passion born in his college days into a three-year-old venture called Aquafuture Inc. And it is here that he sees the future of fish farming -- or aquaculture, as it's called in this $28.4 billion global industry.
Aquafuture is closing in on selling a million pounds a year of hybrid striped bass, all raised in a single building here in western Massachusetts. As a private company, Aquafuture does not divulge financial data, though Mr. Goldman did say annual revenues exceed $2 million.
That is far larger than all but a few pond-based farms. But Mr. Goldman hopes to build plants 10 times the size around the nation.
Aquafuture now occupies a boxy 45,000-square-foot building (that's an acre-plus) in an industrial park, the bland facade giving no clue to what's inside -- an elaborate web of tanks and piping and electronics. And, oh yes, an awful lot of fish.
Those fish -- a hybrid of saltwater striped bass and freshwater white bass -- are spawned elsewhere, then brought here at two months of age. In the first tank, thousands of these "fingerlings" can be kept for up to nine months, their growth slowed by chilling the water, if the company wants them to mature later; here, striped bass are always in season.
They move on to ever-larger tanks, always monitored, graded, given more elbow room. They have an ever-faster current to swim against; it's their instinct to do this, and without it, Mr. Goldman says, their texture would be wrong. No slouches, by the time they do their last laps before becoming dinner, they log 20 miles a day. And they're far from lonely: cradle to fillet, the building houses 900,000 fish.
THE last stop is a "purge tank," where the fish are given no feed. Mr. Goldman says he can grow the fish to market size in nine months, half the normal time.
All is controlled and sanitary. A visitor entering a cavernous, tank-filled room follows Mr. Goldman's lead and dips his shoes in a pan of disinfectant. Up ahead, two orange-aproned men work under lights on a high platform, as if on a surgical stage set. On a table lies a pile of anesthetized 6-inch fish, and, needles flashing in a quick rhythm, the men vaccinate fish after fish -- between them, they say, 6,000 an hour.
From there, the fish plunge through a plastic pipe into a cold wake-up bath, electronically counted en route. All these safeguards, Mr. Goldman says, enable Aquafuture to reduce mortality to less than 15 percent, half the industry average.
The fish that make it, he insists, aren't tainted the way many wild fish are, taste better than other farm-raised fish -- and are produced with less environmental damage.
The need is clear. Relying on the wild supply is like "having a livestock industry based on hunting," said Mark Priest, president of the New York City chapter of Trout Unlimited, a conservation group.
So why not traditional fish farming, in either ponds or offshore cages? There are many environmental concerns, like the creation of faster-growing hybrids. When these escape, "we are genetically polluting the wild fish stock," said Rebecca Goldburg, senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund.
Such farms also consume large amounts of water -- at least 1,000 gallons for each pound of fish, Mr. Goldman said. "Even the best water resource in the world," he said, would eventually prove wanting.
And the water discharged, unless it's treated properly, is laden with fish feces and uneaten feed. "The public does not want another source of pollution," said Victor Mancebo, executive director of the Northeast Regional Aquaculture Center, which advises fish farmers.
Mr. Goldman says his system solves these problems. Because the fish are raised indoors, it would take a striped Houdini to find its way to the nearby Connecticut River. And no birds, bearing disease, can get in.
AQUAFUTURE uses a nearly closed system -- constantly recirculating and purifying the water -- and thus uses just 150 gallons to create a pound of fish. The water it does discharge, after treatment, exceeds numerous drinking-water standards, Massachusetts environmental officials say. The feces are given to farmers for fertilizer.
Also, Mr. Goldman said, traditional farms waste feed because, unable to count dead fish, "you're feeding an unknown inventory." So while ponds use 2.5 pounds of feed to produce a pound of fish, he said, Aquafuture needs just 1.4 pounds. By contrast, Mr. Goldman said chicken farming used 15 pounds of feed to produce a pound of chicken in 1925. Today, the ratio is 2 to 1.
Ms. Goldburg said she "was very impressed by the steps they've taken to create an environmentally sound" operation. And Mr. Mancebo called Aquafuture "a world-class attempt to fill a niche that is really pretty much vacant." Production costs may be high, he said, but as fish prices rise, "this will be successful."
Mr. Mancebo estimates that in 1991, the United States accounted for just $636 million, or 2.2 percent, of the world aquaculture industry, which in turn accounts for roughly 12 percent of the world fish harvest. He said that China, which farmed fish 5,000 years ago, has more than 90 percent of world aquaculture production, but that indoor Chinese systems are mainly hatcheries.
As for Mr. Goldman's fish, the proof is in the eating. Arthur Kloack, director of seafood processing for the big Boston restaurant chain Legal Seafoods, said Aquafuture's fish -- he buys as much as 3,000 pounds a week of it -- is "cleaner and more consistent on quality" than much of the fish he buys. "The feedback from customers is tremendous," he said. The fish are sold from New York to Toronto, at $2.25 to $3 a pound, with some sold live to Asian buyers.
The idea was born at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., where Mr. Goldman took part in a fish-breeding project involving 30 students over two years. After graduating in 1986, he co-founded a company called Bioshelters to put his theories to the test. But he and his co-founder, John Reid, differed on goals, and a year later he left.
Mr. Reid, still Bioshelters' president, says he favored a less-risky approach, that he wanted to move slowly. He still considers Mr. Goldman a good friend, but says that his former partner fell prey to a bit of the "techno-arrogance common in aquaculture circles," that he "wanted to get big fast."
Mr. Goldman's response: "At a certain point you have to confront the realities of scaling up. I think we've met that challenge."
BIOSHELTERS breeds tilapia, a tropical fish that Mr. Reid says is less costly to raise. It is also a much smaller operation, though Bioshelters too is expanding. There are only a few operations around the country on Aquafuture's scale, mainly raising tilapia.
One approach elsewhere is to combine raising fish with growing hydroponic vegetables with the nutrients in the water, but Mr. Goldman said he had tried this and decided it was "dragging down" the operation.
When Mr. Goldman moved on, he started a research operation, going three years without pay. (He started drawing a salary three years ago, just in time: he is now married, with two sons aged 2 1/2 and 3 months.)
Convinced that Mr. Goldman was onto something, a Hampshire classmate, Artemis Joukowsky 3d, was there with the seed money.
Backed by his family's insurance fortune, Mr. Joukowsky had provided financing for Mr. Goldman all along, believing in his "total focus" on his goal. In January 1990, through his venture fund, HFG Expansion Fund One, he enabled Mr. Goldman to break ground on Aquafuture's current home. The fund has now put $4.5 million into Aquafuture, much of it from Mr. Joukowsky's family.
The partners soon felt the need for a seasoned manager, and in 1992 they brought in Charles S. Olcott, a former president of Burger King, as chairman and chief executive; Mr. Goldman is president.
They make a slightly odd couple -- Mr. Olcott, at 47, a hearty veteran of the rough-and-tumble corporate world outside, and Mr. Goldman, a generation younger, a slim, dark-haired man with the air of a sober, slightly distracted graduate student.
What next? Mr. Olcott says the company is on the verge of being profitable. The partners have no plans to go public, but say they are close to getting more venture capital. And just last month, Aquafuture received a $654,000 grant from the National Marine Fisheries Service for a project to raise flounder.
Mr. Goldman foresees true economies of scale in expansion, with his only reservation being finding committed people to run the plants. "People here have been part of creating the process," he said.
For now, Mr. Goldman's research continues into creating new hybrids. Does he have any qualms about this genetic tinkering with nature? "We're merely doing what every good farmer's done since the dawn of agriculture," he says quickly.

LENGTH: 820 words

HEADLINE: At Work;
Still In the Dark on Diversity

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
THOSE whose business it is to ride up in the crow's nest of life, scanning the trend horizons, say there are few instances of a single piece of work having as fast and pervasive an impact as the Hudson Institute's "Work Force 2000: Work and Workers for the 21st Century."
The 1987 report projected an increasingly diverse American labor force, that is one increasingly composed of women, members of minority groups and other alternatives to the traditional white, male breadwinner. A certain number of forward-looking companies immediately grasped the implications of employing a work force that might -- but might not -- arrive at the office sharing the same social and cultural assumptions. Diversity, the consulting specialty, was born. 
 Diversity could, of course, cause confusion, but handled properly could also be turned into a tool to open up markets, improve profitability and allow companies to compete globally. It seemed hard to find a company that had not jumped on the diversity bandwagon.
Time for a reality check, according to a benchmark study released last month by researchers in New York. Business, says the report, "Corporate Responses to Diversity," has actually responded "passively" to what many would say are the economic opportunities presented by diversity.
Awareness of diversity issues is high at the 300-plus companies in the New York metropolitan area that responded to the survey because their own employees have grown more diverse. But most of the companies indicate they are doing what is necessary to comply with government employment law and little more. For the most part they have not taken the step beyond what would move diversity out of a pigeon hole in the personnel department and into the strategic center of the corporate environment.
"Companies have diversity, but they don't do anything with it to make it work for them," said Joanne Miller, the study's director and interim head of the Center for the New American Workforce at Queens College. "They don't think in terms of productivity."
What companies do think in terms of, Dr. Miller said, is compliance with affirmative action guidelines and disability law. Nearly 90 percent of the surveyed companies have established programs for groups identified as having "distinct needs," all but two of them mandated by government. Of the eight groups typically targeted by company programs, only part-time and skill-deficient employees are not covered by some type of government mandate.
A diversity program, in the eyes of the company, Dr. Miller said, may be anything from a family leave policy to a company-wide posting of a promotion opportunity. That in itself is troubling, because it suggests diversity has become an omnibus category so broad it may be meaningless. Indeed, Dr. Miller and her colleagues were surprised to find, when they began exploring the diversity question, that companies have little information on diversity policies at other companies.
Most experts would say diversity is no longer simply about recruiting mere numbers of, say, African-American or female employees and keeping them moving along the company pipeline, although the latter especially is by no means a non-problem. Diversity is taking people from different backgrounds, with different expectations and at different stages of life and melding them into a force that will drive the company's profitability and competitiveness.
MOST companies deal with post-affirmative action diversity only when they try to switch from a hierarchical management mode to some version of employee empowerment, in which workers are expected to work together in teams. They often find the switch daunting, in part because they have not prepared employees for the kind of communication and cooperation required of teams. The company brings in consultants, sends employees on retreats, gives them therapy -- and yet the teams don't jell.
In a genuinely diverse work force, employees may worry about extending trust to colleagues who appear not to be like them. "What do you do when you think another person's interests are not your own?" Dr. Miller asked. "When you worry someone won't behave as you would, you don't use them in the same way."
It may be little wonder that companies are reluctant to tackle the conundrum of difference, which, after all, roils many sectors of American society far beyond the boundaries of business. On the other hand, as Dr. Miller pointed out, sociologists regard the work place as a microcosm of society, which suggests however much executives may hope diversity will blow over and become last week's management revolution, it is not likely to happen.
The reluctance of business to confront diversity in the New York area, one of the most diverse in the country, is especially disturbing, Dr. Miller contended. "If it's not happening in New York," she said, "it's probably not happening anywhere."

HEADLINE: World Bank Loans

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Apart from their flawed economic logic, John Cavanagh and Sarah Anderson have employed questionable arithmetic in contending that International Monetary Fund and World Bank adjustment loans to developing countries have reduced United States exports by $1 billion a year ("For U.S., Aid Banks Aren't Too Helpful," Viewpoints, Oct. 2). 
 Their mistake is to assume that if the loans and the policy reforms had not been made, United States exports to these countries would have continued at the same pace as in the years before the loans.
This assumption is absurd. The countries in question had been spending beyond their means. Their deficits were unsustainable. Their import levels were likewise unsustainable, having been financed by a rundown of international reserves or by foreign borrowing that was rapidly drying up. They had to reduce their imports. There was no money left to continue buying -- from the United States or anywhere else. And without significant reforms, no one was going to lend these countries any more money.
Anyone whose economic knowledge is sophisticated enough to understand that things cost money can see the problem with Mr. Cavanagh and Ms. Anderson's analysis.
As to their arithmetic, one flaw is that Mr. Cavanagh and Ms. Anderson have left Mexico and Argentina out of their calculations. Both have been recipients of World Bank and I.M.F. adjustment loans, and both are significant markets for American exports. Recalculating, using their method but including Mexico and Argentina, shows that World Bank-I.M.F. adjustment lending increased United States exports by $8 billion a year and provided 162,000 new jobs in the United States.
It is easy to see then how the writers reached their conclusion: they fudged the economics and they fudged the arithmetic.
In the last decade, about a quarter of the World Bank's loans have been adjustment loans. Several decades of success in Southeast Asia and a decade of success in Latin America attest to the economic sense of such adjustments. Because of such success, adjustment lending is declining -- it was 12 percent of World Bank lending in fiscal 1994.
Though increasing the exports of donor countries is not the primary objective of World Bank lending, it should be obvious that prosperous countries will import more than stagnating ones. In fiscal 1994, United States companies earned $970 million from contracts from World Bank-financed projects. Over the 50-year history of the bank, United States companies have received back $1.10 for each $1 of paid-in capital and International Development Agency contributions that Washington has invested in the World Bank.
 
J. MICHAEL FINGER
Washington, Oct. 5
 
The writer is chief economist at the World Bank's international trade division.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2292 words

HEADLINE: A Hot Investment Entices, But It's Not Always Wise

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Do you pay too much in taxes?
You bet. 
 Do you invest in mutual funds?
Yessir.
What would you say if I told you about mutual funds that grow tax-free -- and you don't have to pay a commission to buy?
Sign me up.
That pitch is being repeated millions of times a year, all across the country, as brokers, insurance agents and financial planners sell Americans on a hot investment product with a long, boring name: variable deferred annuities.
And the hard sell is working -- this year, people are expected to pour more than $55 billion into these investments, which blend mutual funds with a little life insurance to qualify for Federal tax breaks. That roughly equals the net investments so far this year in American stock and bond mutual funds, and is up from less than $10 billion five years ago.
But along with raising money, today's sales are raising concerns among financial watchdogs and advisers. Because while this hot investment may be a winner for a small group of people, it may not be a great deal for many buyers who may be better off in simpler, less restrictive investments with lower annual fees. And buyers will probably not find that out for years -- if ever.
For most people, a variable annuity is not a wise choice, said Robert Markman, president of Markman Capital Management in Minneapolis, who refuses to sell such investments. Nonetheless, he said, "it sounds great when it's being pitched to you over the phone at dinner time."
No one is suggesting that investors are being defrauded or predicting an investment debacle. But regulators, who are starting to receive complaints from people who have bought these investments, worry about the future.
"I feel very strongly in my gut that this is the next big problem," said Debra M. Bollinger, director of the South Dakota Division of Securities. "People don't know what they are buying."
Variable annuities are basically a group of mutual funds from which investors can pick and choose, wrapped inside a very small insurance policy. Generally, the policy guarantees that investors willing to pay a big annual fee can be sure that if they meet an untimely death, their heirs will get back at least the amount originally invested.
That little insurance policy brings with it another big benefit: investors do not have to pay taxes on their investment gains until they start spending the money, so long as they do not begin making withdrawals before they reach age 59 1/2. So money that will eventually go for taxes remains in the mutual fund to earn interest in the meantime. That appeals even to people who expect to remain in the same tax bracket once they retire; it is even more attractive to those who expect their tax rates to fall.
 
 
Insurance Policy With Yearly Charges
 But that insurance has big drawbacks, too, chiefly large annual charges for the policy, which can be more than $310 a year for a $25,000 investment. Those costs can wipe out the benefits of tax deferral unless the buyer holds on to the variable annuity for 15 or 20 years -- a very long time for the average investor. It takes sizzling investment gains -- the kinds made by extremely aggressive investors in very strong markets -- to overcome the handicap of the expenses.
Most insurance companies impose steep penalties on investors who take their money out within seven years, and investors who need their money before they reach age 59 1/2 must pay a 10 percent tax penalty along with the Federal Government's regular bite.
Financial planners say that variable annuities can be good investments for a small group of people: those who pay a lot of taxes; and have already put all the money they can into their other retirement plans; and have a lot of extra income; and are sure they will not need that money for a very long time, certainly not until they retire; and are aggressive, successful investors, and plan to withdraw the money very slowly.
But this leaves a lot of people for whom variable annuities are a bad investment: those who are too old to leave the money locked up for a decade or two; those who are too young to be sure they will not need cash to pay college tuitions or mortgage bills; those whose tax brackets are too low (or even too high), and those who are cautious or just average investors (and who, investment advisers note, tend to be the ones most attracted to the insurance guarantee).
"That's typical of what happens when the insurance industry comes up with a great idea -- they intended something for specific people, but on the agent level, they sell it to everybody," said James A. Shambo, a Colorado accountant who heads the personal financial planning division of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.
 
The Seductive Vision Of Avoiding Taxes
 The sheer complexity of these products may make them a bad choice for many investors. One sign that Americans do not really understand the pros and cons of variable annuities is that many are sold to people for individual retirement accounts and the retirement savings accounts known as 401(k)'s and 403(b)'s, which are already sheltered from taxes. So these buyers may be paying a big price for a benefit they already have.
If variable annuities are bad bets for so many people, why are Americans suddenly snapping them up? Tax avoidance, said Laura Pantaleo, first vice president of Smith Barney Shearson, the big brokerage firm. Avoiding taxes has become harder in recent years as Congress has eliminated most tax shelters, limited contributions to retirement savings plans and even tightened the rules on tax-free municipal bonds.
Sales of variable annuities have become big business for large insurers like the Equitable Life Assurance Society and Prudential Insurance, and more are getting into the act every day. Meanwhile, many mutual fund companies, like Franklin Resources, have teamed up with insurers, while others, like Fidelity Investments, have started their own insurance units so that they, too, can offer variable annuities. And banks are becoming big sellers, too.
Insurance companies, which every year charge fees based on the amount in the variable annuity, like the fact that these investments -- and thus the fees -- are likely to remain around for a long time. Investors can move their annuity accounts from one firm to another, but they must fill out special tax forms, which many find daunting. And some salespeople like the fact that the insurance company pays them a relatively fat commission, perhaps as much as 6 percent of the investment, at a time when commissions on regular mutual funds have been falling (they generally range from 1 to 4.5 percent up front, with perhaps an annual fee as well).
 Insurance and investment executives say their firms make every effort to explain variable annuities and sell them only to people who will benefit. "I would never put a person in a variable annuity if they themselves didn't completely understand the reason for the product and the restrictions," said Ted M. Beal, the Equitable district manager in New Jersey.
 
Picture Is Rosy For Some Investors
 For the right person, in the right financial circumstances, with the right investment results, variable annuities may turn out to be wise investments.
Glenn S. Daily, an independent insurance consultant in New York, compared investments in variable annuities with those in similar mutual funds. In his model, the mutual funds had annual costs of 1.3 percent of assets, and the variable annuity had annual costs of 2 percent; both are slightly higher than the average, according to Morningstar Inc., a Chicago research firm.
 In the best case for the variable annuity, an investor whose combined state and Federal taxes put him in the 35 percent bracket -- a high rate, but not the highest -- invests $25,000 in a variable annuity's mutual fund that earns 12 percent a year before expenses. If the investor holds onto it for 20 years he would end up with $117,048, Mr. Daily found. But if the same investor put the same amount directly into a mutual fund, received the same return and paid taxes every year he would end up with considerably less: $103,798.
Of course, in the real world an average investment gain masks a lot of ups and downs: in some years the market goes up more, in some years it goes up less, in some years it falls. Using a statistical model that insurance actuaries use to simulate real returns, Mr. Daily found that this investor had almost a 75 percent chance of doing better in the variable annuity than in the mutual fund.
In fact, this investor could improve his financial picture if he were willing to withdraw the money from the variable annuity very slowly, which allows the money to grow longer without being taxed. He could also help himself if he were willing to use those investment proceeds at retirement to obtain a traditional annuity, an insurance product that pays income for life and also provides tax benefits. The proceeds of the variable annuity would then provide annual income of $13,158 a year, compared with $9,741 a year from the annuity bought with the mutual fund proceeds. Unfortunately, very few variable annuity holders -- probably fewer than 20 percent -- choose to do this.
 
 
The Payoff Comes Only With Patience
 There are a lot of ways this nice picture can go awry.
One obvious problem is that few Americans seem prepared to stay in the same investment for decades, so that there is enough time for the benefits of tax deferral to overcome the costs. Variable annuities have not been around long enough for anyone to know if their buyers will hold on for many years, but if investor behavior holds true to form, many people will not have such patience. For example, in stock mutual funds, investors take out about half of the money they put in each year.
In Mr. Daily's example, an investor who locks up his $25,000 for 10 years but then takes it out would be worse off in a variable annuity than in a regular mutual fund, getting back $50,613, compared with $50,774. That $161 difference may not seem like much, but investors in variable annuities have given up a lot of flexibility, because they cannot use the money to buy a house or a car or invest in gold or real estate or move the money to a better investment manager (unless that manager happens to run a variable annuity, too). And if the investors are not about to turn 60, they also face a big tax penalty.
And the results could well turn out worse -- Mr. Daily's actuarial analysis shows that over 10 years, an investor has a 75 percent chance of doing worse in a variable annuity than in a mutual fund.
Then there is the fact that few if any investors will be able to achieve 12 percent gains every year for two decades. The average annual gain for the stock market since 1928 has been about 10 percent; at that level of return, an investor has to hold on to a variable annuity for 15 years before it begins to match the mutual fund's after-tax results.
 
 
Picking Investments With Low Returns
 Even a 10 percent gain may be too rosy an assumption, because many annuity buyers are too conservative -- or too scared -- to invest only in stocks. Many choose money-market funds or low-yielding fixed-rate accounts that barely beat inflation.
The most popular new investment options for variable annuity investors are asset-allocation funds and balanced funds, which mix stocks and bonds, said Geoff Bobroff, a consultant in East Greenwich, R.I. Such funds historically have lower returns than regular stock funds.
With an 8 percent return, one that might be more typical of a balanced fund, an investor in a variable annuity would have almost $1,100 less after 10 years than in a similar mutual fund, because of the high annual costs. Even after 20 years, he would be just barely ahead in the variable annuity -- and Mr. Daily calculates that there is more than a 50 percent chance that he would be doing worse.
For people in the very highest tax brackets, there is still another potential drawback: profits from variable annuities are taxed as ordinary income, instead of as capital gains. This means an investor who might pay Federal taxes of 28 percent on mutual fund gains could end up paying 36 percent or more on the profits from a variable annuity.
 
Regular Insurance Is Called Cheaper
 Despite the high costs, insurance executives argue that because of the death benefit, variable annuities are good for people who are scared of investing in stocks. "People may know that to hedge against inflation they should put money into equities, but a husband will say, 'If I do this and something happens to the market, when I die my wife will complain about me forever,' " said Rodney R. Rohda, chairman of Fidelity Investments' insurance company. Once the guaranteed death benefit is explained, he added, "You can see the tension leave the guy's face."
That person should just buy more life insurance, many financial advisers say; it would be a lot cheaper. Furthermore, if he really is investing in stocks for the long haul, his chances of losing money are small; Ibbotson Associates of Chicago notes that there has been no 20-year period since 1926 in which investors would have suffered a loss by investing in the stocks included in the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
Regulators, who are understaffed and overwhelmed by other investment problems, can only hope that investors do value the death benefit and that they understand what they have bought. As Barry Barbash, head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment management division, put it, "Variable annuities shouldn't be viewed as just another way to buy mutual funds -- because people are paying a lot."


GRAPHIC: The people who sell variable deferred annuities often use payout statistics based on rosy assumptions about long-term rates of return and emphasize the annuities' favorable tax treatment. But unless investors stick with them for a long time, their high costs make variable annuities a lackluster choice even after taxes are considered, especially if returns turn out to be not so rosy.

HEADLINE: In Poignant Public Letter, Reagan Reveals That He Has Alzheimer's

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Former President Ronald Reagan said today that he had entered the early stages of Alzheimer's disease, an incurable brain ailment that steadily destroys memory and eventually leads to death.
In a handwritten letter to the American people, the 83-year-old Mr. Reagan said he was in good health now, and while he maintained a positive tone, he did strike a fatalistic note. 
 "I now begin the journey that will lead me into the sunset of my life," Mr. Reagan wrote. "I know that for America there will always be a bright dawn ahead." [Text of the letter, page 47.]
Mr. Reagan's letter, issued by his office in Los Angeles, was accompanied by a statement from his doctors, who explained that the disease was diagnosed through repeated observations and testing for a year.
"Over the past 12 months we began to notice from President Reagan's test results symptoms indicating the possibility of early-stage Alzheimer's disease," the doctors wrote. "Additional testing and an extensive observation over the past few weeks have led us to conclude that President Reagan is entering the early stages of this disease."
The doctors said that Mr. Reagan's current health was good, but "it is expected that as the years go on it will begin to deteriorate."
Alzheimer's disease is an incurable neurological disorder, which affects communication between brain cells and, ultimately, causes the cells to die.
The disease leads to memory loss, which can produce disorientation, difficulty in speaking and personality disorders. It afflicts about four million people in the United States. Most victims are older than 65.
At a Democratic rally in Alameda, Calif., this afternoon, President Clinton asked the crowd to put its partisanship aside and wish Mr. Reagan well, and then he passed on the news that Mr. Reagan was suffering from Alzheimer's disease.
Mr. Clinton recalled a visit with Mr. Reagan shortly after his own election and said there had come a point when the former President stopped and said he had forgotten what he was going to say.
"When he said that, it touched my heart in a particular way," Mr. Clinton said.
While he was the President, Mr. Reagan had a relaxed leadership style and was know for occasionally becoming disengaged and bored during White House meetings. His associates said that in recent months he had changed markedly and that he was failing to recognize people he had known. Some longtime friends of Mr. Reagan said tonight that the former President's memory had begun to slip noticeably for two years.
"You could tell that he had it as early as, say, two years ago," said an associate who spent considerable time with the former President in recent years. "He was having a definite memory problem, and he'd say time and again, 'I just can't remember.'
"He talked at times about his memory problems," said the associate, who spoke only on the condition that he not be publicly identified. "He even mentioned that his mother had died of Alzheimer's, and he wondered whether he might have inherited it. But then he'd go on in his usual breezy manner and that would be the end of the discussion."
The oldest man ever to serve as President, Mr. Reagan said when he was elected in 1980 at age 69 that he would have the White House physician test him periodically and that he would resign if serious evidence of senility or mental deterioration were detected.
"If I were President and had any feeling at all that my capabilities had been reduced before a second term came," he said at the time, "I would walk away. By the same token, I would step down also."
He was elected by overwhelming margins in 1980 and 1984, touting his program to cut taxes, strengthen the military and reduce the deficit.
On foreign policy, Mr. Reagan was more pragmatic than his cold war talk suggested. But his supply-side economics led to soaring deficits.
During his final year in office, he was politically hobbled by the Iran-contra scandal. But while the Iran-contra affair claimed many victims, Mr. Reagan's popularity was relatively unscathed.
During office, he survived an assassination attempt in which he was shot in the chest. He has also been operated on to a remove cancerous polypfrom his colon and has had prostate surgery.
After retiring, Mr. Reagan remained physically vigorous. In 1989, hesurgeons removed fluid from his brain, apparently the result of his having been thrown from a horse.
One associate speculated that Mr. Reagan's family decided to issue a public announcement today because his behavior was becoming too difficult to ignore. Even so, many old friends were shocked.
"It catches me totally by surprise," said Fred F. Fielding, who was Counsel to the President from 1981 to 1986.
Sheila Tate, who served as Mrs. Reagan's press secretary, fought back tears tonight. "The letter was quite emotional," she said. "But it was so like Ronald Reagan to do something like this -- so gracefully."
Ms. Tate said that she had spoken at length with the former First Lady earlier this week but that Mrs. Reagan had provided no clue that she was under any special strain. "She was in good humor," Ms. Tate said. "We talked about everything, from politics to politics."
In his two-page letter, Mr. Reagan said he had decided to make his condition known to raise public awareness of Alzheimer's disease after discussion with his wife.
"I have recently been told that I am one of the millions of Americans who will be afflicted with Alzheimer's disease," Mr. Reagan wrote in his hand-written letter, which was faxed to news organizations. "Upon learning this news, Nancy and I had to decide whether as private citizens we would keep this as a private matter or whether we would make this news known in a public way.
"In opening our hearts, we hope this might promote greater awareness of this condition. Perhaps it will encourage a clearer understanding of the individuals and families who are affected by it."
Mr. Reagan said he felt "just fine" and planned to spend his time with his wife and family and to enjoy the outdoors in California.
He thanked the American people for electing him.
His letter was written in a steady hand, his writing marred only when he speculated about his death. In that passage, Mr. Reagan crossed out two words and then continued his phrase.
"When the Lord calls me home, whenever that may be, I will leave with the greatest love for this country of ours and eternal optimism for the future," he wrote. "I now begin the journey that will lead me into the sunset of my life. I know that for American there will always be a bright dawn ahead."
At the Democratic rally, Mr. Clinton, recalled Mr. Reagan's sense of optimism.
"We disagreed on a lot of things over the years," the President said of his predecessor. "But he always fought with a sense of optimism and spirit."
Mr. Clinton said he was particularly grateful for Mr. Reagan's support in the last year for the North American Free Trade Agreement, the ban on assault weapons and for criticizing Oliver L. North in the Virginia Senate campaign.
"I want every one of you in this room to give Ronald Reagan a hand and wish him well and goodness," Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE SENATE;
CONTROL IN SENATE NEAR G.O.P. GRASP AS RACES WIND UP

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
One of the closest, nastiest and perhaps most consequential off-year set of Senate campaigns in decades is clattering to an end in the same volatile climate of voter unrest, partisan invective and incumbent anxiety with which it began.
After months of state-by-state drama punctuated by increasingly mean and shallow advertisements, and after a record-breaking total of more than $200 million in Senate campaign spending, the central question remains: Can Republicans pick up the seven seats they need to control the chamber? 
 And the answer is no easier to come by than it was when Congress adjourned in October after a display of legislative bickering and gridlock that left much of the public disgusted.
Both sides agree that the goal is within the Republicans' grasp, and with it the chance to thwart President Clinton's legislative agenda for the next two years and alter the political balance heading into the next Presidential election cycle.
But with polls showing at least half a dozen races still too close to call, the outcome will hinge on whether Democrats, in the next three days, can counter what now appears to be a significant advantage in turnout for Republicans.
In state after state, Democratic stars once thought virtually immune from serious challenge this year -- from Edward M. Kennedy in Massachusetts to Harris Wofford in Pennsylvania to Jim Sasser in Tennessee and on to Dianne Feinstein in California -- have had to fight for their political lives.
With each party constantly checking its polls to see where national leaders could do the most good on the stump, the frenetic campaigning continued today.
After stumping in California today, Mr. Clinton planned to return to Minnesota on Sunday for his second stop there in three days, hoping to give a boost to Ann Wynia, who is in a neck-and-neck race for a Senate seat.
Vice President Al Gore was back in his home state, Tennessee, trying to give a lift to the flagging campaigns of the two Democratic senatorial candidates there.
And after campaigning in Minnesota, the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, returned to the capital today and declared in his response to Mr. Clinton's weekly radio address that Democrats were "in a state of near panic."
Despite the Democrats' early campaign predictions that the continued growth of the economy would be the overriding issue, it fell flat on the campaign trail this fall, as did moves by Democrats to seize on other public concerns, like welfare and health care.
Instead, campaigns across the country featured broad attacks, by incumbents and challengers alike, against government itself. If they were not flailing at government, the candidates were bitterly ridiculing one another's character, and often distorting opponents' records, in 30-second bursts of paid television time.
When they did turn to issues, the language of both parties was decidedly conservative, with candidates battling in particular to look toughest against criminals.
Republicans in the Senate have already proved a formidable stumbling block to Clinton-proposed legislation. And if they take their first control there since 1986, thus assuming leadership of the Senate's committees, they will be in a position to derail the President's legislative program entirely. Whatever legislation did pass would likely be pushed to the right, not only because of the change in party control but also because many Republican candidates are more conservative than the Republicans who are leaving the Senate.
Republican dominance in the Senate would also influence the politics of the 1996 Presidential campaign.
Consoling themselves in anticipation of bad news, some Democrats even argue that Mr. Clinton might benefit from losing the Senate because he could then campaign against the Republicans in the tradition of President Harry S. Truman's 1948 crusade against the "do-nothing 80th Congress."
But Republican control would energize the Senate Republican leader, Mr. Dole, who is considering a run for the White House, as well as Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who is already putting a 1996 campaign structure in place.
Most polls show that in their quest for seven more seats, the Republicans are likely to pick up Democratic seats in Ohio, Maine, Tennessee and Arizona. The question is whether they can win three other seats now held by Democrats without losing any now held by Republicans.
That is possible, if by no means certain. Polls show that Democratic seats in Pennsylvania, Michigan, Oklahoma and Virginia, and a second one in Tennessee, could go either way. And Democratic seats in California and New Mexico are not completely safe either.
In contrast, the only Republican seat that polls show could be in real jeopardy is in Minnesota, where Senator Dave Durenberger is retiring, although two other Republicans -- Senators James M. Jeffords of Vermont and Slade Gorton of Washington -- are in tight races.
"One poll has us 10 points down; our own poll has us a little ahead," said Mr. Wofford, the Pennsylvania Democrat who won in an upset two years ago and now finds himself in one of the tightest races, against Representative Rick Santorum. "I'm in the eye of the storm, and I feel it's the Battle of Gettysburg."
One possibility, less talked about than a Republican takeover, is that the elections will produce a Senate of 50 Democrats and 50 Republicans for the first time in a century. In that case, Vice President Gore, in his role as President of the Senate, might frequently cast tie-breaking votes. There is also the chance that Senator Richard C. Shelby, an Alabama Democrat who often votes with the Republicans, would be enticed to switch parties.
It was not supposed to end up this way. Senator Bob Graham of Florida, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, sounded perfectly reasonable seven months ago when he asserted that "there's no single factor that is as significant in 1994 as the state of the economy."
But although the economy continued to improve, few voters gave the Democrats any credit. Meanwhile, the Republicans' success at blocking legislation like that on health care seemed to neither help nor hurt them.
In this season of the campaigning outsider, ignorance in the ways of Washington was championed. Incumbents did not dare include the image of the Capitol dome in their advertisements; challengers used photographs of the dome with relish, lampooning good-for-nothing insiders, and boasted of political naivete.
"I worked in the Senate as a young college student in 1963, when it was an enormously revered institution and Ted Kennedy was lean, young and attractive," said Thomas Cronin, a political scientist who is president of Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash. "But there has been a massive sea change where the burden is on the members of the Senate to defend themselves. The high water mark is this year."
With 16 Democratic incumbents and only 10 Republican incumbents running, it is the Democrats who seem to be paying the price for the discontent with Washington. And Republicans have had another advantage: their relentless linking of Democratic opponents with the unpopular President.
Republican challengers whom the Democrats did not initially view as serious threats have become the candidates to beat. There is Fred Dalton Thompson, a lawyer and movie actor in Tennessee; William Frist, a heart and lung surgeon, also in Tennessee, who did not register to vote until 1988, and, of course, Oliver L. North of Virginia and the Iran-contra affair.
"Once again, we are proving that whatever you say a year out is likely to be wrong," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster. "People seen as safe a year ago, like Sasser and Feinstein, are having trouble; people who were very endangered, like Frank Lautenberg, are doing relatively better."
The roots of the Democrats' predicament date from early this year -- long before the talk of ousting incumbents reached a fever pitch -- when the party failed to persuade some of its strongest potential candidates, like former Gov. James Blanchard of Michigan, to run for the Senate.
In addition, there were the unexpected retirements. First, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, announced that he would be leaving; his seat is widely expected to turn Republican. Then Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma announced that he too would retire, two years before the end of his term, to become president of the University of Oklahoma; his seat could go either way.

HEADLINE: Political Turmoil Distracts Poland as NATO Decisions Loom

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Poland's increasingly chaotic political situation is more confused than ever these days.
Embarrassing the Government at an important juncture in its foreign policy, Foreign Minister Andrzej Olechowski announced last week that he would resign because his reputation had been impugned by a fellow Cabinet member. 
 He soon changed his mind, saying that he would stay for now, but the damage was already done.
"The consequences won't be good," said Krzystztof Skubiszewski, a former Foreign Minister.
"In the eyes of international public opinion, the picture of Poland is changing for the worse for a number of reasons," he said, alluding to the Government's uncertainty over how strongly Poland should push to join NATO, and the Prime Minister's slowing of the privatization of state enterprises.
The uncertainty over Mr. Olechowski's future developed just as Washington announced a more aggressive policy toward welcoming former Soviet-bloc countries into the NATO alliance.
The country's relations with Russia are also taking a turn for the worse.
The Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, suddenly postponed a visit to Warsaw this week, saying that the Polish Government had failed to apologize for an incident in which Polish police beat some Russians at a Warsaw rail station. The cancellation was seen here as a way of showing opposition to Poland's efforts to join NATO.
Mr. Olechowski resigned after he found his name on a list released last week of 68 Government officials who had broken a little-known law forbidding them to draw salaries for second jobs outside the Government.
An economist who worked at the World Bank and served on the boards of several Western corporations, Mr. Olechowski chaired the supervisory board of the state-owned Bank Handlowy, one of Poland's largest banks. Under Polish law, Government officials are permitted to represent the Government on the boards of nationalized companies but are not allowed to accept pay. Few knew of the law and it contains no penalties.
"The fact is that nobody has ever heard of the act, never mind observed it," Mr. Olechowski said last week when he announced his resignation. "The prosecutor general, with the Prime Minister's knowledge, challenged my honesty."
A few days later, Mr. Olechowski apparently sensed that the Justice Minister, Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz, who is also known as the prosecutor general and was a prominent figure in the former Communist Party, had found little support in the Government for the so-called anti-corruption campaign. The Foreign Minister said that he would suspend his resignation until a constitutional tribunal ruled and that he would leave if there was no ruling by year's end.
In what many here see as a more serious of conflict of interest, Prime Minister Waldemar Pawlak traveled in an airplane provided by General Motors and Ameritech when he visited the United States recently. Both companies do business in Poland.
The fuss over Mr. Olechowski briefly overshadowed the intense squabbling between President Lech Walesa and Mr. Pawlak's Government, which is a coalition of parties rooted in the Communist past.
"If I had the power I would have dismissed this government a long time ago," said Mr. Walesa, who is seeking re-election. This was Mr. Walesa's tit-for-tat against the Parliament, which had passed a motion accusing Mr. Walesa of "destabilizing" the country.

HEADLINE: Report Says Group Long Had Deficits

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The financial crisis that led the N.A.A.C.P. to furlough most of its employees last week is part of a longstanding pattern of unusual financial practices and cash flow problems, according to sworn statements by two officers, a newspaper reported today.
Depositions given in September by the civil rights group's treasurer and chairman indicated that the organization routinely operated in the red and had a "liquid asset deficit" of $500,000 when Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. became its executive director in April 1993, The Washington Post reported. The depositions by the treasurer, Jerry L. Maulden, and the chairmain, William F. Gibson, were given in connection with a wrongful dismissal suit filed by Mr. Chavis. 
 National leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People have contended that Mr. Chavis alone created the organization's current $3.8 million deficit. They said Mr. Chavis's financial mismanagement contributed to his dismissal in August. But the depositions suggest that the financial troubles may have dated to the term of his predecessor, Benjamin L. Hooks, The Post said. Mr. Hooks has said there was no deficit when he retired.
Mr. Chavis, Mr. Hooks and Mr. Gibson could not be reached for comment today.
The auditing firm of Price Waterhouse has been working with the N.A.A.C.P. to sort out its tangled finances.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: Massachusetts
The Last Weekend: Senate Races Where the Battle Has Been Intense;
Romney Eclectic In Final Sprint

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Mitt Romney, the Republican venture capitalist who wants to replace Senator Edward M. Kennedy, is down in the polls as the election campaign nears the wire. So he is borrowing a tactic or two from Presidential races of recent and not-so-recent memory.
Taking a page from the Ross Perot scrapbook, Mr. Romney went on television Friday night with the first broadcast of a new half-hour commercial. Then, appropriating an old Harry S. Truman trademark, the Romney campaign pulled out of North Station here this afternoon on a whistle-stop train tour. And Mr. Romney plans to spend Sunday campaigning through the state by bus, reminiscent of the Clinton-Gore caravans of 1992. 
 Mr. Romney is even using an old Kennedy strategy, enlisting the help of a family dynasty. Dozens of Romneys are hitting the campaign trail in these last days, led by the candidate's 87-year-old father, former Gov. George Romney of Michigan. There were 68 members of the Romney family on the whistle-stop tour this afternoon, wearing sweatshirts emblazoned with "Romneys for Mitt" and "TKO Squad."
TKO? That means "Ted Kennedy Out," Mr. Romney explained.
Mr. Kennedy, who campaigned with Hillary Rodham Clinton in Springfield on Friday, went to South Boston this morning to announce a $330 million Federal grant for Boston's transportation system.
"Nothing else will work unless we have a growing, sound economy," the Senator told a small group of supporters. "And that means jobs, jobs, jobs, jobs, jobs for Boston and jobs for Massachusetts."
Mr. Romney, who was even with Mr. Kennedy in polls just five weeks ago, has seen his support erode during the last month. A Boston Globe/WBZ-TV poll published today showed him trailing Mr. Kennedy by 55 percent to 37 percent.
The challenger, placing blame for his waning popularity on negative advertisements run by the Kennedy campaign, said he hoped to regain lost ground with his new half-hour television commercial. "It will give me an occasion to talk, once again, in some depth on the issues that I think people really care about," he said before videotaping the ad on Friday.
Unlike Ross Perot productions, this infomercial has no pie charts. It begins with a short biography of Mr. Romney, and most of it is set in a television studio where the candidate fields questions from an audience selected by his campaign staff. Although he said he was modeling the program on a town-hall-style meeting and would not know the questions in advance, many of those questions -- including one about recovering drug addicts in senior citizen centers -- touched on themes he had addressed in a campaign speech earlier in the day.
In the last days of the race, the Romney campaign will spend $100,000 to broadcast the commercial five times. MICHAEL COOPER
