HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
The Rites of Fall New York's Religion: What Else but Fashion?

BYLINE: By SUSANNA RODELL 

 BODY:
To the list of most-repeated lies -- the check is in the mail, I'm from the government and I'm here to help you -- add one more: I don't care what I look like.
 Especially in New York, this is self-deception at its most flagrant. A quick look at police statistics, combined with a little basic research, will confirm that people are much more likely to commit a major felony than to show up at the office in the wrong shoes. Yet even here, in this city of surfaces, where walking down the street looking good is the most widely practiced art form, people cling to another strange vanity: that they have none. 
 This week, of all weeks, perhaps it is time to let go of this last scrap of Calvinist mythology, as New York finishes up another round of fashion fever. All week long the runways set up in the tents in Bryant Park behind the New York Public Library have thudded under the stilettoed heels of Kate and Naomi and Linda. All week long the papers have screeched with speculations about models' pay and threatening boyfriends, and even the once-restrained New Yorker magazine has devoted a whole issue to this alleged non-issue.
 Face it: this city cannot live without fashion. For one thing, its economics feed us. Other industries may have fled, but the rag trade -- from the design schools to the sweatshops to the upmarket showrooms to the modeling agencies to the magazines to the department stores, boutiques and street markets -- remains spiritually and practically fused with New York.
 More personally, New Yorkers themselves, though they often hate to acknowledge it, are fashion's most ardent devotees. It is a matter of necessity. This is a hierarchical city; rank matters. It is also a city in which few people have any time. Impressions must be made quickly. To do this verbally takes precious minutes. The witty remark, the display of erudition need the right opening and the right, relaxed setting. It's so much more efficient to display these qualities in a way that takes mere seconds to appraise: the cuff button, the combination of boot top and hemline, the cocktail of old and new, grandfather's tweeds and this week's loony handbag, the Dead-Serious suit with the small visual joke of red bobby socks.
 In fact, we are talking religion. Nowhere was this more evident last week than under those canvas pavilions where the yearly rites were being performed. The pilgrims had arrived from all over the world and lined the magic aisle to worship. The high priests delivered the goods: the magic potion of young female forms and cloth. The acolytes, who sat in banks opposite the altars, pointed their lenses, whistled and stomped.
 The priest or priestess of each denomination proffered his or her interpretation of the textile text: the younger ones going for tacky wit with variations on 50's Ban-Lon sportswear accessorized with food containers; the older, long-ordained bishops offering classic girl-clothes that would do Audrey Hepburn proud.
 On Friday morning, the reigning Pope -- a Mr. Klein -- offered the most New York statement of them all, unremitting black and white and beige and the tiniest hint of mauve in maybe one garment, clothes that said: "I'm from New York and I care deeply about how I look, but I also care very deeply that people should not know how deeply I care, and I've therefore just thrown on this little silk number that really isn't any color at all and has no shape either except for my perfect body, which you can see just enough of.
 "Oh? I look stunning? How very surprising. Thank you." SUSANNA RODELL

HEADLINE: In America;
The Doom Mongers

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The Republicans in Washington in the spring and summer of 1993 predicted catastrophe.
 President Clinton, in office only a few months, was struggling to pass his deficit reduction plan. Nowhere could he find a Republican, not one -- not in the House and not in the Senate -- who would vote for it. 
 Late in May, when the bill narrowly passed the House, Republican Congressman Curt Weldon of Pennsylvania said: "We will remember this vote when unemployment goes up, when inflation goes up, when spending goes up, when the national debt goes up. No more blaming Reagan and Bush."
 Senator Bob Dole, who will become majority leader if the Republicans take control of the Senate in Tuesday's election, said in August 1993, "President Clinton knows . . . I know, and the American people know that the plan does not tackle the deficit head on."
 Republican Congressman Rick Santorum, who is challenging incumbent Democrat Harris Wofford for a Senate seat in Pennsylvania, said: "I rise in opposition to this bill because it is bad for America. It does not create jobs."
 And Republican Senator Phil Gramm of Texas declared, "We are buying a one-way ticket to a recession."
 Maybe they really believed the sky was falling. Maybe they just wanted to hurt a young Democratic President. Whatever the reasons, they were wrong. Very wrong.
 Employment is up, inflation is down and there has been a startling decrease in the Federal budget deficit.
 For the many who claimed the President's program was a "jobs killer" came the news last week that unemployment had dropped to a four-year low. Nearly 5.5 million jobs have been created since Mr. Clinton became President.
 Since passage of Mr. Clinton's economic plan, 79,000 jobs have been created in the automobile industry. By the end of this year, the United States will overtake Japan as the world's top auto producer for the first time since the 1970's.
 Despite the dire predictions (and perhaps wishful thinking) of the G.O.P., the Clinton Administration has managed to sustain the economic recovery and create jobs while keeping inflation low. And it has done this while sharply reducing both the budget deficit and the size of the Federal bureaucracy.
 If Ronald Reagan had done these things he would have been canonized.
 The deficit ($73.8 billion when Mr. Reagan took office) had climbed to nearly $300 billion in the last year of the Bush Presidency. Under Mr. Clinton, the deficit fell to $255 billion in the first year and $203 billion in fiscal 1994. That is the sharpest two-year drop in history. And it is the first time the deficit has fallen two years in a row in more than 20 years.
 This is not widely known. A recent poll showed that only 23 percent of Americans were aware that the deficit had been reduced at all. Next year the deficit will fall below $170 billion.
 Proponents of smaller government should know that the Federal work force is already shrinking rapidly. By fiscal 1999, under the President's plan, we will have the smallest Federal bureaucracy since John Kennedy was President.
 There is so much chaos, static, incoherence, mean-spiritedness, gutlessness and deliberate deception in the political discourse that voters are finding it increasingly difficult to know what is really going on. Few Americans realize, for example, that the income tax increases in the Clinton budget plan affected only the top 1.2 percent of all taxpayers. The remaining 98.8 percent paid the same amount in taxes, or less.
 Americans are discontented, and with good reason. Despite a surge in the economy, too many are without good jobs, too many are without adequate health care and too many are afraid of the very real threat of violent crime. But voters should ask themselves if those kinds of problems will be handled best by a rerun of the Reagan-Bush years.
 If it were not for the interest that still must be paid on the debt run up by Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush, President Clinton would have a balanced budget. In fact, he would have a $7 billion surplus.
 The Republicans were wrong last year when they derided the Clinton economic plan; and those who continue to make the fantastic claim that they can cut taxes, increase military spending and balance the budget are wrong now.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Players Are Talking Rival United League Seriously, Agents Say

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
With the price of franchises pegged in the area of $5 million, the United Baseball League should have little trouble finding owners for their projected 10 franchises. That's a bargain-basement rate compared with the $150 million that major league baseball will probably charge the people from Phoenix and St. Petersburg, Fla., to get into that exclusive club.
More difficult for the fledgling league will be the seduction of major league players into their teams' uniforms, and a still more arduous task will most likely be the effort to induce 10 cities to build stadiums in return for 15 percent equity in the team and a 15 percent share of the pretax profits. 
 But, said Tom Reich, a prominent player agent who is knowledgeable about the economics of baseball: "Dick Moss and his associates deserve to be taken very seriously. They are not autumn leaves blowing around in the wind."
Speaking of the new league's ability to lure players, Reich said: "I think some very good players will play in that league if it succeeds in getting started. Do I think Frank Thomas or Junior Griffey, guys like that, will play? No, not so fast. There is no question the established league always will have a big leg up on a new league for a variety of reasons, not least of which is Cooperstown. But I think there would be a lot of very good players who would be willing to play in the new league."
By the very salary strategy they have pursued in recent winters and that will be most pronounced this winter, major league clubs will drive veteran, but very usable, players to the other league. The middle class of players is shrinking because teams would rather pay the minimum salary to a rookie than the average salary to a veteran.
An increasing number of experienced players will not find jobs with established teams and will look for employment where it is available. If initial indications are accurate, some players may not even wait to discover they are unemployed to seek jobs in the United League.
Tony Attanasio, another long active agent, said he polled all of his clients about the new league and they reacted with unanimous interest. Attanasio said he presented this proposition to each of his players:
"If you were offered 'x' to play in major league baseball and 50 percent of 'x' to play in the new league with profit sharing, which would you take?"
"I was shocked at the response," Attanasio said. "One hundred percent would go to the new league. The point is that guys are fed up to their eyeballs with the Bud Selig-Jerry Reinsdorf nonsense. I've talked to other agents and they've said essentially the same thing."
Now if the new league's founders can find places for these players to play, they'll be ready to open for business.
"We're not talking about having to talk 10 cities into spending $170 million to build a replica of the stadium in Baltimore," John Bryant, a Congressman from Texas, said, referring to state-of-the-art Camden Yards.
Richard Moss, whose name has become most popularly attached to the venture because of his vast experience with major league baseball, talked about two types of stadiums that interest the new league.
One type could be built in 9 or 10 months, Moss said. It would have a basic shell with permanent seats and luxury boxes from first base to third base and temporary stands around the rest of the park. Those stands could be replaced in the following year or two. The cost of the initial structure, Moss said, would be about $30 million for a stadium with 35,000 to 40,000 seats.
Project No. 2, he said, would resemble the much-praised Pilot Field in Buffalo, being constructed as a more permanent edifice at a cost of about $50 million to $60 million. It would have 20,000 to 25,000 seats initially, with expansion in the following year to 40,000 to 45,000. Initial stage of the construction could be done within a year, Moss said.
"Stadium construction has become very advanced in the past few years," he added.
Besides equity and profit sharing, Bryant said, cities would have the benefit of using the stadiums the rest of the year for whatever profit-making purpose they desire.
"It won't be like it is in most of these cities, where the cities build stadiums and get hardly anything in return for it," he said.
The line forms to the left.
 
Memos, They Get Memos
 Instead of box scores and scouting reports, club executives read memos and directives about labor negotiations. Except they can't always agree on what's in them.
One executive said last week that he was reluctant to speak to a reporter because management people had been "gagged" under a threat of fines. The executive said everyone had been instructed, at the request of the mediator, Bill Usery Jr., not to talk about the collective bargaining process now that it was in mediation.
An executive of another club said he saw a memo from Bud Selig attached to a copy of an Oct. 24 letter from Usery asking that people not comment or engage in rhetoric that wasn't constructive. But, he said, he didn't recall any reference to a fine in Selig's memo.
But officials from two other clubs said they either had read or heard about the threat of fines for saying the wrong thing.
Selig said he sent to the clubs a memo stating what he said Usery said to him at the White House last month, but he added, "There never has been any suggestion of a fine."
Selig, however, acknowledged sending a more recent memo. That one, he said, dealt with the disclosure of the details of a memo outlining the ingredients of the new proposal the owners plan to make.
"When we send internal memos," Selig lamented, "we find it disturbing that even before the ink is dry, it's in the newspapers."
 
Threat or No Threat?
 The owners' Player Relations Committee may have been unfair to Bobby Bonilla in the unfair labor practice charge it filed with the National Labor Relations Board last week against Bonilla and John Franco, the Mets' player representatives, and the Players Association.
In the charge, which stemmed from harsh comments attributed to the two players about players who might report to training camps next spring, the clubs' labor lawyers said that Bonilla "threatened that club employees who crossed the M.L.B.P.A.'s picket line would 'end up in the East River.' "
Gene Orza, a union lawyer, said Bonilla never made that statement. He noted that as the basis for the charge, the Player Relations Committee relied on newspaper reports, one of which quoted Bonilla as saying, "You've got to remember, our negotiations are not any different than any negotiations in any labor situation. Try to cross that teamsters line. You'd end up in the East River, right?"
Lou Melendez, a management lawyer, said he thought Bonilla's meaning was clear even if he didn't link the East River directly to players.
"I think from the statement he's made you can draw the inference that he's applying it to replacement players," Melendez said. "The board will investigate the charge. If the board doesn't believe you can draw the inference from that statement, they'll say so. But we think you can draw the inference."
Melendez also said that contrary to another report, the Yankees' Scott Kamieniecki, who also made comments about strikebreakers, was not included in the charge because he is not a player representative.
 
Richards vs. Bush
 In what might be the generally nastiest and angriest midterm campaigns ever, much worse has been said about candidates for public office, but a campaign spokesman for Gov. Ann Richards of Texas recently made some comments about George W. Bush, her Republican opponent, that were far off base.
Bill Cryer, the spokesman for the Democratic Governor, criticized Bush for his "his hands-off management style" of running the Texas Rangers.
"He doesn't know what's really going on and apparently doesn't really care," Cryer said of Bush, one of the Rangers' two managing partners. "I think his management of the Texas Rangers mostly consists of sitting in the stands and watching games -- when they had games."
Political views aside, Cryer could not have been more wrong. It is true that when Bush began running for Governor he distanced himself from the day-to-day operation of the Rangers, but he was involved in the recent selection of Doug Melvin as the club's new general manager and before he became a candidate, he was the most vigorous supporter of the baseball operation.
Bush always opposed cutting funds for scouting and player development, and he didn't stop the baseball people from spending to get good experienced players. In fact, as much as he would like to be governor, the Rangers will be better off if he loses Tuesday. Bush's involvement also could be beneficial to baseball's labor problems.
The Texas race, incidentally, has developed an interesting stretch-run matchup: Ross Perot versus Nolan Ryan. Perot has endorsed Richards while Ryan has been spending his own money in support of Bush.

HEADLINE: Marathon Stories Almost Outnumber the Runners

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
As they stream by his Brooklyn church today, the Rev. David Dyson says he will honor the New York Marathon runners from the pulpit, summoning Isaiah's prophecy that the young shall run and not be weary. But he will also read from the first verse of the 12th chapter of Hebrews, in which Paul speaks of runners being surrounded "by a great cloud of witnesses."
It is this verse that inspired the mural surrounding the inside of the church, which depicts "a cloud" of neighborhood folks from street people to firefighters to a kilt-wearing chap playing a bagpipe to, yes, runners in sweats. 
 "The marathon is for everybody in New York who can sweat and get sore feet -- and that includes all of us," said Mr. Dyson, pastor of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene. "Occasionally, the little miracles of grace do occur."
Through the church's open doors, worshipers will be able to glimpse a tide of 27,000 runners, about a third of the way through a tour of 26.2 miles and zones of sometimes inexpressible pain. The runners come from nearby -- a firefighter from the neighborhood company, a delivery man from a local supermarket -- and from every state and 100 countries.
They will huff past two million people, maybe more, from myriad places themselves -- standing on curbs, relaxing on lounge chairs, sipping soft drinks and taking pride in someone else's immense accomplishment.
The marathon has transformed the city for almost a week: Central Park has been filled with faster runners than usual, and sporting goods stores are crowded with customers eager to buy running shoes. The observation decks of the World Trade Center and Empire State Building are packed, restaurants serve mountains of such high-carb delicacies as pumpkin ravioli and some poorly heeled contestants from out-of-town find accommodations on strangers' floors.
"It's one of the few events that makes the city seem like a huge amount of fun," said Bruce Blank, the owner of Paragon Sporting Goods at Broadway and 18th Street, who was giving away lunch outside on Friday. The store hired four translators just for the week.
At Fitzpatrick's Hotel on Lexington Avenue (between 56th and 57th Streets), a group of 30 runners from Ireland has been staying. They are led by the world-class runner Eamonn Coughlan, but say they are equally inspired by the chief of New York's Police Department, John Timoney, who ran last Sunday in the Dublin Marathon and was planning to return yesterday to run in New York today.
"There's going to be a wild party here," promised the hotel's owner, John Fitzpatrick, who promised corned beef and cabbage, Irish stew, smoked salmon and something to wash them down.
And if ever this city is a glorious mosaic it is on Marathon Day, with the human spectator landscape changing as much as the tide of runners flowing by: a clump of French here, a pocket of Argentines over there, the Mexicans out ahead with the Africans.
Along Fourth Avenue in Bay Ridge, the first neighborhood runners pass in their long journey through Brooklyn, the Scandinavians are almost gone, but the Arabs who have bought many of the stores will cheer. In Sunset Park, the next neighborhood, Chinese are increasingly prominent in the still largely Hispanic crowd. National flags are always in evidence, along with special words of encouragement for compatriots.
Nowhere is the constant flux of things more apparent than in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section, where Hasidic supporters have long passed out glasses of seltzer instead of water to runners. An emerging Mexican-American population there eagerly anticipates cheering for the many elite runners their native land has produced in recent years.
"I think a Mexican will win; I just don't know which one," said Hector Martinez, who owns a tiny restaurant called Valle Mexico along the marathon route at 280 Bedford Avenue. He plans to drape a huge Mexican flag outside and set up tables to sell tacos.
It all rings melodically at the municipal cash register, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani estimating that this year's marathon will mean $100 million to the city's economy. More than that, the race offers an image of the city decidedly different from the many television series about the N.Y.P.D. "It gives a little depth to the normal picture of New York," said Richard Altman, spokesman for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. "And it gives us an opportunity to remind people we have five boroughs."
For those who live here, this long, winding course makes the event different from the much shorter holiday parades on Fifth Avenue or the Macy's Thanksgiving parade on the West Side. "We bring the race to the people, not the people to the race," said Allan Steinfeld, president of the New York Road Runners Club, sponsor of the race. "You have to go to a parade."
It is hard to describe how much the race means to participants, particularly the many who never imagined they could do such a thing. Gary Baronofsky, a Brooklyn Pepsi delivery man, ran the race in 1984, and still carries in his wallet a picture of himself crossing the finish line that he'll be glad to show you. On his second date with Shelley, the woman he married five years ago, he showed her a video of his marathon in which he appears for perhaps five seconds passing another mid-pack runner.
"The marathon is one of the great New York moments," he said. "It's like the seventh game of the N.B.A. playoffs and you're Willis Reed coming out to center court, or you're Muhammad Ali at center stage in the Garden."
For families, it's the same story. Michele Hagen plans to send her husband, Claude, a firefighter in the Bronx, off for his first marathon from a house festooned with inspirational posters. Afterward, she plans to call her family in Sicily to report his certain success.
Manfred Klein, a businessman from Hamburg, Germany, is running his first New York City Marathon since 1970, the year the event began. His wife, Ulla, says she has been monitoring his training menu closely, crammming him mainly with bananas and noodles. "He will finish between 10 and 25,000," she predicted.
To be sure, the marathon can have its dark side. Dr. William Fried, associate director of psychiatric residency training at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, notes that anorexic women tend to be runners, and that for runners in general the pursuit of perfection can sometimes get out of hand.
"You can see it as a symbol of the rat race we engage in every day," he said. "There is a mean-spirited way to approach it."
Indeed, marathon preparation can be a threat to marriages. Raoul Felder, the divorce lawyer, says complaints about the time a spouse spends training have been the death knell of many matches. And in at least two instances, he says wayward husbands used marathon preparation as an excuse for liaisons.
One was caught by his wife because he never came back sweaty. The other thought he was being shrewd and always wet his clothes after visiting a woman friend a block south on Park Avenue. But one day he forgot to wet his underwear and the jig was up. "I don't know how he did in the marathon," Mr. Felder said.
This year the marathon has actually changed the shape of the city. The Vernon Avenue Bridge in Long Island City, Queens, was scheduled for demolition as part of a new development project, but appears to have been at least temporarily spared. "Because it was on the marathon route, the bridge is still there," said Rochelle Wyner, a member of a community group fighting to save it.
But some things may be less susceptible to change. Anna Moses, a spokesman for Weight Watchers International, promised to try to find some members who run. Though she didn't expect marathoners, she couldn't find anybody.
"Our members don't like the 'e' word," she confessed, referring to exercise.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: GOLISANO;
Perot Backs Golisano as a Shaker-Up in His Own Image

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
There was an unmistakable pride of authorship in Ross Perot's eyes yesterday as he stood next to B. Thomas Golisano and backed the businessman's independent bid to become governor of New York. Mr. Perot may have met Mr. Golisano only once before, but he clearly discerned a candidate very much in his own image.
"Tom has lived the American dream, and he is determined to pass it on," Mr. Perot said, using phrases almost identical to the ones he used to describe himself two years ago. "He's putting his time, his money and his reputation on the line for the people of New York State and the United States." 
 Both men, in fact, are very wealthy entrepreneurs in the data-processing business who are willing to spend millions of their own money to make a political point. Both are essentially conservatives, appalled at what they see as the excesses of the two-party system. Both are convinced that their experience as chief executives is the best possible qualification for governance.
But while Mr. Golisano does not share Mr. Perot's sandpaper personality, neither does he have anything like the Texan's way with a crowd. At yesterday's endorsement appearance in Manhattan, Mr. Perot described Mr. Golisano's candidacy as, variously, a shot heard round the world, electroshock therapy to the political system, a Weimaraner at the gate and an alligator emerging from the swamp. The best that the somber, earnest Mr. Golisano could do was claim to be an iceberg headed for the two parties.
Mr. Perot's menagerie of symbols seemed to underline his depiction of Mr. Golisano as basically a symbolic candidate. Reflecting Mr. Golisano's standing in the polls -- he typically draws 5 to 10 percent, impressive for a third-party candidate but still not competitive -- Mr. Perot said almost nothing about what Mr. Golisano would do in office. Instead he praised him simply for running at all as a third-party candidate.
The effect of those who vote for him, Mr. Perot said, will be mostly to shake up the political system.
"If you want political change in America, if you want a third party established as a tangible signal to Albany and Washington, go ahead and vote for Tom Golisano on Tuesday and you will be making history, big history in this country," he said. "It can be the beginning of a new direction in American politics."
Mr. Perot rejected the notion that by endorsing Mr. Golisano, who has been drawing support from voters who might otherwise have supported the Republican candidate, State Senator George E. Pataki, he was actually helping the Democrat in the race, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
He had heard himself called a spoiler during his entire Presidential run, he said, adding that those who see him and his endorsements solely in those terms are missing his point, which is to support a third party.
Actually, though, Mr. Golisano is the only independent among the four candidates Mr. Perot has endorsed this year. He has campaigned for George Nethercutt, the Republican trying to unseat House Speaker Thomas S. Foley in Washington State, and for Gov. Ann Richards, Democrat of Texas, and yesterday at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey he endorsed Democratic Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who he also said was living the American dream.
"Frank Lautenberg is an independent," Mr. Perot explained. "They say, 'Ross, he is a Democrat.' Oh, he is a Democrat. But I have watched him up close go nose to nose with the Democratic party, when he disagreed with them on the Clinton economic plan. He voted against it and that takes courage."
There is, as always, little detectable pattern in Mr. Perot's series of endorsements beyond what may be a rewarding of like-minded entrepreneurs or a settling of scores with opponents. Some New York Republicans have charged that Mr. Perot is doing a favor for Mr. Cuomo, who has become a telephone friend of his in the last two years. But those in Mr. Golisano's camp insist the Texan simply agreed with his philosophy.
"We asked him about endorsing maybe six or eight weeks ago," said Gordon Black, Mr. Golisano's campaign manager and a former pollster for Mr. Perot. "I think he's been kicking it around as a possibility. He wanted to see what kind of a campaign we were running, and I guess he wouldn't have come up if he didn't like it."
Beyond the adrenaline shot of publicity that it gives to Mr. Golisano, the effect of Mr. Perot's endorsement is not easy to determine. Though he won 16 percent of the Presidential vote in New York two years ago, many of his supporters have drifted away from him or grown weary of his personality.
His grass-roots organization, United We Stand America, has splintered into several different groups, some loyal to him and others proudly in dissent. One group that broke from him, United We Stand America-New York, has endorsed Mr. Pataki, while many other Perot supporters are working for Mr. Cuomo.
Susan Stehling, a Rochester resident who was formerly Mr. Perot's regional campaign coordinator for the nine-county Finger Lakes area, says he now holds little sway among his former voters.
"His message was the right message at the time, but most people have turned against him now," said Ms. Stehling, who is now a volunteer for Mr. Cuomo. "I don't think he's going to change anyone's vote."
Alex Rodriguez, president of the New York splinter group that backs Mr. Pataki, said New Yorkers did not appreciate a Texan's telling them how to vote, and she questioned whether Mr. Golisano would hold the same appeal that Mr. Perot once did.
"He's not charismatic like Perot is," Mr. Rodriguez said. "He doesn't fire people up. People are looking for someone who's going to save them, and he doesn't fill the bill."
A festive rally late yesterday afternoon in Rochester, Mr. Golisano's hometown, drew about 100 people to hear the two men, and each had his supporters. Warren Schmidt, a member of United We Stand from Rochester, said he had attended to hear Mr. Perot and believed the endorsement could make a difference for those still on the fence.
"This could be the beginning in this state of a third party," Mr. Schmidt said amid the balloons and marching-band music. "We need to take a different tack, not just Republicans and Democrats."
Mr. Golisano, who might otherwise have had a hard time getting attention this weekend, made it clear he was grateful for the endorsement.
"I think this is of tremendous importance," he said yesterday. "I think the fact that somebody of Mr. Perot's stature recognizes the importance of third-party movements in this state, and is willing to travel here and energize the third-party movement, I think it's indicative of this iceberg I talked about coming to the two-party system."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: LEGISLATURE;
Democrats On Defensive In a Handful Of Contests

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
The Democrats are on the defensive in a handful of contested legislative races around New York State this year, and while the Republicans could pick up seats in both the Assembly and the Senate, the gains would not upset the balance of power in either house and seem unlikely to have any sway in the death-penalty debate.
In the Assembly, where 100 of the 150 members are Democrats, officials from both parties estimate that the majority could lose up to seven or eight seats, though it will probably be fewer. In the Senate, where 35 of the 61 members are Republicans, both parties have concentrated efforts on two tough races in the Rochester area currently held by Democrats. 
 There does not appear to be a blanket reason for the Democrats' potential weakness this year, officials in both parties say: over the last decade, the Democrats have lost seats in every year when there is no Presidential election, except for 1990, because lower turnout seems to favor local Republicans.
And while many races have focused purely on local issues and personalities, Republicans say that their party's themes -- crime, taxes and, in some cases, the tensions between the Republican upstate and the Democratic New York City -- are playing better this year.
"Frankly, the discontent that people are feeling throughout the state concerning the economy and crime are issues where the Republican Party has more credibility with the voters than the Democrats," said Assemblyman John J. Faso, Republican of Kinderhook, who oversees his party's election efforts in the Assembly. "We're seeing that nationally as well."
But any shift in seats will apparently not affect the annual drive for the death penalty, which would probably be a moot issue anyway if State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor who supports the measure, beats Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. For 12 years, Mr. Cuomo has vetoed death penalty legislation, but the Assembly has been unable to muster the two-thirds vote to override his veto.
This year, supporters of the measure in the Assembly stand to pick up only two, at most three, new pro-death-penalty votes, in addition to the estimated 95 current supporters. That remains short of the 100 votes required for an override, if Mr. Cuomo is elected and continues to veto the measure, as he has vowed.
In the Senate, money from both parties has been pouring into two Rochester districts, where two freshmen Democrats fight to hold onto their seats.
In the 54th District, there is a rematch between the incumbent, Richard A. Dollinger, who beat his challenger, Ralph Quattrociocci, a four-term State Senator, in a Democratic primary two years ago. Mr. Quattrociocci has since registered Republican.
In the 55th District, Mary Ellen Jones, the incumbent, a former school teacher, is facing a challenge from Carol Ellis McManus, a Republican Monroe County legislator, in a district where Republicans outnumber Democrats.
There is also a battle for the Republican Senate seat currently held by Mr. Pataki, representing Putnam County and parts of Westchester and Dutchess Counties. In the 37th District, Alfred B. DelBello, a Democrat and the Lieutenant Governor in Mr. Cuomo's first term, is running against Vincent L. Leibell 3d, a Republican Assemblyman, in what looks like a tight race.
Also, in what has been a Democratic seat in Albany, Michael Hoblock, the first Republican county executive in decades, is fighting James McCaffrey, a former Albany county director of social services and a Democrat.
State Senator Martin Connor, the Brooklyn Democrat who will become the body's minority leader next session, said: "I'll be happy if we maintain 26 seats. I'll be delighted if we gain one or two. And I'm prepared to be down one."
In the Assembly, the closer races have concentrated upstate in the suburbs.
On Long Island, in the Third District, the incumbent Democrat, I. William Bianchi, faces a challenge from Debra Mazzarelli, who owns a real-estate brokerage.
In the 96th District, an open seat which has been represented by a Democrat, Michael Murphy, a Democrat who heads the public works in Poughkeepsie, faces Thomas Kirwan, a Republican and former state trooper.
In the 97th District, representing parts of Dutchess, Greene and Columbia Counties, Eileen M. Hickey, the incumbent Democrat, is running against Joel Miller, a Republican and a dentist who has never run for office.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
The Election: A Voters' Guide To the Candidates

 BODY:

UNITED STATES SENATE
 
CANDIDATES
FRANK R. LAUTENBERG, 70, Democrat. Elected to the United States Senate in 1982; no experience in elective politics before that. A millionaire businessman who co-founded one of the most successful computing services in the world, Automatic Data Processing. Born in Paterson, now lives in Cliffside Park. Has raised $7.4 million for this race.
GARABED (CHUCK) HAYTAIAN, 56, Republican. An electrical engineer first elected to the State Assembly in 1981; Speaker of the Assembly since 1992, which makes him the third most powerful elected official in New Jersey. Born in the Bronx, now lives in Independence, in rural Warren County. Has raised $4.4 million.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	ANDREA LIPPI, independent
RICHARD J. PEZZULLO, Conservative Party
GEORGE PATRICK PREDHAM, independent
ARLENE GOLD, Natural Law Party
JOANNE KUNIANSKY, Socialist Workers Party
BEN GRINDLINGER, Libertarian Party
MICHAEL P. KELLY, independent
 
THE ISSUES
Politically, the candidates are polar opposites -- Mr. Lautenberg's politics are liberal to moderate and Mr. Haytaian is a strict conservative. The centerpiece of Mr. Haytaian's campaign is a flat Federal income tax, and one of his campaign props is a slick brochure outlining 94 ways to cut waste and spending in Washington. Mr. Lautenberg says the tax plan is a fraud that would add $1 trillion to the national deficit over five years; he calls other Haytaian ideas unworkable or unoriginal.
Although both candidates have been in office a long time, each is trying to cast himself as the outsider and his rival as the career politician. At times, however, Mr. Lautenberg portrays himself as an inside outsider, saying that he would be able to do more for New Jersey as a third-term Senator than Mr. Haytaian would as a novice in Washington.
 
ANALYSIS
Though polls throughout the campaign have shown Mr. Lautenberg with a comfortable lead, the New Jersey electorate is notorious for last-minute volatility and there is still a large bloc of undecided voters.
Mr. Lautenberg needs a good turnout from the traditionally Democratic urban areas. A year ago, Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, lost to Christine Todd Whitman by about 25,000 votes out of 2.5 million votes cast, largely because he did poorly and she did surprisingly well on that kind of turf. For Mr. Haytaian to win, he must rally his bedrock of conservative voters and the rest of the Republican faithful, but as importantly, he must match Mrs. Whitman's performance in urban areas, particularly among black voters.
 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
 
SECOND DISTRICT CANDIDATES
FRANK A. LOBIONDO, 48. Republican from Vineland, a State Assemblyman who works as the operations manager for his family's trucking business. A former member of the Cumberland County Board of Freeholders, first elected to the State Assembly in 1987. Has earned a reputation as its most conservative member. Sponsored law making "stalking" a crime. Lost 1992 race for Congress against the Democratic incumbent, William J. Hughes.
LOUIS N. MAGAZZU, 37, Democrat from Vineland. A lawyer, currently the solicitor for the city of Vineland; has never held elected office.
 
THE DISTRICT
Before 1974, the Second could be counted on to vote Republican. But Mr. Hughes rode to victory that year on the Watergate wave that swept dozens of Democrats into office. In spite of his party label, his conservative politics and his support of environmental protection, anti-crime legislation and senior-citizen issues helped him hold on to that office for 20 years before he decided earlier this year to retire. It is expected that with the popular Mr. Hughes now off the political scene, the district will return a Republican to office.
 
THE ISSUES
Mr. LoBiondo has campaigned unwaveringly on conservative beliefs: lower taxes, spending cuts and reduction of the Federal Government. Mr. Magazzu has stressed fighting crime as the main theme of his campaign, including championing gun control laws.
 
ANALYSIS
In land mass, southern New Jersey's sprawling Second District -- which encompasses all of Atlantic, Cape May, Cumberland and Salem counties and parts of Gloucester and Burlington counties, is the largest in the state. In politics, it is bedrock Republican and conservative. In 1992, registered Republicans outnumbered Democrats 85,000 to 70,000 with about 150,000 unaffiliated voters. If Mr. LoBiondo loses, it will rank as a major Election Day upset. The Republican candidate has raised more money than his opponent by a 3-to-1 margin and polls show him with at least a 30-point lead.
The race has significance beyond even the impressive boundaries of the Second. Under the redistricting that reduced the New Jersey Congressional delegation to 13, Mr. Hughes's lock on the Second District gave Democrats a 7-to-6 majority. The majority will assuredly shift to the Republicans on Nov. 8. In practice, it will give the Republicans little more than political bragging rights, but it will be another blow to the political psyche of New Jersey's Democrats, who in the last four years have also lost control of both chambers of the Legislature and the Governor's mansion.
 
EIGHTH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
HERB KLEIN, 64, a Democrat and a lawyer from Clifton. Served in the State Assembly for four years in the 1970's. Won Congressional seat two years ago in an expensive and bitter race. A prominent Democratic fund-raiser between his two stints in elected office, Mr. Klein spent more than $500,000 of his own money and $1.2 million overall in his victory two years ago.
BILL MARTINI, 47, a Republican and a lawyer from Clifton. Served on Clifton City Council and is a Passaic County Freeholder; also a former Assistant United States Attorney for New Jersey.
 
THE DISTRICT
The Eighth was redesigned two years ago after New Jersey lost one of its 14 Congressional seats as a result of the 1990 Census. When Representative Robert A. Roe, a 12-term Democrat, saw the new district lines, he decided to retire. The district, once a haven for Democrats, is now highly competitive. It includes the blue-collar urban centers of Paterson and Passaic, as well as suburban towns like Glen Ridge, Cedar Grove and Verona.
 
THE ISSUES
Both candidates say fear of crime is the chief concern of voters, with the economy, taxes and government spending also high on the list. Mr. Klein points to the recently enacted Federal crime bill as the first initiative coming out of Washington in years that offers real hope of increasing public safety. Mr. Martini calls the bill "pork laden," with programs that have little to do with crime-fighting. He has said that only the certainty of prison sentences will reduce violent crime. Mr. Klein said he voted against the Clinton budget because it did not have enough spending cuts, and has consistently opposed tax increases that affect the middle class. Mr. Martini charges that his opponent later voted for all the spending proposals in the budget he opposed and that he repeatedly passed up opportunities to vote for further deficit reductions.
 
ANALYSIS
Leaders in both parties agree that this is the closest Congressional race in the state this year. Both sides have spent heavily on campaign advertising and have been supported by visits from party luminaries from outside the state.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Races in Connecticut for Governor, Other Statewide Offices and Congress

 BODY:

GOVERNOR
 
CANDIDATES
WILLIAM E. CURRY JR., 42, Democrat. State Comptroller since 1990, lawyer, State Senator from 1979-83, ran unsuccessfully for the United States House of Representatives in 1982, former political director of Freeze Voter, the political arm of the nuclear-freeze movement.
EUNICE S. GROARK, 56, A Connecticut Party. A one-time Republican, Lieutenant Governor since 1990 when she ran on the third-party ticket of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker. Lawyer, corporation counsel for Hartford from 1987-90, and a Hartford City Councilwoman from 1981-85.
JOHN G. ROWLAND, 37, Republican. Congressman from Waterbury from 1985-91, barely lost the 1990 race for governor, member of House Armed Services Committee. Consultant since 1990 for several military contractors based in Connecticut.
TOM SCOTT, 36, radio talk-show host, State Senator from 1981-1991, led anti-income tax movement in 1991, ran unsuccessfully for United States House of Representatives in 1990 and 1992.
 
THE ISSUES
The state income tax, imposed in 1991, has been the central issue. Mr. Rowland and Mr. Scott promise to scrap it without raising other taxes. Mrs. Groark would not change the income tax, and Mr. Curry wants to keep it and economize elsewhere to provide money to cities and towns to cut property taxes. All candidates have called for expanded efforts to reduce crime, and all four favor the death penalty. Mrs. Groark has been attacked over the Weicker administration's policy of giving tax breaks and cash incentives to attract and retain companies, an approach she favors. Mr. Rowland and Mr. Scott says tax cuts would do more for the economy than such incentives. Mr. Curry would shift economic assistance to smaller companies.
 
ANALYSIS
Mr. Rowland has been the front-runner since the campaign began, and has had a large advantage in financing, spending much of his money on television commercials. But Mr. Scott, who appeals to many of the same conservatives, has drawn off some support, and many voters, particularly women, have been troubled by Mr. Rowland's efforts to suppress a police report on a domestic dispute with his ex-wife in April. After a surprise primary victory, Mr. Curry has campaigned aggressively, but in a close race he may lose critical votes to Mrs. Groark.
 
OTHER STATE RACES
(x denotes incumbents)
LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR M. Jodi Rell, Republican; Joseph P. Ganim, Democrat; Audrey Rowe, A Connecticut Party; Glen R. O'Keefe, independent
TREASURER Christopher Burnham, Republican; Joseph M. Suggs, Democrat (X)
COMPTROLLER Gene Gavin, Republican; Nancy Wyman, Democrat, A Connecticut Party
ATTORNEY GENERAL Richard Arnold, Republican; Richard Blumenthal, Democrat, A Connecticut Party (X)
SECRETARY OF THE STATE Andrea Scott, Republican; Miles S. Rapoport, Democrat, A Connecticut Party
 
UNITED STATES SENATE
 
CANDIDATES
GERALD LABRIOLA, 62, Republican, retired pediatrician, State Senator from 1981-83, ran unsuccessfully for lieutenant governor in 1982 and for the Republican nomination for governor in 1982 and 1986.
JOSEPH I. LIEBERMAN, 52, Democrat, United States Senator since 1991; State Attorney General from 1983-89, State Senator from 1971-81.
 
THE ISSUES
Mr. Lieberman's TV advertising depicts him as an advocate for creating jobs, fighting crime and making Congress more accountable. Dr. Labriola, relying largely on handshaking and yard signs, assails Mr. Lieberman for backing President Clinton's budget plan last year, calling it the largest tax increase in history. Dr. Labriola says Mr. Lieberman "fakes right and votes left."
 
ANALYSIS
Mr. Lieberman has had a commanding lead in the polls from the beginning and a huge advantage in fund raising, allowing him to air television commercials that focus on his family and his achievements and do not mention his opponent. Dr. Labriola has had little money for television ads. Some Democratic Party analysts have predicted the most lopsided victory in state history.
 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
 
SECOND DISTRICT CANDIDATES
SAM GEJDENSON, 45, Democrat, dean of the Connecticut delegation to the House of Representatives, seeking his eighth term.
EDWARD W. MUNSTER, 53, Republican, a retired statistician at Pfizer. Served one two-year term in the State Senate before challenging Mr. Gejdenson in 1992, a race he narrowly lost.
 
THE DISTRICT
The Second Congressional District is the state's largest, geographically, covering most of eastern Connecticut. It has been in flux economically as military jobs have declined and as gambling and tourism jobs have increased with the rise of the Foxwoods casino in Ledyard.
 
THE ISSUES
Mr. Munster campaigned last time on the argument that Mr. Gejdenson had lost his local bearings after more than a decade in Congress. This time, the debate has centered more on effectiveness. Mr. Munster's commercials attack Mr. Gejdenson's attendance record for major votes. Mr. Gejdenson's commercials say Mr. Munster failed to do much of note as a State Senator.
 
ANALYSIS
Mr. Gejdenson did not appear to take Mr. Munster seriously in 1992, but he is fighting hard this time, trading blow for blow in a negative campaign that seems to have shifted the advantage to Mr. Gejdenson. He has portrayed his Washington savvy as reaping huge benefits for the district in business for military contractors.
 
FIFTH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
GARY A. FRANKS, 41, Republican, seeking his third term, the first black Republican elected to the House of Representatives in 60 years. Former labor-relations executive.
JAMES H. MALONEY, 46, Democrat, State Senator from Danbury since 1986.
 
THE DISTRICT
The district is economically diverse, encompassing wealthy enclaves like Wilton and Ridgefield and blue-collar cities like Waterbury and Meriden. Once a Democratic stronghold, it was seized by the Republicans in the 1984 Reagan landslide.
 
THE ISSUES
Mr. Maloney, with far less name recognition or money than his opponent, has tried to portray Mr. Franks as a Congressman more interested in gaining a national reputation than serving constituents. Mr. Franks has contended that Mr. Maloney has no real agenda to pursue if elected.
 
ANALYSIS
Mr. Franks was considered vulnerable in 1992, when Bill Clinton carried Connecticut in the Presidential election, but he won with a 43 percent plurality when two Democrats -- one running as an independent -- split the Democratic vote. This year, he could benefit from having John G. Rowland, the Republican candidate for governor, on the ticket. Mr. Rowland represented the district from 1985 to 1991, and remains popular there.
 
OTHER CONGRESSIONAL RACES
(x denotes incumbents)
FIRST DISTRICT Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat (X); Douglas T. Putnam, Republican

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: NEW JERSEY;
A Negative Lautenberg and Haytaian

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
In New Jersey, it's all the other guy's fault.
The Democrat is soft on crime and big on raising taxes, and an incumbent to boot. The Republican is a hypocrite who consorts with racists, and besides, that was a pretty expensive parking garage he voted for. 
 The polls show that New Jersey's voters are angry at government and cynical about the promises politicians make. If that is so, the television commercials produced for the United States Senate race between Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democrat, and Chuck Haytaian, the Republican challenger, are tailor-made for a public in the mood to hear bad news about politicians.
Only two of Mr. Lautenberg's six television commercials are positive in the sense that they speak to his own record, and do not mention Mr. Haytaian. None of the six television commercial released by Mr. Haytaian, the Speaker of the General Assembly and less well known in the state than the senator, focus solely on himself and his accomplishments.
"Between 75 percent and 90 percent of the information we get about campaigns we glean from commercials," said Steven A. Miller, an instructor at the Rutgers University department of journalism and mass media. "What strikes me about this race is that Lautenberg's commercials and Haytaian's commercials all seem to be about the same information, and they meld together after a while -- they even use the same colors and the same style."
While both campaigns also use mailings and newspaper ads, they are putting by far a majority of their money into television.
When they do speak of themselves, the candidates seem to be reciting the same political text: Each has commercials promising to be tough on crime and tougher on taxes. Mr. Lautenberg adds his sponsorship of legislation to prevent the dumping of sewage sludge in the ocean -- a potent message for shore-conscious New Jerseyans -- and to toughen Federal penalties for rape.
Mr. Haytaian stresses his support for the death penalty, which Mr. Lautenberg opposes, and he makes full use of his most important ally, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. Mrs. Whitman, who is hugely popular right now, appears in three Haytaian commercials as a polished and soothing witness for the gravel-voiced and rough-edged speaker's virtues as a champion of tax cuts.
When attacking each other, the candidates use the same themes. Each calls the other a longtime incumbent, Mr. Lautenberg for his 12 years in the Senate, Mr. Haytaian for 20 years in public life, counting back to two years on a school board.
Each attacks the other for votes for spending bills and tax increases.
These themes reflect the public's interests, according to an Oct. 24 poll conducted by Rutgers's Eagleton Institute of Politics and The Star-Ledger of Newark.
Crime topped the respondents' list of major concerns, cited by 20 percent of probable voters. Job creation and the economy, unmentioned by either candidate in television ads, was second, with 14 percent, and taxes, Mr. Haytaian's major emphasis, was mentioned by 9 percent. Issues stressed in other states, like schools, patriotism and family issues, are untouched in the New Jersey race in the advertisements.
The negativity of both sides' ads also elicited a negative response from poll respondents. Of those who had seen Mr. Haytaian's ads, 39 percent said they had made them less likely to vote for him, and 28 percent said the ads made a Haytaian vote more likely.
For viewers of Mr. Lautenberg's commercials, 38 percent said they were less likely to vote for him and 34 percent said more likely.
Most of Mr. Lautenberg's attack ads have focused on Mr. Haytaian's tenure as a New Jersey assemblyman, including a spot devoted to the construction of a badly needed but expensive underground parking garage for the State House. Aware that reporters these days check the veracity of each side's commercials, the Lautenberg campaign investigated the costs of all of New Jersey Transit's parking decks and the Short Hills Hilton's underground garage to buttress its claim that the new Capitol parking garage will cost three times as much per parking space as other garages.
But it was a Lautenberg advertisement released on Wednesday that provoked a particular uproar, not only among Republicans, but also in negative coverage in the press.
The commercial strikes heavily at Mr. Haytaian's refusal, so far, to disavow his friendship with Bob Grant, the sometimes crudely spoken and always conservative host of an afternoon radio talk show on WABC in New York City.
Asking "How much do you know about Chuck Haytaian?" the ad builds a triple-decker assault. It illustrates the Speaker's opposition, on constitutional grounds, to a law to stop demonstrations around abortion clinics with footage of a wild melee between protesters and the police. It treats Mr. Haytaian's efforts to overturn a state ban on certain semiautomatic firearms with a scene showing a bullet-spitting machine gun of a type which is federally regulated, outlawed in all states and not the subject of the New Jersey ban.
And the commercial finishes up with some of Mr. Grant's barely printable comments while aiming at separating Mr. Haytaian from Mrs. Whitman's appeal.
"Grant calls blacks 'savages,' " reads the voice, over a throbbing musical score. "Governor Whitman renounced Grant, Haytaian called Grant to offer his support. Pro-life extremists. The national gun lobby. Racists. They're all supporting Chuck Haytaian. Should you?"
Mr. Haytaian's reaction to this, the hardest-hitting commercial from either side, may be significant. While state Republicans from Mrs. Whitman on down sharply deplored what they said was the commercial's inflammatory tone, the candidate seemed almost to get a lift from it.
"Desperate people do desperate things," he told interviewers on Wednesday. And, perhaps mindful of Mr. Grant's large following among conservative voters in the state, Mr. Haytaian would not be drawn into condemning the talk-show host's racial remarks.
For his part, Mr. Haytaian, 56, portrays the Senator, who is 70, as nearly doddering with age. A clip of the Senator played in slow motion makes Mr. Lautenberg shake his head at his own suitability for office.
Mr. Haytaian's favorite commercial, judging by its frequent broadcast, does not even feature him. Instead, it shows citizens being interviewed on the street and reacting negatively to Senator Lautenberg's two terms, his opposition to the death penalty and his votes for spending bills.
One element that has not turned up in this season of commercials is the last-minute spot known in political lingo as the "warm and fuzzy."
"Usually the pattern is for the candidates to hit hard and try to define their opponent before the opponent defines him, and then, with about a week to go, to come out with the warm and fuzzy ads about themselves," Mr. Miller said. "But in this race, we're not seeing that. They're both hitting hard."

HEADLINE: Region News Briefs;
Civil Rights Act Failed,
Movement Veterans Say

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 5

 BODY:
Veterans of the civil-rights battles of 30 years ago gathered at Connecticut College on Friday to reflect on the movement they led, but they agreed they had little to celebrate.
Herbert Hill, a professor of African-American studies and industrial relations at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, told a crowd of about 250 civil-rights advocates, teachers and students that the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was a high point in the history of the movement and that there has been a retreat ever since. 
 "It is tragic to see what has now happened," said Mr. Hill, who was involved in the original drafting of the equal employment provision of the Civil Rights Act. "The movement failed to eliminate the great disparity in the economic status of blacks and whites."
Mr. Hill, who spent more than 20 years on the staff of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, speculated that if the law were to come to a vote today, it would die.
"As far as I'm concerned, this is not a celebration. It's a funeral for the Civil Rights Act," he said. "Abolishing legal racism does not produce racial equality."
Nicholas D. Katzenbach, the former United States Attorney General responsible for implementing the law during the Johnson administration, called the Civil Rights Act "a drop in a very large bucket."
"It did nothing, nothing for the great mass of African-Americans citizens in this country," Mr. Katzenbach said. As long as blacks are subjected to poor education, poor housing, unemployment and crime, there will be racial discrimination, he said, because some whites will "feel they're superior."

HEADLINE: Religions Are Putting Faith in Environmentalism

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
Considering that insulation, energy-saving light bulbs and low-flow shower heads are sold along with menorahs and seder plates, the gift shop at Temple Adath Joseph might seem like a one-stop shop for the observant and conservation-minded handyman. Rabbi Jeffrey Glickman considers all the items to be Judaica, and he will even help install them.
"The concept of the environment is central to Judaism," said Rabbi Glickman, who also talks about ecology at services at the Reform temple in St. Joseph, Mo. "God, who could have done any number of things to talk to Elijah, didn't waste. He used the smallest possible means for communication: the still, small voice. We should choose the same." 
 More and more religious groups nationwide are choosing to renew -- or begin -- an examination of their responsibility to the environment. Evidence comes in several forms: inserts about recycling in the bulletins handed out at Southern Baptist services, a new magazine called Green Cross that is devoted to a Bible-based approach to ecology, and a new nationwide coalition that is urging Protestants, Catholics and Jews to incorporate the environment into their congregational life.
Whether the efforts are purely educational or have a more specific goal, like cleaning up a neighborhood, most share a common thread: They are firmly rooted in the believers' religious traditions.
For some groups, this means making sure no one interprets their actions as a New Age form of pantheism, the belief that the divine resides in all aspects of the natural world. Others are concerned about building a theological foundation distinct from the secular environmental movement, whose liberal bent could offend more conservative believers.
"We make it very clear, we do not worship creation, we worship the God of creation," said Richard Land, the executive director of the Southern Baptist Convention's Christian Life Commission. "What we're trying to do is combat what is a real bad image among rank-and-file Southern Baptists about the environmental movement, while at the same time speak to our concern for the environment. For us to join with other groups that don't speak expressly in Biblical terms dilutes our message."
The Southern Baptist Convention has produced a book on environmental issues and a series of bulletin inserts on conservation, recycling and pollution reduction. The publications emphasize biblical foundations for the messages, noting that the Bible said God took joy in His creation and that it was up to people to preserve and develop it responsibly.
Bruce Hamilton, national conservation director of the Sierra Club, which has helped some religious groups in poor communities organize against pollution, said he welcomed the religious involvement.
"I see the churches as one natural and very helpful ally," he said. "Ultimately, there can be no justice without environmental justice."
The Rev. Thomas Berry, a Roman Catholic priest of the Passionist order, who has written extensively on the link between faith and ecological responsibility, said the issue cuts to the heart of humanity's relationship to the spiritual. The destruction of nature, he said, is as much a loss to the soul as it is to the earth.
"We need the experience of the natural world to activate our emotions and our sense of the sublime," he said. "If we do not have this experience, or these wonderful natural phenomena are destroyed or disfigured, then our experience of the divine is disfigured."
Earlier this year, a coalition called the Religious Partnership for the Environment mailed 53,000 information kits to Catholic, Jewish and Protestant congregations across the country, urging them to integrate the environment into their traditions of worship and social action.
The kits sent to Roman Catholic parishes, for example, talk about the statements on the environment made by Pope John Paul II and Catholic bishops, and feature ways to introduce themes on caring for the earth into the liturgy.
In June, Clinton Administration officials, led by Vice President Al Gore, met with members of the partnership. Paul Gorman, executive director of the partnership, said he and his colleagues were not asked to endorse any legislation or testify at hearings. In a way, he said, Administration officials wanted spiritual counsel.
"They were looking for a deeper, moral vision in how to frame the environmental issue and communicate it to mainstream America," he said. "They came back to how the major obstacles they faced were individualism, greed and social fragmentation. If the religious community cannot address these conditions, who will?"
Christian evangelical leaders were looking for answers themselves when they convened earlier this month in Michigan for discussions on the environment. Also this month, the first issue of Green Cross magazine, a new publication devoted to a Bible-rooted approach to ecology, will feature articles about congregations that saved energy or reduced waste, as well as tips on starting similar activities.
Congregational responses have ranged from establishing ecology discussion groups and encouraging home recycling to demanding action from public officials.
In Dallas, members of the New Waverly Baptist Church persuaded city officials to open up a clinic at the church, which is near a closed lead smelting plant. Pollution from the plant, which closed more than 10 years ago, was thought to be responsible for rashes and headaches, among other problems, which are treated at the clinic.
Augustana Lutheran Church, a Chicago congregation that belongs to the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, performed an energy audit that resulted in the installation of energy-saving lights. The change sliced a third off the church's electric bill and prompted the metropolitan Chicago synod to establish a revolving loan fund for other churches that want to take similar energy-saving measures.
Dr. Jean Sindab, the director of environmental and economic justice for the National Council of Churches, an umbrella group of mainline Protestant churches, said it was sometimes difficult to get people to look beyond the immediate benefits of ecologically minded approaches. Recycling, for example, has profound spiritual ramifications, she said.
"We need to get to a deeper understanding of why there is so much waste in this country," she said. "Then people have to think about materialism and consumerism. Do we as religious people need to consume so much to achieve happiness?"
The Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan literally welcomes the natural world into sacred spaces with its St. Francis Day blessing of the animals, a ceremony that celebrated its 10th anniversary on Oct. 2. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, the dean of the cathedral, said the tradition was more than a spectacular procession of pets, pachyderms and pests.
"All of that is the human responsibility for preserving and conserving," said Dean Morton, whose cathedral has been active in environmental issues for decades. "This really hits very deep levels."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in some editions on Sunday about religious leaders' turn to environmentalism misidentified the clergyman shown blessing an elephant during the feast of St. Francis at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York City. He was Bishop Craig Anderson, the Dean of the General Theological Seminary in New York. The caption also referred incorrectly to the Dean of the cathedral, whose name erroneously appeared. He is the Very Rev. James Parks Morton.
