HEADLINE: From the Andes, Indians Spread the Word: They're Argentine and Proud of It

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO DE LOS COBRES, Argentina

 BODY:
Some 12,300 feet above sea level in the Andes Mountains, Coya Indians were laughing, waving, pointing and jumping for joy the other day as a tourist train pulled into the station of this isolated mining village.
The Indians, whose ancestors established the village more than 300 years ago to escape Spanish domination, come to the train station every Saturday to sell their handicrafts, receive donations of food and clothing, and read old newspapers that have been left on the train. 
 But they also come for what they say is a more important reason: to pledge allegiance to the Republic of Argentina, an act their ancestors would probably find appalling since they migrated to this high desert plateau to live and worship free of Spanish influence.
When the so-called Train to the Clouds arrives each week, the Indians stand at attention and proudly belt out the national anthem as train tour guides raise the blue and white striped Argentine flag.
"We are proud of our heritage and our culture as Coya Indians, but we are also proud to be Argentine," said Isabel del Isuasa, who wore traditional long black braids and a colorful multilayered skirt and had her baby daughter strapped to her back. "It means so much to us that our fellow countrymen haven't forgotten us and acknowledge that we are part of the same nation."
Several Indian women and children cried openly as they sang "Let us live crowned by glory, or sentenced to die for glory," the music to the national anthem ringing slightly behind the voices because of weak batteries in a boom box.
Perhaps the Indians were sentimental because this tourist train was the last to pass through San Antonio de Los Cobres until March, when mudslides caused by heavy rain are no longer a danger. While cargo trains regularly pass through on the way to Chile, visitors rarely call except when the Train to the Clouds is running.
Tour guides say they began the flag-raising ceremony this year to give the Indians a sense of connection with the rest of Argentina and to expose Argentines, who are almost exclusively of European descent, to the indigenous people. The tourists and the Indians stand side by side singing the national anthem, equal citizens, at least for the moment.
"Most people who take this train are from Buenos Aires and other big, sophisticated cities, so we stop here in San Antonio de los Cobres to show them that they have countrymen who have a different culture and live under different conditions," said Martin Yaguado, a tour guide.
Village officials are hoping that rising interest in trips through Argentina's Andean region into Chile will bring money and jobs to San Antonio de Los Cobres. Private investors plan to open a small hotel in the village next year and there is talk of developing the area's hot springs into an attraction.
Government estimates of the number of Indians in Argentina's population of 33 million range from 100,000 to 300,000; human rights groups and Indian groups say the number is 750,000. Before the Spanish conquest, millions of Indians are believed to have lived in what is now Argentina, especially in the pampas. The Indians there were virtually wiped out, and in other areas Indians have faced discrimination, seeing much of their culture, language and religion disappear.
Located in Salta Province, about 1,100 miles northwest of Buenos Aires, San Antonio de Los Cobres is an ugly mining village set on a bleak high desert. Most of the village's 4,000 people live in stone huts, few of which have electricity and running water.
The town's main source of income has been the copper, zinc, lead and silver mines and train maintenance, but recent privatizations and consolidations of these businesses have brought steep unemployment.
"We don't mind so much being isolated because we enjoy our customs and traditions, but we really need jobs now to feed our children," said Mario Perez, a teacher at the secondary school.
Because this was the last tourist train of the season, schoolchildren had decorated the station with exhibits celebrating Coya cultural and religious heritage.
The people of San Antonio de los Cobres have retained many traditions. They revere Pacha Mama, or Mother Earth, who they believe provides them with food and copper from the mines. Despite their conversion to Catholicism, they perform traditional dances of praise to Pacha Mama.
The Coya Indians are Incas whose ancestors are believed to have fled the Spanish colonization in the lowlands after they were forced to change their way of life and religion. "Coya" is an Inca word meaning eminence that was reserved for royalty. All Coyas eventually adopted the word for themselves because they considered themselves divine compared with their conquerors.
The unspoiled landscape of the region shifts radically from lush, verdant mountainside to desert plateaus. Brilliant colors of lead, silver, manganese and iron periodically coat the mountain slopes, and cacti and other desert plants are everywhere.
"We have a different way of life up here," said Mr. Perez, the schoolteacher, "but please don't forget that we are Coya-Argentine and we would like to share that with the rest of our country."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CONNECTICUT;
The 4 Possible Governors On a Final Weekend Tour

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 6

 BODY:
John G. Rowland toured western Connecticut with busloads of supporters today, rallying Republicans in the part of the state that nearly elected him Governor in 1990. The final poll before the election showed him holding on to a statistically insignificant lead in the four-way governor's race.
Comptroller William E. Curry Jr., the Democrat, who has generally held second place in the polls, spoke at churches and rallies in the New Haven area, while Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark of A Connecticut Party, third in polls but gaining, spent the day contesting Mr. Rowland in Fairfield County. 
 With no one favored by even a third of the respondents in any recent survey, and with anywhere from 15 percent to 20 percent undecided in recent polls, the candidates appealed to their core supporters with familiar messages while trying to woo voters who were wavering.
Casting himself as an underdog although he has been leading in polls throughout the race, Mr. Rowland urged supporters here to call their friends before the election, even those leaning to "a third- or fourth-party candidate," a reference to the race's two former Republicans, Mrs. Groark, and Tom Scott, an independent pledged to repeal the state's income tax. "Tell someone who's leaning toward a third- or fourth-party candidate that perhaps their vote will help elect someone they don't want to be Governor," he said.
In a new television advertisement, Mr. Curry uses the prospect of a Rowland victory against Mrs. Groark. "Groark?" a narrator says. "Hmm. Same stuff as Weicker. And is she strong enough to stop Rowland? I don't want Rowland."
Mrs. Groark, gaining in polls as Mr. Rowland and Mr. Curry attack each other, is trying to keep supporters from defecting. "My opponents want you to believe I can't win," she says in an ad. "But if that's the only reason you're voting for one of them, aren't you wasting your vote?"
The final Courant/Connecticut poll, published today, showed both Mr. Rowland and Mr. Curry slipping, while Mrs. Groark and Mr. Scott gained. Mr. Rowland still led, with 30 percent, followed by Mr. Curry with 25 percent. The margin of sampling error was four percentage points, making the lead inconclusive.
Mrs. Groark was third with 18 percent, a 10-point gain in the last month, while Mr. Scott had 11 percent, a 6-point gain. Fifteen percent of the 1,085 people surveyed from Monday to Saturday said they were undecided.
On the trail today, Mr. Rowland spoke at Congressional district rallies in Stamford, Torrington and Waterbury, where he received 60 percent of his votes in 1990.
Mr. Rowland's base is in Waterbury, where he represented the Fifth District from 1984 to 1990. Lower Fairfield County, the Fourth District, is the traditional mother lode of Republican votes and funds.
He entered the final weekend with a large advantage here, where most people watch New York rather than Connecticut television: with $500,000 of his $3.3 million war chest still on hand, he is the only candidate able to afford the New York stations.
"We're feeling fine with the five-point lead," said John Chapin, Mr. Rowland's press secretary, as supporters on streets around the Stamford Government Center waved signs and asked motorists to honk their support. "If we win by five points, we'll all be happy campers."
A handful of Curry volunteers scored a tactical victory when they paraded by with a large banner, drawing many of the Rowland people away from the curb. But anger flashed when the volunteers disrupted Mr. Rowland's speech inside the building by rapping on windows.
Looking a bit tired from it all, Mr. Rowland tried to turn the commotion against Mr. Curry, whom he has attacked as a liberal throughout the campaign. The protesters, he said, were just like "the liberals up in Hartford who want to control our lives."
Mr. Curry spent much of the day looking for support in cities. On a Windsor radio station and at African-American congregations in New Haven, he pushed his proposals for a billion-dollar cut in local property taxes, which would help Connecticut's cities, and for school-loan and small-business-loan programs.
He also portrayed the race as between himself and Mr. Rowland, ignoring Mrs. Groark, who is drawing some Democrats to her. At this point, he said, he is only as far behind in polls as he was just before the Democratic primary, which he won as the challenger.
"I thought what he had to say made sense," said Carol F. Moore, a member of the United Church of Christ on Dixwell Avenue in New Haven. "But see, they all talk a good game. It's when it comes down to the goosing that tells."
Mrs. Groark began her day on the East Side of Bridgeport, one of Fairfield County's poorest neighborhoods, handing out literature printed in both English and Spanish. Then she moved on to Fairfield, a well-off suburb, where more people recognized her, sometimes to her advantage and sometimes not.
"She's honest and she's not slick," said Patricia Nelson, a young Fairfield woman who promised Mrs. Groark her vote. But an older man stopped to complain that Mrs. Groark and Mr. Weicker were costing him $37 a week because of the income tax they pushed through in 1991 to end a fiscal crisis.
Mrs. Groark has pledged to continue the fiscal policies of the Weicker administration, which she says have started Connecticut back to economic health, while the other candidates are promising tax cuts. But she has campaigned largely without Mr. Weicker, who today was in Washington at a football game.
"I had to stand on my own," she said. "If I was too close to Weicker, I would be eclipsed. I'm running on my own, and I called the shots."
At Mr. Scott's headquarters, the usual weekend tag sale to raise money for the bare-bones campaign was under way as he left in a motorcade to greet shoppers at supermarkets. With him was his mother, Dorothy Scott, who was wearing a sweatshirt that said, "I'm Tom's Mom."
Mr. Scott, a former state senator and talk-show host whose opposition to the income tax pushed Mr. Rowland to pledge for its repeal, said the polls understated his strength because of his "notorious factor." Many people, he said, are embarrassed to admit they support him.

HEADLINE: As Bosnian War Intensifies, Debate Grows Over Partition Plan

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Nov. 6

 BODY:
In the Sarajevo office of Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose, a map that divides Bosnia and Herzegovina under an American-backed peace plan hangs on a wall. Gazing at it recently, an aide to the general scornfully said, "If you were a Serb, would you accept that?"
The map, prepared by the United States and four other countries as part of a peace agreement, is regarded by General Rose and the British officers who surround him as unrealistic, ill-conceived and unfair to the Bosnian Serbs. 
 Offering 51 percent of Bosnia to the Muslim-led Government in alliance with the Bosnian Croats and 49 percent to the Bosnian Serbs, the map has now been on the table for almost four months, rejected by the Bosnian Serbs but accepted by the Bosnian Government. It has now become a subject of heated debate because the quest for peace is in limbo as the war escalates.
The military tension was evident today and on Saturday in fierce fighting around the northwestern town of Bosanska Krupa, where the Bosnian Army has recently advanced, and in sharp artillery exchanges between Bosnian Serb and Muslim-led Government forces in the western suburbs of Sarajevo that only died down when NATO planes passed overhead.
Faced with that deterioration, officials from the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia met here this weekend. Central to their discussion was the map, people close to the talks said.
Referring to General Rose, the commander of United Nations forces in Bosnia, one official said: "He thinks there was not enough consultation with the Serbs on the map. And when he goes up to see them he seems to convey these reservations, and the Serbs get the idea the West is about to change the plan."
Col. Tim Spicer, General Rose's spokesman, denied that the general had had anything more than vague discussions about changing the map with the Bosnian Serbs' leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic.
The American view is that the map cannot be changed because this would undercut the way it was presented -- as a take it or leave it proposal -- and would probably also lead the Bosnian Government to reconsider its acceptance of the plan. Rather, the Clinton Administration argues that military and economic pressure must be maintained on the Bosnian Serbs, while indicating some flexibility to Mr. Karadzic.
"The fact is that the Bosnian Serbs misunderstood the plan," one official said. "Once they say yes, everything is negotiable. The map is a starting point."
This was the view that Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, also tried to impress on the Bosnian Serbs before they rejected it. Mr. Milosevic then imposed a blockade that has contributed to the current problems of the Bosnian Serbs.
Mr. Karadzic has insisted that the map divides territory held by Bosnian Serbs into four dislocated parts and denies them cities, economic resources and access to the sea.
Recent military successes by the Bosnian Government suggest that the war may grow far worse. "There is a danger that the Bosnians could well say we don't need the contact group any longer," one official said, referring to the five-nation alliance. "Or that the Croats decide the Serbs are on the run and their moment has come to attack in Croatia. Or that the Yugoslav Army reacts to either of these scenarios by getting involved itself."

HEADLINE: U.S. Oil and Gas Companies Test Waters in Brazil, Again

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Oil and gas companies from the United States are returning to Brazil, their first major effort since 1953, after being effectively excluded for four decades by the country's old nationalist and protectionist policies.
American oil-service companies, sometimes called the pilot fish of the big international producers, turned out in force last month at the Brazilian Petroleum Congress. Competing for an annual market estimated at $1 billion in sales and contracts, 47 American oil-service companies mounted stands here. 
"Until 18 months ago, the door was basically shut in our faces," said Bob Greenwood, a salesman with Bestolife, a Dallas company that makes drilling-pipe sealant. "You could ship the product down here, but it would sit on the dock and rot."
Now that Brazil is discarding tariffs and protectionist quotas, American companies have won about half the oil-service market, a survey by the United States Consulate here indicated. Other opportunities await production and pipeline companies.
By the end of the 1990's, Latin America is expected to pass the United States and Canada and become the world's second-largest oil-producing region, after the Middle East. Brazil is Latin America's third-largest oil producer, after Venezuela and Mexico, extracting about two-thirds of its oil from wells offshore Rio de Janeiro state.
"With the new Government, there is going to be an explosion of this sector," said Etienne Kvassay, a Brazilian trade economist who prepared the consulate's survey. "This market should grow at the rate of 30 percent in the next three years."
Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who will become President on Jan. 1, pledged during the campaign to relax the monopoly that Brazil's state oil monopoly, Petrobras, has enjoyed for 41 years over oil exploration, production and refining.
Mr. Cardoso's campaign platform called for the establishment of partnerships and joint ventures between Petrobras and private business.
The President-elect went further in a recent interview with Brasil Energy, an oil and gas monthly. "Petrobras is already a sufficiently mature business to open itself up to partnerships or to competition with private companies," he said.
In Petrobras's largest joint venture to date, two United States energy companies, Tenneco and Enron, both of Houston, signed contracts in August to participate as minority partners in the construction next year of a $1.8 billion, 1,400-mile pipeline linking gas fields in eastern Bolivia with the industrial heartland of southern Brazil. The project is regarded as a prototype for future joint ventures valued at $2 billion.
Antonio Luiz de Menezes, Petrobras's project manager for the Bolivia-Brazil gas line, said United States companies had also been invited to bid next year on a second Brazilian gas line projected to run 375 miles within the Amazon basin.
Oil exploration may be on the horizon. Betting that Brazilian legislators would approve a constitutional amendment next year to allow foreign joint ventures, executives and geologists from Amoco, Occidental Petroleum and Pennzoil traveled here for the petroleum congress.
"I'm here to make contacts, to build up relationships," said Don B. Felio, director of new Latin American ventures for the Amoco Overseas Exploration Company. "But there's a lot of competition for oil investment in South America. If Brazil decides it wants foreign investment, it will have to compete."
Steven Hopper, general manager of Pecten do Brasil, expressed optimism that exploration and production would be opened to foreign companies. "There is not any doubt that the industry as a whole looks on Brazil as one of the plums in the world tree, up there alongside Russia," said Mr. Hopper, whose company operates a gas concession.
Foreign companies are also benefiting from Brazilians' dissatisfaction with Petrobras's long monopoly. Of the seven countries where oil production is treated as a state monopoly, Brazil is the only importer, buying almost half its oil abroad.
And with the nation's economy expected to grow 5 percent annually through the rest of the decade, Petrobras has no hope of making Brazil self-sufficient in the near future. Because offshore deposits make production expensive, Brazil would have to invest $13 billion a year to attain self-sufficiency by 2010. But with an exploration and new production budget of $3 billion this year, the company has been forced to shelve 270 expansion projects.
Although Petrobras's international arm has operations in dozens of other countries, the company has a history of fighting foreign investment at home. And as Brazil's largest company, it can marshal immense resources -- 50,000 employees and annual revenue of $21 billion.
In 1975, when Brazil briefly allowed foreign exploration contracts, Petrobras geologists allocated some of the least promising areas to the foreigners. After 35 companies had wasted millions of dollars drilling dry holes, Petrobras cried victory, claiming a 35 percent success rate in its own drilling operations.
Last spring, when the Brazilian Congress was considering a proposal to allow exploration by foreign oil concerns, Petrobras responded by announcing four major discoveries of its own, flying legislators to its offshore platforms and spending an estimated $20 million to advertise itself as "a Brazilian success story."
"Petrobras extorts money from the citizen, and then with this same money, convinces him that he should continue to be extorted," asserted Antonio Delfim Netto, a conservative Congressman from Sao Paulo.
But with even sections of the left-wing Workers Party supporting relaxation of the oil monopoly, Petrobras's lobbying appears to have failed. Veja, Brazil's most influential news weekly, recently published a 10-page article attacking the company under the headline: "Petrobras Is Afraid of Competition."
Representatives of United States companies that were hurt by contracts between 1975 and 1986 stressed that Brazil must now create more competitive conditions. The assignment of exploration acreage, they say, should be taken away from Petrobras, and joint ventures should allow foreign companies to work as operating partners, not limit them to financing operations for Petrobras.
"It all depends on the geology and on the contracts," said the representative of an American company that lost millions in Brazilian dry holes in the early 1980's. "There are a lot of other places in the world to invest in."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: VOTERS;
Last-Ditch Efforts Begin To Get People to Polls

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
He is a bridge inspector by trade. But yesterday at an intersection in Forest Hills, Queens, Tom Murphy sat at a table in the driving rain and with his "Cuomo '94" hat turned backward, played the role of carnival barker.
"Vote for Cuomo!" his booming voice yelled to passersby. "If you value your children, Vote for Cuomo. Re-elect Mario Cuomo." 
 Often they ignored him, rushing to get out of the rain -- or maybe just away from him. But Mr. Murphy, a veteran volunteer, said that he didn't mind the indifference because there was a chance that his loud refrain might echo in their heads on Election Day. "I realize when they go into that poll booth that if my voice can go with them, my influence can help," he said.
This weekend, the final effort to turn out the vote on Election Day began in earnest. Thousands of volunteers from Buffalo to Staten Island staffed phone banks, hung posters and stuffed mailboxes in the hope that one more reminder could inspire the party faithful, sway the undecided and excite the apathetic come Tuesday.
With the tightest Governor's race in more than a decade and an anti-government fervor feeding voter apathy and anger, both Democrats and Republicans say these last days may make the difference between victory and defeat. Politicians and poll takers say that if 55 percent of the state's registered voters actually vote, it will be a heavy turnout.
And so after months in which millions of dollars have been spent on television advertising, the final result hinges on translating potential support into votes. And so party officials, partisan clubs, unions and special interest groups have banded together to support their candidates -- and discourage those who would support their opponents.
On Sunday, while volunteers for the Democratic Party fanned out to intersections and neighborhoods, workers for the Christian Coalition of New York distributed voter guides at 2,000 churches, focusing on how candidates stood on certain issues.
On Saturday, a caravan of 20 cars led by a flatbed truck honked its way through the streets of the Bronx, blasting music and a message to support the Democratic slate. On Friday, the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League of New York State kicked off a "Broadway for Choice" campaign by passing out 62-page voter guides to theater patrons. They planned to do the same at Manhattan subway stations through Election Day.
"I see a close race," said the Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, who is in charge of State Sen. George E. Pataki's campaign in New York City. "And I think the side that works harder and more effectively in the last few days is the one that's going to win."
While the emphasis is being placed on personal phone calls to supporters, mass mailings and face-to-face appeals, there is also some negative campaigning taking place.
Mr. Murphy in Queens links the election of Mr. Cuomo to the survival of New York's children. A postcard showing a woman behind bars says that the Republican candidate for Comptroller, Herbert London, wants women prosecuted for choosing to have abortions. (Mr. London has favored fining women who get abortions, rather than jailing them.)
A brightly colored leaflet with a picture of Pat Robertson offers "four frightening statements every New York woman should read." It includes quotations from Mr. Robertson under the headings "Women Are Not Equal," "Feminism Is Witchcraft" and "George Pataki Is My Favorite State Senator." Among the pictures are those of women wearing dunce caps and witch's hats. (Mr. Pataki himself has not taken such positions, but the literature is linked to high ratings he has received from Mr. Robertson's Christian Coalition based on his votes, including those against increases in taxes and spending and Medicaid payments for abortions.)
Whatever the message, there are many messengers. The Republicans have enlisted a statewide volunteer force in the tens of thousands to distribute millions of pieces of literature in the final days, said John Sweeney, executive director and counsel of the New York Republican State Committee. One leaflet, from the National Republican Congressional Committee, says a candidate is interested in Asian affairs just because he likes the food.
On Long Island, a critical battleground in the race for Governor, roughly 500,000 pieces of literature are to be distributed in Suffolk County alone and dozens of volunteers plan to make calls right through election day, said Howard C. DeMartini, chairman of the Suffolk County Republican Committee.
Meanwhile, the Democrats were to distribute 10 million pieces of literature between Friday and Tuesday using legions of volunteers, said Joel Benenson, a spokesman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's campaign. One flier from the State Democratic Committee looks like the cover of a tabloid newspaper. "Pataki to City: Drop Dead," it says.
In all, 25,000 volunteers statewide were expected to make four million phone calls to identified Democratic supporters in the last five days of the campaign, Mr. Benenson said.
Unions like the Communication Workers of America and the United Federation of Teachers have also been critical components of the Democrats' get-out-the-vote effort.
In the northeast Bronx, a primarily black community where there was an 80 percent turnout in last year's mayoral election, the logistics of getting out the vote have been honed to a science. Volunteers often leaflet their own blocks, placing cards under doors rather than thrusting them rudely into people's hands. Different pieces of literature are given to people in different economic groups.
For residents of the community's housing projects, the leaflets evoke images from black history and speak of apartheid's fall in South Africa as ways to inspire a disillusioned voter to get involved.
One leaflet has pictures of Nelson Mandela and Mayor David N. Dinkins next to a photo of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who, if elected, will be the first statewide black elected official. "Breaking Down Barriers," the cover says, "Making History for Our Community." Another black-and-white leaflet displays an X on its cover to remind the voter of Malcolm X. But in this case it represents the mark on a ballot.
"A lot of people need to be motivated because of Dinkins's loss of the election," said Oliver Seabrook, who is coordinating the Northeast Bronx Democratic Community Club's campaign efforts.
Other areas also use personal messages to voters. Mr. Molinari sent 100,000 letters to constituents, signed by either himself or his daughter, Congresswoman Susan Molinari, blasting Mr. Cuomo's record and praising Mr. Pataki.
Last week, volunteers waded through traffic jams on the streets leading to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to hand the letter to motorists, Mr. Molinari said. And they may do the same today and tomorrow, while continuing to distribute leaflets at ferry points and train stations around the island.
Upstate, Babbidean Huber, a member of the Amherst Republican Committee, spent Saturday carefully attaching rolled leaflets to the handles of storm doors. She never dropped one in front of a door or walked on a lawn, because, she said, "I don't want to create a negative impression."
She has been involved in politics for 10 years, and believes that whether or not her efforts gain the G.O.P. any ground, at least they help insure none is lost. "Even if it doesn't do anything, you've got to just keep it even-steven. You don't want the other side to have one up on you."

HEADLINE: China's Power Needs Exceed Investor Tolerance

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 6

 BODY:
As China's supply of electrical power falls more and more behind its surging demand, the nation's Communist Party leadership is paralyzed by an ideological struggle over how much profit foreign investors should be allowed to make from the power industry.
With economic growth of nearly 12 percent predicted this year, China is failing to meet its goals for adding power generation. Blackouts are plaguing the largest industrial centers like Shanghai, and shortages are cutting deeply into productivity nationwide. 
 But instead of accelerating a program to build power plants with foreign financing, the Chinese leadership has refused to approve a single joint-venture power plant since late in 1992, when Gordon Y. S. Wu, a prominent Hong Kong developer, signed an agreement for his last power project, in Guangdong province in the south.
Nearly 50 projects involving foreign partners are now on hold in China, power-industry officials say. Large American companies like Mission Energy, Wing International, Entergy and General Electric have been negotiating joint-venture deals for months to build power stations, but the local authorities have not been able to get approval from the central Government in Beijing.
"Without power, without roads, without transport, the rest of China's development is not going to happen," said Rigdon Boykin, a Hong Kong-based lawyer whose firm represents two dozen clients seeking to enter China's power market. "These are the building blocks of industry."
China is the world's fourth-largest power producer. But the average Chinese consumes less than 650 kilowatt hours, barely enough to burn a 75-watt light bulb year round. And about 120 million rural Chinese -- one-tenth of this enormous country's population -- live without electricity in their houses or villages, China's Minister of Electric Power, Shi Da-zhen, said.
The internal debate over foreign profit has pitted reform-minded bureaucrats and province leaders hungry for electricity against central planners who are distrustful of foreign ownership and suspicious of financial arrangements that would provide competitive rates of return on invested capital.
Mr. Wu complained that the Government under Prime Minister Li Peng issued orders last fall to limit profit margins on power projects to about 12 percent -- well below the 18 or 20 percent obtainable elsewhere in Asia.
"I think some of the Chinese leaders have decided that if foreign investors are making money, it's at the expense of the Chinese," said Mr. Wu, who has built the only large, foreign-financed power stations in this country.
Constructing a modern electrical-supply system for 1.2 billion Chinese is critical to sustaining economic growth and to maintaining political stability, Chinese and Western economic experts say. But the demand for electricity from thousands of new factories, office towers and shopping centers is outpacing China's current generating capacity by 30 percent in the fastest-growing coastal provinces and by 20 percent nationwide.
Mr. Shi recently said that China's energy crisis was already here, adding, "Without the necessary supply of power, the entire economy will be bottlenecked."
Where Western power grids build a 25 percent-surplus generating capacity into their systems to meet peak demand and allow down time for maintenance, officials say that China's power grid is running every piece of equipment it has.
And because China's economic growth is surging nearly 12 percent, after two years of 13 percent growth, the demand for electricity is enormous. In the last 12 months, officials managed to bring only 6,400 megawatts of new power on line, which is hardly enough.
The Power Ministry says China needs to add 15,000 to 17,000 megawatts of generating capacity each year for more than a decade. That is the equivalent each year of duplicating all of Southern California Edison's plants, which supply Southern and Central California.
Communist Party officials have said that an investment of $80 billion over the next five years would nearly double the current national generating capacity -- from 175,000 megawatts to 300,000 megawatts, which is still well short of the country's power needs.
Chinese banks and government agencies can finance 70 percent of this total requirement, officials say, leaving the remaining 30 percent, or about $45 billion worth, to come from foreign investors.
Some negotiations are making progress, and there are indications that Chinese authorities may authorize a handful of large projects to go forward on an experimental basis in the next few months under face-saving formulas that would yield rates of return in excess of 15 percent.
One power consortium. which includes the Los Angeles-based Mission Energy, Bechtel Enterprises and the Lippo group of Hong Kong, is said to have received preliminary approval from the State Planning Commission to build a 700-megawatt power station in southern Fujian province, facing the Taiwan Strait. But a Mission executive said China's top political authorities had not signed off on the deal and that it also had not yet been presented to the bankers.
Even the influential leaders of Shanghai, the nation's industrial giant, have not been able to wring approval from Beijing for a joint venture with General Electric to build a 400-megawatt oil-fired plant that would provide their city with an infusion of electrical power.
Some provinces, desperate to circumvent the policy gridlock in Beijing, are making small-scale deals to purchase oil-fired turbines to produce enough power to run a single industrial park or a real estate development.
Mr. Wu's company and a number of other foreign concerns have staged what they hope will be a temporary walkout from the Chinese market, leaving behind letters of intent Mr. Wu negotiated with province authorities to build 12 additional power stations across central and southern China.
"If some investors want to withdraw, they are free to make their choice," said Jiang Shaojun, a spokesman for the Power Ministry, "but some others will come to replace them."
But while the demand for power has mounted, billions of dollars in capital has flowed elsewhere in Asia.
"Basically, I think what the Chinese are trying to do is control the cost of capital, and they are not succeeding, and so something is going to have to give," an international banking official said.
J. P. Morgan's senior economist for Asia, Guocang Huan, added, "They have to offer a better deal; otherwise, I just cannot imagine where the money will come from."
Mr. Wu took the $1.8 billion he raised for his China projects and has signed deals in Indonesia and the Philippines.
An American utility executive who is negotiating with the Chinese to supply several large power plants said Western banks had assigned a risk rating to China that required higher rates of return. Chinese officials are trying to squeeze better terms by withholding approval.
"They are disputing our risk credit rating," the executive said, "and they are setting themselves apart from the rest of the world."
Power plants are huge, capital-intensive projects that pay out over decades. Evaluating political risk means guessing whether the Communist Party can guarantee enough stability over, perhaps, 20 years so that the electrical output of a power plant will be purchased on an uninterrupted basis.
"What some investors are worried about is whether China will change" after the death of Deng Xiaoping, China's 90-year-old paramount leader, Mr. Jiang at the Power Ministry remarked. "But there is no risk as far as this question is concerned."
Still, China's thirst for capital to finance infrastructure projects has not abated, but a clear strategy to reassure investors has yet to emerge.
"China's needs are huge and its growth targets are ambitious," said James Thompson, Mission Energy's negotiator in this country, "so Beijing cannot afford indefinite paralysis. If they turn out to be shortsighted on their policies about capital, what could be coming in the future is scarcity."

HEADLINE: Scientology and Its German Foes: A Bitter Conflict

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAMBURG, Germany

 BODY:
It would take something like an invasion of space aliens -- maybe something out of an L. Ron Hubbard science fiction novel -- to match the climate of fear and mutual suspicion that prevails between the Church of Scientology that Mr. Hubbard created and its frightened opponents in Germany.
"Fear is part of their system -- it's a totalitarian organization that seeks to control everybody else, a dictatorship," said Ursula Caberta y Diaz, who heads the four-member working group that was set up four years ago by the Hamburg government to combat the Scientology movement and that has tried to get the courts to declare it a criminal conspiracy. 
 "This couldn't happen anywhere else in the world," said Franz Riedl, the church's spokesman in this country. "Our members have been subject to systematic persecution, arson, threats of violence, and dismissals, and children have been thrown out of kindergartens simply because their parents were Scientologists. The situation has become unbearable."
The church, the high fees it charges members for services and rites that are similar to psychological counseling sessions, and its open involvement in business and marketing have provoked strong reactions all over Germany since it first turned up here in the 1970's.
The Church of Scientology, with headquarters in Los Angeles, was founded in 1954 on the basis of what Mr. Hubbard, an American writer of science fiction who died in 1986, had set down in a book called "Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health."
The church's goal, according to its literature, is "to bring an individual to an understanding of himself and his life as a spiritual being." Global membership is estimated variously from 50,000 to eight million.
The latest scare here is that Scientologists are using the high-priced Hamburg real estate market to amass huge profits for more nefarious purposes.
"They have been buying rental residential properties and turning them overnight into cooperatives, using disreputable methods to frighten and coerce the renters into buying them back at high prices," said Peter Landmann, chairman of the Hamburg branch of the German real-estate agents' association.
Mr. Landmann said companies controlled by the church and companies run by church members were involved. He declined to identify any, but said that as much as a third of the cooperative apartment market in Hamburg might have fallen under their influence.
Mr. Riedl said there might be some real-estate agents who were members of the church, but denied that it was in the business to make money.
According to Mr. Riedl, the church has 30,000 members in Germany, mainly concentrated around Hamburg, Munich, Frankfurt and Baden-Wurttemberg. But in his view, it is the state and its political institutions that are out of control.
Mrs. Caberta's Social Democratic Party organization in Hamburg fears subversion, and bars church members from joining. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union and its Government coalition partner, the Free Democratic Party, bar them countrywide.
Renate Rennebach, a Social Democratic member of Parliament in Bonn, has called on the Government to ban the church outright, a step that seems unlikely unless somebody can prove in court that it actually practices the extortion, blackmail and subversion it is so often accused of.
"Scientology, despite official denials, is pursuing an expansion strategy that strives for nothing less than global domination," Mrs. Rennebach warned.
Other German politicians have charged that what the church wants is political and economic power -- Germany today, tomorrow the world. "It is a psycho-sect that makes people financially dependent on it and then squeezes them like lemons," said Stefan Schwarz, a Christian Democratic youth leader in Bonn.
But he said that too often the church's opponents did not back up their charges with the facts needed to take action in court.
The banners hanging on the church's five-story glass-walled headquarters in Hamburg say it is being persecuted. Scientology has tax-exempt status in the United States, Canada, Australia and Russia, the signs say -- why not in Germany?
The church and 150 of its related corporations won that status from the United States Internal Revenue Service a year ago, after 39 years of legal battles. Here, there has been no definitive court ruling yet that the church is a nonprofit organization.
But in August, a Hamburg administrative court ruling forbade Mrs. Caberta's office from distributing a pamphlet charging that "Scientology amounts to this: A sick person has succeeded in selling his own madness, in the form of courses, for a great deal of money to mankind as a desirable goal."
The court also ordered the excision of passages accusing the church of "brainwashing" and racism. The city has appealed the decision.
The church gets a uniformly bad press here, and its building has had to be evacuated several times because of bomb threats. "I've been threatened and sprayed with tear gas for distributing church literature," said Karl-Otto Clausen, a 44-year-old church worker.
Mr. Riedl said the church charged 30,000 marks, about $20,000, for the services -- including counseling and questioning sessions -- required to reach the level of "clear," which Mr. Hubbard's teachings define as "a new state for the individual in which he is no longer adversely affected by his past and is capable of living a rational existence."
But according to some former church members, "clear" is just the beginning of a cycle of financial indebtedness the church uses to ensnare adherents. Gunther Trager, a public relations agent in Frankfurt, said he paid six-figure amounts to reach higher levels before he left in 1991.
"They didn't do anything for three-quarters of a year," he said. "Then I gave an interview to a news magazine, and they started threatening me."
The established churches and Government authorities here say they are often asked for help by relatives of members who accuse the Church of Scientology of trapping them in a web of financial and psychological dependence.
Early this year, interior ministers of the 16 German states accused the church of combining "elements of business crime and psychological terror against its own members with economic activities," but stopped short of taking any action. In June, prosecutors in Hamburg dropped a three-year investigation of the church on grounds of "lack of sufficient evidence of the existence of a criminal conspiracy."
The church then began a publicity counteroffensive in the United States suggesting that history was repeating itself here. "It is simply appalling to compare what's happening to them in Germany today with what happened to the Jews under the Nazis," said Professor Fritz Stern, a leading American expert on Germany at Columbia University.
The church recently called attention to its problems here with a series of full-page advertisements in The New York Times and The Washington Post. The advertisements place the measures against the church in the context of widespread racist violence against foreign immigrants and asylum-seekers here, suggesting that the authorities condone the attacks and persecute the church the way the Nazis persecuted the Jews.
The German authorities have denounced the comparison, and the advertising campaign, as being highly misleading. They have banned neo-Nazi groups for inciting violence, not encouraged them.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Guide to New York Elections for Congressional and State Offices

 BODY:
Candidatess are listed in the order they appear on the ballot.
 
GOVERNOR
 
CANDIDATES
MARIO M. CUOMO , 62, Democrat, Governor since 1983. A native of Queens who ran for lieutenant governor in 1978 and has not lost an election since. During his three terms as Governor became a major figure in national Democratic politics but turned down opportunities to run for President and to sit on the Supreme Court. If he wins, he has said, his fourth term will be his last. 
 GEORGE E. PATAKI , 49, Republican State Senator from Putnam County. A native of Peekskill who became its Mayor in 1981 and was elected to the State Assembly in 1985. Elected to the State Senate in 1991 and chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee. Mr. Pataki was little known until he won the Republican nomination in September with the backing of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
B. THOMAS GOLISANO , 52, Independence Fusion Party candidate. Mr. Golisano, whose personal worth is estimated at $150 million, is founder of Paychex Inc., a payroll-processing company based in his hometown of Rochester. A political novice who is spending up to $10 million of his own money on the campaign, he says he never voted until 1992, when he supported Ross Perot.
ROBERT T. WALSH Sr. , Right to Life Party
LAWRENCE A. LANE , Socialist Workers Party
BOB SCHULZ , Libertarian Party
 
THE ISSUES
Mr. Cuomo's long tenure in office at a time when the state's fortunes are seen to be declining has been the key issue in the race. Most of Mr. Pataki's campaign has been directed against Mr. Cuomo, blaming him for high crime and taxes. Mr. Pataki has promised to cut taxes substantially and to enact the death penalty. Mr. Cuomo has said that the state is on the economic rebound and that the death penalty will do nothing to lower crime rates. He has said Mr. Pataki's tax cut plan would be ruinous to New York City and force many localities to raise property taxes. Mr. Golisano's positions are similar to Mr. Pataki's, but he has proposed a deeper tax cut and is calling for electoral reform that would eliminate the influence of political action committees, which contribute heavily to both of the major-party candidates.
 
ANALYSIS
Mr. Pataki and Mr. Cuomo have each spent the last week claiming to be the underdog, but the label now appears to apply mostly to the Republican. Bolstered by an endorsement and strong campaigning assistance from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Governor has surged in recent polls, particularly in the city and suburbs. Many voters say they still don't know enough about Mr. Pataki and his plans. He has also been hurt by Mr. Golisano's strong independent candidacy, fueled by heavy advertising and a late endorsement from Mr. Perot. But many voters continue to express dissatisfaction with Mr. Cuomo, and the race remains close.
 
OTHER STATE RACES
(X denotes incumbents)
 LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR Stan Lundine, Democrat and Liberal (X); Elizabeth McCaughey, Republican, Conservative and Tax Cut Now; Dominick A. Fusco, Independence Fusion Party; Virginia E. Sutton, Right to Life; Mary Nell Bockman, Socialist Workers Party, and Stanley H. Dworkin, Libertarian Party
 
ATTORNEY GENERAL
 
CANDIDATES
KAREN S. BURSTEIN , 52, Democrat and Liberal. Resigned in April as a judge in Brooklyn Family Court, a position she held since 1990. Elected State Senator in 1972, representing Long Island and southeastern Queens. Has been executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board, president of the State Civil Service Commission and Auditor General of the City of New York.
DENNIS C. VACCO , 42, Republican and Conservative. United States Attorney for the Western District in Buffalo from 1988 to 1993; assistant district attorney in Erie County from 1978 to 1988, including six years as chief of the grand jury bureau for that office.
ALFRED J. SKIDMORE , Right to Life Party
DANIEL A. CONTI Jr. , Tax Cut Now Party
NANCY H. ROSENSTOCK , Socialist Workers Party
JAMES M. HARTMAN , Independence Fusion Party
 
THE ISSUES
The differences between the two leading contenders for the job, Ms. Burstein and Mr. Vacco, are clearly delineated. Ms. Burstein, a liberal Democrat, says she wants to use her wide-ranging experience as a judge, legislator and state commissioner to emphasize the traditional duties of the office of attorney general, which are to defend state agencies, consumers, the environment and civil rights. Mr. Vacco, a conservative Republican and a career prosecutor, has said he wants to expand the office's role by lobbying for harsher penalties against street crime, over which the office now has no jurisdiction, and he is unlikely to achieve that unless the Legislature makes significant changes. Mr. Vacco has stressed his support for the death penalty -- and her opposition to it -- and has accused his opponent, a lesbian, of trying to promote a "homosexual agenda."
 
ANALYSIS
Ms. Burstein has maintained a double-digit lead throughout the campaign. If that margin holds up on Election Day, she will be the first woman elected to a state office in 20 years.
 
COMPTROLLER
 
CANDIDATES
H. CARL McCALL , 58, Democrat-Liberal. Ordained minister, United Church of Christ. State Senator from Manhattan, 1975-1979. Deputy Ambassador to the United Nations, 1979-81. Citibank vice president, 1985-1993. New York City Board of Education President, 1991-93. Appointed by Legislature as Comptroller, 1993.
HERBERT LONDON , 55, Republican-Conservative-Right to Life. John M. Olin Professor of Humanities at New York University, where he founded the Gallatin Division and served as its dean for 20 years. Conservative Party candidate for New York mayor, 1989. Conservative candidate for governor, 1990.
RICHARD L. GEYER , Libertarian Party
BROCK SATTER , Socialist Workers Party
LAUREEN A. OLIVER , Independence Fusion Party
 
THE ISSUES
Few differences have emerged in how Mr. London and Mr. McCall would perform the duties of the comptroller, who invests the $60 billion pension fund, audits state and local government and signs all the state's checks. Rather, the race has focused on bitter personal attacks. Mr. London has questioned Mr. McCall's independence, has charged that he politicized the office and suggested that he has anti-Semitic associations. Mr. McCall has also questioned Mr. London's independence, accused him of using racist tactics and attacked him for opposing abortion rights. Each man has pledged to be an independent voice in Albany, a responsible investor and a force for lower taxes and on-time state budgets.
 
ANALYSIS
This has shaped up to be a close race. Conventional political wisdom says Mr. McCall should have the advantage: he is a Democrat who holds the office he is seeking, has five times more money, and has qualifications more directly related to the office's fiscal duties. Mr. London, by contrast, has never held public office. He has, however, focused intently on economic issues, especially tax cuts, which have particular appeal this year. Analysts also wonder whether some voters will resist Mr. McCall because of his race. (If he wins, Mr. McCall will be the first black candidate elected to statewide office.) But other factors argue against the interpretation that race is at issue; for example, Mr. London seems to have higher name recognition, and some polls show that even many black voters do not know Mr. McCall is black. Indeed, few voters seem to know much about either candidate or the office they are seeking.
 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
 
FIRST DISTRICT CANDIDATES
GEORGE J. HOCHBRUECKNER , 56, Democratic incumbent. A Navy veteran and engineer from Coram, he served in the New York Assembly for a decade before running for Congress in 1984; he lost that race but won two years later. A member of the Armed Services Committee and a strong supporter of the defense industry.
MICHAEL P. FORBES , 41, Republican from Quogue. Raised in Westhampton Beach and a former aide to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, he is currently on leave from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. He won a three-way primary race.
MICHAEL STRONG , Fed Up Party
 
THE DISTRICT
The First District in eastern Suffolk County, running east from Smithtown on the North Shore to Patchogue on the South Shore, includes both the Hamptons and the defense plants that have been the area's economic center. Politically conservative, the district is 2-to-1 Republican.
 
THE ISSUES
Mr. Forbes says the major issues in the race are taxes, jobs, crime and incumbency, in that order. Mr. Hochbrueckner has made an issue of Mr. Forbes's anti-abortion position and opposition to gun control. He has also accused him of "carpetbagging," because Mr. Forbes, who grew up in the area, has spent most of his adult life in Albany and Washington.
 
ANALYSIS
With the district's demographics, Mr. Hochbrueckner always has a tough race, and never more so than this year, when voters are dissatisfied with both Congress and the economy. Republicans are counting on him to pay the price for anti-incumbent sentiment and take the fall for the decline of the area's defense industry. The incumbent says that as a member of the Armed Services Committee, he is in a better position to help push for retraining than would a newcomer. But Mr. Forbes, who has never held elective office, is pointing to his outsider status as an advantage. This is one of the hottest races in the state, too close to call.
 
FOURTH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
PHILIP M. SCHILIRO , 38, Democrat. An environmental lawyer and chief of staff for Representative Henry A. Waxman of California. Narrowly lost to Mr. Levy in 1992 general election.
DANIEL FRISA , 39, a State Assemblyman from Westbury. After losing to Mr. Levy in 1992 G.O.P. primary, squeaked by this year in race that left the party divided.
DAVID A. LEVY , 40, a freshman Representative from Baldwin. Lost in the Republican primary by just 54 votes but remains in race on Conservative line.
VINCENT P. GARBITELLI , Right to Life Party
ROBERT S. BERKOWITZ , Liberal Party
 
THE DISTRICT
 Running across Nassau County's South Shore, this is mostly Republican territory, although the heavily Jewish Five Towns and largely black and Hispanic Roosevelt in Hempstead tend to favor Democrats.
 
THE ISSUES
 Mr. Frisa is running as a fiscal conservative and an environmentalist who has portrayed Mr. Schiliro as an outsider who returns only to run for Congress. Mr. Schiliro, who is credited with writing the legislation for Mr. Waxman that led to a Federal study of possible environmental links to breast cancer on Long Island, has made an issue of gun control, which he favors, and tried to paint Mr. Frisa an "extremist on guns" with high marks from the National Rifle Association.
 
ANALYSIS
 Mr. Schiliro is counting on the deep divisions in the district's Republican Party to hand him a victory and hoping that Mr. Levy will siphon support from Mr. Frisa. But Mr. Frisa, who is considered an exceptional campaigner, cannot be counted out in this longtime Republican stronghold.
 
14TH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
CAROLYN B. MALONEY , 46, first-term Democratic incumbent who is also running as an independent. A Manhattan resident, she served 10 years on the City Council; best known for pushing through a system that improved oversight of city contracts.
CHARLES MILLARD , 37, Republican and Liberal Party. Manhattan resident, lawyer and former VISTA volunteer. As a City Council member, he is best known for advocating quality-of-life measures to restrict sex businesses in residential areas and fine cyclists for riding on the sidewalk.
THOMAS CALEB WHITFORD , Conservative Party
THOMAS K. LEIGHTON , T.B.A. Green Party
 
THE DISTRICT
The old Silk Stocking district on Manhattan's East Side, which sent John Lindsay and Edward Koch to Congress, was redrawn two years ago to include heavily Democratic Astoria in Queens, Greenpoint in Brooklyn, Roosevelt Island and a finger of the West Side, increasing the Democrats' traditional advantage to more than 2 to 1. The district has the highest average household income in the country.
 
THE ISSUES
Ms. Maloney says the only real issue is experience, and she has much more of it. Mr. Millard, a fiscal conservative and social liberal, is running against tax increases and has taken exception to the incumbent's opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 
ANALYSIS
Two years ago Ms. Maloney barely defeated Bill Green, a popular Republican moderate and seven-term incumbent. In that race she had help from Bill Clinton's coattails plus the Liberal Party endorsement, which went to Mr. Millard this year. But the demographics of the district still work against a Republican challenger, and though Mr. Millard is well liked here, the conventional wisdom says he has not made the case for dumping the incumbent.
 
19TH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
HAMILTON FISH Jr. , 43, running as a Democrat for the open seat being vacated by his father, Hamilton Fish, a 13-term Republican. Adviser to Human Rights Watch, a worldwide monitoring group, and former publisher of The Nation, the liberal opinion magazine.
SUE W. KELLY , 57, Republican and longtime party worker. Businesswoman and former hospital-patient advocate from Katonah.
JOSEPH J. DIOGUARDI , 53, Conservative and Right to Life Party. A former Republican Congressman from the neighboring 20th District who was defeated by Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat, four years ago. A retired accountant, he lives in Scarsdale.
CATHERINE PORTMAN-LAUX , Independent
 
THE DISTRICT
The 19th, covering much of the lower Hudson Valley, stretches from Poughkeepsie to North White Plains, including parts of Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess and Orange counties. It was once a Republican stronghold, but since 1990 redistricting is more diverse, with some 113,000 Republicans, 91,000 Democrats and 87,000 independents.
 
THE ISSUES
 All candidates say the main issue is jobs, with major employers like I.B.M. laying off thousands of workers and General Motors scheduled to close its assembly plant in North Tarrytown in 1996. Mrs. Kelly has tried to make an issue of the political differences between the incumbent and his son. Mr. Fish, meanwhile, criticized Mrs. Kelly for running against Washington and then, soon after the primary, traveling there to sign the Republican Contract With America, which he attacks as unrealistic in promising tax cuts, increased military spending and a Constitutional amendment to balance the budget.
 
ANALYSIS
 There has been a Hamilton Fish in Congress since the current candidate's grandfather was first elected in 1922. But anything could happen in this nontraditional race.
 
26th DISTRICT CANDIDATES
 MAURICE D. HINCHEY , 56, the Democratic incumbent, also on Liberal line. A Saugerties resident who, as a member of the State Assembly, concentrated on environmental concerns and had more than 600 bills passed.
BOB MOPPERT , 52, Republican and Conservative Party. A civic leader and former Broome County legislator who owns a moving company in Binghamton.
THOMAS F. KOVACH , Right to Life Party
 
THE DISTRICT
This rural district stretches from the Catskills to Binghamton and north to Ithaca. Its major employer is I.B.M., which has laid off thousands of employees in recent years.
 
THE ISSUES
Mr. Hinchey says the race will come down to intangibles like reliability and integrity. He takes credit for saving more than 1,000 local jobs at Martin Marietta in Westover by intervening in Congress and with the Pentagon to transfer the title of the plant to Broome County's local development agency. Mr. Moppert also says jobs are a major issue -- and promises to turn things around so that his company won't have so much business from people moving out of the area because they have lost their jobs.
 
ANALYSIS
The freshman incumbent is facing an uphill race against a challenger who came within three percentage points of beating him two years ago, even without the support of national Republicans, which he now enjoys. Newt Gingrich, the minority whip, has campaigned for Mr. Moppert, while the all-star lineup pitching for Mr. Hinchey has included Vice President Al Gore, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbit, and Gloria Steinem. With both national parties focusing on the race, it remains a toss-up.

UNITED STATES SENATE
 
CANDIDATES
 DANIEL PATRICK MOYNIHAN , 67, Senator since 1977, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Cabinet or subcabinet member for four Presidents, from Kennedy to Ford; Ambassador to India; professor at Harvard; author or editor of more than a dozen books. Has raised more than $3 million.
 BERNADETTE CASTRO , 50, a former executive of her family's convertible sofa business who was previously known for appearing in television commercials for the business, beginning at the age of 4; has long been a fund-raiser for Republican candidates, and is running for elective office for the first time. Has raised about $500,000 and has estimated that she will also spend about $1.2 million of her own money.
HENRY F. HEWES , Right to Life Party
NORMA SEGAL , Tax Cut Now Party
NAOMI L. CRAINE , Socialist Workers Party
ISMAEL BETANCOURT Jr. , Independence Fusion Party.
 
THE ISSUES
 Mr. Moynihan, who is running for a fourth term, has confounded the conventional wisdom that incumbents are particularly vulnerable this year. Despite his penchant for bluntness, he remains the state's most popular politician. Polls show him leading Ms. Castro by as many as 30 percentage points. Ms. Castro describes herself as a "Christine Todd Whitman Republican," someone who is fiscally conservative and socially moderate. She has tried to portray Mr. Moynihan as far more liberal and free-spending than she would be as a senator, but in fact the two candidates do not disagree significantly on major issues, except for the death penalty, which Ms. Castro supports.
 
ANALYSIS
 Ms. Castro has had an uphill fight against Mr. Moynihan, a Democrat who is difficult to categorize politically and who has often done well among Republican voters upstate. Ms. Castro has had difficulty raising money to challenge the well-financed Senator, in part because even some Republicans have viewed her as a neophyte with a limited chance of success. Ms. Castro has accused a fellow Republican, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, of telling potential backers not to contribute to her campaign and to support the top of the Republican ticket instead. But even without the internal party squabbling, Ms. Castro is a long shot.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Where Hope Survives Only as a Basketball

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE LAST SHOT
City Streets, Basketball Dreams
By Darcy Frey
231 pages. A Richard Todd Book/Houghton Mifflin. $19.95.
 
 "People, they come down to Coney Island and they look at the boardwalk and all the rides and they say, 'Isn't that nice?' And then they see all those buildings behind them and they say, 'Gee, do people live back there?' Yeah, well, we live back here. There are people back here. There are lives going on here. Just because we're black doesn't mean we're stupid."
So speaks Joyce Thomas, the mother of one of the high-school basketball players whom Darcy Frey writes about so perceptively in "The Last Shot: City Streets, Basketball Dreams," a 1990's version of such 1970's factual reports as "The City Game: Basketball in New York" by Pete Axthelm and "Heaven Is a Playground" by Rick Telander. 
 Mrs. Thomas is no doubt justified in her anger at the obscurity of the Coney Island housing projects. As Mr. Frey describes it, the area has undergone a steep decline since a young Richard Feynman began to think about physics while gazing at the ocean and wondering about the movement of the waves. "During the urban-renewal years" of the 1950's, "Coney Island became a dumping ground, the terminus of forced migrations for hundreds of black families who were pushed to the sea."
And Abraham Lincoln High School, once among the top academic schools in New York City, has deteriorated so much that it is the last place the academically ambitious want to go. Mr. Frey writes, "Just about the only students who enroll at Lincoln now as their predecessors once did -- with the conviction that it will serve their future well -- are its athletes."
For most young residents, the prospect is a nasty, brutish existence of drug dealing and machine-gun fire. The only ticket out is to be a basketball star. "Basketball is all we got," says one playground coach whom Mr. Frey describes. "There ain't nothing else to do in Coney Island."
Yet Mrs. Thomas can no longer complain about being completely ignored. For in writing "The Last Shot," Mr. Frey has shone a brilliant light on the community and sharply revealed four of its brightest basketball stars: Tchaka Shipp, a majestic-looking, 6-foot-7-inch 17-year-old; Russell Thomas, Mrs. Thomas's high-strung son, who is a talented scorer and defensive player; Corey Johnson, whose skill on the court is surpassed only by his interest in girls, and Stephon Marbury, at the time of the book's writing perhaps the most gifted freshman point guard in the country.
On basketball talent alone, these four would unquestionably make it all the way to an athletic scholarship at a Division I college and on to a multi-million-dollar contract in the National Basketball Association. But the young men must surmount a hurdle put up by the National Collegiate Athletic Association in 1986 called Proposition 48, which is supposed to show the organization's commitment to education by requiring student athletes to score at least 700 out of a possible 1,600 on the combined Scholastic Aptitude Tests.
Unfortunately, to accomplish this, Mr. Frey reports, most inner-city athletes are found to require a triangular foundation of family, neighborhood and schooling. "The rule is that a player can triumph over one weak point in that triangle, maybe two, but almost never three," he writes. Failure to score 700 means attending junior college instead of a Division I basketball power, and, all too often, an eventual return to the ghetto. For the young men in Mr. Frey's story, all three corners of the foundation are crumbling.
In his sensitive job of reporting, Mr. Frey, who is white, wins the trust and friendship of his four basketball stars, and draws revealing close-ups of their struggles to overcome. He describes following the older ones to basketball camps, where they compete for the notice of coaches and sneaker manufacturers. He recounts sitting in on interviews with unctuous college recruiters who, he says, wheedle prospective players for commitments the recruiters themselves do not intend to honor. He waxes indignant over what he sees as the hypocrisy of a system that demands academic integrity from participants in a game that is purely for profit. After finishing "The Last Shot," a reader finds it difficult not to sympathize with athletes for being greedy.
Happily, Mr. Frey's narrative keeps coming back to the game of basketball itself, and in the book's best passages, the athletes perform. "It's past midnight now," begins a description of a pickup game on a Coney Island playground, "and the ambient glow of Manhattan's remote skyscrapers has turned the sky a metallic blue. Standing courtside, we can see only the darkened outlines of the projects, looming in every direction, and the shirtless players streaking back and forth, drenched in orange light.
"Now and then the ref steps out from the darkness onto center court and his official stripes glow incongruously beneath the court lights as the Doppler wail of police sirens drifts in from the nearby streets. Corey, sprinting down court, calls out, 'Homeboy! Homeboy!' Standing under his own basket, Stephon lets fly with a long, improbable pass that Corey, running full speed, somehow manages to catch and dunk in one balletic leap. The game is called on account of total pandemonium. . . . Stephon laughs and points to the rim, still shuddering from its run-in with Corey's fists. 'Yo, cuz!' he yells. 'Make it bleed!' Then he raises his arms jubilantly and dances a little jig, rendered momentarily insane by the sheer, giddy pleasure of playing this game to perfection."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Darcy Frey (Mary Schjeldahl/Houghton Mifflin)

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON;
They Come From Afar Just to Feel at Home

BYLINE: By GRACE LICHTENSTEIN 

 BODY:
They came to run but they stayed to shop, to go to museums, to eat bagels, to see shows and to party.
For about 11,700 foreigners who made up more than 40 percent of the runners in the New York City Marathon, yesterday's race was only one part of what amounted to a mini-Olympic festival and an adventure vacation. 
 "Un marathon formidable," -- a terrific marathon -- declared Jean-Yves Perron of Nevers, France, as he walked toward the reunion area to find his wife on the Great Lawn of Central Park after finishing in under three hours.
"The road surface was very hard, there was a lot of wind, but the crowd was wonderful," the 36-year-old runner added, echoing the sentiments of many non-American first-timers here.
Perron was one of 2,200 members of the French contingent, the largest among foreign groups. Germans were the second-largest group with 1,661 entrants, the Netherlands third with 1,165.
Although West Europeans dominated the foreign entrants, there were representatives from 99 countries, according to the New York Road Runners Club.
The runners, the overwhelming majority of them men, came from as far away as Japan, India, Malaysia, Cambodia and Ukraine, as well as from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean.
New York, they said, has become the marathon of choice for recreational runners.
"It is the only big one with such an international flavor," said Jorge Carrido, a Mexican member of the Naucalli Club, as he strolled into Central Park on Saturday with five of his cohorts.
Along with thousands of other non-Americans who attended the Saturday "Breakfast Run," which ends at Tavern on the Green, they showed up to munch on muffins and to trade T-shirts and other souvenirs with runners from other countries.
One young Mexican boy proudly wore a giant foam rubber hat in the shape of a wooden shoe, which he got from a Dutch runner in exchange for a sombrero.
In Europe, the New York City Marathon is famous for its friendly crowds, said Grete Waitz, a nine-time champion of the race. She said New Yorkers will stop runners who are staggering back to their hotels after the race to pat them on the back and congratulate them simply for finishing, whereas in Europe, passers-by say, "What was your time?"
"We are not used to that kind of admiration," Waitz said.
Many Europeans came to the race on four- to seven-day package tours bought from travel agents who secure in advance the crucial official entry numbers, which are very difficult for people overseas to obtain any other way. The packages, which include air fare, lodging, bus transport around town and in many cases a Broadway show and sightseeing trips, are priced in the neighborhood of $1,200 to $1,400.
One Dutch group, sponsored by a radio station that provided the athletes with handsome black-and-red jogging suits, filled all the economy seats of a Boeing 747.
Among the 175 runners and 125 of their supporters were Paul Vierboom, a 36-year-old schoolteacher, and Ruud Wolff, a 29-year-old sign maker. A surprise greeted them as they stepped off the plane: Ruud's wife, Gwendoline, who was supposed to be in Paris, and a friend of hers were at the airport with a big sign that read, "Rudd and Paul -- the girls are already here!"
The four got into the Gotham spirit by donning green Statue of Liberty foam rubber crowns before the race.
By Sunday, the Dutch visitors had taken the Circle Line boat around Manhattan, bought as many pairs of Levi 501 jeans as they could stuff into an extra suitcase (they are much cheaper in New York than in Rotterdam), gone to museums and visited the Empire State Building.
Not everyone came in clusters, however. Dana Seetahal, an assistant solicitor general for civil affairs in Trinidad, came all by herself, arranging to stay at the home of a friend in Brooklyn. A veteran of several marathons in her own country, she said she did not tell her colleagues at home that she was about to run the New York Marathon, because "you don't want people to give you goat mouth," a Trinidadian expression for bad luck.
The 39-year-old lawyer was astonished by the helpfulness of New Yorkers, one Herman's Sporting Goods salesman in particular. Upon her arrival, she discovered that an air bubble in her single pair of Nike running shoes had burst. She could not find a pair of the same shoes at the Marathon Expo, a bazaar of equipment booths, but someone directed her to a Herman's store.
The shoes were not in stock there either, but John Flynn, a salesman, not only phoned another store to find a pair for her, he gave her money for a taxi to get there.
"He probably thought I was a waif, but he was the nicest person I have met," Seetahal said. "I'll never forget him. And he was nice looking, too."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Victor and Felipa Ramirez, with 4-year-old son Daniel, take their position on the grandstand in Central Park. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times); Runners from around the world relaxing yesterday in Staten Island before the start of the 26.2-mile marathon through all five boroughs. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Commuting

 BODY:
Continuing a trend that began last winter, ridership is up on the region's commuter railroads and bus lines while vehicle traffic into Manhattan is down. Transit officials largely credited last winter's harsh weather with enticing commuters out of their cars and onto trains and buses. But aggressive marketing campaigns, the improving economy and improved service are also factors in reversing years of declining ridership. Traffic at toll bridges and tunnels into Manhattan was down about 4 percent in the first eight months of 1994 from the first eight months of 1993. The figure does not include statistics for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, which had abnormally low volume in 1993 because of the World Trade Center bombing.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 589 words

HEADLINE: Tilting East

 BODY:
President Clinton's theme of putting the economy first takes him this week to Indonesia for the second annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting. APEC is an 18-member group of Pacific Rim countries that includes China and Japan. On the agenda is a proposal to create by 2020 the world's largest free-trade and investment zone -- a dramatic symbol of America's tilt toward soaring opportunities in Asia and away from the enervated economies of Western Europe.
Mr. Clinton pushed Nafta, the accord with Mexico and Canada, through Congress over the opposition of important Democratic constituencies. He also signed, along with more than 100 trading partners, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- which Congress will vote on after the elections. An APEC accord is an enticing next step. APEC members account for about half of the world's economic output; yet the U.S. share of trade and investment in the group is falling. A trade agreement would guarantee fair access, a key to U.S. growth. 
 An APEC trade accord could boost economies everywhere along the Pacific Rim. It could also nudge countries outside the region toward more open trade and investment agreements: after the U.S. embraced Nafta, Western Europe got serious about negotiating GATT. And by tying Asia and the U.S. closer together, an APEC trade agreement would help to defuse political tensions.
Yet for all its promise, an APEC accord, like other regional trade pacts, could be worrisome. By granting preferential market access to members, it would discriminate against exports from non-members. The proponents of an APEC accord propose to mitigate the threat in two ways: by knocking down trade and investment barriers left standing by GATT and by offering APEC trade benefits to non-members willing to live by the same rules.
An unresolved issue is how quickly to proceed. Paula Stern and Robert Manning, two former U.S. trade officials affiliated with a Democratic think tank, call for an incremental approach. Free trade among countries at different states of economic development would be difficult to define, let alone achieve. Ms. Stern and Mr. Manning want to select a few modest goals over the next couple of years. For example, APEC could start immediately to formulate protections for foreign investors, adopt common customs procedures and open access to telecommunications markets.
A few quick victories could undermine protectionist opposition in Congress. That is important because Congress has so far blocked Mr. Clinton's request for "fast track" status for future trade negotiations -- the procedure by which Congress agrees to vote on a trade proposal quickly and without amendment. Mr. Clinton needs "fast track" if he is to secure the trade agreements called for in his economic strategy.
Not everyone in APEC is thrilled by the prospect of free trade. Some, like Malaysia, are afraid of close involvement with the U.S., partly because they fear the squabbles over human rights and other issues that have marked U.S. relations with Japan and China. China has threatened to fight the proposal, perhaps as a way to bargain for early admission to the new World Trade Organization that will oversee international trade rules.
The U.S. and other supporters of free trade will have to fight hard to get APEC to move toward free trade. But the U.S. imports more from Asia than from the rest of the world combined. It sells more than 30 percent of its exports to Asia. Mr. Clinton is headed in the right direction.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial
