HEADLINE: American Cites Intimidation by Singapore Over Article He Wrote

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Nov. 6

 BODY:
An American economist who left Singapore last month said today that he would not return here because he was fearful of being imprisoned over a newspaper opinion article published in Singapore in which he criticized "intolerant regimes" in Asia.
The State Department has protested the treatment of the economist, Christopher Lingle, who was interrogated by the Singapore police twice last month as a result the article, which appeared in The International Herald Tribune on Oct. 7. 
 In an interview from his family home in Atlanta, Mr. Lingle, who had taught for the last year at the National University of Singapore, said he would not return to this authoritarian city-state because "these people weren't playing games -- if I had stayed, I would have faced the prospect of imprisonment or a heavy fine." The Singapore police, he said, "intimidated the hell out of me."
In the article, Mr. Lingle wrote of the clash of Western and Asian values and said authoritarian governments in Asia were "ingenious at suppressing dissent." He referred to the tendency of Asian leaders to rely "on a compliant judiciary to bankrupt opposition politicians." He did not name any particular nation.
In a statement issued in Washington, the State Department said it "was disappointed at this apparent attempt by Singaporean authorities to intimidate Professor Lingle."
"We continue to believe that everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression," it said.
The State Department has repeatedly protested to Singapore this year over the treatment of American citizens here, most notably an American teen-ager, Michael P. Fay, who was flogged in May after he pleaded guilty to spray-painting cars.
The Singapore Government, which has denied allegations from Americans living here that they are being singled out for harassment as part of a Government crusade against American values, expressed surprise over the State Department's defense of Mr. Lingle.
"If anybody impugns the Government's integrity and it amounts to defamation, the Government will take action," Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said.
Ten days after the article was published, Mr. Lingle said, two police officers appeared at his office at the university, where he was a senior fellow in the European studies, and questioned him for nearly two hours. He said he had been told by the officers that the investigation centered on "criminal defamation and contempt of court, and the contempt of court was based upon an inferred criticism of their judiciary system."
Two days later, he was questioned again for two hours at the university, and policemen went to his home, requesting the research material on which he had based his article. He said he had given them a collection of news magazines. The Herald Tribune, which is owned by The New York Times Company and the Washington Post Company, prints a regional edition in Singapore.
After the interrogations, Mr. Lingle, who is 46, left Singapore on a leave of absence to visit his ailing father in Atlanta. He has since resigned from the university.
"Dr. Lingle has written the article in his personal capacity, and this has nothing to do with the university," said Ng Suan Eng, deputy director of the university liaison office. "Our staff are allowed to raise their voices on any issues and are personally responsible for their own views."
Last month, though, the four editors of the university's alumni magazine resigned in protest after the alumni association canceled publication of its latest issue, which focused on cultural freedom.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 8, 1994, Tuesday

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about intimidation of the press by the Government of Singapore referred incorrectly in some copies to an article written by an American economist and published in The International Herald Tribune. The article criticized "intolerant regimes" in Asia, but did not single out any country.

HEADLINE: Italy's Big Banks on a Merger Spree

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 6

 BODY:
For decades, Italy's sclerotic banking system was the ward of politicians, with overstaffed and grossly inefficient banks providing jobs and patronage and successive governments providing the money to keep the system oiled.
Now, with the Government trying to get out of the business of running the economy, and some of the biggest banks formerly owned by the state sold to private shareholders, the banks are loosening their limbs. 
 Last Wednesday, Credito Italiano, Italy's eighth-largest bank, announced expansion plans, proposing a $1.3 billion takeover of Credito Romagnolo in Bologna. Credito Italiano is looking for size, to compete in a changed banking environment where governments have less to say and the barriers between national markets are falling.
To fend off Credito Italiano's bid, Credito Romagnolo announced instead a merger with the Cassa di Risparmio di Bologna, which would create Italy's 10th-largest bank.
A day later, Banca Commerciale Italiana announced plans to acquire control of Banco Ambrosiano Veneto for $1.13 billion, which would create Italy's largest totally private bank.
Such dealing is a consequence of the privatization of Banca Commerciale and Credito Italiano this year, when their shareholder voting rights were acquired by the powerful Milan investment bank Mediobanca.
The appetite for acquisitions looks likely to continue. Antonio Maccanico, a former Mediobanca president, identified two other big banks likely to go shopping next. Banca di Roma, which became Italy's second-largest in 1992 after two smaller bank companies merged, is eyeing Banca Nazionale di Agricoltura. And the Turin-based Instituto Bancario San Paolo wants the Banca Nazionale delle Comunicazioni.
"Italy's big banks, in the European context, are small in size," explained Mario Noera, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank's Italian unit. "For global business, they need critical mass."
Deutsche Bank itself illustrates the threat from abroad. In 1986, it acquired control of Banca d'America e Italia from BankAmerica, giving it 160 branches throughout Italy.
Indeed, with investing habits that have tended toward Government securities because of chronically high interest rates and an anemic stock market, Italy has been a prime target for major investment banks, including Morgan Stanley, Goldman, Sachs and Salomon Brothers.
The downside of the present concentration, some bankers say, is the powerful role of Mediobanca and its secretive 86-year-old chairman, Enrico Cuccia. Through a complex web of shareholdings, an investor club led by Mr. Cuccia's bank took control of Credito Italiano and Banca Commerciale when they went public this year.
"What some people evidently fear," Mr. Noera said, "is that this concentration will mean less transparency in regions of greatest economic interest."
Concern is heightened by the significance of the latest banks that are takeover targets. Ambrosiano Veneto and Credito Romagnolo are in business centers in the Veneto region of northeastern Italy and the Emilia-Romagna regions of central Italy, respectively. Both areas have concentrations of the small, aggressively export-oriented companies that form the profitable backbone of Italy's economy.
Lamberto Dini, the Treasury Minister and former deputy head of the Bank of Italy, the central bank, asked whether he saw Mediobanca's hand behind the new wave of takeover attempts, as some analysts do, replied: "I don't know what hand they're talking about. I only see banking companies pursuing determined objectives and strategies."
The consolidations should move ahead, Mr. Dini said, "so that we can have institutions that are competitive with the large European banks."
To compete internationally, banking analysts say, the Italian banks need to resolve problems of internal organization and lagging technology. They have come under pressure from many directions. Falling interest rates have reduced their spread -- the difference between what they must pay for money and what they can charge their customers -- and tighter central bank operating rules have forced commercial banks to tie down larger amounts of capital than used to be required.
Coming as the economy struggles out of recession, these have squeezed bank profits and in some cases generated immense losses. Major banks like the Banco di Napoli and Banco di Sicilia avoided bankruptcy only through rescue operations carried out by more profitable banks at the behest of the central bank.
The acquisition bids of Banca Commerciale and Credito Italiano still face hurdles.
For Banca Commerciale, the obstacles are mainly financial. In a bold stroke, the bank offered $4.67 a share for Ambrosiano Veneto, fully 80 percent above the going price on Oct. 26, before speculation about the expected takeover drove it up 50 percent. By doing so, Banca Commerciale effectively sought to block another international player, France's Credit Agricole, which has a 15 percent stake in Ambrosiano Veneto.
"Credit Agricole must either sell, or bid," if the French bank wants to fight the takeover, said Flavio Cereda, who follows Italian banking at Barclays de Zoete Wedd International in London.
Credito Italiano's bid, by contrast, affords a test for measuring the degree to which Italian banking has shed old political ties.
Under the old partitioning of the banking system among the political parties, Credito Romagnolo was a fief of the former Christian Democrats, who were swept from power this year. Moreover, the bank is based in Bologna, the traditional heartland of the powerful Party of the Democratic Left, as the former Communist Party now calls itself, and its labor union allies. They view with disapproval the inroads of the big banks of Milan.
In the end, banking analysts give Credito Italiano's takeover bid good chances for success, if for the first time the decision is based on profit rather than politics.
While Credito Italiano's offer involves paying shareholders $12.40 a share, Credito Romagnolo's proposed merger with the Cassa di Risparmio means essentially a share swap.
"In the end, shareholders have a choice between cash and paper," Mr. Cereda said.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 14, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day last Monday about proposed mergers in Italian banking referred incorrectly to the financial condition of one bank. Banco di Napoli is not threatened by bankruptcy and was not bailed out by other Italian banks at the behest of the central bank.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
 
South Korea said it would ease restrictions on business with Communist North Korea. Little is known about the workings of North Korea, but the chance to open one of the world's last closed economies seems likely to pique international business interest of the kind whetted by China and even Vietnam. [Page A1.]
Losses at Carl Zeiss reflect the difficulties in reuniting economies of eastern and western Germany. The lenses and optics company says it faces collapse unless it further slashes jobs. [D1.] 

Companies
 
Levi Strauss has begun offering digitally tailored blue jeans. A personal computer at an Original Levi's Store can transmit the measurements of a customer to a factory in Tennessee, where a robotic tailor will cut a bolt of denim to order. The jeans are part of a trend toward mass customization, in which computerized instructions permit factories to modify mass-market products to suit the needs of individual customers. [A1.]
Sears, Roebuck handed over ownership of the Sears Tower to a trust set up to benefit the building's mortgage holders. [D1.]
The appeal of producing videos for the home market is growing in Hollywood. Virtually every large studio is trying to cash in on the "direct-to-video" approach. [D1.]
Bell Atlantic and Nynex settled a lawsuit with AT&T, removing a final hitch in AT&T's absorption of McCaw Cellular. [D1.]
An alliance between Apple Computer and I.B.M. was met with skepticism. Until the two companies form a common software strategy, they will be at a disadvantage, some analysts said. [D4.]
Upjohn will sell its agricultural seed subsidiary to Empresas La Moderna of Mexico for $300 million in cash. [D4.]
The chief financial officer of Gtech Holdings plans to resign. [D4.]
Service Merchandise named a Saks Fifth Avenue executive as president and chief operating officer. [D5.]
Siemens announced an interactive video alliance with Sun Microsystems and Scientific-Atlanta. [D5.]
NEC says it can build a supercomputer that is the fastest of its kind. NEC wants to build market share in supercomputers. [D7.]
ESPN agreed to acquire 80 percent of Sports Ticker, a sports-wire news service, from Dow Jones, which will keep 20 percent. [D24.]
 
The Economy
 
Three-dimensional computing is taking its first steps. Engineers in the United States and Japan are starting to build computing systems that rise from the surface of silicon chips the size of a fingernail. The goal is more power in less space. [D1.]
Consumer borrowing increased at a 14.6 percent annual rate in September. Growth in auto loans was especially strong. [D2.]
The Supreme Court heard arguments on Amtrak's rejection of a political ad, a potential First Amendment case. [A15.]
 
Markets
 
Stocks were mixed as traders awaited today's elections. [D10.]
Treasury prices were flat in quiet trading. [D21.]
Crude oil prices tumbled after a report showed supply could outstrip demand this winter. Cotton prices rose. [D23.]
The dollar was little changed against other leading currencies amid uncertainty over United States monetary policy. [D23.]

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: NEW YORK GOVERNOR;
Cuomo and Pataki End Bitter, Costly Race

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
Mario M. Cuomo and George E. Pataki ended the most expensive -- and arguably the most negative -- gubernatorial campaign in state history yesterday with passionate entreaties for unity and bold predictions of victory, leaving 8.8 million New York registered voters to choose whether to end or extend 20 years of Democratic rule in Albany.
In casting their ballots today, voters also will determine whether New York will elect a black official to statewide office for the first time and whether it will become the first state in the country to elect an openly homosexual candidate to statewide office. The results are likely to leave their imprint on the state's politics for years and could have a lasting impact on the careers not only of the candidates but also of their leading surrogates, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the state's Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato. 
 On the last day of what he has suggested will be the last campaign of his 20-year political career, Governor Cuomo cast today's election as a race that will send a national message and warned that his Republican opponents "will go wherever the political winds blow."
"How do you know where they'll be tomorrow?" he shouted to a crowd of several hundred frenzied supporters at a V.F.W. hall in Syracuse. "How do you know where they'll be on you tomorrow? How do you know how they'll feel about women tomorrow? How do you know how they'll feel about Italians tomorrow, about blacks, about union people, about Syracuse, about upstate, about downstate? When they shift to meet the political winds, there's nothing but chaos."
Mr. Pataki, a state senator, made a final appeal to New Yorkers from all regions to unite around his candidacy, or at least to unite against Mr. Cuomo's, a pointed rebuttal to the Governor's charge that the Republicans are trying to divide the state.
"It's not just the Republicans and Conservatives," Mr. Pataki said at an airport rally in Rochester. "It's the independents and the Democrats. It's the city dwellers, it's the rural people, it's the farmers, it's the people of Bedford-Stuyvesant, that understand that regardless of where they live in this state, their future has been hurt by the spending and tax increases of Mario Cuomo."
The campaign has been notable for its high stakes, its dramatic moments, its bitter tone and its unprecedented expense. While individual gubernatorial candidates in the past -- most notably Nelson A. Rockefeller, who won four terms, and Lewis E. Lehrman, the businessman who ran against Mr. Cuomo in 1982 -- have spent sums rivaling those spent by this year's contenders, the total spent this year is the highest ever.
Including the $9 million that B. Thomas Golisano is expected to spend out of his own pocket on his third-party candidacy, the race is expected to cost about $31 million, according to campaign officials.
Both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki seemed loose and confident as they campaigned yesterday, clearly moved and energized by the cheers of their supporters.
"We're going to win this thing and we're going to win comfortably," Mr. Cuomo said in Syracuse, though he later urged his volunteers to work as if they were behind.
Mr. Pataki said his campaign's polling "shows consistent strong movement in our favor and away from Mario Cuomo up to and through" Sunday night. He added that he believed that if the election was held Sunday night, "we would have won."
But just in case, Mr. Pataki told reporters that he plans to indulge his superstition of not polishing his dusty black shoes or changing their frayed laces until after the results are in.
After spending the morning in Syracuse, Mr. Cuomo took a symbolic ride by high-speed ferry from La Guardia Airport down the East River and up the Hudson to Battery Park City, where he received a warm hug from his wife, Matilda, and wild applause from a crowd on a swaying, floating pier. He was greeted there by Mayor Giuliani, former Mayor David N. Dinkins and a number of local Democratic officials. Last night, the Governor participated in a televised debate with Mr. Golisano and other minor-party candidates but without Mr. Pataki, who was being interviewed at the same time on WCBS-TV.
On the boat trip, Mr. Cuomo donned a red-and-white "Cuomo '94" baseball cap and stood on a bench on the upper deck. As the ferry cruised past the United Nations, he suggested -- without pledging -- that this campaign would be his last. "I think I should be able to get my work done over the next four years," the 62-year-old Governor told reporters.
In Syracuse, Mr. Cuomo also made one final effort to cement in voters' minds the ties between Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato.
"I speak with one voice and it's my voice," he said. "Nobody speaks for me. Every once in a while I'll make a mistake, but you can believe I speak for myself."
Mr. Pataki, 49, hopscotched around the state, touching down in Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Albany and Manhattan before finishing with a rally in his hometown, Peekskill.
Mr. Pataki called the election the most important in 20 years. "This will decide the future of New York over the next four years and, more important, it will decide whether we can again become the engine of opportunity, become No. 1 in new jobs and economic growth instead of No. 1 in lost jobs and the rate of taxation in America," he said.
In purely political terms, today's voting will determine whether Mr. Cuomo, a larger-than-life figure who has lost popularity in his own state, will be returned to Albany for a fourth four-year term. But it also could have a profound effect on the state's policy toward taxation, welfare and the death penalty, which Mr. Pataki has promised to enact early in his term. Mr. Cuomo has vetoed death-penalty bills passed by the Legislature in each of his 12 years in office.
Strategists in both campaigns said they expected between four million and five million New Yorkers to vote today. Little rain was expected except in the far northern reaches of the state.
Both campaigns spent much of the day on get-out-the-vote efforts. Mr. Cuomo's workers, for instance, started to distribute thousands of fliers in minority neighborhoods with pictures of South African voters lined up at the polls last spring. The caption: "They walked miles. You can go a few blocks to vote."
Other candidates also had busy campaign days. State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who hopes to become the first black official elected statewide in New York, joined Karen S. Burstein, the attorney-general candidate, and Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine in flying around the state. Mr. McCall's Republican opponent is Herbert London, a New York University professor who ran for governor in 1990.
Ms. Burstein, who is a lesbian, said the key question in the election is whether New Yorkers will "pick competence and achievement and diversity over people who have made pleas for everybody in this state to be fearful, to be homophobic, to be racist, to be sexist."
Her Republican opponent, Dennis C. Vacco, said on the steps of City Hall that "my opponent continues to talk about issues that are not at all related to law enforcement."
Also on the ballot today, United States Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan faces Bernadette Castro, and New Yorkers must elect 31 members of Congress and 211 members of the State Legislature.

HEADLINE: Appeal of 'Direct-to-Video' Grows Among Film Studios

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Alongside advertisements for "Interview with the Vampire" in newspaper movie sections this week are those for "Texas." But don't look for any theater listings in the promotions; this film is available only on video.
"Texas," based on the James A. Michener novel, has never played in theaters or on television. And unlike low-budget kung-fu, horror and sex thrillers -- so-called grade B titles -- which typically cost less than $500,000 to make, "Texas" cost $12 million and signals a sea change in movie-making economics, raising the stature of video stores as showcases for programming. 
 "The video market is doing what theaters did for movie studios 20 or 30 years ago," said Jeffrey Fink, senior vice president of sales and distribution for the Live Entertainment Corporation in Van Nuys, Calif., one of many independent film companies making movies for video. "Video stores are becoming like Home Box Office or cable -- another outlet for original programming."
Virtually every major studio is trying the "direct-to-video" approach, though most are focusing on the lucrative children's sector, where videos are priced to sell rather than to rent. For instance, "The Return of Jafar," the sequel to "Aladdin" that is the Walt Disney Company's first direct-to-video release, is already one of the top 10 grossing videos of all time, having sold 10 million copies since April.
The Sony Corporation and MCA Inc. are also chasing the children's made-for-video market this year with releases to cash in on the consumer trend toward building home video libraries.
The leading studios, however, have been slower to venture into the made-for-video market for adults, leaving a few independent film makers to blaze the trail. Republic Pictures, the producer of "Texas," says more than half of the 36 movies it plans for next year will be direct-to-video releases, and, unlike its past production, will feature well-known actors and budgets of several million dollars each. This year, Republic released only five direct-to-video movies, of which "Texas," which is scheduled for release on Wednesday, was the most expensive to make.
The approach is less risky for Republic than for other studios in part because its parent company, Spelling Entertainment, is owned by Viacom Inc., which also owns Blockbuster Entertainment, the leading video store chain. The Blockbuster connection guarantees Republic a strong distribution outlet, and telegraphs to skeptics the synergistic powers of the Viacom-Blockbuster-Spelling combination.
With the video-first release of "Texas," Republic built a financial backstop for itself should the video sales prove disappointing by also selling the television rights. ABC will broadcast it as a two-part mini-series this spring, and got a bargain price on the program.
"A mini-series normally costs a network about $2.5 million an hour," said E. Duke Vincent, the executive producer of "Texas." "But we are giving it to them for half that price in exchange for a 90-day video window."
In addition, Mr. Vincent figures, ABC benefits from Republic's marketing of the video, with little loss in TV viewership. "Say one million people see the video," he said. "That won't hurt ABC's ratings much. Maybe 13 million people will watch it on TV instead of 14 million."
In the early 1990's, the demand by video retailers for exclusive products to distinguish their stores gave rise to a whole new genre of movies known as the erotic thriller, like "Tales From the Dark Side" and "Beastmaster II," with unknown actors and modest budgets. Direct to video was something of an industry joke, implying inferior goods.
Still, video rental stores typically bought 5 of these titles for every 20 major films because of their cult following, longer shelf life and profitability. "A retailer might buy 100 copies of 'Jurassic Park' and in six months, everyone has seen it, leaving a big inventory of little value," said Thomas K. Arnold, executive editor of Video Store magazine in Cleveland. "But they'll buy only two copies of 'Dark Side,' which will still be renting after six months, with little inventory risk."
Yet the competitive landscape has changed in the last year or so, forcing independent studios that made erotic thrillers, like Prism Entertainment, Full Moon Entertainment and Live Entertainment, to turn out higher-caliber films.
Now, instead of buying B-movies, more retailers are now purchasing more video games and they have more Hollywood titles from which to choose.
Heartened by consumers' return to the theaters as the recession has lifted, and by two banner years at the box office, Hollywood is producing movies in record numbers. What is more, the studios' purchase of independent film makers, like Disney's acquisition of Miramax, means that even more product has filled the pipeline.
That means B-movie makers must move up market or out. Live Entertainment has created a line exclusively for movie videos starring actors from the big screen. (The first of the series, introduced in September, is called "The Young Americans," with Harvey Keitel.) And Full Moon has switched its emphasis from R-rated cult thrillers to PG-rated science fiction fantasies.
The attraction of these family films is the opportunity to cash in on the market's biggest growth trend: consumer spending on video libraries. In 1988, of the $6.7 billion spent on videos, just $1.5 billion was to buy them. Last year, consumers spent $5.2 billion to buy videos, almost as much as the $7.6 billion to rent them, according to Video Store magazine.
Disney, on the heels of its success with "The Return of Jafar," introduced the "Muppet Classic Theater" in late October, and will release other sequels directly to video. Instead of spending $40 million -- and two years -- on the "Jafar" sequel, Disney invested an estimated $5 million, at most, and made an estimated $120 million from video sales.
Those economics, no doubt, are drawing other studios into the direct-to-video children's market. Through its Sony Wonder arm, which plans to concentrate on children's films, Sony has three direct-to-video titles this year and seven planned for 1995. Like Disney, it recreates the classics, with the release of its version of "Snow White" close to Disney's own video release this fall of its 1937 movie, perhaps benefiting from Disney's promotion.
Similarly, after Christmas, MCA Home Video is releasing a direct-to-video sequel to the animated 1988 feature, "The Land Before Time." MCA Home Video will have 10 more children's titles made for video next year.
"Children's is a bigger opportunity because of the added merchandising, television, theme park and book possibilities," Louis Feola, president of MCA Home Video, said.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CONNECTICUT GOVERNOR;
The 4 Major Candidates Debate Tax Cut to the End

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 7

 BODY:
From the beginning of the race for governor of Connecticut, the four major candidates have been debating tax cuts, and today, the final day of the campaign, was no different.
Once again, John G. Rowland, the Republican candidate, and Tom Scott, an independent candidate, talked about repealing the income tax, which constitutes about one-third of the state's revenues. William E. Curry Jr., the Democrat, said that the focus should be on a 25 percent cut in the property tax, which he believes weighs more heavily on working people. 
 And Eunice S. Groark, the candidate of A Connecticut Party, said that any talk of a tax cut was an empty promise, given the state's precarious financial position.
With all this talk about taxes, only one thing seemed to be clear about tomorrow's election: a majority of the voters will cast their ballots against the victor. All of which means that no matter whom the people of Connecticut elect as governor, that person is not likely to have much of a mandate to follow through on dramatic promises to cut taxes or to maintain the status quo.
While almost all the polls have shown Mr. Rowland as the leader and Mr. Curry a close second, Mrs. Groark could still overtake them if most of the undecided voters break her way.
"I would guess that the winner would not get more than 35 percent of the vote and that's unprecedented in this state," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, on a radio call-in show on Thursday.
Candidates today talked optimistically about their ability to implement their plans, and dismissed concerns about the lack of a mandate, noting that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., of A Connecticut Party, was elected with 40 percent and still managed to push through an income tax.
At a campaign stop in Hartford, Mr. Rowland was asked whether he would deliver an income tax cut, and he responded quickly: "You better believe it. We'll cut it by one-third my first two years in office."
Elsewhere, Mr. Curry, the State Comptroller, told voters that Mr. Rowland was cutting the wrong tax. "We raise more money from the property tax than we do from the income tax and sales tax combined," he said.
In New Haven, Mrs. Groark, the Lieutenant Governor, argued that the present administration had saved the state from a $1 billion deficit by imposing an income tax in 1991 and that it would reappear with massive cuts, whether in property taxes or income taxes.
"Our future is bright," she said. "But we must not embrace the free-lunch theory of government proposed by my opponents."
And Mr. Scott, a conservative Republican who abandoned his party to run as an independent, continued to lambaste Mrs. Groark and GovernorWeicker for "pouring fuel on a fire" by imposing an income tax during a recession in 1991. He insisted that he was the only candidate truly committed to repealing it, and that Mr. Rowland had not detailed a serious plan.
Over the last month, the debate over taxes has been somewhat eclipsed by questions about Mr. Rowland's character, and the controversy over a domestic dispute between Mr. Rowland and his former wife, Deborah, may well be a deciding factor.
Mr. Rowland has said that he and his ex-wife had an argument at her home in Middlebury on April 10, but he successfully fought in court to block the release of the police report about the incident.
Mr. Rowland has argued that making the report public would harm his three children, a point his ex-wife disputes.
In recent weeks, polls have shown Mr. Rowland losing support among women of both parties.
Today, as Mr. Rowland shook hands with voters, he would smile brightly every time a woman said she planned to vote for him, and on at least one occasion he mentioned the "negative and slanderous campaign" that had been waged against him.
Mr. Curry tried to cast the race as a two-person contest between him and Mr. Rowland, and said that a vote for Mrs. Groark was a vote for Mr. Rowland.
"It is appropriate for people to ask if their vote makes not just a statement, but a difference," he said. "Because of the configuration of the race, John Rowland might eke out a one-point win that he hasn't earned and that the vast majority of people in this state don't want him to have."
But Mrs. Groark dismissed Mr. Curry's argument at a news conference this afternoon. "As we wind down the campaign, we are surging, and with such a high percentage of undecided voters, obviously they are going to decide the outcome," she said.
With these starkly different positions, pollsters say that Connecticut voters are confused about what to do, with as much as one-fifth of the electorate still undecided.
Betsey Todt, director of the Quinnipiac College Poll, said: "It's the only race I've been associated with since I've been doing polls where any poll you've been reading up 'til now is not a predictor of what's going to happen on Tuesday. Even though we had Rowland ahead in our last poll, it is still very much up for grabs."

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Rises for the 22d Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
American consumers took on substantially more debt in September, the Federal Reserve said today, marking the 22d straight month that such borrowing has grown as the economy has strengthened.
The Fed said that everything from credit card to auto debt to bank consumer loans grew by some $10.57 billion, or at a 14.6 percent annual rate, following a staggering $15.16 billion increase in August -- an annualized jump of 21.3 percent. 
 Growth in auto loans was especially strong. Auto credit outstanding rose in September to $5.59 billion, at a 21.7 percent annual rate, after rising by $4.53 billion, or at a 17.8 percent annual rate, in August.
The Fed said the overall August increase in consumer borrowing, a sharp revision from the previously reported $11.20 billion rise, was the largest rise since January 1989, when it grew $16.33 billion.
The increases have fueled concern that consumers may pull back from their spending spree, undermining the vitality of the economy.
The Fed, on the other hand, has seemed more worried that the strong demand in the malls and auto dealerships will give sustenance to its avowed enemy -- inflation.
For this reason, it is generally expected that Fed policy makers will vote to increase interest rates for the sixth time when they meet to map out policy next Tuesday.
Revolving, or credit-card, debt in September rose by $2.29 billion, at an 8.6 percent annual rate, compared with a $7.77 billion August advance, at a 29.7 percent annual rate, the latter the largest rise since June 1984, when it rose 31 percent.
Other credit, which includes consumer bank loans but not real estate mortgages, rose by $2.68 billion, at a 13.5 percent annual rate, slower than the $2.86 billion, or 14.5 percent, August increase, the Fed said.
Before seasonal adjustment, the total outstanding consumer credit in September was $880.2 billion, up from $869.6 billion in August and $772.2 billion in September 1993.

HEADLINE: South Korea to Lift Curbs On Business Ties to North

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 7

 BODY:
South Korea said today that it would begin lifting restrictions on business dealings with North Korea, clearing the way for economic cooperation between the two countries still divided by the legacy of the cold war.
In short North Korea, one of the world's most isolated nations and a last bastion of Stalinism, looks open for business. 
 The announcement today by President Kim Young Sam of South Korea effectively fires the starter's gun for a race by South Korean companies to establish factories and build resorts in North Korea. Such plans had been announced two to three years ago, but were frozen last year as a crisis developed over the Communist nation's suspected nuclear weapons program.
"It is true that in the past, intra-Korean relations were bogged down over the nuclear issue and went through a difficult phase," President Kim said in a speech today to a group of businessmen in Seoul. "However, we have reached the point when we should seriously re-examine this topic and start pushing for a policy of economic cooperation with North Korea."
Mr. Kim said he would take "step-by-step measures" to create an atmosphere conducive to cooperation by encouraging joint industrial projects between North and South Korea.
Little is known about the workings of North Korea, a reclusive Communist state, so its worth as an emerging market is hard to calculate. Yet the prospect of opening one of the world's last closed economies seems bound to pique the kind of international business interest that has been whetted by China and, to a lesser degree, Vietnam.
Until now, direct trade between North and South Korea has been prohibited. But indirect trade, through Hong Kong or other third parties, has grown to about $200 million a year. Much of the trade consists of North Korean exports of raw materials and clothing.
South Korea's huge conglomerates, known as chaebol, began staking out their turf in North Korea well before the latest nuclear crisis.
The Hyundai Group, for instance, has expressed interest in developing a resort near Mount Kumgang, a scenic spot north of the eastern end of the demilitarized zone separating the two Koreas. And another conglomerate, Daewoo, reached an agreement with North Korea to run factories in Nampo, a port near Pyongyang, the capital, to produce shirts, underwear, eating utensils and other light products.
American, European and Asian companies are also quietly exploring opportunities in North Korea. But the American companies are generally quiet about their plans because Washington has not yet lifted restrictions barring them from doing any business with North Korea.
"There's no reason to go beyond the borderline at the moment," said an executive of AT&T in Seoul. The company, which would like to connect North Korea to its telephone service and sell it telecommunications equipment, has been talking to people at the North Korean mission at the United Nations.
Businessmen in Seoul say other American companies interested in at least looking at North Korea include Coca-Cola, Bechtel and Hewlett-Packard.
Shell Oil and the ING Bank of the Netherlands are two European-based companies whose officials have visited North Korea, but say they have not yet decided whether to invest.
Kim Jong Il, who took over as North Korean leader in the aftermath of the death of his father, President Kim Il Sung, in July, seems to be looking for foreign investment to shore up a tottering economy. The North Korean economy has been contracting at a rate of 5 percent a year and is beset by severe fuel shortages. The country's gross national product has been estimated at well below $1,000 per capita in a population of about 22 million.
The Communist Government is soliciting foreign companies to set up operations in a free trade zone in the far northeast corner of the country, near the Tumen River and the borders with China and Russia. This especially isolated area was believed to have been selected, in part, to prevent Western and capitalist ideas from loosening the Pyongyang leadership's hold over the population.
In foreign economic terms, what North Korea is believed to offer is an obedient, low-wage work force and a location near the attractive markets of China, South Korea and Japan. The country is also rich in some metal ores.
But roads and telecommunications are extremely poor. The potential market of 22 million is small by Asian standards, and the nation lacks a convertible currency.
Prospective investors will also wonder whether North Korea, with no history of private enterprise, will respect private property and profit.
"We don't even know how much water costs there," Yi Hyo Keun, senior researcher at the Daewoo Research Institute, said in an interview in Seoul, the South Korean capital, last week.
As a result there is a lot of information-gathering, but foreign companies have not yet committed themselves to an economic or business role. "Everyone seems to be waiting for someone to make the first leap," said Michael Breen, a Seoul-based consultant on North Korea.
Tony Michell, president of the Euro-Asian Business Consultancy, which offers to help set up shop in North Korea, said his company had been approached by 42 companies -- 10 American, 10 Asian and 22 European. But only five of those companies are serious about investing in North Korea, he said. He did not identify them.
The American Chamber of Commerce in Korea, which is based in Seoul, is trying to arrange an information-gathering trip to North Korea. Some executives are concerned that American companies will be left behind if Washington does not move rapidly to lift restrictions.
American businessmen are allowed to visit North Korea and pay for their hotel, food and transportation. But United States laws forbid them to open a bank account, hire a North Korean employee, enter into a contract or transact just about any other business.
The companies most interested in North Korea are South Korean. The common language and culture and proximity to home compensate for the possibility that the North's wages may not be as low as in Vietnam or China.
South Korean companies have expressed fear that Japanese competitors might beat them to set up factories in North Korea. But Japanese companies are expected to go slow, partly because of a history of poor relations between Japan and Korea resulting from World War II.
Moreover, profit is not the only motive for South Korean companies. Another is to bolster North Korea's economy in expectation of eventual reunification on the Korean peninsula.
"I'd like to see that North Korea can be built," said Kim Young Chull, who escaped from North Korea as a boy with his family in 1946. Mr. Kim is now vice chairman of the Jindo Corporation, which makes fur coats and shipping containers.
The Kolon International Corporation, a manufacturer of clothing, sporting goods and other products, has been sending fabrics to North Korea to be sewn into school bags and backpacks since 1989, when Seoul first loosened some restrictions on business with the North.
But Kolon officials have never been able to visit the company's factories in the North or even to talk directly to the factory managers, Instead, they work through middlemen in Hong Kong or Beijing. With restrictions now likely to be lifted on business travel, a Kolon manager said, the company can produce more finished goods, like fashionable clothing, in North Korea.

U.S. Backs Seoul Move
 ELMENDORF AIR FORCE BASE, Alaska, Nov. 7 (Special to The New York Times) -- In another sign that the barriers to dealing with North Korea are crumbling, the United States will support the Communist country's entry into the 18-member forum for Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation and will encourage North Korean economic ties with South Korea and the rest of Asia.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced the Administration's position today as he embraced remarks by President Kim of South Korea that Seoul would lift its ban on business contacts with the North.
Speaking to reporters on the way to Seoul, where he will meet with South Korean leaders, Mr. Christopher heaped praise on the policy shift by the south and credited the Administration's recent nuclear accord with North Korea for making it possible.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed In Advance of U.S. Elections

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed in cautious trading yesterday amid uncertainty over United States monetary policy on the eve of elections.
"People view the election as important, but they don't know what it's supposed to mean for the dollar," said William Dudley, currency analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. 
 In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 97.35 Japanese yen from 97.45 yen on Friday. The dollar also fell to 1.5170 German marks, from 1.5147 marks on Friday. The British pound fell to $1.6145 from $1.6160.
After two days of dollar-buying by the United States last week, traders continued to be on guard for further interventions, which helped support the value of the dollar yesterday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which acts as the United States Treasury's agent in the foreign-exchange market, bought an estimated $2 billion for Japanese yen and German marks on Wednesday and Thursday.
"People still would like to go short on the dollar but they don't want to get burned," said Siobhan Lackey, assistant vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York. To short dollars, a trader sells them for another currency, hoping to buy them back later at a lower rate.
The Clinton Administration will be under pressure to order further interventions to support the dollar after today's elections, regardless of the outcome, Mr. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs said.
"There are questions about whether the intervention was primarily motivated by the elections," he said. "The Clinton Administration will probably want to continue to intervene for that reason. If the dollar weakens and we don't see action, that would reinforce pressure on the downside."
Uncertainty about the timing and size of the next increase in United States interest rates also discouraged currency dealers from taking new positions.
Analysts expect the Fed to raise its benchmark for short-term rates at least half a percentage point to 5.25 percent after its policy-making committee meets next Tuesday.
Higher rates in theory should help strengthen the dollar by attracting more funds into dollar-denominated deposits. But the Fed's five increases in short-term interest rates have failed to calm inflation fears in the bond market, dragging down Treasury prices and the dollar.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: GOVERNORS;
As Democrats Struggle, G.O.P.'s Gubernatorial Stars Seem to Lead Their Races

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

 BODY:
While many of the country's most prominent Democratic governors are in close races for re-election, the best-known Republican governors seem to be comfortably ahead of their challengers.
Democrats whose futures are in doubt include Mario M. Cuomo of New York, Ann W. Richards of Texas, Lawton Chiles of Florida and Zell Miller of Georgia. 
 As for Republicans, Pete Wilson of California and William F. Weld of Massachusetts are among the well-known governors who seem to be safe bets for re-election. If they win second terms, they will doubtless rise on their party's list of prospects for the national ticket in 1996.
Other Republican governors who are expected to win handily today include several from the Middle West: Jim Edgar of Illinois, John M. Engler of Michigan, Arne Carlson of Minnesota, George V. Voinovich of Ohio and Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin.
Democratic strategists have been frustrated all fall that so many of the party's stars were unable to pull away once the campaign began in earnest. "What's maddening," said Doug Richardson, executive director of the Democratic Governors Association, "is that the ones that seemed to be close are still close and don't seem to be breaking away."
As matters now stand, 29 states have Democratic governors, 20 have Republicans and one, Connecticut, an independent. Of the 35 states other than Connecticut where there is a gubernatorial election today, Democrats are now in office in 21, Republicans in 13.
At least a dozen of those races were still up for grabs on the eve of the election, including the ones in Texas and Florida, where two of former President George Bush's sons are challenging prominent Democrats. In addition to the large states where Democratic incumbents are threatened, the party is fighting in several states to retain seats where the Democratic incumbent retired or lost in the primary.
Such states include Hawaii, Idaho, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Tennessee and Wyoming. Democrats seem to have fallen behind in Kansas and Oklahoma, both of which have Democratic Governors who are leaving office.
Only one Republican Governor, J. Fife Symington of Arizona, seems to be in serious trouble. He has been accused of financial improprieties connected to a savings and loan failure. But a double-digit lead once held by his Democratic challenger, Eddie Basha, the owner of a chain of supermarkets, has faded, and Governor Symington could still be re-elected.
For a time, Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, trying for a fourth term, seemed to be the one Middle Western Republican Governor whose re-election was not secure. But the most recent polls show him ahead of the Democratic Attorney General, Bonnie J. Campbell.
The only Democratic Governors who seem safe are Howard Dean of Vermont, Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Roy Romer of Colorado.
If Republicans win a big enough share of the races that seem to be close, the party could end up holding a majority of the governorships for the first time since 1970.
Some of the races could turn on local issues like immigration in California and ethics in Alabama, where Gov. Guy Hunt, a Republican, was removed from office last year after he was convicted of pocketing $200,000 from a special fund to pay for his inauguration.
But much more than usual, the races for governor in the large states this year are following a similar pattern. As a rule, the Republicans, whether incumbents or not, are running hard-edged conservative campaigns in which they advocate lowering taxes, restricting welfare and cracking down on crime and accuse the Democratic incumbents of being tax-and-spend liberals who are soft on criminals.
Governor Engler of Michigan has become the archetypal Republican Governor, and many of the Republican challengers are trying to copy his success. In his first term, Governor Engler moved well to the right of any of his postwar predecessors. He cut property taxes, raised sales taxes, abolished general assistance welfare programs and cut money for the mentally ill and cultural programs. Most important, he changed the way public schools are financed and began providing state money to some private schools.
The Michigan economy is now thriving, and Mr. Engler is one of the most popular governors in the country. "We're bringing this state back," he said in a debate last month with his Democratic challenger, former Representative Howard Wolpe.
Chris Henick, executive director of the Republican Governors Association, said that the issues Governor Engler has emphasized have been nourishing for Republican candidates across the country.
"The whole more government vs. less government environment is one in which our candidates have thrived," he said.
Among the Republican challengers who are taking the conservative tack are Jeb Bush, 41, and George W. Bush, 48, neither of whom has ever held elected office.
Jeb Bush, who is challenging Governor Chiles in Florida, said in Fort Myers yesterday, "When you cut to the chase, Lawton Chiles is a liberal who thinks government is the answer to our problems. On the other hand, I'm a conservative that believes in limited government."
Jeb Bush had a lead for weeks this fall. But the most recent polls show Mr. Chiles narrowly ahead.
In Texas, George W. Bush has hammered away at Ms. Richards, saying she has coddled criminals and welfare recipients. As has been the case in other races in the South this fall, President Clinton has been a drag on the Richards candidacy.
A statewide poll, the results of which were published over the weekend by The Dallas Morning News and The Houston Chronicle, showed that 55 percent of Texans had a favorable view of Ms. Richards but that only 38 percent had such an opinion of Mr. Clinton. It is rare for a candidate with an approval rating as high as Ms. Richards's to lose, but the polls show this race to be dead even.

HEADLINE: Urban Crime Rates Falling This Year

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
The number of incidents of murder, robbery and assault has declined in almost all the nation's largest cities, most markedly in the West, according to a survey by the New York City Police Department.
Twenty of the 22 police departments that were surveyed said there were fewer felonies in the first six months of this year than there were in the same period last year. The cities showing the greatest declines in felonies were San Francisco, Seattle, Los Angeles, El Paso and San Antonio, in descending order. San Francisco reported a 25.2 percent decrease in total felonies, with better than 20 percent decreases each in murder, rape, robbery, burglary, larceny theft and motor vehicle theft. 
 New York City ranked sixth in the survey, with a decrease of 9.7 percent in total felonies from the same six-month period last year. Homicide in the city fell by 10.9 percent; robbery by 12 percent and auto theft by 14.5 percent. The numbers fell particularly fast during the summer in New York and in many other cities, compared with the summer before, according to police officials.
Unlike most of the other cities, where the reported decreases followed years of rising crime rates, New York saw a downward trend continue; it had already recorded three straight years of modest declines.
The only reported increases in felonies were in Phoenix (11 percent) and Baltimore (3.2 percent), the survey said.
Mark Moore, a criminologist at Harvard University, said the survey was "probably good news," but he noted that "it doesn't capture the fear that is out there."
Indeed, a single set of new statistics, no matter how encouraging, is unlikely to allay the fears of a country that saw crime rates soar after crack came to the cities in the mid-1980's. Many experts say it will take years of declines in crime rates for this pervasive anxiety to recede.
While the survey results were based on preliminary police data, and though as much as 50 percent of violent crimes go unreported, criminologists and police officials said the new numbers nevertheless suggested at least a short-term downward trend in crime. But the experts differed widely on whether the apparent improvement in urban safety was related to improvements in the economy, the cold winter, demographic trends or changes in police tactics and law-enforcement policies.
Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, said the results partly reflected demographic shifts, because the number of teen-agers -- those most likely to commit crimes -- had declined over the last decade. Experts expect that trend to reverse, as more children of the baby-boom generation become teen-agers over the next 5 to 10 years.
Explaining the national downturn, Deputy Police Inspector Joseph E. Lovelock of New York City credited the "building boom" of new prisons nationwide, tougher local and national gun-control regulations and a national trend in law enforcement toward community policing -- taking officers out of patrol cars and putting them on city streets, where they can come to know a neighborhood and its problems, and the neighborhood can come to know them.
The national survey was carried out by New York City police officers, who collected the data by telephone, mail and fax machine at the request of Police Commissioner William J. Bratton. Police officials said Mr. Bratton wanted to compare the results of his crime strategies to the records of other police departments. The statistics will be released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the next few months.
James Alan Fox, dean of the College of Criminal Justice at Northeastern University in Boston, said the declines reported in the survey might reflect little more than a natural leveling off from the high crime levels after the introduction of crack in the mid 1980's. Indeed, the number of violent crimes rose by 5.6 percent in 1993 from the year before, to 10.9 million incidents, according to the annual National Crime Victimization Survey by the Bureau of Justice Statistics, an arm of the Justice Department.
"Crime rates fluctuate much like the stock market," Mr. Fox said. "Good years are generally followed by bad."
San Francisco saw a 28.7 percent increase in homicides from 1990 to 1993, reaching a total of 130 that year, before declining by 23.8 percent in the first six months of this year, compared with the same period the year before. Similarly, aggravated assault increased by 10 percent from 1992 to 1993, reaching 4,396, before dropping 18.1 percent during the first six months of 1994 compared with the same period in 1993.
Mayor Frank Jordan of San Francisco said better police work explained the decline in crime.
"We're setting standards of behavior," Mayor Jordan said in an interview yesterday. He said the city's police department had hired 200 more officers since he took office in January 1992, bringing the total to 1,900; stepped up security in parks and public transportation stations, and begun an offensive against nuisance crimes like panhandling and graffiti vandalism.
Seven of the 12 cities with the largest reductions are in California and Texas.
San Antonio, for instance, reported a 25.4 percent decline in homicides for the first six months in the year. That decline roughly brings the annual homicide rate this year in line with the 168 committed in 1989.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trying New Tactic With Zaire

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, hoping to avert economic and political disintegration in Zaire, has adopted a new strategy that seeks to strengthen that country's Prime Minister and isolate its longtime President.
But many Africa experts and Zairians say the Administration's tentative embrace of Prime Minister Leon Kengo wa Dondo will do the opposite of what it intends: rehabilitate Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's dictator, whom the Administration has shunned in recent years because of his human-rights abuses and large-scale corruption. 
 The Administration's Africa strategists say they are working to support Mr. Kengo so he can develop a power base independent of Mr. Mobutu. That would enable him to prepare Zaire for free elections and stabilize its out-of-control economy, which suffered inflation of more than 10,000 percent last year.
To buttress Mr. Kengo, who some officials say is a sincere reformer, the Administration received him in Washington in early October, and Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott visited Zaire two weeks ago. Mr. Talbott hinted that Washington would work to resume loans from the International Monetary Fund and would send a new Ambassador, after having withdrawn its Ambassador last year because of dismay with Mr. Mobutu.
Critics of the Administration's policy say the strategy of backing Mr. Kengo and hinting at economic aid will strengthen Mr. Mobutu's hand because the longtime ruler can point to it as a sign of acceptance by Washington. These critics also argue that embracing Mr. Kengo is misguided because he is at worst a puppet of Mr. Mobutu and at best largely dependent on him.
"The United States is deceiving itself if it thinks Kengo is anything more than a puppet of Mobutu," Lambert Mende Omalanga, an opposition member in Parliament, said in an interview. "He cannot do anything without Mobutu's go-ahead."
Before joining an opposition party, Mr. Kengo served as a Prime Minister under Mr. Mobutu from 1982 to 1985 and from 1988 to 1990. Like Mr. Mobutu, he has often been accused of human-rights abuses and of siphoning off Government funds.
Critics of Washington's policy also fear that in pushing Mr. Kengo to prepare for elections, the Administration is paving the way toward legitimizing Mr. Mobutu, because many view him, thanks to his money and clout, as the likely winner.
"I think there is a rehabilitation of Mobutu going on," said Peter Rosenblum, an Africa expert with the International Human Rights Law Group, based in Washington. "The Administration's view seems to be, he is an actor and we have to deal with him."
For most of Mr. Mobutu's 28 years in power, successive Administrations backed him as a helpful, strategically located client during the cold war. But with the collapse of Communism, the Administration has stopped supporting him.
Nonetheless, State Department officials say they want to help pull the mineral-rich nation of 41 million back from the brink of political disintegration and economic disaster, fearing that it can spin out of control into a Rwanda-like civil war.
In the three years before Mr. Kengo was elected last June, there was a political impasse in which Mr. Mobutu and Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi sought to block each move taken by the other.
When a reconstituted Parliament elected Mr. Kengo last June, the United States -- joined by France and Belgium, two former colonial powers in central Africa -- saw an opportunity to push Zaire toward democracy and economic stability.
The Administration lauds Mr. Kengo for allowing opposition leaders to debate Government officials on television, something Mr. Mobutu never permitted. They also praise him for seizing 30 tons of counterfeit currency that was flown into Zaire as part of a scheme that American officials say was intended to enrich Mr. Mobutu and his entourage.
Some Administration officials acknowledge that they are not convinced that Mr. Kengo is independent of Mr. Mobutu. For example, Mr. Mobuto blocked the Prime Minister from replacing the head of Zaire's central bank.
Still, diplomats say Mr. Kengo has gotten the Zairian President to give him some freedom by threatening to quit, something Mr. Mobutu apparently fears because it would bring him more international opprobrium.
Under current law, the Administration is barred from providing aid to Zaire because it is behind in repaying its $800 million debt to the United States. The Administration is providing $12 million this year to relief organizations in Zaire.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
30-Second TV Spot: The Chicken Pox of Politics

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Television watchers, whatever their political leanings, ought to be able to join today in celebration: the campaign of 1994 is over.
For weeks there has been lamentation on all channels about the nastiness of the advertising on all channels. Except for the professionals who turn out the stuff (and for whom every negative is a positive on their balance sheets), campaign commentators have chorused their disgust at charges and countercharges that have little to do either with truth or with issues that really touch voters' lives. 
 But they also agree that the voters, in this sour season, did not seem to know or care much about candidates' experience or policies or about the consequences of, say, cutting taxes. The commentators were especially incensed by 30-second television spots that explained nothing. Money buys time and time buys votes and attack ads breed attack ads.
So what is to be done, except for preparing ourselves for even worse in 1996? By now, eyes glaze at the mention of campaign reform, yet without restrictions on contributions and expenditures and serious Federal financing, our political arrangements will remain in thrall to the fat cats and their hired media manipulators. Unfortunately, with so many Senators and Representatives reluctant to give up the largesse, campaign reform is not around the corner.
So the burden falls on television itself. For reasons of self-interest and concern for freedom of speech, networks and stations cannot be expected to bar those invidious 30-second spots or to deny candidates other opportunities to slander their rivals. And the polluters are not going to stop the dumping in an outbreak of guilty conscience. Still, perhaps their products can be subjected to public examination without violating anyone's liberties. At least, the possibility demands discussion.
Network news departments have lately been making efforts to sort out truth from fiction, relevance from irrelevance in the din. Good, but that is not nearly enough to stem the effluvia poisoning the political environment. Here, then, is a short, not overly ambitious wish list:
*Any advertisement that attacks a rival's character should be delivered personally by the candidate who is making it, not by some anonymous voice. Say anything you want, sir or madam, but say it openly on screen. And every respectable news department should feel an obligation to give the target an opportunity to respond, again in person.
*Any advertisement that attacks a candidate's record should be followed with all deliberate speed by a news-department accounting of its accuracy and its method of delivery. The analysis should come while the advertisement is still fresh in mind. If this discourages the 30-second spots, so much the better. (This suggestion could be usefully applied to so-called positive advertising, too, which is often positively misleading.)
*Considerably more of prime time should be given to interviews with the candidates, conducted not by blank local-news anchors but by real reporters, well supplied with background material and not shy about pressing for comprehensible answers. Debate formats should be aimed at enlightenment, not at agitation, more in the spirit of "The MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour" than of "Crossfire." Some programs and personalities contribute to the brainless brawling even while decrying it.
These proposals (which, I confess, would not do much to reduce the demagogy and lunacy of talk radio) are not original and probably not enforceable; they involve technical and economic as well as legal problems. So if other approaches serve better, fine. The object is simply to add more accurate information to the campaign commotion and reduce the vicious nonsense.
Whether many voters will be more moved by the facts than by the attacks is a separate matter. Asking for more enlightening television campaigns is like asking for more intelligent television dramas; audience preferences may lie in another direction. But that's show business.
Happy Election Day.

HEADLINE: More Than Decoration, Songbirds Are Essential to Forests' Health

BYLINE: By CAROL KAESUK YOON 

 BODY:
THE migrating songbirds that brighten North America's forests each spring with dazzling colors and melodious strains have been regarded by many scientists as mere decorative frills that play a limited role, if any, in the functioning of their ecosystems. But a new study provides what researchers say is the first evidence that these birds, some of which are in decline, play a crucial role in maintaining the health and productivity of forest trees.
In the study, in the current issue of the journal Ecology, two researchers have shown that these voracious predators can protect trees by eating the bugs that chew the leaves. As a result, scientists are predicting that the decline of these birds could eventually threaten the productivity of forests in the United States as well as in the birds' wintering grounds in the tropical forests of Central and South America. 
 "It's really a spectacular result," said Dr. Donald R. Strong, an ecologist at the University of California at Davis, "and it's got to be generally true. The conservation importance and forest management importance is profound. We see that in order to protect our forests we've got to have these birds, some of which are becoming quite rare."
Dr. Richard T. Holmes, a bird ecologist at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., said: "It's a very exciting paper. It's the first time that there have been data to show that birds feeding on insects have an impact on trees."
Working in the forest at the Tyson Research Center, a reserve near Eureka, Mo., the researchers enclosed white oak trees in netting cages. The cages were built with holes big enough to admit all the insects that might attack the trees but small enough to keep out the birds that would eat the insects.
For two years biologists monitored the insects flying in and out of the cages. Most were moths and butterflies laying eggs that would hatch into leaf-devouring caterpillars, the major insect enemies of these economically important timber trees.
What they found was that the plants that were caged to keep out birds were plagued by twice as many insects and had twice as much of their leafy green foliage eaten as uncaged plants. As a result, the damaged plants produced fewer leaves in following years than those trees cleaned of their pests by birds.
"There's been a lot of argument and controversy about the role that birds have in ecosystems," said Dr. Robert J. Marquis, a plant ecologist at the University of Missouri in St. Louis who was an author of the study. "Some say they do no more than provide weekend activity for bird-watchers. We've shown that the birds can have an effect."
Conservationists welcome the work as the first piece of evidence that the colorful dickey birds of spring do have a significant ecological and economic importance.
Dr. Tom Hinckley, Bloedel Professor of Forestry at the University of Washington in Seattle, said: "These birds in a sense enrich our environment, whether it's urban or rural, but it's sometimes difficult to put a value on them other than enrichment. Now here's a case where their value can perhaps be translated to a clear economic value."
Dr. Christopher J. Whelan, who holds the Emily Rodgers Davis Chair in Ecology at the Morton Arboretum in Lisle, Ill., and was the other author of the paper, said the migrants made up more than two-thirds of the nesting bird species in the forests.
During spring migration at the study site in the Ozarks, 40 to 50 bird species arrive to eat the insects on the fresh white oak leaves. Dr. Whelan said, some 30 of those species stay on to nest, including red-eyed vireos, American robins and scarlet tanagers. All appear to help the white oak.
Though many researchers agree that several species of these migrant songbirds are decreasing, the reasons remain controversial. Researchers have attributed the decline to forest destruction and other disruptive forces here and in their wintering grounds.
In addition to documenting beneficial effects for plants, researchers say the new study may provide clues to the birds' decline. Dr. Scott Robinson, an ornithologist with the Illinois Natural History Survey in Champaign, said that the migrant birds' ability to depress insect numbers so greatly on white oak suggests that competition for insect prey on breeding grounds in North America may be important to the birds' survival and reproduction, as well as a factor limiting their numbers.
Based on the new study, ecologists predict trouble ahead for forests, but they caution that for the moment such predictions are speculative. Whether any trees besides white oak will actually suffer remains to be seen.
Researchers say that even if there is an important effect on trees, the damage due to loss of birds may be difficult or impossible to tease out from that due to other causes. Although they cannot point to specific damage resulting from the loss of birds, some researchers say they fear damage to trees may be under way.
"My feeling is that it's going on as we speak," Dr. Whelan said. "In some of the small forest fragments that have very few birds in them, this may very well be happening right now."
Ecologists have known for some time that trickle-down effects along a food chain can be very important in aquatic systems. In these so-called trophic cascades, top-level predators, like fish that eat smaller fish, radically increase or decrease the numbers of creatures at the bottom of the cascade by eating more or fewer of those that act as predators further down the line. But scientists had remained skeptical about whether the terrestrial equivalent of these cascades -- involving birds, insects and plants -- were of much importance. Birds, it was supposed, would not be powerful enough predators to have an effect all the way down to the plants.
"The really exciting thing about this paper is, now we can believe that the birds are playing a big role, having a hand in this," said Dr. Strong.
The authors even propose that the birds constitute an ecologically correct form of pest management.
"Some people say insecticides are the way to go," said Dr. Whelan, "but, actually, what we show is that birds were as effective as insecticide. So if you have the birds, you don't need insecticide." Many ecologists say that anyone who is interested in reducing pests in forest tracts and increasing forest productivity should protect the beneficial birds.
Many options for increasing bird numbers are already well known. For example, many of the birds declining most quickly prefer forest interiors. One way to protect them is simply to prevent the fragmentation of forest tracts. Researchers say such fragmentation not only decreases the stretches of protected interior forest but provides habitat for species that like edges, like raccoons and blue jays, which often prey on the eggs and young of the declining bird species.
The researchers will continue their work by examining the effects of these migrant insect-eaters on tropical forest trees in their wintering grounds in Costa Rica.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
The Candidates Debate

 BODY:

Mario M. Cuomo -- Democrat, on a fourth term
One person's lame duck is the other person's liberated executive. If you assumed it was my last year, that could make me stronger a whole lot of ways because it frees you from any necessity to cater to any political influence. You can go in there and swing with both hands. I think the Senate Republican majority, and I'm assuming it's going to continue to be a Senate Republican majority, may be easier for me to handle next year if I do what I've proposed to do and that is to go directly to the Senate members. 

George E. Pataki, Republican, on whether he would have trouble working with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani
Absolutely not. First, on the personal side. Think back to 1982. There was a pretty difficult primary for governor between two guys from New York City, one named Ed Koch and one named Mario Cuomo. Now, Cuomo won, became the governor, Koch was still the mayor. It worked. They worked well. They worked together because you have to for the future of this city and state. The same thing with Mayor Giuliani. I think he's done a tremendous job in trying to close a very difficult budget gap without raising taxes but by cutting spending. I think his emphasis on law and order and having the police make arrests is exactly the right thing.
 
Robert T. Walsh Sr., Right to Life, on Mr. Pataki's abortion stance.
 I have to tell you that everywhere I've gone on the campaign trail, from one end of the state to the other, the voters have told me they feel betrayed by George Pataki. After voting consistently over the years against Medicaid funding of abortion, he flip-flopped and now tells us that he's pro-choice. No one really knows where George stands on this issue. It's difficult to know whether he is pro-life or pro-choice. I find with great pride that I am the only pro-life candidate running in this election and you know something? I'm not for sale. You were speaking just before about whether or not we're spoilers. I hope that I'm a spoiler for all the other candidates. A recent independent poll showed that 70 percent of all voters in this state profess to have a pro-life philosophy and if they vote for what they believe in, especially being betrayed by the Republicans and the Conservatives, well then, you're looking at the next Governor of New York. [At this point, Mr. Walsh pulls out a rubber chicken.] In all fairness, we've got to ask George how he feels about this issue. [Mr. Walsh puts the beak of the chicken to his ear, as if it is whispering to him.] George says he has to ask Alfonse what to say. You can go back into hiding now George.
 
Lawrence A. Lane, Socialist Workers, on why he is running
My campaign is part of the growing resistance of workers and youth to the consequences of the deep economic crisis of this rotten capitalist system: downsizing, speed-ups, cutbacks, growing instability, right-wing solutions, fascism and war. All my opponents see that this for-profit system isn't working but they place the blame elsewhere.
 
B. Thomas Golisano, Independence Fusion, on being a third party candidate
When you go to vote tomorrow, you have some options: One of them is Mario Cuomo. I ask you the question: Do you think you are better off today than you were 12 years ago? He's gotten us here. I think he blames everyone and everything but himself and now he wants four more years. George Pataki and the Republicans -- In 1986 they offered Lew Lehrman, all of his money and they failed. 1990: Pierre Rinfret. He was lucky he got 25 percent of the vote. In 1994 they offer George Pataki -- no C.E.O. experience, a Mayor, a legislator with a modest record. The Mayor of the largest city in the state did not endorse him. An Al D'Amato-puppet reputation.
 
Bob Shultz, Libertarian on what he wants to accomplish
I think the primary objective of mine is to see that the back-door borrowing ends. I firmly believe that we must, we have a constitution that prohibits borrowing by the state without voter approval. If we can those in government to abide by this constitutional constraint then government will have no choice but to begin to focus on issues of efficiency in government and productivity and accountability.

HEADLINE: Clean Up Reactors In East Europe Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"East Europe Still Choking on Air of the Past" (news article, Nov. 3) provides a compelling description of the difficulties facing Eastern European countries in abandoning the dreadfully polluting plants and practices of their Communist past. 
 However, your discussion overlooks Western investments in unsafe Soviet-designed reactors, which may in fact divert investment capital from industrial modernization and environmental cleanup.
The decisions to complete the Temelin plant in the Czech Republic and the Mochovce plant in Slovakia will have important implications for development of the energy sector throughout the former Eastern bloc.
While Westinghouse is at work at Temelin, the future of the plant is uncertain. A Congressional committee is investigating the United States Export-Import Bank's move to provide loan guarantees for the project. Over the summer, the existence of approximately $200 million in cost overruns was disclosed. Czech officials have also committed themselves to a Western-style licensing proceeding where the safety of this untested hybrid will be challenged by local opponents.
The United States-supported European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has been asked to finance the completion of two units at Mochovce. The project will receive intense scrutiny in the coming months as the bank releases a least-cost study and an environmental assessment for public review, the first ever for a Soviet reactor.
There is still an opportunity to avoid additional investment in unsafe, uneconomical nuclear power. The countries of Central and Eastern Europe should adopt, instead, a flexible energy strategy, one that incorporates increased efficiency with smaller supply-side projects to capitalize on the drive of industries to modernize and compete in global markets.
 
S. JACOB SCHERR
DAVID SCHWARZBACH
Washington, Nov. 4, 1994
 
The writers are, respectively, senior attorney and policy analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council.

TYPE: Letter
