HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE OVERVIEW;
G.O.P. WINS CONTROL OF SENATE AND MAKES BIG GAINS IN HOUSE; PATAKI DENIES CUOMO 4TH TERM

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
The Republican Party seized control of the Senate and moved within a few seats of capturing the House yesterday, winning eight Democratic seats in the Senate and at least 38 in the House. The gains were the Republicans' strongest in decades and put them in position to thwart President Clinton and his legislative proposals for the next two years.
The Republican tide also extended to the races for governor in several important states that will be critical to Mr. Clinton's hopes for re-election in 1996, including New York, Pennsylvania, Texas and California. 
 One after another, once unassailable Democrats like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Chicago and Senators James Sasser of Tennessee and Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania fell to little-known Republican challengers.
But Republicans, who have held the Senate in only 6 of the last 40 years, were particularly overjoyed that they had picked up Democratic Senate seats in Pennsylvania, Michigan, Tennessee, Oklahoma, Minnesota, Michigan and Maine. Mr. Clinton had criss-crossed most of those states in a frenetic eight-day campaign swing, but it did no good. The Republicans ended the night with at least a 52-to-48 majority in the Senate.
"I've never known a better night in electoral politics for the Republican Party, and the best is yet to come," a beaming Bob Dole declared to an overflow crowd at the Republican National Committee headquarters in Washington. Mr. Dole, who will become the majority leader, studiously avoided saying whether he would focus on that job or on running for President in 1996, but the crowd was excited about the party's prospects, chanting, " '96! '96!, '96!"
The Democrats were not completely shut out. Senator Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, defeated Oliver L. North in one of the most closely watched races in a particularly volatile election season, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts hung on to his seat after the biggest scare of his political life.
In metropolitan area races, two Democratic Senators, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut coasted to victory.
Despite those victories for Democrats, after a campaign season notable for restive voters, vituperative candidates and an astonishing amount of mudslinging, the Republicans enjoyed their best mid-term elections in decades. The last time the Republicans controlled both houses of Congress was in the early years of Dwight D. Eisenhower's first term.
Last night's results will leave the Senate, and potentially the House, in control of an entirely new lineup of committee chairman who will have the power to decide what legislation reaches the floor. The elections also immediately raised the stakes on the Republicans' battle for the 1996 Presidential nomination.
In one of the most stunning upsets of the evening, Mr. Rostenkowski, who faces 17 counts of fraud and other improprieties, was defeated by Michael Patrick Flanagan, a little-known 31-year-old lawyer in Chicago.
In another significant upset, George W. Bush, the former President's son and part owner of the Texas Rangers, defeated Ms. Richards. It was a particularly welcome victory for the Bush family, for it was Ms. Richards who ridiculed the elder Bush at her party's 1988 national convention as being "born with a silver foot in his mouth."
Another Bush son was not as successful. Though the race was close, Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida defeated an aggressive challenge from Jeb Bush. Mr. Chiles was the only Democrat incumbent governor from a major state who won re-election.
But mostly, as the polls closed from East to West last night, there was predominantly bad news for the Democrats.
The Democrats suffered a triple blow in Tennessee, losing both Senate seats to political newcomers as well as the governor's office. Fred D. Thompson, a lawyer, lobbyist and sometime movie actor defeated Representative Jim Cooper, a six-term House member who drew national attention for proposing a moderate alternative to Mr. Clinton's health care program. He won the seat that was once held by Vice President Al Gore, whose intense campaigning in Tennessee proved of no effect.
Many Democrats were more surprised that Senator Sasser, a three-term veteran and chairman of the Senate Budget Committee who was in line to become majority leader, could not beat back a challenge from William Frist, a millionaire heart surgeon.
While White House officials insisted that the elections were not a referendum on Mr. Clinton or his policies, many of the victorious Republicans had campaigned aggressively against the President, and espoused far more conservative views.
It was a despondent night for Democrats, as a parade of White House officials, rather than giving grudging congratulations to the Republicans, challenged them to be more constructive than they have been in Congress this year.
"This was not a vote against the lower deficit, lower Federal spending and smaller Federal bureaucracy as provided in the Clinton economic plan. The mission remains the same," said the President's senior adviser, George Stephanopoulos. "I think there's no question that in the front of voters' minds is making sure the system works again."
Mr. Stephanopoulos said the White House would work with leaders in both parties "in a nonpartisan way" to pass a legislative program. But he declined to say how, and on what issues.
The reversal of fortunes for the Republicans was stunning, coming only two years after the party lost the White House. The sudden shift in power and in the mood of the party was dramatized in Pennsylvania, where Representative Rick Santorum defeated Mr. Wofford. Only two years ago, Mr. Wofford's upset election, in which he made health care a centerpiece of his campaign, put that issue on the legislative map and was widely taken as a signal of the Democrats' power.
In Ohio, Lieut. Gov. Michael DeWine became the state's first Republican Senator in nearly two decades, defeating Joel Hyatt, who owns a chain of legal service stores.
In Michigan, Spencer Abraham, a former Republican state party chairman, defeated Representative Bob Carr, a nine-term House veteran, for the seat of retiring Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr.
In Oklahoma, Representative James M. Inhofe, a Republican, defeated Representative Dave McCurdy in a bitter contest for the seat of Senator David L. Boren, who resigned two years before his term expired.
In Maine, Representative Olympia Snowe, a Republican, defeated Representative Thomas Andrews, a Democrat, for the seat vacated by Senator George J. Mitchell, the Democratic leader.
And in Delaware, Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Republican, beat back an aggressive challenge from the state's Attorney General, Charles Oberly. Mr. Oberly had been one of his party's best hopes for winning a Republican seat.
Republicans also held on to the seat in Missouri of retiring Senator John C. Danforth. Former Gov. John Ashcroft easily defeated Representative Alan Wheat.
Though discouraged by the parade of defeats, Democrats were exuberant over Mr. Robb's re-election. The Senator, ebullient before a spirited crowd last night, compared his comeback to George Foreman's 10th round knockout on Saturday night, giving him the heavyweight title back after 20 years. "George Foreman is indeed an inspiration," he declared.
Moments later, at his Richmond headquarters, Mr. North thanked his supporters. "You have successfully redefined political debate in this land," he said. "We will elect candidates of principle who deem the next generation as more important than the next election."
Two incumbent Democratic Senators who never appeared in danger, Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Lieberman, kept their seats. Mr. Moynihan was opposed by Bernadette Castro, a former sofa bed company executive, and Mr. Lieberman was challenged by a former state senator, Gerald Labriola.
Another Democrat, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, won a seventh term, easily defeating his long-shot Republican challenger, Stan Klos, who is in the real estate business. Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland beat back a challenge from William Brock, a former Republican Senator from Tennessee.
Several Republican Senators who had seemed secure throughout the campaign easily beat back their challengers. Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the senior Republican on the Agriculture Committee, defeated former Representative Jim Jontz. Others Republicans who easily won re-election were Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas and Trent Lott of Mississippi.
In Florida, Senator Connie Mack of Florida defeated Hugh Rodham, the brother of Hillary Rodham Clinton, who was making his first bid for public office.
Two incumbent Republican Governors, William F. Weld of Massachusetts and George V. Voinovich of Ohio, coasted to easy victories.
Haley Barbour, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, called it a great day for his party and sought to make the returns a referendum on the President. "What the American people did tonight is they rejected President Clinton's policies," he said.
One bad sign for Democrats for the future is that their voters tended to be much older than the voters who cast their ballots for Republicans.
The preliminary results of a nationwide poll of voters as they left polling places showed that voters over 50 were slightly more likely to have voted for Democratic candidates. But voters aged 25 to 40 were much more likely to have cast their ballots for Republicans.
The poll found that about a third of the respondents said their votes for House candidates had nothing to do with their views of President Clinton. Of the remainder, slightly more said their opposition to Mr. Clinton affected their vote yesterday than those who said their support for him was a factor in their vote.
Given the throw-the-bums-out climate that pervaded the election campaigns, voters said by a majority of more than 2 to 1 that they preferred an experienced candidate to a new face, and a clear majority said they preferred having Congress and the Presidency controlled by the same party.
Protestants and Catholics alike were more likely to have voted Republican than Democratic. Jews voted heavily Democratic as did respondents who said they were not particularly religious.
In the poll, 2,600 voters were questioned at selected precincts in every state.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, with his chief of staff, Sheila Burke, and his press secretary, Clarkson Hine, after it became clear his party had taken control of the Senate. Mr. Dole was trying to arrange a meeting with Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, who had not sought re-election. (David Scull/The New York Times) (pg. B5)

PUB-DATE: November 9, 1994

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1440 words

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE OVERVIEW;
New York Voters End a Democratic Era

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
George Elmer Pataki, a lanky lawyer-legislator from the Hudson Valley who has promised to slash income taxes and restore the death penalty, was elected the 53d Governor of New York yesterday, ending 20 years of Democratic rule in Albany and toppling Mario M. Cuomo, a legendary figure in state and national politics.
In other New York races, H. Carl McCall became the first black New Yorker to win statewide elected office, defeating Herbert London in the race for state comptroller. Mr. McCall, a former State Senator, investment banker and president of the New York City Board of Education, was appointed Comptroller by the Legislature last year to fill a vacancy left by the midterm retirement of Edward V. Regan. 
 In the race for attorney general, the Republican, Dennis C. Vacco, a former United States Attorney from Buffalo, won a narrow victory over Karen S. Burstein, a former Family Court judge in Brooklyn.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, easily dispatched his Republican opponent, Bernadette Castro, to win a fourth term. But he lost the chairmanship of the Finance Committee to Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon when the Senate went Republican.
Mr. Pataki, a 49-year-old State Senator, won by drawing a strong turnout in upstate New York counties where Republicans traditionally fare well, by taking narrow majorities in the suburbs surrounding New York City, by winning Staten Island and by faring well in Erie County.
B. Thomas Golisano, a millionaire businessman from Rochester who was the gubernatorial candidate of the Independence Fusion Party, proved less of a factor than some had anticipated in siphoning anti-Cuomo votes from Mr. Pataki.
With 97 percent of the precincts reporting, the results were:
Pataki . . . 2,405,631 (49%)
Cuomo . . . 2,223,567 (45%)
Golisano . . . 196,327 (4%)
Mr. Pataki's election represents a political triumph for his patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, and a potentially devastating defeat for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who alienated the state's Republican leadership by crossing party lines to endorse Mr. Cuomo.
About 12:30 this morning, the Governor-elect, calling himself "a mailman's kid from Peekskill," declared victory in a ballroom at the New York Hilton and asserted that New Yorkers had voted for change. "If there's one thing this campaign has stood for day in and day out," he said, "it's about again restoring people's confidence in the future of this state, again restoring their belief that the best of this state is ahead of us."
And in an impish nod to Mr. D'Amato, whose relationship with the candidate was mocked in Cuomo television commercials, Mr. Pataki said, "Let me just say, you can call me, Al."
Earlier, Mr. Cuomo had appeared at the Sheraton New York to congratulate Mr. Pataki, whom he said he had been unable to reach by telephone. Removing his eyeglasses and speaking with a strong voice that occasionally cracked with emotion, the Governor thanked his aides and supporters and said: "I'm sorry to have let you down because you deserved another four years."
He added: "I've surely made mistakes as Governor, but I'm as proud as I can be of what we have accomplished together. I'm absolutely convinced that there's an enormous amount more that we can do."
As Mr. Cuomo left the stage, the first person to embrace him was former Mayor David N. Dinkins, who had to give a similar concession speech a year ago.
Republicans cast Mr. Pataki's election as a revolution in the state's politics that mirrored national results on a dismal day for Democrats. But a survey of voters leaving the polls showed that Mr. Pataki won on the strength of the public's weariness with Mr. Cuomo rather than on enthusiastic support for the Republican or his policies.
The poll showed that fewer than half of Mr. Pataki's voters said they were voting for him, while more than half said they were voting against Mr. Cuomo. The Governor retained only 6 in 10 of the voters who supported him in 1990, when he faced lackluster opposition.
As such, the results suggested something far less than a mandate, particularly given that polls at the end showed that most New Yorkers had little sense of Mr. Pataki as they drew the curtains in their voting booths. Instead, the election seemed to reflect the anger and frustration of a surly electorate that felt increasingly squeezed by taxes, intimidated by the randomness of crime, and perhaps tired of Mr. Cuomo's combative and pedantic style.
The poll of voters showed a substantial difference by sexes, with Mr. Pataki winning 6 in 10 of the men and fewer than half of the women. Mr. Pataki was favored by 6 in 10 of the white voters, fewer than one-tenth of the black voters and about one-sixth of the Hispanic voters.
Two of Mr. Cuomo's top strategists, Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader, and David Garth, the media consultant, said in interviews that Mr. Giuliani's endorsement of Mr. Cuomo had allowed Mr. Pataki to play on upstate-downstate divisions, which may have stimulated the large turnout upstate.
Mr. Pataki has served for one term as a member of the State Senate's Republican majority and eight years in the Assembly minority. His record in the Legislature is unremarkable except for his decision to break ranks with his Republican colleagues in the Senate to vote against tax increases, a move widely regarded as a calculated precursor to his gubernatorial candidacy.
The Governor-elect's only executive experience came as the two-term Mayor of Peekskill, a city of 20,000 in northern Westchester County, where Mr. Pataki grew up on a family farm. Mr. Pataki now lives in nearby Garrison, in Putnam County. He will be the first Governor from outside New York City, and the first Republican since Gov. Malcolm Wilson left office in 1974.
For the 62-year-old Mr. Cuomo, the loss caps a public career that includes almost two decades in Albany, as Secretary of State and Lieutenant Governor under Gov. Hugh L. Carey, and then as Governor.
While he remained the darling of the liberal wing of the Democratic Party nationally, his popularity at home began to plummet in his third term, when a deep recession led to a loss of more than 500,000 jobs in New York. As budget gaps widened, Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature raised taxes and cut the state work force.
The Governor argued during the campaign that the state's economy was turning around, largely because of his handling of the recession, and that a Republican administration would undercut the state's commitment to the poor. But the voters yesterday showed that they had little patience left for Mr. Cuomo and that they preferred the uncertainty of change to the certainty of a fourth Cuomo term.
While there will be fresh blood in the Executive Mansion, where Mr. Pataki will live with his wife, Libby, and their four children, the new Governor will arrive in Albany to face the same divided Legislature that so often frustrated Mr. Cuomo. With only a few alterations, the Democrats retained their overwhelming majority in the Assembly and the Republicans maintained control of the Senate, insuring the continuation of a long history of polarization along partisan and geographic lines.
One notable exception may be the death penalty. Under Mr. Carey and then Mr. Cuomo, death-penalty measures have been vetoed every year since 1977, and the Legislature never succeeded in overriding their vetoes. Mr. Pataki has promised to sign death-penalty legislation early in his term, a move that would restore it as the ultimate punishment for murder in the first degree for the first time since 1965. New York, which last electrocuted a convict in 1963, is one of 14 states without the death penalty.
Mr. Pataki has also proposed to cut the income tax rates by 25 percent over the four years of his term, a reduction of $5.6 billion in a general fund budget that totaled $34 billion this year. Mr. Cuomo and other Democrats ridiculed Mr. Pataki's plan throughout the campaign, charging that it would require huge cuts in state programs and aid to local governments and would force steep increases in property taxes.
Mr. Pataki was little known statewide when Senator D'Amato anointed Mr. Pataki as the candidate of the Republican hierarchy. The Senator helped him raise enough money to outspend Mr. Cuomo and contributed many of his top political aides to the Pataki campaign. The Governor tried to make Mr. D'Amato's role a major liability for Mr. Pataki, and Mr. Pataki's ability to overcome it should bolster Mr. D'Amato's influence in the Republican Party both in New York and nationally.
